title: Very nostalgic place to spend a good time
review_text: We went towards the evening and our children thoroughly enjoyed watching the numerous deers and peacocks in the open. The extensive roots of the trees over the ruins of the old buildings is definitely a sight to watch.

title: Beautiful ruins with natural flora & fauna
review_text: It's a beautiful island with ruins from British era.its renamed as Subhash Chandra Bose dweep.you can spot deers, peacocks,rabbits,birds. Majestic trees have grown over dilspitaed buildings.The roots are humongous & create a mystic experience. Nature supercedes man's creation.a stroll around the island is nice.There is a buggie for Rs80 for the tour but I would not recommend as you will miss the fun.

title: Amazing Light and Sound show
review_text:
In my opinion the best time to go there is in the evening. I went to Ross island from Port Blair. The ferry is from Aberdeen jetty at the Rajiv Gandhi water Sports Complex(close to cellular Jail). Private ferries charge 350 Rs per person and there is a 30Rs entry fee per person to enter Ross island. They let you explore there for an hour.The island has a lot of ruins from the british era as well as a beach, a pond and a monument to sailors. If you are going in the morning take enough water from Port Blair. I went at around 10.30 am and it was quite hot. However, the best time to go is not in the morning, but rather in the evening. There is a light and sound show at Ross island at 4.30 pm. Tickets must be bought from the Andaman tourism department office for Rs100 per person. Apart from this, one must book a ferry for Rs300 and also pay island fee of Rs 30. I went twice- once in morning and evening and would recommend going in evening only. Not only would you save money, but you will have a much better experience. It is best to get on the first ferries which starts at around 4pm to spend maximum time on Ross island before the start of the light and sound show. The island is quite empty in evening and you... Private ferries charge 350 Rs per person and there is a 30Rs entry fee per person to enter Ross island. They let you explore there for an hour.The island has a lot of ruins from the british era as well as a beach, a pond and a monument to sailors. If you are going in the morning take enough water from Port Blair. I went at around 10.30 am and it was quite hot. 

However, the best time to go is not in the morning, but rather in the evening. There is a light and sound show at Ross island at 4.30 pm. Tickets must be bought from the Andaman tourism department office for Rs100 per person. Apart from this, one must book a ferry for Rs300 and also pay island fee of Rs 30. I went twice- once in morning and evening and would recommend going in evening only. Not only would you save money, but you will have a much better experience. It is best to get on the first ferries which starts at around 4pm to spend maximum time on Ross island before the start of the light and sound show. 

The island is quite empty in evening and you can see all deer,rabbits and peacocks running around which were not there in the morning. Further, the island is cooler and so easier to walk around. Lastly, the light and sound show is of a very high production value with lots of famous names working on it (like Gulzar,Shabana azmi , resul pookutty etc). I felt it was much better than the one at Cellular Jail. More

title: Wow
review_text: As we arrive on Ross island we were welcomed by dears n when moved further we started hearing the voice of peacock. Then we saw them n the while island was so nice but that boat people give less time to covering the island as still many things to see.

title: Pre Independence British colony
review_text: Deputy commissioner and Secretariat of British colony lying in ruins as bombed by the Japanese during WWII. Ferar beach and peak point is worth a visit. Tuk tuk drive cost is 80 per person. Lots of deers and peacock in this island.

title: Over-rated place
review_text:
There is not much to see here. The ruined buildings from British era are not that special. 
There are some interesting sign boards explaining how the colony was established. But, it gets very hot and makes walking around the buildings very tiring. Worth the trouble only if you are a big history buff. 
Did not get to see the light show.

title: Colonial ruins
review_text:
The island gives a clear picture of the bygone British rule and the ruins (bakery, stores, water treatment plant, church, tennis court, printing press, secretariat, hospital, cemetery, swimming pool and more) are being eaten up by nature. Boat ride to Ross Island was for Rs. 200/- pp (our driver said that it was Rs. 300 pp and at the gate, I found a guy who offered it for Rs. 200/-. Moral: approach service providers directly, if not always bargain!) Entry ticket was for Rs. 30/- and the island was to be covered in an hour. We realised that it was difficult to walk up and down and all around in an hour. Very conveniently, there were large rickshaws for ferrying visitors up and down the island. They charged Rs. 640/- for an 8 seater and the ride was for 20 min. It doesn't go towards the cemetery due to the poor condition of the road. So we got off near the Chruch, walked up to the Cemetery and back to the entrance gate. We couldn't walk down to the lighthouse due to lack of time. The boat which took us to the island was to pick us in 1hr 15 min. There were peacocks and deers roaming around as if they don't care. This was a time well spent. title: Optional place to Visit
review_text: You can skip this place, As there is not much attraction except deer & rabbits. At this place some old forts & homes available which were created in 80s.

title: Ask Gopal to organize your journey on Ross Island
review_text:
The turist office is hard to find in Port Blair so you need a Tuk Tuk and I do recommend the tuk tuk of Gopal Bhayya. Call or text him on 9531918600 for any assistance. He can also wait for you at the airport of Port Blair to pick you up if you contact him before. 
He will organise everything for you, ferry tickets, hotels and restaurant, visits..... 
Very friendly man, 100% reliable and his prices are good 
He is a travel agency by himself

title: Histrionically important
review_text: A 15 min ferry ride from Port Blair. This place has beautiful history behind. The ligth and sound show here is amazing in the evening.

title: Historical glimpse to the islands....
review_text:
Situated approx 2 km east of Port Blair. It was the location of British administrative set up the ruins of which can be seen scattered on the island. It is also seen as a shield of the main island or port blair as it took most of the tsunami brunt which reduced the destruction to the main island. Going sequentially, you have to get on a boat from jetty which is a return journey. it can be only ross island vis or combined with the north bay coral reef - a loc for water sports. you get arnd an hour on the island at teh end of which your boat picks you up for water sports or jetty, as per your deal. 
At the outset you can see the japanese bunker after which you enter the island proper on purchasing the ticket from the counter. You have an option of oing solo around the tracks or taking guided tours on electric carts. Ruins of administrative and military set up can be seen along the tracks which are explained by the boards placed next to the ruins. Most of the buildings are damaged by tsunami or engulfed by vegetation. Also, wildlife on the island mesmerizes you with who keep moving about the island oblivious of the visitors. Be sure not to disturb them, to avoid penalty more so to avoid alarming them. More

title: Ruins of British military headquarters
review_text: It's an island near Port Blair. Takes five minutes by a speed boat .it has the ruins of British HQ. They have kept lot of deer which roam freely. Light n sound show is great. It is recommended that u hire the lady guide(Ms RAO) n do a walking tour. Do not use the E rickshaw.

title: worth visiting
review_text: the light and sound show is amazing and must visit and appreciate the history. the site has life still

title: A part where u visit in short period of time
review_text: Ross is under indian navy a 20 min water journey from port blair.. a place where u can visit in short period of time where u see British bunkers u can play with deers can ride in electric baggi

title: Stunning blue water views and the British grandeur
review_text:
We had a memorable family vacation in Andaman islands. We covered Port Blair, Swaraj Dweep (Havelock), Shaheed Dweep (Neil) and Netaji Subhash Island (Ross). We were disconnected from the world with no mobile connection (except in Port Blair) and no data connection, and still we did not miss anything. On day 1 we took a flight from Hyderabad to Port Blair. Port Blair is a small city with hilly terrain, and ocean on almost all sides. It has a small airport with landing and take-off only in one direction i.e. from and to south. A new terminal building is coming up in view of growing traffic, and possibly international connections. We had booked right side window seats for all four of us in advance in the Indigo flight so that we could see the islands during the descend. We could spot Tarmugli and Boat Island and the view was mesmerizing - island completely covered with dense forest. People in Port Blair are soft spoken and helpful. One reason could be that they understand the need to help each other in a small island. We had booked only the hotel and the cruise to Swaraj Dweep and Shaheed Dweep. For transfer to the hotel from airport we took a cab at the airport itself. There is a pre-paid taxi booth near baggage claim manned by Port Blair traffic police. We got a cab for Rs 150, outside the terminal it would... We had a memorable family vacation in Andaman islands. We covered Port Blair, Swaraj Dweep (Havelock), Shaheed Dweep (Neil) and Netaji Subhash Island (Ross). We were disconnected from the world with no mobile connection (except in Port Blair) and no data connection, and still we did not miss anything. 

On day 1 we took a flight from Hyderabad to Port Blair. Port Blair is a small city with hilly terrain, and ocean on almost all sides. It has a small airport with landing and take-off only in one direction i.e. from and to south. A new terminal building is coming up in view of growing traffic, and possibly international connections. 

We had booked right side window seats for all four of us in advance in the Indigo flight so that we could see the islands during the descend. We could spot Tarmugli and Boat Island and the view was mesmerizing - island completely covered with dense forest. 

People in Port Blair are soft spoken and helpful. One reason could be that they understand the need to help each other in a small island. We had booked only the hotel and the cruise to Swaraj Dweep and Shaheed Dweep. For transfer to the hotel from airport we took a cab at the airport itself. There is a pre-paid taxi booth near baggage claim manned by Port Blair traffic police. We got a cab for Rs 150, outside the terminal it would have cost 200-300. On the way to the hotel the cab driver suggested us to visit Ross island that very day. So we dumped our bags at the hotel and rushed to the Aberdeen jetty. We got the first glimpse of a stunning blue water, something I had never seen before. 

We hopped on to a ferry from there to go to Ross island now renamed Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose island. Netaji visited this island in 1945. Though Ross is a small island it has its own history. First settlement was in 1788 and then abandoned in 1796. It was settled again after 1857 and remained headquarter of British rule in Andamans until 1941, when it was captured by Japanese. It came under control of the Government of India 1945. 

As you enter the island there is a Japanese bunker who built it during their occupation of the island during WW II. Island has the ruins of a typical British colony, full with colonial buildings of English grandeur. It has barracks, hospital, church, club and so on. Over the time the trees have embraced the buildings, and thus protecting whatever remains of the ruins for posterity. Modern filmmakers must have got a lot of ideas from such places. 

By the way there are plenty of Indian spotted deer on the island. There is also a water purification plan with long pipes to convert sea water into drinkable water. 

We further trekked into the north of the island to reach other end where there is a jetty leading to a light house. View from there was absolutely stunning. 

There are also facilities for water sport here but we ran out of time. 

Evening we visited the bazaar near the clock tower in Port Blair. Being Sunday most of the shops were closed, but we could pick some bakery items for the morning. 

Recommendations - Cost of boat ride was Rs 350 per head. Last boat leaves from the Aberdeen jetty at 2 pm, so make sure to be there as early as possible so that there is sufficient time at the island. Do not waste money on cabs. Take autos, scooters and remain free. It is much cheaper, will help you explore and also allow you to interact with local people. Everyone speaks Hindi there and if you know Bangla, even better. title: Seen nothing like this before.
review_text: If there is one place I had tried to read and look up before going to Andaman, it was Ross Island. I have always loved visiting ruined cities and all, and this place was on my checklist!

title: This island can be skipped
review_text:
Not much to do in this island other than loiter under sweltering sun and watch old buildings consumed by big banyan trees. 
If you can then skip it.

title: Nice place to visit
review_text:
It is an island were you can see old buildings and monuments from the british era. Lot of the buildings have been destroyed. One can see the remains of the past. There are animals like, deer, rabbit and peacock on the island which adds to the experience. However, one thing which is very essential if you want to visit this island is a guide named Anuradha Rao. She is a 65 year old lady who knows everything about the past and present of island. Today, one can only understand the place if she explains the same. The animals of the island are friends with her and obey her commands. If she is your guide on the visit to Ross island, the place is worth a visit. Ross island is hardly 10 minutes by boat from Port Blair jetty. One can get shared govt. ferries private boats to visit the island. We opted for the private boat, would recommend the same. The island also a Japanese bunker which was constructed by Japanese army when they invaded the island during the second world war. It also has a beach, however the same is rocky. One cannot swim in the island. Port Blair is more like a transient place for visit to Andaman islands. title: A glimpse of British rule
review_text: Most of the buildings are overgrown in quite a spectacular way. You could walk around the place in less than an hour but it is probably worth spending money on a guided tour in a golf buggy. The British certainly built a home from home here. A huge desalination plant, swimming pools, tennis courts, croquet lawns, they had it all. And apparently one of the best bakeries in the world. The island became known as the Paris of the East. The island is teeming with wildlife, spotted deer, peacock and millions of squirrels.

title: A lavish past
review_text: A worth visiting place, easily visited from port blair. Gives an insight into the lavish and luxury lifestyle of the Englishmen who lived there.

title: Ross island sound & light
review_text: Most amazing sound and light ever seen. Almost a blink and miss blip on the sea...had it's own charm for the Brits and their settlements. Ferry to and fro from port Blair...attend the sound & light...walk around the half a mile lonely place...old time park, cemetery, church, commissioners house and barracks all in a dilapidated condition...great time there.

title: Paris of the East to Britishers
review_text: It is a nearby Island to Port Blair. One has to travel by boat to reach Rose Island. Now in ruins. Old Churches, Buildings, Press, swimming pool, Tennis court, Housing colonies all in ruins which big tree roots pierced the structures. It gives us an idea of how Britishers lived in luxury, made a home away from their home, of course with their Engineering skill during their colonial period.

title: Ross island
review_text: Ross island is beautiful. It was the headquarter of britishers. Their administrative buildings are still ther ( rotten ). The water is super clear. You can spend a wonderful time by sitting near the sea. Well maintaind and surrounded by coconut trees. You can also take pictures with friendly deers. Its hardly 15 mins boat ride from the main land.

title: Wonderful place: nature reclaiming historic heritage
review_text: We visited Ross Island as a late addition to a trip to the Andamans and were absolutely delighted by it. It has a wonderful combination of history and nature, with the jungle reclaiming the remains of the British occupation and astonishingly tame deer wandering around. Our trip over by boat gave us an hour there but we would really have liked double that, to explore more of the island and have time for a coffee at the cafe.

title: A long needed vaccation
review_text: If you want to explore oceans, beaches then definitely one of the nice place. Its economic, safe and friendly with a taste of culture. Overall a beautiful treat!

title: Ok place
review_text: You can go here if you have nothing else to do. There r deers and peacock, u can click some good images. Not much to see here.

title: Much hyped
review_text: Not very gd ...no beach there..only some remains of old buildings ...entrance fee of 30 rs per person...Visit if u don't have any better option

title: For history and nature lovers
review_text: Schedule 2 hours from your trip to visit this beautiful island which is full of historical monuments and old trees. the landscape is great with hilly roads and ruins of British club houses and bungalows.

title: Great place to relive history
review_text: A ferry ride to Ross Island from Water Sports Complex jetty would cost Rs. 350 per head for to and fro journey. Remember, the ferry that takes you there would bring you back, no one else. You also have the option of getting into a shared battery rickshaw which would give you a tour of the island. However, we could not obtain a seat after 2 or 3 attempts and then decided to explore the place on foot. That was a good decision. The times when the island was inhabited must have been a paradise. Despite loathing the times when we were ruled by the British, you can't help but admire their sense of planning. In late 1800 they planned a swimming pool filtering sea water. They had made distilleries to provide drinking water to the inhabitants. The cathedral, though in ruins, still stands majestically. And the icing on the cake was, wild deers and peacocks loitering freely in the open. It must have been a great place to live in those times. We were informed by a local that because of Ross Island, Port Blair was least affected by the tsunami in 2004. It bore most of the brunt and saved Port Blair from major damage. A must visit when in Andamans. More

title: Worth a visit
review_text: Beautiful little island, the ruins are a reminder of our history. The light and sound show is one of the best. Lovely place to walk around and admire the view of the colourful little boats bobbing around in the water made crimson by the setting sun. Lots of deer and peacocks wanting to be fed. The major downside is the ticketing booth on Port Blair jetty, no queues and no information. The climb down to and back up from the boat also requires some expertise and surefootedness.

title: Historical island one must visit
review_text: Just a short speed boat ride from Port Blair. showcases the British settlement including the ancient church, English bakery,water treatment plant, barracks for soldiers, bungalow for the chief officers. Good vies of the ocean, palm trees with free roaming deers. Photographers delight!

title: Awesome - An abandoned city !!!!!
review_text:
Let me begin this review by saying that Ross Island ( renamed as Netaji Subash Chandra Bose Island by Honourable PM of India ) was instrumental in saving the city of Port Blair from the ghastly Tsunami of December 2004. 
This place is hardly two kilometres from Port Blair Aberdeen Jetty. Ross Island is actually an abandoned city, built ( and abandoned ) by the British. You could see ruins of everything that makes up a city. There is Commissioner's Bungalow, Church, Power Plant, Cemetry, Barracks etc. All this in a very small area that can be effectively covered walking. The path is hilly and is not advisable for the elderly and infirm. However, electric battery operated vehicles are there for assistance. You find lovely deers roaming around in the open, freely mingling with humans, and eating whatever is offered to them. There are few peacocks that add to the attraction. You need to walk down a steep path to go the beach on opposite side of the beach where you landed by boat. You can spend whole day in this island, if you are really interested in history and old ruins. Boat guides hassle you and try to get you out of the island in maximum 2 hours. There is a small shop dispensing popular items like Lays, Coke, Frooti, Mineral Water etc. 
Certainly worth a visit. 
No second thoughts. More

title: Good place at port blair
review_text:
You have to go by boat from port Blair to visit the island. You have to pay the entry fees there. After entering there you may visit the british times old building which all destroyed at the time of world war 2. 
you will get an out standing view of ocean from this island. Swimming and bathing are strictly restricted in this island.

title: Ruins worth a capture
review_text: From port Blair it’s a tiny boat ride for INR 350 each! The ride was choppy and the boats are not particularly well kept but it’s very functional and takes about 5-7 minutes to reach Ross Islands. The entry ticket is minimal and you have the option to walk across the entire place (make a note it gets very hot) or take a golf cart ride. The golf cart ride is a 8 seater and the driver charges INR 80 per person , one has the option to book the entire cart and be flexible or wait for 8 passengers. The place is a photographers treat. The history behind the ruins are worth learning. Like many other places, due to irresponsible tourists it’s not very well kept, plastic bottles and packets thrown here and there. There’s a lot that can be done to this place but it’s worth a visit! The ruins are so rustic and the place exudes edgy charm. More

title: An abandoned city
review_text: This island is just two kilometers from Port Blair by boat. This used to be the administrative headquarters of British settlements until they abandoned it after an earthquake. The ruins of the old settlement are all there but very poorly maintained. It's a miniature Pompei. Very interesting to visit.

title: A Place of Historical Importance
review_text: Lovely place to take some beautiful pics and has lot of history behind which is interesting to know..........

title: Its the best place in Andaman
review_text:
This place is much shady than other parts in andaman, I mean this olace is much cooler. Battery cars are availabel to you around of that place. The battery cars costs rs60 per head and its worth the money too. This place also reflects the british era like the celluar jail in port blair. You can see spotted deer and pecocks there. You can take pictures with them. Just a small request that please dont feed them, and if you are feeding deers please feed them with your bare hands, and dont litter around as deers eat the left over wrappers and that can affect their health. 
Please go to this island as it is worth seeing. More

title: Ross Island visit
review_text: Destroyed by the tsunami, this needs substantial upgradation without which this is a place that can be avoided

title: Ross Island- glimpses of British raj
review_text: Visited Ross Island with family on 7/2/19. It was administrative headquarter of britishers. Old Church, offices, bakery and water distil plant parts were in torn conditions explaining history. Deer and rabbit travelling freely on island.

title: Becoming too commercialized
review_text: We visited Ross island in Feb 2019...for anyone who's looking to spend more than an he there you will be disappointed...you take a ferry from the water sports complex...they start from 9:30 onwards (go a little early say by 9 so you can get tickets about 350 per person) you will get exactly one hour on the island and then you have to head back by the same ferry in which you came...if you are fond of exploring the place at leisure one hr is not enough....and if you want to spend a couple of hrs you have to hire a whole ten seater ferry for 3 to 4 thousand and then you can spend as much time possible there....Ross island is beautiful but one hr is not enough for people like me and my husband who like to take time and see the place properly... title: Great visit
review_text: Ross island is very near to the port Blair..it's a very small island which is having great asthetic value and pleasing to see deers, peacocks,ducks roaming around freely in island.

title: fine to see
review_text: very nice to see the island It has many memories of last days .The buildings and markets etc are completely covered by trees to see it amazing

title: Ross island experience
review_text:
Port Blair: Cellular jail sound show was a bit long but good. You can book tickets on net. The Jogger park is very nice. The Marina was fully lit up on the evening due to Republic day. Nice place for an evening stroll. The sound and light show on Ross Island was very good. This starts at sunset around 5.45PM. The script is written by Gulzar, music by Shankar Mahadevan,Ehsan and produced by Aprna.Karve. Visited the cellular jail. This Kala Pani has a lot of history and gory stories to tell. You take pride of the freedom fighters like Veer Savarkar and others who gave their childhood and life for our country. Had dinner at the Fortune hotel. This place is cosy and value for money. Visited the limestone caves at Barahtang. This is at the northern most tip of Andamans. We had to leave early in the morning at 3.30 to take the 6AM convoy into the restricted area. This area is dense forest where the nomads reside and the place is controlled by the police. It is a 45Km stretch. No photos allowed. We did see a few nomads. Finally after a tiring 2hrs bumpy car ride reached the boat jetty at 7.:30. A big Ro-Ro boat ferries everyone across to Barahtang. From here a speedboat takes you to the caves. title: Deer and rabbits!
review_text:
Ross Island was the older British capital of Andaman and right now, everything is in ruins. The natural beauty however is amazing, both on the island and around it. There are very old trees with roots spread all over and blue water all around. 
Our trip to the whole of Andaman, including Havelock Island was arranged by Ms. Monisha and her team at Pristine Andaman (pristineandaman@gmail.com). We booked air travel and hotels on our own. All the rest (ferry/speed boats/transfers from airport, hotel, etc./permits/divers) were managed by them. They reserve hotels too but we came to know of them only after we had already done that. They have a complete chain. So basically after landing in Portblair, you don't have to worry about anything. They will design a package and ask you for your comments and the itinerary can be tweaked as per your preference/ convenience. Charges for water activities are your own, depending on what you want to go in for. They are quite flexible and considerate of your needs. A very high level of coordination wherein they assure you that the driver will call you before you land at a place and the driver actually does that! Strongly recommended. More

title: awesome !
review_text:
must visit. steeped in history. 
though a plastic free island, there was quite a bit of trash. including in the jetty

title: Don’t miss out Ross and North Bay in Port Blair
review_text:
An amazing place I can say , Ross Island was once the capital during British Rule and then taken over by Japanese . 
Now it’s more like a ghost town with hardly any inhabitants. You will find deers , peacocks etc roaming around and can click pics with them. 
It gives a picturesque view of North bay and Port Blair as well. 
There’s also a museum and an old Japanese bunker present. 
Do check out this place while u r in Port Blair

title: Hectic and confusing transfer to very worthwhile site.
review_text:
We walked 1 km east from our Ross View Hotel, purchased our tickets ($5 each) for "Seagull Express". After waiting for an hour, it came and we were not permitted to board as it was reserved for a group. A dock coordinator came and wrote out a new ticket for "OB Sea Liner" which came in 15 minutes to collect 5 foreigners and 3 locals. 
Arrived on island at 10:10 AM and given instructions to re-board at 11:20 AM. We walked the island circuit; to the bakery, up to the church, to the cemetery, down to the market, reviewed all the signage before the more organized return to Port Blair on the "OB Sea Liner'. 
Lots of history here to go along with our afternoon visit to the Tentative UNESCO Cellular Jail. More

title: Lovely small Island.Get to be with hundreads of deers/peacocks and rabbits
review_text:
I enjoyed my trip to Ross island with my family recently in Jan 2019. 
Right from the Water sports complex to board the jetty till Ross island and return ,everything was perfect .The only regret was that I got only 45 minutes to see the island. 

Ross is a small island. The ruins are there ,and worth seeing. But what I found to be a unique experience was that in Ross hundred's of tame deer's roam about in the open. Initially you will be able to get close to them ,but if you are patient and gentle you can actually touch them. This is a magical experience. 
That apart there are tame white rabbits and plenty of peacocks. 
I took the evening boat to Ross that leaves at 4pm for the light and sound show. Since the boat got delayed I could not spend enough time .At least an hour and a half is required if one wants to experience ross in its entirety and this does not include the time for the light and sound show. 
I found the light and sound show at Ross to be very good .It is definitely worth seeing .Much better than the light and sound show at Cellular Jail. 
Do not miss Ross during your Andaman visit. You will enjoy it. If you have kids ,it is an absolute must. More

title: Lovely piece of history
review_text: The place is just amazing and has some wonderful views and amazing sights, you get to see a lot of old British construction that have collapsed over the years and reclaimed by the forest, and some as good as new. There are still a few scars left by the Tsunami. It's a place u must visit, but the only down side is that u can stay on the island only for an hour

title: "The Paris of East" as it was some 85 years ago
review_text: Complete with every detail of Luxury living this Administraive HQ of erstwhile British Dominion in Andamans is appealing till date.Can be reached by speedboat from RGWSC jetty Portblair in 5 -7 mins.

title: very interesting island to visit
review_text: Great island with a british heritage to visit, nice for photography, looks a bit like Angkor for the vegetation

title: Worth to see it
review_text: Britishers are excellent in choosing and locating the place, When the live they make the place comfortable. More than 100 years back also they had all modern comfort in Ross Island which even now many of the our villages are not having.

title: MESMERIZING/HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE
review_text: Visited here on 18th Jan 2019, A must visit for all the travellers going to Andamans, it has a lot of History associated with the place and the best part is that it also has Peacock, Deers who can be seen wandering. You can get guides by Paying Rs 50/- Per Head. The Boat Operators allow 2 Hrs time to spend at Ross Island. Recently after PM Visit the name of the Island is changed to Bose Island.

title: Peacocks in Ross Island
review_text:
We took the ferry to Ross Island from Port Blair. Because we had to leave the same day, we chartered a boat just for us to make sure we could return on time. Ross Island is the island where the British first landed and they subsequently left it several years later due to an earthquake which damaged the buildings. As a result, the buildings all have trees growing over them. Interesting to see. You can walk around the island in an hour or two. If you cannot walk, you can pay Rs. 50 and go on a golf cart to see the main exhibits. However, it is more fun to walk around since you see more at a leisurely pace. The golf cart just goes from point A to B and at many points, the cart does not stop at all. The swimming pool is cleverly built. As you go around the island, you will see several peacocks strutting about. Very pretty. We also saw kingfishers and other birds. Overall, it was a pleasant couple of hours. Trying to get into your boat to take the trip back is chaotic. There is no organized way to let people off and on (you have to take the same boat you came on and there is no way to know when exactly your boat will come). Our boatman said he would come by 10:40 and showed up at 11:00 and we got... We took the ferry to Ross Island from Port Blair. Because we had to leave the same day, we chartered a boat just for us to make sure we could return on time.

As a result, the buildings all have trees growing over them. Interesting to see. You can walk around the island in an hour or two. The golf cart just goes from point A to B and at many points, the cart does not stop at all. 
The swimming pool is cleverly built. As you go around the island, you will see several peacocks strutting about. Very pretty. We also saw kingfishers and other birds. Overall, it was a pleasant couple of hours. 

Trying to get into your boat to take the trip back is chaotic. There is no organized way to let people off and on (you have to take the same boat you came on and there is no way to know when exactly your boat will come). Our boatman said he would come by 10:40 and showed up at 11:00 and we got on to the boat by hopping into another boat that was at the jetty blocking access to our boat. 
So make sure you allow some extra time for delays like this. However, the ferry ride is ten minutes or less to Port Blair. More

title: Legacy island but with pockets of garbage
review_text: The island is 15min from Pt Blair and has some historic British era ruined buildings. Ruined by earthquake and recent tsunami. Its under Indian Navy administration now. While the island has a calm atmosphere and great views there are several places where junk and garbage is deposited - used commodes, furniture etc, which is a spoils the experience. The administration should clean up these junk.

title: 1 hours is enough
review_text: From Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports you will combine boat for north bay and ross island. You can enjoy ride in batter vehicle, driver will also guide through all the way.

title: A drenching experience!
review_text: A place to visit for people who are enamoured by ruins and the romance of trying to imagine the past. You can see firsthand the power of mother nature over anything human over here. Once called the Paris of the East for its grand buildings and the opulent lifestyles of its inhabitants, the entire island is in ruins and grand Banyan trees have taken hold of the walls of once regal buildings and crumble them by a few inches each year. The deer are very friendly and don't mind being petted. They expect to be fed, despite the boards which warn you against it. Be careful about the boat ride to the Island, though short, you will get drenched by sea spray. Keep your belongings, specially your wallet, mobile phone and cameras in a water proof bag before you get on board. More

title: Visit it and see what a Tsunami can do to an island
review_text: The island is now all captured hey the huge trees and nature has taken its toll on the island. But if you happen to meet the local guide at the island whose name is Anuradha then you will surely understand the history of the island and the importance of the buildings over there. Since she's the one who have stayed in the island before tsunami hit it and destroyed it. There's a lot of walking over here but a buggy can be hired at Rs. 80 per person. However then the drivers will be the one to inform you about the island and it might not be as good as Anuradha. More

title: Super fun place for all
review_text:
Visited Ross island with my family. Chose to visit in the evening for the famous light and sound show. Here's what I think of the place: 
1. The place itself is quite beautiful. It was a township that was deserted after a massive earthquake divided the island in the middle. What is left is heartbreaking ruins of an era gone by. Church, commissioner's bungalow, barracks...all are beautiful and I loved visiting those. 
2. For the young ones, the place offers an unequalled experience of walking with the deers. The place is brimming with deers and rabbits. And you can even feed them ( with permission from the caretaker). Both my kids LOVED it. 
3. The light and sound show is very well produced and professionally curated. I have not seen an equivalent show in India so far. To top it all, gulzar's story telling transports you to a different world. Mesmerizing is the only word. 

All in all, a visit to Ross island is a must. Do not miss it More

title: small island
review_text: It is a small island. one can reach there by a Boat from Abbardin jetty point, port blair. It was a capital at British time. Kids enjoy with Deers/peacock etc.

title: Ross Island
review_text: Ross Island can be viewed from Andaman island itself. It used to be place where Britisher had their club but the whole place is in ruins now. The island also have a good population of deer and peacocks. Deer on the island are not afraid of humans so they will come and even touch your hand in anticipation of some food.

title: The Blue Island
review_text: The erstwhile capital of Andaman & Nicobar islands. British period, the island was large inhabited by British officers as well as natives. The island had all the modern facilities such as tennis courts, restaurants and hospitals

title: MMT premium package
review_text: Visited Ross Island which is a beautiful visland in Port Blair. One can reach this Island by taking boat. Before taking boat one can enjoy scenic beauty of sea both sides of the jetty . Ross island is spreaded in huge area giving history of colonial period. Battery operated vehicles are their to take a round of islandby paying RS. 100 per person . Island is full of deers. Which is one of the main attractions of the island. Everyone like to click pics with deers and enjoy there

title: Beautiful n Historic
review_text: One can visit this island by boat only. Speed boats (INR 350 / person) take group of 8-12 persons to this island. One hour is given to tourists for exploring this island. Battery operated rickshaws are available for this. This one is beautiful island having remains of buildings built by Britishers. Also a good location for shooting horror movies...:)

title: Brutal British History in Ruins
review_text:
Now known as Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose Island, Ross Island is a painful reminder of the British Raj. Named after the Captain Daniel Ross who was a hydrographer employed by the East India Company is still wonderful as the tossing waves, the blue waters, tall coconut trees and the silver beach haven't changed a little. 
A boat ride of about 10 minutes would take you from the Port Blair and one can see a colony in it's ruins. British Officers used to stay there and on coming to know of the execution of an Indian freedom fighter from the Cellular Jail (Guantanamo Bay of the British Raj), parties would begin in the tiny islands then. 

It is a natural beauty unparalleled lulled by the inhuman history. A person who loves his nation and humanity has to go around the island with a heavy heart as nearly thousand patriots fell to the gallows still preserved in their finest cruel history. Cruelty was at its best display and hence the sad narrative. But, yet again I reiterate the entire Andaman Islands group is one of the rarest,still with it's pristine beauty. 

Visit it for it's the rarest history, geography, biology, environment , anthropology and what not! More

title: harmony on animals and man
review_text: Beautiful experience with deers, rabbits and dancing peacocks coupled with history, a definitely must visit if you like history.

title: Good place
review_text: Good place to spend around half a day if you have interest in history. Around 10 min by boat from Port Blair. Can see deers and rabbits. Though most of the buildings are dillipidated, still you get an idea about British administration structure. View of Beach on the backside from top is awesome, some pretty old trees with widespread roots can be seen. Though could do with a little more maintenance, Worth a visit. Don't go if looking for any activity or water sports, they are at North Bay.

title: During low tide, it is one single island but during high tide it separates into two islands.
review_text: Ross & Neil islands is very popular. During low tide, it is one single island but during high tide it separates into two islands. Ross Island was the administrative headquarters of the British during World War II. Formerly known as Paris of the East, this place now lies in ruins. Its manicured lawns adorned with umbrellas and shades and the majestic ballrooms were destroyed in an earthquake in 1941.

title: Small Island with Ruins
review_text:
Ross island is reachable through a boat that usually stops at North Bay first. This island has ruins of British time buti could be more nicely maintained. While it is clean, most of the buildings could have been preserved better. Basic amenities such as bottled water are not available and it becomes difficult in the heat to move around. 

The beach is very good with a pleasant breeze and good views.

title: Symbol of Past
review_text: During British era Ross Island was the capital of A&N Admistration. Now it's controlled by Indian Navy. Very small Island near mainland. Ruins of British time structures can be witnessed. You must read the history of this Island which is displayed at the main entrance. Battery powered cars are available for visitors to go round the place. 1 to 1 1/2 hour is sufficient to cover the place. Must carry water bottles .

title: Amazing place with British Era ruins.
review_text: Ross island is a great place for a walk. Island has architectural ruins from the British era. Ross island has old structures build by the colonial era prisoners. We have to book a boat from Port Blair to reach Ross Island. Usually, the trip to Ross Island and North Bay is offered together from Port Blair. They allow you to spend 1 hour in Ross Island then go to North Bay for two hours.

title: Ruin island
review_text: This is one of the tourist attraction in Port blair. You have to visit this place through ferry around 8.30am. Place is ruin but well maintained. There are some animal here.

title: boating
review_text: Nice. We could not get food (lunch). otherwise the boating was nice. The guide explained well. Again that day was also heavy showering.

title: Nice island, messy boatrides
review_text:
Cool place to do a day trip to for a few hours but really messy boatsystem to/from the port. We met a couple who got stuck at Ross island harbour because their boat got two hours delayed without notice. I payed 350 rupees for a returnticket and 1,5h on the island. There are probably cheaper tickets available, you might want to ask around. 

The island ruins with trees growing through them are really cool and something special, like the jungle took the island back after the brittish. 
There are deers on the island who is not afraid of people. Also peacocks and rabbits. But please respect wildlife on the island and never feed or interfere with any animals. Drinkingwater is available at the port at Ross. Make sure not to leave any trash behind. More

title: Nice 1h walk
review_text: This is really worth seeing. The forest is literally eating the buildings. Deers, squirrels and peacocks are walking freely. Very nice experience. In order to get to Ross you need to get into one of tons of boats for around 350 rupies. We've been unlucky to select the company called Seagull Express. Customer service doesn't exist there, they said they will pick us up at 2PM whilst we needed to wait till 4PM in full sun on pier for them to pick us up. While I raised my complaint and demanded refund they called me idiot :-) Better avoid them, there is lot of other boats your can get in. More

title: Historical place
review_text: If you are in Port Blair must visit Ross Island and take motorised cab to take a trip to the heights point of Island. The driver nicely explains historical value of various places during your ride. You come across and witness the historical facts.

title: serene and a nice walk
review_text:
Old British construction absolutely in ruins a short boat ride from Andaman sports dock 
The place would do well to have the place restored and would surely attract hordes of tourist especially Britishers who wish to touch base with there ancestors - nevertheless it makes a lovely walk amongst the largest palms that one is likely to ever set eyes on

title: Short and Sweet Island
review_text: Natural beauty with Deer near by area. Small walk with your dear ones would refresh you. Indian Flag brings in a new look to the outlook.

title: Good place to visit to understand how british where staying on this Island and how Japnies destroyed it
review_text:
This island was occupied by British initially and then occupied by japnies during 2nd world war. Visit can be complete in 1-2 hrs time. 
Evening sound and light show. Need to travel by boat to reach this island.This travel depends on the Sea weather condition

title: If you have time you should go.
review_text: first of all at this island is only remains of what it was before freedom at the time of British & from the times of Japanese capture. The clubs, swimming pool, helipad, the church and the governor house all are just remains (khandhar) just walls are there though you can read so many things mentioned. Yes one thing is there that caught my attention was Distilled water plant from like 80 years earlier planted by British residence. Can spot peacock, deer and rabbits playing around.Much of the area of island are banned because of navy settlement. Must go by last jetty at 2;30 PM so that can be there for an hour and roam without being sun burned.Don't wear heels must get some very comfortable footwear.Eat something before coming as won't get anything good in here's single restaurant . More

title: history times
review_text: the island is famous for its old houses build by the Britishers when they used to rule the island . famous amongst the tourist for its natural beauty.

title: Very good beach , British history repeats
review_text: Very good beach, British stayed/ruled from here also developlement done by britishers are seen in there.

title: best place for excurssion
review_text: the island is very nice for day time. you can see there dear and peacock. we enjoyed lots with nature. the old church also there which build by british.

title: Ross Island
review_text: well worth a couple of hours visit with historical places and a good walk around to capture the history. deer and peacocks wandering around

title: Great location
review_text: Very nice location but the steep walk inside may not be suitable for elder people but view is good. Some old buildings including church. Overall it’s a small beautiful place.

title: history
review_text: this island stand there for history. Youngsters walk and see the the things hoe the history played. This place stands for the history lovers.

title: Light and Sound show @ Ross
review_text:
The trip from Port Blair to Ross Island and back should be done at leisure. The island is to be visited afternoon/evening. Its good for children as well as there are deers, rabbits, peacocks running around freely on the island. 

The highlight of the visit would be the sound and light show which should not be missed. Its conceptualised beautifully and is full of history of how Andaman and Nicobar island were inhabited

title: Excellent light and sound show
review_text:
You should not visit the island during the day time as there is nothing to do. The island has been destroyed during the tsunami and you will see just the ruins. 
It is good for children as there are many deer's, rabbit's and peacocks on the island and they come close to you and you can touch them. There is a guide called Anuradha there who explains about the history of the island which was once the capital during British rule. 
The highlight of the island is the light and sound show which happens in the evening. If you are going to see the light and should show there , you can see the island just before that and then enjoy the light and sound show. You need to take a ferry from Rajiv Gandhi Water Complex to reach there. The tickets for the light and sound show are difficult to get so plan in advance or get in touch with a travel agent. 
This is really one of the best light and sound shows you will get to see in India, the cellular jail light and sound show is nothing as compared to the quality here. 
Go to Ross Island only if you want to see the light and sound show or else you may very well skip visiting it. More

title: Worst Island
review_text: I went with my 2 friends as soon as we reached the island we looked around as nothing to do all there. Waisted of money n time. We just sat there for more than an hr waiting for our boat to take us back. Nothing to c n do.

title: Very hot and dry
review_text: Its an island situated very near to port blair. You will go there in a jetty. The island was British capital. This island is very dry and hot with very intense sunrays. So be prepare for that before going there. Keep sufficient water with you. No water activities are there and the beach is not an open beach.

title: Beautiful Tiny Island at Portblair
review_text: This tinny Ross island is just 5 minutes away by a jetty ride. The island has ruins of British buildings used for their own convenience during their empire. It had a bakery hospital and rest houses for the British officers. Now the island also has beautiful garden. It can be accessed by a battery car. Which takes you the hill top for a wonderful view of the ocean and surroundings. Children will enjoy this place as there are deers and pecocks around the park. I would also suggest to explore the park by a guide tour of Anuradha Madam.

title: Historic !
review_text: What an historic place to visit after Cellular Jail. The whole island keeps up with the ruins of World War II fought between the Brits and the japanese. Lot of deers are on this island too. Witnessed a deer fight too. Great place for photography ofcourse

title: Dont miss it
review_text: Small island but very picturesque. Got to see peacock, rabbit, deers etc roaming around freely. Has a small church but it has been closed for gen public. This island is must visit, can skip northbay island if you dont want to do any water sports activities.

title: GIVES ONE A CLEAR PICTURE OF THE LIFE THE BRITS LED IN THE EMERALD ISLES
review_text: Ross Island lies a couple of km east of Port Blair and is a unique place which is a must visit. The Island is under the Indian Navy and we had the fortune of getting a ride in a Naval Barge to the Island and had a lovely time exploring it during our recent visit to the Andamans. The Island was the Capital of the Brits during their time in the Andamans. The history of the place is beautifully depicted by a Son et Lumiere, which is of EXTREMELY HIGH QUALITY. It brings the island alive in its depiction of the life spent by the British. There are plenty of spotted deer and rabbits on the Island, who roam around absolutely freely and are extremely friendly. A couple of golf carts are available which can be used to go around the island. The island is extremely small and can be gone around in an hour and a half. Most of the old buildings are in ruins. There are adequate boards which depict the history of the Island, which are on display if one wants to skip the Son et Lumiere. Though the Son et Lumiere is a must see. A MUST VISIT ISLAND. More

title: Very good
review_text: A British Island with old buildings, a must visit in Portblair, just 10 min boat transfer from Rajiv gandhi water complex

title: Earstwhile Capital
review_text:
Ross island was the capital during British rule. Now, ruins depict the grand luxury it had in its hey days. 

It is astonishing to see water treatment plant, ro, swimming pool, printing press ruins.

title: Nice little island
review_text: This island can be given a miss. We fed some deer on the island. The animals are not bound to a certain boundary, they are free on the island.

title: Ruined island with Lone Sailor
review_text: Take 15-20 minutes speed boat ride from water complex...Choose speed boat,would be a great ride...Would require 1.5 to 2 hours to fully explore the island..Electric cars available for those who don't want to walk..I wouldn't recommend it because it takes away the real joy of exploring the island. All you would find in Ross island is ruins....Now the important thing.The best spot in the island is the "Lone Sailor".It is on the beach.But to get there one would have to walk up to the highest point and then go downstairs to beach side from there...which 95% of people don't do...They return from the highest point without visiting Lone Sailor.....Real beauty of Ross island is at Lone Sailor...A bridge across the sea, a statue and a lighthouse...Very scenic place....Don't miss it. More

title: The Queen in the Bay.
review_text: Ross island,the British capital of the andaman,now controlled by the Indian navy a tiny island amidst coconut and palm trees full of nature's beauty.

title: Worth a Visit
review_text: Ross island is not too far from Port Blair and is an excellent destination. It has numerous buildings of a bygone era which tell the story of the British Raj. We hired an electric rickshaw that took us to the highest point and the driver was kind enough to show us the numerous places of historical interest. Highly recommended.

title: Vacation at andaman
review_text: A must visit place in your itenery. The ruined structures is fabulous to watch. Lots of deer and peacocks roaming around you freely. Magnificent view of beaches. Multiple shades of sea water can be seen from there. Beautifully very well maintained. There is a battery operated car for those who cannot walk.

title: The Iconic Island.
review_text: If you are clubbing together your tour with north bay island, it is ok but Don't miss to see light, laser and sound show at Ross Island which start at 5:30 Pm and for that you have to again visit the island by different farry. so it is better to go at once to visit the island for light and sound show and side by you can visit the island also. You can online book light and sound show tickets through Andaman Tourism website and Ferry tickets to be purchased on the spot (Rs. 250) at Rajiv Gandhi Sport Complex (Aberdeen Jetty), Port Blair at 4:00 PM. Roaming deer and rabbits are fun for kids at Ross Island. Rs.30/person is need to pay while entering the island. The Island is under Indian Navy. More

title: Nothing great. Enjoy the ferry ride.
review_text: Just like any other park, but in an island. For the religious, there's a church here. For the photographer, there are scenic spots to the rear or this island. They offer a buggy ride, but it's a bit expensive. It'd not hurt to avoid this place if you seek adventure. There are other places to visit.

title: A lovely island near Port Blair. Reminiscent of the Colonial past
review_text: A well preserved,well maintained island.Housed the government buildings during the 1800s. The flavour still lingers.It is a ten minute speed boat ride from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports park generally combined with the visit to the North Bay Island. There are no water sports activities at Ross is but there is a Light and Sound programme in the evening.There are no great eating joints.Keep the programme for max 2 hours

title: Old British buildings
review_text: Old British buildings and a bunker. During Colonial era, British stayed here. you can see the remains of their buildings. Not much facilities for the tourists.

title: Good place
review_text: It is a good place to walk ignoring humidity.u can cover easily in 30-45 mins or more (or more if boat people give u more time to explore). Nature is great. Deers can be seen. Though feeding them is prohibited but Indian tourist never listen. Saw many times feeding them. Nice place to go.

title: Former Paris of the East
review_text: Difficult to imagine the luxuries the British had built for themselves so many years ago. From swimming pools to water distilling plants, tennis courts & the works. Now everything lies in ruins with the trees having taken over the island. Now you see reindeers & peacocks roaming about freely. You get an hour on the island so i suggest a quick walk through following the pathway.

title: Sunset view of a Dynasty
review_text: Remnants of a place which was once thriving. The administrative capital island of the British which had remnants of officers’ quarters, subordinates club, cathedral, pond, bakery and printing press . A beautiful Ferar beach is also there though swimming is not possible. The island is now owned by peacocks, Deers and rabbits. The view of the ficus trees that had invaded and climbed over the remnant buildings is quite picturesque

title: Blast from the past
review_text:
The Ross Island is named after the marine surveyor Captain Daniel Ross. The island became the base for the British and served as their Administrative Headquarters. Initially, barracks of grass and bamboo were put up for the prisoners, while the rest of the party remained on board of the ships that had brought them to the island. Later on, the prisoners built houses, barracks, offices and other structures. 
This island is a 15 mins ride from Aberdeen jetty. You will have to buy entry tickets and if one can't walk, you can take a buggy ride. 
My suggestion would be to walk, there are several places to sit if one gets tired and you can explore the island and take pictures. 
There is small snack bar and a souvenir shop. One and half hour is more than sufficient to explore the island. Carry hats or umbrellas and the sun can be extremely harsh in mornings. More

title: Ruins of Old British Township still Picturesque
review_text: Can be traveled in a package along with North Bay Island from Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex. Motor Boat Per head cost for two and fro cost for both island is Rs. 550 to 650 per person. No need for advance bookings and pay more to agents. Tickets are available on spot at Sports Complex. The Island was once a sprawling township for British Rulers. Ruined due to earth quake. Ekart available at 80 Rs. / person is good way to move around the island quickly. Ruins of the buildings and view of sea from the island are really picturesque. Pack of peacocks and Deers can be spotted at island. Entry tickets of Rs. 30 per person is to be purchased. More

title: History Preserved
review_text: Ross Island is worth visiting, if you are accompanying the kids or there is a child inside you. Perhaps this is the only public place where one can pet the heard of Spotted Dears, White Rabbits or wild Bulbul Birds and peacocks eats from your palms. The place is maintained by Indian Navy. Lot of old ruins on the Island, are maintained in clean but dramatic conditions to appreciate the old British Headquarters of colonial era. A tourist can reach here only by the boats runs by private services providers, from Sports complex Jetty of Port Blair against payment. The Island has provision for free filtered drinking water, a small cafeteria and clean washrooms for visitors. If you are averse to walk then electrical vehicles are available on the Island. There is Light and Sound Show conducted in the evening, which is perhaps the best in Andaman. However, show is highly dependent on weather conditions. Any type of increase in wind speed results into cancellation of Boating permission by Port Authority or even little Drizzle makes the show organizer cancel this open air show. More

title: History
review_text: Ross island was capital of port blair. British officers used to stay here. It has old buildings which are damaged by tsumani and earthquack. You will see deer,rabbit,peacock on island. Its a small island you can take boat from port blair which takes 10 mints to reach there. Charges are 280rs per person including up and down. You can see island by taking ride on golf cart by paying 80rs per person.

title: Most famous Old historical place
review_text: Ross Island was also the base for the British Administrator of the penal colony in Port Blair.After some time, the Japanese converted the site into POW camp, and built war installations, remnants of which can still be seen. It now lies deserted, and the few signs of its colonial glory, such as the Chief Commissioner's house and the Presbyterian church, are dilapidated and overgrown. The area is now under the control of Indian Navy.

title: Very Beautiful and scenic place

title: Great experience
review_text:
Ross island is located opposite the Marina in Port Blair. One has to take a tourist ferry to reach it. 

The island was at one time the seat of British administration for Andman while Port Blair was the penal settlement. One can see the ruins of the British buildings like barracks, shops, church, swimming pool etc. There is a Japanese bunker also constructed during the Japanese occupation. 

There's a small beach. Also there are some deers and peacocks which fascinate the children. The deers are quite friendly and come quite close to people 

A part of the islands was damaged during an earthquake forcing the British to shift. Later the tsunami lashed the island. 

A sound and light show is organised every evening except Wednesday. It's worth watching as one learns about the history of the islands. The Hindi show has narration by Gulzar sahib and English is by Shabana Azmi ji. 

One can take an afternoon boat and explore the island at leisure, and return after watching the sound and light show. 

Must visit place More

title: British Pleasures of the Past
review_text: Ross island the then capital of Andaman And Nicobar islands during British period for sometime was under the grip of Japanese also. This island is now under Indian Navy. Just a 20 mins sea journey from Phoenix bay jetty of Port Blair, here we can see the ruins of buildings built during British period. Ruins of Church, Printing press, Government offices, Power house, Tennis court, Bakery, pond etc... A museum is being maintained by Navy in this island. A graveyard of Britishers surrounded by coconut palm trees is also available here. People can also visit the beaches located at the other side of the island by walk. Fearless deers and peacocks are found in the island. The island is full of coconut and palm trees. More

It is about the history of Andaman and Nicobar Islands and Ross Island in particular and is worth watching.

title: The bakery of the prison flour
review_text: The island had a small English settlement consisting of prison guards, british army officers and their families. The place has a graveyard of the yore and is filled with friendly antlers who are very sociable. This may be the only place in the entire archipelago where you can sit down with a deer or any wild animal. There are peacocks on the island too. An old Japanese bunker stands at the entry of the island which is a mark of the oppressive Japanese rule. Also there are the ruins of the bakery where the flour made by the persecuted Cellular jail prisoners was used to make cup cakes and bread for these foreign "guests". A piece of history that one should not miss. More
