title: Angelic !!
review_text:
Once the seat of British power, today the island has its charming ruins to boast about.You can find numerous deer's running in open and you can click photographs with them. Very huge picturesque trees, you would not have seen anywhere. 
Walk and see the Ross island and do not take the golf cart otherwise you will miss the close view of peacocks and the hidden beauty of the island. 

See its sound and light show (4 pm)

title: Ross island trip with Barefoot
review_text: Ross Island was the administrative center of British. Now it contains the ruins of the past. One can see deers, peacocks roaming freely. Its a blend of nature & history.

title: Nice place to visit
review_text: Good historical place to visit and what an idea to develop to live such luxurious way. Great feelings and next time like to see light and sound show

title: Not worth
review_text: it was having residential quarters of British officials. Nothing much to see. Not worth spending time there.

title: Lovely Island to spend couple of hours
review_text:
Located about 5 KMS from Port Blair, Ross Island served as administrative capital of the British before Port Blair. Today, this is controlled by the Navy. 
The Island very small with less than a mile long but one can spend about 2-3 hours here. There are old British structures including Bakery, Distillery and Church, all of them in ruins but they take you back to the time when it must have been so grand. Ross Island was once referred to as Paris of the East and it was for this grandeur. An old Japanese bunker can be found at the entrance. 
Apart from these, the major attraction for kids are the deers and peacocks. There must be about 100 deers freely roaming around. Some pose for photos and some train their horns at you. There are some peacocks as well. 
The best time to visit would be late afternoons around 3 PM during summers and 2 PM during winters. One is needed to go back in the evening to the main land. There are speed boats available from Port Blair and the to-and-fro journey costs around Rs. 300. 
Tips: Carry your own water bottle. There is a aquaguard dispenser in the Island and a small canteen that serves snacks and cold drinks.Coconut water can be brought at the Island More

title: British lived in Ross Island
review_text: Scenic . Although the destroyed ...but tells a lot about the past and how large and comfortable British lived . Location of island is the other side of Cellular jail.... it shows 2 shades of life of past . Kids enjoy the sight of Deer and peacocks on the island today

title: Worth a visit to see and feel the history
review_text: Britishers made it their capitol and developed it for their comfort to an extent that it was called Paris of east. Now you see remnants of what they did so definately worth a visit.. My advise...go here but not to North bay. Use the saved time for a visit to other places like Anthro museum and Samudrika museaum in Port Blair. North Bay is commercial and if u go to havelock and NI, you can definately give north bay a miss

title: A slice of destroyed paradise
review_text:
Ross island gives you a glimpse into new kind of tourism. The ruins tourism. While telling you of the glorious old days, these sites will present a grim picture. And Ross Island does that perfectly. Thanks to Indian Navy, it has been restored and kept in great shape. For those who cannot walk through the island, there is a cart to ferry you around. 
Do not forget to read the descriptions.

title: Night show is awesome
review_text: Ross Island is one of the smallest island as per the tourist wise but must watch specially at the evening. Night show is awesome in Ross Island. Cervus, rabbit & peacock will welcome you.

title: Historical Ruins, Nature, Deer and Peacocks
review_text: This location should be kept as a hopping point while returning from North Bay Island. Today the island is left out with the ruins but they are still well maintained by India Government. Deer and Peacock are easily visible here and there.

title: Surprisingly cool!
review_text: We headed to Aberdeen Jetty around 8.30am. If you go much later the place is teaming with boatloads of tourists. We waited until our little 10 person boat was full and the boat left. You have around 1.5 hours on the island - plenty of time. You return on the same boat. There is no clear route to take, but we wandered around - and it was really cool! Interesting to see the Victorian houses completely overgrown. There are good information boards telling the story of the island. There are chipmunk and deer everywhere too and even a friendly white rabbit!

title: Nothing much to enjoy except seeing the ruins of an old city
review_text: Fairly well maintained. The place can be covered by walking in an hour. Indian Navy maintains the island and is worth a visit .

title: Wonderful place with lots of shades
review_text:
Historically it has significance, lots of deer, ruins of British govt administrative setup, Japanese bunker, so do not miss this great place. 
2 hours for the Ross Island, 1 hour to go there and come back. 
Do not carry your food, do not feed any thing to deer. 
Coconut and Ice cream would be there. 
Take buggy ride to see entire island and then walk the area which you liked during buggy ride.

title: spectacular ross island
review_text: apart from japani bunker of world war 2 and the remains of officers mess, church, club house, community hall, library of the british era, when we travelled to the top by a battery operated car, we were spellbound looking at the sea. but i must say the time allotted for ross island tour was very short so that we could not travel on foot.

title: Must Visited Place
review_text: Beautiful place to visit.It takes about 10 minutes To Ross island from Port Blair. The island represents the structures of British period which are ruined now.It has many more deers with garden.People ca touch the deer and give some food just like cows. Childrens enjoyed well. You have to take a boat to reach there.Highly recommended.

title: Hunted by deer!
review_text: The Japanese bunkers and the ruins of the island take at least an hour on foot. No other way to see the place. Lots of deer who roam about freely. Also a home for lovely peacocks. Do not take food out of your bags else the deer will come hunting behind you!

title: Must Visit
review_text: worth visiting, you can see the way Britishers has setup the entire island to control Cellular Jail. you can get Golf cart and can reach all the way to top and come back in 15-20 min. Try the coconut water. take a round if you have time, you can spot Deer. the beautiful Blue & green water from the top. it looks stunning.

title: British headquarters
review_text: The Ross Island was the headquarters of the britishers back in those days. It's a beautiful island. Please take a golf car to go about the island.

title: How British people lived @ Andaman
review_text:
You will know how British people lived @ Andaman.. luxuries party ruined Island.. 
1. We have to visit early.. 
2. Use local ferry.. 
3. Around 2 to 3 hours is required visit the island. 
4. If u go in local ferry they will return in an hour.. (check ur feasible time with ferry how can you spent more than an hour) 
5. Its ur convenient to take guide in island..

title: Just to visit place
review_text: This is an average place to go for. Just having ruins of administrative era. Plan your visit if you are having an extra day with you and club it with north bay.

title: Good well maintained island must for salute to Anuradha Rao. Great light and sound show.
review_text:
This is place which was preferred by Britishers as safe place close to Port Blair, for administration and residence. Now totally abandoned and under control of Indian Navy. Another wonder is legendary Anuradha Rao. Watch her calling deers and peacocks by name and they responding by rushing to her. They do understand her language. That lady is doing great conservation work without being sponsored by anybody. Salute to her. 

We had very limited time to see island as we were on light and sound ferry. This ferry earlier used to start from Aberdeen jetty and therefore one could visit island properly as well as enjoy light and sound show in same visit. But from beginning of march this ferry starts from Janglighat jetty and therefore takes about 45 minutes more to reach island thereby leaving hardly any time before light and sound show. 

The light and sound show is high quality show. More

title: Good place
review_text:
We went to this place twice,once for Light & sound show in late evening/night and on next day( We planned only for going to North bay but couldn't find a ferry that goes only to North bay as all ferry's would go to Ross Island and north Bay Island). Light & sound show For Light and sound show tickets have to be booked in advance from Tourist office,(The name of place where tourist office is located is junglighat). From Clock tower at Abeerdeen bazaar Autos took Rs 30.00 to tourist office(Just say the auto driver you have to book tickets for Light & sound show at Ross Island). We reached tourist office at about 1 pm for booking Light & sound show for same day and were lucky to get the last two ferry tickets.I advise to reach early morning and book tickets if one is interested to watch Light & sound Show at Ross Island.Ferry tickets costed Rs 280.00 per person. For light & sound show one must report at Junglighat jetty and the ferry leaves at 4:15-4:30 Pm. Autos take Rs 80 from Abeerdeen Bazar to Junglighat jetty and to enter junglighat jetty Rs 20 is the charge for Autos which we have to pay. The ferry from Junglighat jetty takes about 30-35 minutes to reach Ross Island.The ferry has a snack shop. Toilet in the ferry was disgusting.After reaching Ross Island one has to take Light &... We went to this place twice,once for Light & sound show in late evening/night and on next day( We planned only for going to North bay but couldn't find a ferry that goes only to North bay as all ferry's would go to Ross Island and north Bay Island). 

Light & sound show 

For Light and sound show tickets have to be booked in advance from Tourist office,(The name of place where tourist office is located is junglighat). From Clock tower at Abeerdeen bazaar Autos took Rs 30.00 to tourist office(Just say the auto driver you have to book tickets for Light & sound show at Ross Island). We reached tourist office at about 1 pm for booking Light & sound show for same day and were lucky to get the last two ferry tickets.I advise to reach early morning and book tickets if one is interested to watch Light & sound Show at Ross Island.Ferry tickets costed Rs 280.00 per person. For light & sound show one must report at Junglighat jetty and the ferry leaves at 4:15-4:30 Pm. Autos take Rs 80 from Abeerdeen Bazar to Junglighat jetty and to enter junglighat jetty Rs 20 is the charge for Autos which we have to pay. The ferry from Junglighat jetty takes about 30-35 minutes to reach Ross Island.The ferry has a snack shop. Toilet in the ferry was disgusting.After reaching Ross Island one has to take Light & sound show tickets at Rs 50 per person.The ferry is organized by Andaman Tourism and show happens in Ross Island which is property of Indian Navy,so i think we have to take two different tickets one for ferry at tourist office and other at entrance of Ross Island. 

When ferry reaches Ross Island,there will be two or three electric vehicle waiting as you enter Ross Island after taking tickets for Light & sound show.It is a scam,people sit on the electric vehicle thinking its a free service.The electric vehicle just goes to different locations in Ross Island and the driver explains what we see.Because it was dark we could not see anything properly.After less than 10 Minute driving across Ross Island the driver will drop you in front of place where Light & sound show happens and will demand Rs 80.00 per person. This is a scam which authorities must look into. The place where light & sound show happens is just 3-4 minute walk from the entrance of Ross Island,so don't fall prey to the electric vehicle scam there. 

Light and sound show at Ross Island is very good compared to light & sound show at cellular jail ,if you have spare time in evening i will highly advise you to watch this light & sound show.We were back to Junglighat jetty at 7:45 Pm after the show which last for about 40 minutes i think.You will get Autos at exit of Junglighat jetty so nothing to worry. 

Ross Island 

Ferry's to Ross Island can be got from Abeerdeen jetty or Junglighat Jetty. We took Ferry from Abeerdeen jetty.Ferry's go to two Islands,Ross Island and North bay Island and we cant go to a single Island. There are many private Ferry's from Abeerdeen jetty to go to Ross Island(also North Bay Island). Ticket costs Rs 580.00 per person for going to Ross Island and North Bay Island. It takes about 10-15 minutes from Abeerdeen jetty to reach Ross Island and you will get one hour to see Ross Island.Entrance to the Ross Island costs Rs 30.00.A brief history of Ross Island is written after entering Ross Island,do read it.Just while entering there will be a person sitting selling Kulfis @ 20 Rs.The Kulfi was good . There are electric vehicle at entrance which takes one around the Ross Island and costs Rs 80. Those having walking problem should avail this electric car as there some steep places to climb. It is a very good place to see having many dilapidated buildings and roots grown over buildings.This place has a small restaurant we only had tea there so cant comment on the restaurant.The rest rooms at Ross Island is clean and maintained properly. 

This is a good place to visit while at Port Blair. More

title: Amazing Light and Sound Show
review_text:
Visit During the Day: 1. You can visit Ross during the day and see various ruins and other structures on the island 2. If you read about the history of the island before, you will enjoy it much more. Otherwise, all you will see is depleted structures 3. You can get ferries from Port Blair to Ross from multiple jetties. The one that I am aware of are 1. Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex Jetty (just opp to Ross Island on Port Blair; takes 20 mins to reach) 2. Junglighat (it is on the other end of Port Blair and ferry take more than 40 mins to reach Ross) 4. Most operators offer a combined trip of Ross and North Bay island, which I think makes sense as visiting Ross alone may not be worth it Please plan your trip in advance as ferries run for limited time only during the day Visit During the Night (Light and Sound Show): 1. As far as i know, there is only one ferry (from Junglighat) that goes in the evening to Ross Island (leaves at around 5 PM). The ferry is exclusively for L&S Show. 2. Since, it leaves late in the evening, it is already dark by the time you reach. So you have very limited time to see Ross 3. But, the L&S Show is worth itself the visit, The whole ambience, graphics, sound effects, etc. makes it a great show.... Visit During the Day: 
1. You can visit Ross during the day and see various ruins and other structures on the island 
2. If you read about the history of the island before, you will enjoy it much more. Otherwise, all you will see is depleted structures 
3. You can get ferries from Port Blair to Ross from multiple jetties. The one that I am aware of are 1. Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex Jetty (just opp to Ross Island on Port Blair; takes 20 mins to reach) 2. Junglighat (it is on the other end of Port Blair and ferry take more than 40 mins to reach Ross) 
4. Most operators offer a combined trip of Ross and North Bay island, which I think makes sense as visiting Ross alone may not be worth it 

Please plan your trip in advance as ferries run for limited time only during the day 

Visit During the Night (Light and Sound Show): 
1. As far as i know, there is only one ferry (from Junglighat) that goes in the evening to Ross Island (leaves at around 5 PM). The ferry is exclusively for L&S Show. 
2. Since, it leaves late in the evening, it is already dark by the time you reach. So you have very limited time to see Ross 
3. But, the L&S Show is worth itself the visit, The whole ambience, graphics, sound effects, etc. makes it a great show. One should not miss it. One of the best L&S Show I have seen in India 
4. Total cost of Ferry and Show is Rs. 300 per person + Rs. 50 which is charged by Indian Navy on entering the island 
5. Once you know the history of Ross via this show, you will like the island even more 

Some great old picture of Ross can also be seen in Cellular Jail museum. You will know, how pretty it was during the British time. 

Ross Island is closed on Wednesdays. More

title: Most Beautiful
review_text: Undoubtedly the best maintained of all the islands.It is under the Indian Navy and they have preserved it so beautifully. One can see nature (tree roots) overtaking man creations, scores of deer and the neat and clean surroundings.

title: Beautiful Island
review_text: Beautiful abandon island. The best one to visit in port blair. Enjoy view of an abandoned town & sea.

title: Reminiscence of a colonial past!
review_text: Known as Paris of east in its time, this place definitely has a charm to it.. even though in ruins! Awesome light and sound show here better than the cellular jail one!! Went there on 4.30pm ferry and returned at 6.40pm.. need about 3 hour if you wish to visit all buildings on feet and attend the show too. Snacks were available with colddrinks and coconut water. Lot of deer, rabbits and peacocks along with a kids play area too. There was a museum but it was closed when we visited.

title: A tale of suffering of Kala Pani and Luxury lifestyle of British Officers
review_text:
Ross Island just is a kilometer away from Port Blair. The island is named after the British Surveyor Sir Daniel Ross. Ross Island was once the Administrative capital of British rule at Andaman & Nicobar Islands. It was an exclusively planned settlement with Administrative buildings, barracks to accommodate 500 odd British and their families with luxury facilities like Churches, Bakery, Swimming Pools, Printing Press, Water filter plant and a power generation plant. Because of its luxurious lifestyle amenities in the Island the Island was also known as ‘Paris of East’. This ‘Paris of East’ is destroyed majorly by the disastrous earthquake and Tsunami of June, 1941. The Island has also witnessed the Japanese invasion during the WWII. Because of its strategic location the Indian Navy has taken over the island in the year 1971 but kept it open for the visitors and tourists. Also this was the Island which took the brunt of the Tsunami of December, 2004 saving the Port Blair from major destruction. Due to some maintenance reasons at Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex (i visited in Feb '18), now ferries start from Junglighat Jetty. On arrival at Island, a Japanese bunker of WWII welcomes the visitors at the gate. This ‘Paris of East’ is destroyed majorly by the disastrous earthquake and Tsunami of June, 1941. The Island has also witnessed the Japanese invasion during the WWII. Because of its strategic location the Indian Navy has taken over the island in the year 1971 but kept it open for the visitors and tourists. Also this was the Island which took the brunt of the Tsunami of December, 2004 saving the Port Blair from major destruction. 
Due to some maintenance reasons at Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex (i visited in Feb '18), now ferries start from Junglighat Jetty. On arrival at Island, a Japanese bunker of WWII welcomes the visitors at the gate. It’s a very small island and one can cover the whole island just within an hour by foot, But, It is advisable to go for golf kart ride as the drivers double up as the tourist guide and cover the whole island under 20–25 min. Though the structures are in ruin state it is unbelievable to see the township planning, technology used to generate electricity and to filter sea water using complex see-water treatment plant. While on-boarding and off-boarding the boat one can see schools of fish in the see through crystal clear blue water. More

title: Good historic place with only ruins left
review_text: To reach Ross Island, boats are available from jungli ghat at Port Blair. One boat accommodates about 35 persons. Charges are fixed by A&N Govt, 550 rs per head for Port blair-Ross island- North bay- Port Blair journey. Usually one hour is the stopover at Ross Island after which boats proceed for North bay. Ross Island was the primary place of British Govt administration at Andaman islands, it had many offices and clubs and few shops. Most of the buildings were damaged in floods of 2004 and only ruins are left. There are deer and peacocks at the island. Views around the island are scenic. The coconut trees add to the beauty of island. Battery operated small cars with 08 persons seating are available for 10 minutes round of a main part of island. This is an ok place to visit but not a must visit as per my experience. More

title: Back to colonial past.
review_text: Due to the mismanagement by our travel agent M/S Thomas Cook we could visit Ross Island for only about 20 minutes instead of two and half hours as per our program. We could take a 5 minutes run by the trolley car around the island and was amazed to see the ruins of the past colonial era. Here the British residents, around 500 in number used to live like kings, being served by the Indian freedom fighters held there as prisoners. There used to be well decorated living quarters, ball rooms, clubs, tennis courts, golf etc., and it used to be called Paris of the East. After a devastating earth quake on 26th June 1941 the Island got ruined and left for ever. More

title: Dilapidated ruins of India's colonial past
review_text: Decent place. You can see ruins of the old British settlement. There are deer and peacock roaming freely on the island. They don't attack humans. That that is all there is. The trip to Ross Island is generally clubbed with a visit to North Bay Island (that's how the boats operate). The North Bay is not worth visiting. I wish there was just a trip to Ross Island and back.

title: A date with History!
review_text: Ross Island was called the Paris of East by the Britishers. Our local guide told us magnificent history of the ruins of Ross Island. We were awed to know it. A must visit island for all age groups. History buffs would enjoy it!

title: Beautiful Island
review_text: Try Semi Submarine Here. NIce experience. Worth the money. Go for scuba at Elephant Beach, Havelock. Dont forget to book for Light and sound show at Ross Island as well. Its different from one shown at cellular jail

title: Historical place
review_text: Must visit place if you are a history lover. all British time made . Broken. Beautifully maintained. you will get ATV car there Rs 80/head (20-25min trip).

title: Nice little place for picnic, a small beach, deers
review_text: Nice place to see how those people living on distant islands. British people had such a wonderful arrangement to live. Now old building covered by nature. But we can still imagine the beauty of the place at that time. There is power house, water treatment plant, canteen, library, hall... What ever you need to enjoy. Only I am feel sorry for those poor deers. They are running here there for food as it is small place for them. Ross island is like good picnic spot. There is a beach opposite side in jetty stop. But you need full day time to enjoy.

title: Visit to Ross Island
review_text: The Ross island can be accessed by boat from Aberdeen jetty near cellular jail. Short boat ride takes you to this tiny island. There is nothing much to see on the island except the ruins of the british era. It is advisable to carry own drinking water. Two to three hours are sufficient for the visit including he boat ride.

title: Good small island near port blair
review_text: One of the place which you can visit after some priority places in port blair. There is small history associated with it. Which you can know there only. Major part of it is destroyed by Tsunami but still good place to visit. lot of dears & peacocks at site. Food & snacks are available.

title: Paradise of Port Blair
review_text: It was used as the the special enjoyment and relaxing spot for during British rule. The island is destroyed in Tsunamis and earth quakes but nice to see the old leftovers of Bungalows and offices. At one time there were all facilities like Tennis court, Spa, Swimming pool etc etc and even a Cemetery inside the small island. Now you can see Peacocks, Deers, Rabbits etc roaming there freely. Drinking water is a problem there and only one water dispenser is available there. So better carry some bottles of water with you once you visit there. However the boat ride to and fro from Port Blair is amazing.

title: small island
review_text: its again how the britishers recognised it as the gateway to andeman islands . They developed it into a naval base with all facilities

title: Ruins Of Ross Island
review_text:
A trip to Andaman's would have been incomplete without a visit to this beautiful island. Particularly if you are a photographer then its a delight for you. 

Take a walk and explore the island completely. 

Highly Recommended.

title: Ross Island - Must Visit
review_text:
Its a beautiful island situated towards east side just at the harbour mouth of Port Blair. The main attraction of this island is the remnants of British Administrator of the penal colony in Port Blair. Also, you can see POW camp, and war installations, built by Japanese in 1941. This island also has open wildlife like birds, deer, rabbit etc. This Island is very well maintained and controlled by Indian Navy. There are two things to do at Ross Island 1/ Visit to Ross island 1a/ Club visit to Ross & North Island 2/ Visit followed by Light & Sound show at Ross Island. If you are going for option 1 than time suitable for you is morning 0900 to 1600. Best way to reach there is by a speed boat from Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex. Per head tariff is 280rs(two way). Boatmen will give you a time limit of 1hour and 15min for Island visit. Also a small entry fees of Rs 30, will be charged from you at Ross Island by Indian Navy, this fees will be utilised for feeding the animals over there. Boat ride is hardly of 15 mins to Ross Island. You can also club your visit of ross island with north island(Beach/Snorkling/scuba point) which is situated north of ross and further you will be charged accordingly for Snorkling/Scuba diving approx Rs3500/head(Bargain option available depending upon numb of personnel). Overall, must visit if you are... Its a beautiful island situated towards east side just at the harbour mouth of Port Blair. The main attraction of this island is the remnants of British Administrator of the penal colony in Port Blair. Also, you can see POW camp, and war installations, built by Japanese in 1941. This island also has open wildlife like birds, deer, rabbit etc. This Island is very well maintained and controlled by Indian Navy. 

There are two things to do at Ross Island 
1/ Visit to Ross island 
1a/ Club visit to Ross & North Island 
2/ Visit followed by Light & Sound show at Ross Island. 

If you are going for option 1 than time suitable for you is morning 0900 to 1600. Best way to reach there is by a speed boat from Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex. Per head tariff is 280rs(two way). Boatmen will give you a time limit of 1hour and 15min for Island visit. Also a small entry fees of Rs 30, will be charged from you at Ross Island by Indian Navy, this fees will be utilised for feeding the animals over there. Boat ride is hardly of 15 mins to Ross Island. You can also club your visit of ross island with north island(Beach/Snorkling/scuba point) which is situated north of ross and further you will be charged accordingly for Snorkling/Scuba diving approx Rs3500/head(Bargain option available depending upon numb of personnel). Overall, must visit if you are in Port Blair. Beautiful place to do photography. So dnt forget to carry your camera. A canteen is established there for eatable/snacks/coconut water. 

If you are going for option 2 than 
Sound and Light Show at Ross Island will educate you about the glorious history of island. This show is available every day at 5.30 pm. The tickets are available from the reception counter of Directorate of Tourism. Entry fee: Adult- Rs. 250/- (inclusive of Boat tickets, entry fee to Ross Island and show charges), Children (5 to 12 Years)- Rs. 150/- (inclusive of Boat tickets, entry fee to Ross Island and show charges). The visitors boarding time and place will be informed by tourism office. Boarding timing normally is at 3.30 pm and departure of the boat is 4.00 pm. Boat ride is about 15-20 mins so you will also get time to visit the island before commencement of Light & Sound Show. 

Remember one thing, All tickets sold are non-refundable in any case. Once ticket sold, even if the boat gets defective or the weather deteriorates, the money wont be refunded. More

title: Ross Island - first capital of Britishers on Andaman
review_text: If you are going, please take Mrs Anuradha rao along with you. She has dedicated her whole life on this island and she talks with deers, peacock, rats etc all animals and they respond. Recent tsunami devastated around 30% of the island but worth visiting.

title: Beautiful
review_text:
Visit this historic island and spend atleast 2-3 hours here to get the full view. 

The island has got only old dilapidated buildings of the British government. But each of the building has got a story to tell. 

You will find beautiful deers and peacocks living together in perfect harmony. 

There is a small restaurant offering limited eating options. 

The view of the sea is stunning from the island.

title: Lived on a Lotus in a dirty pond
review_text:
The British had a way to suit matters for themselves. 

Away from all the cruelty and pain, the British created a heaven for themselves, to include school, church, bakery and electricity. 

Wonder what they prayed in the church and what they taught about humanity to their children.

title: Very beautiful Island close to Port Blair
review_text:
Every morning MVs take guests to this historical island. Entry fees 30/- per adult. It takes about an hour to hike whole island on foot. There's also offer of golf-carts @80/- per head. 
Beautiful spots for photography. Surrounded by colourful Ocean. Coconut trees, Age-old buildings standing up by help of roots of stems of old rainforest around them. 
One can find peacocks, deer, rabbits freely roaming in the island. Deer come close to human, to get feeded, but beware of their antlers.

title: Enjoyable visit
review_text: It is very confusing to figure out how to get a boat. It seems they are booked in advance by groups and individuals are left waiting around for someone to explain what is going on. We were able to share a private boar with two other tourists for a reasonable price. We enjoyed the island, an overgrown Santuary for the British.

title: Average place
review_text: I visited here but I liked it not very much because it was not cleaned and well maintained.I hired battery auto,they helped us to take round the island tell the history of island.It was just on.

title: One Step in History
review_text:
We went through boat from Port Blair. It takes 10 minutes to Rose Island from Port Blair. It is tourist spot in Andaman Nicobar Island. The island represents the structure of British period which are ruined now. It has a historical story. When Japanese invaded Andaman Islands, they would stay at Rose Islands. The island has several Japanese bunkers and tunnels. It is good as a trek. Dilapidated Church was little eerie and small beach behind the church was pleasant with good view. The free roaming animals on the island are quite an attraction - especially for children. We also spotted some deer, peacock, rabbits there. People can touch the deer and give some food just like cows! 
The edges of the island provide wonderful view of the sea and other islands. This place is full of coconut trees. We heard about evening light and sound show. But we could not experience it. 
Overall, it was very very beautiful place to visit. It was good experience. We enjoyed well. It's my personal advice - take some food and water with you. And yes, if you are not interested to visit historical place you can skip it. More

title: Place where time stands still
review_text: Must visit place in Andamans. Light and sound show must attend. The place once was British capital in Andamans. Now maintained by Indian Navy. It was a place where time stands still. Must visit

title: Peaceful
review_text:
I visited Ross island on July 2017. We were the only tourist there. One can easily pass the whole day with his/her dear ones relaxing and chatting there. 
PS, if you expect modern amenities and restaurants, this place is not for you. It is more of nature than of facilities

title: Experience the past in the present!
review_text:
Ross Island is the closest to Port Blair but often skipped by tourists, which may not be a good idea actually! As soon as you step in to Ross Island you feel transported to an era gone by with the ruins of the erstwhile capital of the British empire in Andaman Islands. A walk through the ruins and the island as such can be very refreshing as well as exhilarating. 
There are many deers, rabbits to keep you company there. If possible do carry some bread or biscuits to feed these animals, which is thrilling for children. The old church at the top of the island and the Avatar like tree are really unmissable. Though there is a beach on the other side, access is prohibited after the Tsunami. The presence of Ross Island infact, prevented the Tsunami from hitting Port Blair thus saving the city from further devastation. 
The light and sound show in the evening is something you will remember for your life time. It is best to go to Ross a few hours before the evening show, unlike going in the morning. More

title: An important aspect of our history
review_text:
Ross Island served as the administrative capital of Andaman & Nicobar Islands during the British Rule before being abandoned during World War II. Since then it has been uninhabited and has been handed over to the Indian Navy. Yet, relics from the golden age of the islands do survive in the form of ruins. It is approachable by a ferry from Port Blair and tickets are available from the tourism department. 
There’s lots to do on the island. If you come during the day, walk around to see old buildings - a church, officers club, water treatment plant, swimming pool, a cemetery and even a Japanese bunker. There’s also a battery car drive. There are many animals on the island - deer, peafowl and rabbits and children would love to play with the rabbits. Do be wary of deer with horns though. 
Once the sun sets, do stay back to watch the light and sound show. The words have been penned by Gulzar and have been narrated by him as well (for the Hindi show) and Shabana Azmi (for the English show). It is about the history of Andaman and Nicobar Islands and Ross Island in particular and is worth watching. More

all these are in ruins now but maintained as a relic by Indian navy.It has a small pond which is filled with lotus.You can get electric carts on rent to move around the island. 
its a maximum 1 hour trip here and the ferry operators also plan accordingly.But since this is maintained by Navy ,permits are often put on hold due to weather or sea conditions.So plan accordingly i would suggest More

review_text:

Ross Island has a lot of History. All British time buildings are in ruins, but there are old photographs of how they lived in splendour in those days. 

You also go to North Bay Island by the same boat. Three hours alloted there is not enough. Especially if you want to do all the activities: Scuba and Sea Walking allowed only to people below 60 years. Also not allowed if you have BP, Heart condition, Diabetes etc. So I did snorkelling only (even though I cannot swim). Absolutely safe and so much fun. More

title: The first British settlement in the Andaman Islands
review_text:
Named after the British surveyor Sir Daniel Ross,is situated approximately 800 m away from the Aberdeen jetty. Settlers developed the area with so much vigor that soon it came to be known as 'Paris of the East', till it was invaded by the Japanese forces who built bunkers and drove the British away. 
One can see the ruined buildings with the help of golf carts who run through the places and take the visitors to the highest point in the island. 
Ideally a walk through the place would be more enjoyable for the energetic.

title: British Old Colony
review_text: Ross island is located approx 3 km away from Aberdeen Jetty of Port Blair. It was British main colony when East India Company ruled over Andaman. The island is covered by coconut trees all around. The historical remains make the island remembrance of British stay during that ruling period. All that's here are old buildings, church, water treatment plant, power generator, bakery, administrative and recreation buildings used by the Japanese when they were ruling the islands.Peacock, Deers and Rabbits make one of the attraction to the island.

Terrar beach in the island got destroyed during the 2004 tsunami and has remained closed. 
You can catch a glimpse of deer and peacocks running around the island! 
Don't miss out the Japanese bunkers which is serves as a reminder of history. 
Check out the videos of the spooky ruins in my youtube channel! The link to the channel is in my profile!

review_text:

title: Ross - A comrehensive review
review_text:
Ross island and North Bay are located 2-5 km from Aberdeen Jetty of Port Blair. Tickets are available in Rs 550 for visit to both the islands by Boat. 

1) How to reach Jetty - it is located in Water Sports complex of port blair near Cellulat jail. 

2) How to choose the Boat and what is ticket price - As you enter the complex agents will offer tickets of Boat and Activities. 

There are small and Medium size Boats - 
Mark Marina is the only AC Boat(yellow in pic attached) 
Silvet Jet is the latgest Boat 

Better to go with these boats as in case of high tides you will aboard all wet from small boats. 

Price is 550 inr. 

3) Ross island - You will be given 1.5 hours to explore the island by Boat operator and then they will pick you for North Bay. 

This island is small but historic and beautifull. I spent most of the time at Ferrar Beach which is untouched and have crystal clear water. 

There is a rope after the staircase to go down to the beach. 

Read the sign Boards and decide where you want to roam for 1 hour at ross island. 

It is advised to carry snacks and food items. Humidity is high there. 

I hope it helps. More

title: Ross Island, South Andaman district
review_text: Archibald Blair's survey of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in 1788, a settlement was established at present day Port Blair (then called Port Cornwallis). In 1792 it was shifted to the Northern harbour (present day Diglipur) which was also christened Port Cornwallis (the former became Old Harbour). But, that settlement was abandoned in 1796 because of the high mortality rate. Between 1789-92, Blair established a hospital and a sanatorium at Ross Island.

title: Must visit place at Port Blair
review_text: If you're visiting port blair, please include this location in your agenda. Lots of history and events that happened on this island. The lady guide there knows the island inside out ...

It's a small island only. (Seems it's has lost a lot of its land in a tsunami in 1940s). You can walk around or can avail a battery vehicle to be shown around. 

There's only one guide there it seems. She's Anuradha Rao, quite a veteran guide and a famous personality with respect to Ross island. Google her name to get some interesting info on her. More

title: Among Deer and Peacocks !
review_text:
Ross Island was the old British HQ in Andamans before it was seriously impacted by a major earthquake. Today the place is in ruins. The Presybetarian Church in a ruinous state looks interesting but visitors are cordoned off at the entrance itself. 
The whole place has an eerie old world atmosphere with lots of peacocks (and peahens) strutting around and calling each other ( in reply !). There are also deer (including horned/stag deer? roaming about. I am sure there must be snakes around because of the presence of peacocks, but I did not spot any. 
The other interesting aspect is the Japanese Bunker right at the jetty entrance. 
A nice clean island to visit . More

title: A Island with Memories

title: Interesting.

title: Well Maintained

On the way back you can walk down. Lots of Deer which you can see up-close and take pics with. Peacocks and other animals as well. The view from the Island is amazing. title: Nice place

title: Enchanting Island
review_text:

Good place to walk around and enjoy mother nature at its best. 
Top up your visit with coconut water.

title: A lovely outing out of port blair
review_text: It is a tiny island out of port blair, 5min ferry ride takes you there. Interesting history, a quite place, lots of historic and british era sites and stories, deer, rabbit, peacock are around you when you visit this place. A must

title: Great place
review_text: This is a nice place to visit but if you are short on time, you can skip this for jolly buoy. Jolly buoy is definitely, no doubt better than this. This provides everything that you get in havelock and jolly buoy in one place, but nothing extra.

title: History of the English colonial rule in Port Blair
review_text: This is a must visit place when u come to port Blair. This place has the ruins of English soldiers offices, Japanese bunkers, a cemetery, a sweet water pond, and if you are lucky u can get an opportunity to feed the deer with leaves though it’s not permitted out there. The best part is the place makes you feel at peace and shows the vibrant beauty of nature.

title: Paris of East
review_text: We walked through the ruins and hopped on a time machine.For two hours it was a journey to the oblivion.Wish I could stay there for hours,days and nights.

title: amazing

title: Certainly a must visit place in Andaman
review_text: Today's Ross Island ruins depicts its magnificent past. The entire Island can be covered in 2-3 hours. As you enter the Island, there are information boards that explains the vibrant past of the Ross Island. The Irony is, it is said that the Ross Island was kept crystal clean during the British Raj, It was the duty of the Indian prisoners to maintain beauty of the entire Island and keep it clean. However, after taken over by India, this place must have been looked after with same care. the place which was once called as the Paris of the East, now does not even have the trace to substantiate it's title. There has to be made more efforts to keep the entire place clean and presentable. off course it is also the responsibility of the tourists More

title: for history buffs
review_text: this island has history as Britishers established themselves here but like the whole place the view of sea is good plus they have some animals roaming around and Japanese bunkers give it fort look. we visited it on our way from north bay island and onward to port blair.

title: A Glimpse of the Past!!
review_text:
Ross is a tiny island, about 15 mins from Port Blair. Only day trips are allowed for tourists, since it is a defense island. Why go there? 1.To see history: Ross is where the britishers first established their settlement, complete with all amenities like church, bakery, shops, swimming pool, distillery, tennis court, pond, cemetery, barracks etc (A few photos of Ross are there in Cellular jail museum). One can still see the depilated buildings, shrouded with tree roots. It kinda impresses the brevity of civilizations. 2. To watch sound and light show: This is a must watch! It starts at sunset and is of about 30- 45 mins duration. The show is in Hindi/English(Tuesdays) and narrated by Gulzar and Shabana Azmi, explaining the history of Ross. 3. To see the free living deers, peacocks and rabbits: Touching/Feeding them is prohibited, for the safety of the tourists. A welcome move! 4. To see the Ferar beach: Beautiful beach but entering the waters is not allowed. 5. To see the sunset with Port Blair in the background. How to get there? 1. From the Aberdeen Jetty private boats ply frequently, to and fro with 2 hr wait, from 9 a.m. The last ferry is at 2 p.m. 2. However, if one wants to see the sound and light show, avail the tickets from IP&T (Information, Publicity and Tourism department). The tickets are sold for the days show- no advance booking is available... Ross is a tiny island, about 15 mins from Port Blair. Only day trips are allowed for tourists, since it is a defense island. 

Why go there? 
1.To see history: Ross is where the britishers first established their settlement, complete with all amenities like church, bakery, shops, swimming pool, distillery, tennis court, pond, cemetery, barracks etc (A few photos of Ross are there in Cellular jail museum). One can still see the depilated buildings, shrouded with tree roots. It kinda impresses the brevity of civilizations. 
2. To watch sound and light show: This is a must watch! It starts at sunset and is of about 30- 45 mins duration. The show is in Hindi/English(Tuesdays) and narrated by Gulzar and Shabana Azmi, explaining the history of Ross. 
3. To see the free living deers, peacocks and rabbits: Touching/Feeding them is prohibited, for the safety of the tourists. A welcome move! 
4. To see the Ferar beach: Beautiful beach but entering the waters is not allowed. 
5. To see the sunset with Port Blair in the background. 

How to get there? 
1. From the Aberdeen Jetty private boats ply frequently, to and fro with 2 hr wait, from 9 a.m. The last ferry is at 2 p.m. 
2. However, if one wants to see the sound and light show, avail the tickets from IP&T (Information, Publicity and Tourism department). The tickets are sold for the days show- no advance booking is available and if the weather is unpleasant the show is cancelled. The ferry to sound & light show leaves at 4.30pm from Aberdeen jetty and returns by 7.30 pm. Till sunset the tourists are free to walk around, after which the sound and light show starts. 

Facilities available 
1.Toilets 
2. Food & Snacks: Although there is a canteen, assume that food/ water is not available. A few ferry operators provide lunch. So either confirm with them/ carry your own as needed. 
3. Kulfi, tea/coffee: Mostly available 
4. Guide: One guide is available, who is knowledgeable and is the only person with whom the animals are friendly with. 
5. Battery operated cars: Do not cover the entire island and follow a limited route. Useful for kids or elderly and for people who wish to walk half way and use the cars for the rest. More

title: Beautiful Island but not preserved
review_text: All buildings are destroyed due to earthquakes and tsunamis. However its a beautiful island for an hours walk just to get some history.

title: Paris of the East
review_text:
A 10-minute boat ride from the Rajiv Gandhi sports complex on a rainy morning took us to Ross Island, once called "Paris of the East" by the British. The tiny island, less than a square kilometer in area, with the ruins of a water distillery, swimming pool, church, the Chief Commissioner's bungalow, etc., is a reminder of the lavish lifestyle of the British. The atmosphere is a bit eerie with once grand structures completely taken over by nature. 

Ross Island had shielded Port Blair to a great extent from the devastating effects of tsunami in 2004. At present the Indian navy is doing a wonderful job in maintaining the island without destroying the historical value of the ruins. More

title: Historical Capital of British rule on Andamans
review_text:
Ross Island is 20 minutes ferry from port Blair jetty. You need to book a ferry at the Rajiv Gandhi water sports arena. The ferries start by 9am and generally most ferries will take you to both Ross Island and North Bay in the same trip. You much reach by 8:30am to book the first ferry. 

You get around and hour and 15 minutes at Ross Island so you need to be quick to get down from the ferry so you can see everything and take some panaromic snaps. 

There are battery operated cars if you can't walk however they will not let you enjoy the place at your own pace. 

This island was the capital when British ruled Andamans but an earthquake in 1942 destroyed most of buildings in the Island. 

Ross was also know as the only palace for the British outside Britain. It had so many luxury facilities for the British. 

The swimming pool still existing however it's not maintained , you have the soldiers barracks which is only building still intact . Also some deers and peacocks are now staying on this island. 

Dnt miss the museum suggest you see the small museum and then see the balance island. 

Good place to go to and makes to relive the history of Andamans. More

title: Nice place
review_text: Good to know the history ..and at that time too people had bakery & club kind of things in that small island. 2-3 hours are good enough. If you are not much interested in knowing historical stuff. ..you will not miss anything by escaping this place in your list.

title: Puja Vacation
review_text: After many hits and misses we finally visited Ross Island on our last day, it is a tiny island seeped in history like the rest of Port Blair, we were fascinated by a lady who looked after the birds n deers on the island ,she spoke to them and they responded as if they understood rather others language.We were tired so we took a cart around the island but it's better to walk to get a better view. It was sad watching the ruins of the British era.

title: Excellent

title: Sagar darson

title: a good one day excursion from port blair

ross is to be approached by boat from port blair. you will take easily 3-4 hours by walk to explore the island, make sure you take your time and dont hurry up, take a guided tour. 

please dont feed deers/ animals with the food you have, as they can die of yeast.

title: Old British headquarters with ancient remains
review_text:
Ross Island used to be the administrative headquarters during the British rule in India. Now the island serves as a tourist spot where one can see the remains of old buildings and ancient remains. The island can be reached by taking a ferry from Port Blair, its barely 15-20 odd minutes from Port Blair. 

Upon reaching the island, its mostly about enjoying the scenic beauty. Golf carts are available for tour, however it is best to have a walk as the island is not really very big. Some small animals like peacock, rabbits and spotted deer can be seen on the island. There is a small museum with some old photos and artifacts, apart from that nothing much to do. A restaurant is available however. More

title: Its like bird Island
review_text: This island is nearby to Port Blair it will take 15-20 minutes to reach this island. Its a plastic free island. On this Island all the animals will come close to you unlike zoo where it behind the fense.

title: Awesome place

review_text: 30 minutes boat drive from port Blair. Round trip costbRs. 250 per person from port Blair. Audio and video show exrradinary. review_text:

title: Paris of the east
review_text:
The island was supposed to be one of the most beautiful one and was known as the Paris of the east. However, the 1941 earthquake and 2004 tsunami destroyed the manicured gardens & buildings in the island. 
Ferries to this island depart from Port Blair (check the water current before you buy your ticket)

title: Beautiful historical place
review_text:
The short boat ride from the sports complex takes you to ross island. A short preview regarding the island is given by the boat crew. 
Entrance tickets to the island are purchased here. The island is marked by dilapidated buildings which showcase the glory of the British who used this island as their accommodation. The boards at the entrance should be read to have a fair idea of what to expect. Buggy is available for the elderly. 
As we start our walk we find deers, squirrels and rabbits in plenty. All buildings are carefully kept with notice boards clearly stating their significance. 
The view of the North bay island with the lighthouse is beautiful. A walk up and you find yourself surrounded by peacocks. The last leg of your walk takes you to Ferrar beach which took the brunt of 2004 tsunami saving port blair. 
The boat people give us only one hour at the island as it usually is clubbed with north bay. Lots of opportunities for photographs so please take a little more time. More

title: Ross Island The Ark
review_text: When you enter the island there are ducks, rabbits and dears to welcome you. You can take a walk through island to explore it's human friendly wild life.

title: Historical Island with signifcant Naval Importance
review_text:
Ross Island is the erstwhile capital of the British Settlement in the Andamans and was started around 1789 due to its natural choice of its commanding geographical location. Those erstwhile settlers recreated a home away from home so such a degree that the Island contained a post office, library, bakery, swimming pool, tennis courts and other. Around 1858, a penal colony was also established. For many years the Island was considered the "Paris of the East" until a massive earthquake hit the area in 1941 and with the advancement of the Japanese during WW2, the Island was evacuated. In 1979, the Island was handed over to the Indian Navy due to its strategic importance and they have opened Ross Island to visitors and tourists. They have also tried to improve and ensure that the historical significance of the Island remains. The Island served as a shield to the massive Tsunami of 2004 which saved the City of Port Blair by taking the massive brunt. What was fascinating is how the trees have grown over some of the buildings - very creepy like. One thing that I found not so good was on arrival, it appears very chaotic as one has to pay a small admission fee and that line just takes forever, so people mill around waiting to pass through. A better system should be implemented. There is a fee if one has a camera, but no one seemed to... The island has ruins of several colonial period building like market, church, library etc. The island has great flora and fauna collection. Several trees and plants cover the island. There is a small beach on the island - Ferar beach. Deer, peacock, rabbits are seen on the island.

title: A must visit!!!

title: History of Andaman
review_text: It was the capital of the Island group during British rule. Now we can see the remains of their luxury. Our Tiranga flys high to show who owns the place. You can see hundreds of deer in the Island.

review_text: Very close to Port Blair this place has natural surroundings. The best thing is there was an electrical car which goes around the island to give an overview. One should arrange for this once they land, since you will get short time for your actual stay.

title: Stuck in time
review_text:
Had it not been for Ross Island - Poet Blair would have been destroyed by the tsunami! Ross Island was once a thriving township where Britishers lived and built some extraordinary buildings! There was a desalination plant to turn sea water to potable water! Two swimming pools, churches, tennis courts, magistrates house, barracks and more!!! After the Britishers left and the Japanese invaded Ross and then subsequently left - the island stood as a testament to the shining era... but time and earthquakes have brought the building down and the tsunami has destroyed parts of the island. The structures that still stand are because nature has reclaimed what was hers and she holds these buildings captive in the grasp of the banyan tree roots that have now captured the structures. Had it not been for the roots - the remaining buildings too would have collapsed! 
A must visit. Requires a lot of walking. Some routes are uphill. The island houses more than 500 deers, peacocks and rabbits!!! 
To get there - take the ferries from the Water Sports Complex - the ferries take about 15mins to reach there and then they give you 45 mins to look around before taking the same boat back. 
There is a sound and light show in the evenings 
Walking around the township is like watching a town stuck in a time warp - a reminder of a glorious past More

review_text: The deer, peacocks, and all trees are all out in the open and everything is there for you to explore. it is full of history as it was the capital during British rule but all the old buildings are in ruins. Still great place to immerse oneself and take some great photography.

title: A periscope into the past
review_text:

The most memorable were the abandoned buildings overgrown with treesand populated by Peacocks and deer - "Nature reclaiming it's own"

title: Light and sound show : a must, certainly world class!
review_text: This island is always on the list of every tourist. The sound and light show on this island is simply magical. The theme of this show is the history of Andaman and its connection with the freedom struggle. The show is held only in the evening. It's very interesting and something which I can call is world class. The show has been narrated by none other than Gulzar himself and features tracks composed by Shankar Ehsan Loy. And the best part is that the tickets for this show are very much affordable (less than 300 bucks per person) and it's better to buy these in advance. And if you want to explore the island then you must also visit it once in the day time. More
