title: Picturious Island
review_text: Visit to the Ross Island is a must. You find friendly deer & peacock here. You can play with them, feed them and take pictures as well. Ross Island also provides you good places to take single / family pictures.

title: Britishers' Colony
review_text:
While Cellular Jail was hell for Indian Freedom Fighters, just beside it Ross Island was heaven for Britishers. 

Must see sound and light show here. So better visit it in second half. In morning go to north bay for flying visit then go to Ross so in evening light and sound show can be attended. 

While visiting try to read all things there because they contains detailed history about Ross. 

As island is very much big, open vehicle facility is available to roam around.

title: Beautiful island
review_text: This island can be reached from Port blair by ferry. The island holds the history of placing captives/prisoners in bunks which is also known as "Kalepani ki sazaa" in Hindi. You could see many deers roaming around in the island which is a boon to photographers.

title: Historic Place
review_text: If you want to go back to history and want to know how British people enjoyed when our people are suffering in Kalapani and for independence, then a must visit place. Aged people can leverage battery operated car service. We walked around. You can see deer and peacocks. Definitely not a entertainment spot for kids.

title: light and sound show
review_text: ross land was the Paris of east during british india . old building can be seen there . also deer , peacock and rabbits are there . i went for ligth and sound show . cost me 275.

title: Nice place with Deers and peacocks
review_text:
Visited Ross Island during our recent family vacation in Adman islands 
You need to take ferry to reach Ross Island from port Blair. It take 15-20 mins reach the island 
There are few remains of the British era which you can see 
But interesting part is there are Deers and peacocks and rabbits roaming freely on this island which is a good attraction for young children 
Also if you take services of Authorised tourist guide Anuradha Rao, you would get opportunity to feed these animals 
She would also tell you interesting history of the island and remains on the islands 
Overall a nice place to visit if you are in Port Blair

title: Good Island to be !!
review_text: You have to get in a small boat to reach this island n the ride is for 10mins....here you encounter many deers, peacocks n rabbits roaming freely on the island....this island was a club cum entertainment hub for the British officials and has ruins of their club, market area, church, cementary,etc.

title: short ride from port blair
review_text:
Ross island is nice place. you need to walk a lot to see the entire stuff. from here go to north bay island too for sea walking. 
it is maintained by navy. no entry after 5 pm.

title: Beautiful Island
review_text: This Island is being managed by Naval army. But a must visit place. Connected with Indian history and British Rule. Now there is only remainings of old British Buildings and church.

title: Ross Island the ruins of British empire
review_text: Ross Island is the ruins of British empire time buildings and administrative offices. The island is now under Indian Navy administration and is well maintained though the buildings are now converted in to ruins.

title: clam island..!!
review_text: this island provides you the insight of the British government offices. yet maintained as it is. maintained very neat and clean. lots of deer's are there who also pose for a pics :P . battery operated vehicle is also available for but they will drive it.

title: very nice place
review_text: view from cruse is too good very nice place had a beach old monument like church,buildings,swimming pool,bijali ghar,water purifier oldies

title: historical island.....very hot not too much worth to visit
review_text: very hot when u reached there in morning.......historical place ..they give one hour to visit place and return back....small battry car is ther of rs 75 per person... for 10 to 15 miniut they show some places in island....if u have time then visit ....else it is ok.....

title: Adventure visit
review_text:
This is one of the amazing place for everyone. Let it be a kid or teenager or an adult or family. 
U will find the journey from Portblair to Ross very amazing full of nature beauty's. 
At Ross u will experience everything viz lush green trees, sea blue water, lovely animals like deer, rabbit, hen and squarel. 
U will find glimpses of history in one of the small museums. 
Special attraction of tree roots which are holding rooms and building of old era. 
Scenic lovers can enjoy the photography shoots. 
A must visit recommendation.

title: This island has a got a different vibe to it
review_text: It is absolutely brilliant to explore this island and unravel some amazing history. On this island you will see some Deer's and Peacock's around and there is a beautiful quiet beach on the other side. Light and sound show would be a great pick for history lovers. Although carry some food as you visit, there are hardly any food options.

title: Not worth it
review_text: It was extremely hot when our tour took us there.. So so damn hot.. There isn't much to do there.. Just 45 minutes to visit.. Done deer running wild and big big tree roots and huge trees.. some history is there which is written on posters.. But all in all.. Too hot to visit in the afternoon

title: Historical place
review_text: Nice maintained historical site. light and sound show in evening is a must watch. Good to know about the living style of British empire

title: Nice Place
review_text: Old buildings with lots of trees coming on the walls... it gives a nice view. For us, attractions were peacocks and dear... Kids loved it.

title: Complete Island as an Open ZOO
review_text: We went on a 1 day North Bay island and Ross island tour from Port Blair,the Ross island part was fun. The island used to be the administrative and housing quarters for Britishers, which lies in Ruins now. The island is more like a Open Deer park now, with they roaming around freely. They have a guide Anuradha Bose(If I remember well), charges Rs.300 per head (September 2016), Make sure to hire her, all animals will Follow you and show you the Island. Once she is there, no need of Cart.

title: Remnants of Rulers
review_text: This island is now under the control of Indian Navy and can reach from Port Blair by Ferry. Inside there is a battery operated vehicle to take you around the island. Cost per person is Rs.75/-. There is an entry fee for this Island Beware do not litter anything. You can cover this area within one hour.

title: Good place to visit
review_text: Historical value to see how the British lived in style. The place is well maintained though all the buildings are in ruins. Nice small hike to highest point. Very short boat ride from port blair.

title: Must visit for Light and Sound show
review_text:
Must visit, you will get the feel of abroad location in India. Must go for light and sound show. 

I really fell in love with the place.

title: Relax with Nature and animals
review_text:
If you are going to Port Blair, be sure to visit this island. It's a small one and can be covered in half a day. They have laser shows in the evening during tourist season.. but not always. 
The best thing though is seeing deers, peacocks, rabbits around you. Not in cages but roaming freely around the island! It was awesome! 
The ruins are good to explore too. 
In short do not miss this trip if you are in Port Blair :)

title: ROSS ISLAND-
review_text: The island which was the Capital Of British Rule in Andaman.It's now history with the buildings in dilapidated conditions.It was a planned establishment .You can walk through the place among the trees and can feel the strange silence engulfing you as pleasant breeze blow across the island.There is an entry fee.Enjoyed the trip.

title: Nice Place to visit on foot
review_text: Roam full island on foot for best experience.Many deers, peacocks and peahens on island(All are friendly)

title: Capital of Andamans during British rule
review_text:
Feels like Cambodia except the buildings are British not ancient Khmer. There is an entry fee of Rs 40/person above 5yrs of age. A long path takes you around these dilapidated buildings, built for various purposes when the British ruled from here, before winding at the summit offering a breathtaking view from the top. There are deer and peacocks roaming about the place. 
A small shop offers snacks and tea and there are clean toilets. Nothing else do do apart from roaming around looking at the old buildings and taking pictures. Can skip if you are short of time. Outside food not allowed. There is a sound and light show in the evening. More

title: Wonderful place to visit
review_text:
It was amazing feel to see how English Officers lived their life on small island with all amenities and style. 
Wonderfully thought and designed by British. Though they were ruler for our country however their concepts and design about this island was phenomenal and beautiful.

title: Do NOT miss the Ross Inland Sound and Light Show
review_text:
Absolutely brilliant. Amazing ruins of British era buildings, steeped in history, and gigantic trees with their roots that have taken over the ruins. Unbelievable place. Peacocks, deer and rabbits roam free, allowing you to play with them. 

The 3d sound and light show is absolutely out of the world. The navy band playing anthem will bring u goosebumps. Even the animals stand still. And the sound and light show speaks to you.. you feel for Ross.. You fall in love with it. Dont miss it!

title: Beautiful island
review_text: Old capital of andams. Truely worth a visit. Light show is very spectacular and far better than cellular jail

title: Relaxing walk in Ross Island
review_text: This place is well maintained. A walk for about 2 kms in the island is very refreshing. One can see the remains of British and can imagine their life style of those days. There are deer and peacocks roaming around. There is only 1 shop selling snacks, coffee / tea. They also sell sovereigns like T Shirts. There are sign boards explaining the remains. There is rest room facility also. Looks like there is a sound and light show in evening.

title: nothing to do place
review_text:
If you like adventure, don't waste your time here.It is boring to sit in a place for 2 hours and wait for ferry to take you back, 
Has history but you can skip this unless you have ample time

title: Awsome visit
review_text: The light and show is excellent ...explained clearly about the olden days British ruling and history of the island

title: Eerie history
review_text:
Ross Island is well maintained, being under the control of Indian Navy. This is the Island where about 500 British families lived & administered Andamans in style during their rule. Starting from the Japanese bunker, the island has remnants of the luxurious facilities at the expense of the indentured labour, with their own filtering plant for water, swimming pool, unbelievably big bakery, three clubs, secretariat, temple, a church and a cemetery to boot. The dilapidated structures are held by the roots and vines of trees in an eerie way reminiscent of Angkor Wat. 

The locals have plundered the valuable wood and structures after the British abandoned the island. Ross Island bore the brunt of the tsunami, saving Port Blair from the direct fury. The island was also for a short while under the control of the Japanese. There is a small museum with photos comparing then and now as also a souvenir shop. A ghost island steeped in history worth going to. More

title: Paris of East
review_text: "Paris of East" - Ross Island was given this nickname by British, from which they ruled the whole Andaman archipelago. They have constructed various all the luxurious elements, from tennis court to swimming pool. I was surprised to find deers and peacocks, which is a rare sight in a small island like this. It is located at the entrance of Port Blair, standing as a ruined historical snapshot of the lavish lifestyle of the British rulers. The island is currently maintained by Indian Navy, hence there are not any shops or houses. History lovers would love this place.

title: An important piece of history
review_text: 10-minutes short boat ride away, this place in now in ruins especially after the tsunami devastation. But the ruins make for a great photo-op.

title: Island of british
review_text: Ross island was the centre during British rule ... Which is very near to Port Blair ... Just a good and quite place .... The sound and light show during night is good it shows the British administration during those days ....

title: Good view of town planning in WW2 times
review_text: Gives a view of town and garrison developed by English on this island during pre WW2 times. One could go around the important spots in this island in battery operated buggies for a price. parts of the island is accessible by foot, So please carry enough water and food with you

title: Amazing!!
review_text: Wow- what an incredible sight! An incredible piece of history, beautiful views and some good flora and fauna. One of our favs. Wish we'd had more time here.

title: Very well maintained island
review_text: This is a well maintained island near Port Blair. Lots of deer and peacock are there. Just spent time and have lots of photograph. nice location.

title: This is a wonderful island!
review_text: It has surreal feel to it, you can climb down and sit in one of the isolated beaches, or choose to travel to the pond, or goto the graveyard (eerie!) or get inside one of the japanese bunker (although it might be kind of dirty and smelly) just stare at the huge roots holding the island together. It's a beautiful place. Be sure not to miss your return jetty, those boatmen are very punctual and 12 means 12. No IST. :P

title: deer and peacocks galore
review_text: great place to see the ruins of the British Raj buildings. flocks of deer walk past and peacocks saunter around. lovely place for kids and adults who are kids at heart. their are buggy which takes you around and is good for a quick view if you are travelling with kids or senior citizens.

title: beautiful and pleasent
review_text:
amazing for a outing and to relax and amazing way to end the honeymoon. 

you get to ross island via 15 min boat journey from port blair. It was adventurous and fun. 

once you get there, you are greeted with japaneese bunker and english buildings. It is astounding to see the history and the beauty of the island. It shows the luxury that the english lived in during their rein over india. 

it a beautiful and a clean place for a stroll with many friendly animals and amazing spots for photographs. 

the view of the open sea is amazing and i was lucky to see a big tanker float away into the abyss. 

Over all it was a pleasent and heartwarming place. More

title: Dont miss the light n sound show!
review_text: It was late n was raining. We could only manage to reach Ross just before the light n sound show and we were glad that we witnessed the show. It was by far the best light n sound show! Entire history of Ross n Andaman came alive infront our eyes! Light n sound shows of both Central Jail n Ross Island worth a watch.

title: So cool! Amazing if you like history.
review_text:
I have red mixed reviews about this place but for me a history nerd this was amazing. Almost like an Pompei but with history from recent time with architecture and structures (like the pool) very much the same you still see in Europe everyday. It's an abandon ghosttown with the djungle taking back what it once lost. 

Seeing all pictures from the past and reading about the Islands history made it possible for me to imagine how the life was here once... When walking around the church, barraks and governors villa. The picture is from the floor of the villa... Italian tiles... dirty but still there. 

The ferry was 200 INR back and forth. I took the 12.30 that returned 14.30. The fee to enter Ross Island was 30 INR with an additional 30 INR for camera. More

title: Another island in the Andaman archipelago
review_text:
So this island is part of the sightseeing itenary of port blair. 
We came here on our sightseeing boat. Nice scenic beauty, silver white sands and vast blue sea. Windy and refreshing. 
All beaches of Andaman are beautiful, and this is no exception. 
Nice place to visit.

title: Nice Island and worth visiting
review_text: Need to walk around 30 min to see the Island. For elderly people take electric car. On the way to Northbay Island.

title: Do not miss
review_text:
This island is at 10 mins boat ride from Port Blair . The Ross Island is maintained very beautifully by the Indian Navy. 

Here you will have a Sound & Light show every evening where the stories of the Indian freedom fighters are narrated . 

The tickets for the visit to this island is only available with the tourism board at A & N islands:

title: Nice place to see
review_text: You can reach this beautiful island from Port Blair through boats. It look more scenic from top of Cellular Jail as well as North Bay Light house. Lush green and contrast with deep blue sea water.

title: Very Scenic beauty at this ruined island
review_text:
This place is really beatiful, lot of scenic beauty. Old ruined houses of Britisher's covered with roots tropical tree place a marvelous scene. 
You will really enjoy the beauty of this island.

title: Worth to visit
review_text: Ross Island is very close to port blair(15 mints by Ferry 200). You can recah here from Aberdeen jetty by paying 200 rs PAX. It was Administrative Headquarters in British era.

title: Historical Place
review_text:
Boats are available for Ross island from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex. Last boat leaves at 2pm and the total trip duration is approx 1.5 hours. 
One can see lots of deer's and few rabbit's on the island. Golf cart is available for island tour charging Rs. 75 per person. 
Only one restaurant is available at the island, hence it's preferred to carry own water bottles and food.

title: Not a picnic location
review_text: Only demolished British building. Nothing special in this island. Can see British Swimming pool and their water treatment tanks.

title: Beautiful Island! But one can only visit, can't stay or swim!
review_text:
This island is not far from Portblair, about 10 minutes by boat. This used to be the administrative and living place for the british officers. 
today it is used by the Indian navy! 
Most of the british era buildings are in ruin, no roofs, only walls coverd with roots of trees, except for a church. There are many antilopes and peacocks in this Island. It is coverd with Coconut and palm trees. One hour is enough to visit this Island.

title: Historic place ... no much activity
review_text: take the battery auto ride @75 per person (only one available so grab it at the earliest ) , walking could be tiresome.. awesome view from highest point

title: Place of Historical Importance
review_text: Lot of History associated with this Island and British used to rule the entire Andaman's from here. If you love Historic places, this is a must visit place.

title: nothing much to see here, can skip easily.
review_text: Not worth, but as day package was North Bay Island and Ross Island, we had to go to Ross Island also. But as such, nothing is there to enjoy. Waste of time at Ross Island.

title: Slice of history
review_text: Ferry from Aberdeen Jetty for normal visit. Ferry from Phoenix bay jetty for light and sound show in the evening. Maintained by Indian Navy. This small island has a very rich history in every knook and corner.

title: Wow
review_text: Wow, it's a beautiful little island with south of scenic beauty, can see how the British lived a nice life there and ruled the rest of the island from there.

title: See deer and rabbit come and take food from your hand.
review_text: You can board a ferry from the Ross Island boarding point. Ferry is every hour as far as I remember. The ferry stops for 2 hours on the island. Take the small golf cart for a nominal fee on the island and they will show you around the full island. There is no ATM so carry cash. There are lot of deer, rabbits and animals on the small island and it's beautiful. The entire island is small enough to be covered within 2 hours.

title: Hidden gem
review_text: Our experience of Roos island was increased manifold as we managed to hire Anuradha the only authorised guide for Ross island .The island has ruins of a century old filteration plant, church ,club ,cemetry indian market all in ruins .the devastation of the tsunami is best visible on this island. This island has wild deers and birds ,Our guide anuradha could call out for these animals and unbelievably the animals respond. We could feed the wild deers from our hand .Ross island is not to be missed at all

title: Island inhabited by deers and snakes
review_text: Ross Island was first inhabited by Britishers during the British Raj. Now, u will find deers and other wildlife in this deserted place.

title: A historical island near Port Blair
review_text: Ross Island is another beautiful & historical island near Port Blair. It is located just a kilometre far from Port Blair city. The day, 26.12.2016 at 8.45 am., after having breakfast we're ready to move to Ross Island but 26.12.2004 as the Tsunami triggered, so the people of Andaman offer homage on this day in each year. Homage time was from 10 am to 11 am. so the cruse did not move at that time. After waiting half an hour we moved towards Ross Island by boat. Ross Island was the former capital of Port Blair during the British regime. It had every thing at that period such as bakery, stores, bazar, workshop, water distillation plant, church, tennis court, printing press, hospital, secretariat, open air theatre etc. But today nothing is there. Every thing has disappeared. A few building structures left there which housed some of these landmarks. Now-a-days it is maintained like a museum. More

title: Good spot for half day trip
review_text:
Booked one day trip to Ross island and Northbay.They gave us two hrs time only after which the boat would travel ti North bay.Time was insufficient to visit alk the spots- Tennis court,Bakery,bunker,swimming pool etc.you need a minimum if five hrs to travel around the island which was the administer capital of Britishers.More over trip to Northbay is utter waste since there is nothing other than watersports 

So if you r planning for double island tour,cancel Northbay and spend the entire day at Ross island.Northbay is utter waste.

title: Historic place -Poor ferry service
review_text:
The ferry journey time to this island is 5-10 minutes, for which tourists were made to que up in hot sun for two hours. The reporting time was 3pm, and the ferry left at 5pm. 
On top of it tourists were made to wear inflated suffocating life jackets. 
The island is nice, and so is the light and sound show.

title: Past memories of British
review_text: Old ruins remind us that nothing is permanent. Can walk around this small island, can walk up to top and enjoy company of deer, peacocks, rabbits.

title: Beautiful and well maintained Island
review_text: Worth visiting place. the island is under Indian Navy and they are maintaining the island excellently. There are battery operated cars to visit around the island earlier occupied by various rulers in India.

title: Now ruins once glory
review_text: this place is a time machine. as soon as you land here, it takes you into some another era. ruins of the British empire are unbelievable. Light and sound show is a must.

title: Nothing great about this island
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: All the hype is just useless as this island has remains of buildings from British era only. Few deers added to the photo spots else nothing great about this island

title: NOT a must visit place when you go Andaman
review_text:
This place was once a PARIS OF THE EAST for the British people, its all ruined place of British HiFi private island of their time. there are ruined church, some distillary drums for water purification, cemetery, british office and thats it! 
Visit this place ONLY if you have no where to go. we visited this Island only bcoz every other tourist location was closed on Monday. Not worth spending time here

title: Historical place...
review_text: 15 min journey from Port Blair by speed boat. Historical place comprising of British time architectures. Good place to see deer, peacocks and rabbits. Very small island and hardly requires one hour to cover.

title: An insight into the opulence and extravagance enjoyed by officers of the british raj
review_text: It is indeed a wonder to see the extreme opulence and indulgence of officers of the British Raj. The island itself was self contained even down to having it's own bakery, church, pool , barracks, officers mess etc. Not to forget the little escape jetty on the opposite side of the island facing away from the main island of port Blair. It's a short hop by boat from port Blair and is basically formed by corals. The island is controlled the the govt of India and the Indian Navy. U would find lovely corals here but be warned trying to take the corals is an offence and you are searched for them so take nothing from here but memories and leave nothing here but foot prints. More

title: The great Ross Island
review_text: A must visit island. The light and sound show here is extraordinary. The history of the place during the British rule is perfectly depicted with exceptional special effects with video projection, light and sound.

title: Must visit
review_text:
This island has a lot of history and with marooned buildings and it's exotic feel, it is sure to make one feel like a tourist. 

The light and sound show here is one of the best I have seen in India. They serve an amazing kulfi before the show, do not miss that. It is best to book a ferry before hand from Port Blair! You will board your ferry from the Aberdeen Jetty which is an amazing spot in itself. It was thrilling for me for a first experience.

title: Britishers capital then, ruins now
review_text:
From Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex(Port Blair) We took the island hop boat to visit Ross Island (2 hours) and North Bay Island (3 Hrs) and back to Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex by late afternoon. 

Visiting this island will give you a glimpse on the bygone era. Bakery, Water distillery plant, Officers bungalow, swimming pool, staff quarters, bunker from Japanese time. 

Ross Island is also park for Deer and Peacock, you can find bunch of them walking around.

title: A withered rose
review_text: Tour groups take you there from Port Blair to kill time.A few rundown structures 300 years old- a boiler house, a bakery, a Church, a few peacocks plenty of free Deer roaming.

title: Lessons to be Learnt : To be prepared for War, is to be prepared for Peace
review_text:

Ross is a reminiscence of the painful and indescribable Indian freedom struggle, and the administrative skill of the British. The Japanese bunker, erected during the Second World War, reminds us of Netaji hoisting the Indian national flag and his freedom call, “March to Delhi”. The Ross Island was the British administrative headquarters, housing a secretariat, a resident chief commissioner’s bungalow, a Presbyterian church and the Ferar Beach among others. The anchor, on display beside the Commissioner’s Bungalow, is undoubtedly an archeological and a maritime artifact. “HIT FIRST, HIT HARD, KEEP ON HITTING” – The very words painted at the highest point of the island reveals the intelligent military strategy of the then Royal Navy. There is a park for children, and a cemetery nearby - that bears the mortal remains of young women and children, whose lives were swept away by malaria and other fatal diseases. The distilling and mineral water plants, once installed to combat this malady, are today, all but corroded and dilapidated. On February 24th, 2017 we made our way to the Ross Island from the boating jetty in Port Blaire by “M.V Island Cruise” – a small boat. 
Ross is a reminiscence of the painful and indescribable Indian freedom struggle, and the administrative skill of the British. 
The transported Indian freedom fighters (referred to as ‘political prisoners’) were initially brought to Ross Island, and then shifted to Viper Island (until the construction of the Cellular Jail at Port Blaire, in 1906). The Japanese bunker, erected during the Second World War, reminds us of Netaji hoisting the Indian national flag and his freedom call, “March to Delhi”. 
The Ross Island was the British administrative headquarters, housing a secretariat, a resident chief commissioner’s bungalow, a Presbyterian church and the Ferar Beach among others. The anchor, on display beside the Commissioner’s Bungalow, is undoubtedly an archeological and a maritime artifact. 
“HIT FIRST, HIT HARD, KEEP ON HITTING” – The very words painted at the highest point of the island reveals the intelligent military strategy of the then Royal Navy. 
There is a park for children, and a cemetery nearby - that bears the mortal remains of young women and children, whose lives were swept away by malaria and other fatal diseases. The distilling and mineral water plants, once installed to combat this malady, are today, all but corroded and dilapidated. The boilers are made of special steel, are now encircled with a labyrinth network of tree roots. 
Of all the Andaman Islands we visited, we spotted deer, rabbits and peacocks only here. 
Owing to its strategic location, Ross was handed over to the Indian navy on 18th April 1979 
On the whole, this major island of the Andaman Archipelago is a grim reminder of the Indian freedom struggle and the unyielding military strategy of Britain. More

title: A glimpse of British administration in Kalapani Era
review_text: While two Island tour we were in Ross island and it was nice to see the place,in British era in Kalapani it was Quarter of senior officer

title: Good view
review_text: The old buildings where Britishers and their soldiers lived are now in ruins. Dears are roaming around. battery driven open car is available for drive on uphill side @ Rs 75/person having seating capacity of 8 persons. Good view of bay from top of hill.

title: Lovely!
review_text: We went on our honeymoon and it was a great fun. The journey through the port to Ross Island was beautiful. The prices of all the water sports at the Island are in budget. One can enjoy all the sports. Snorkling and Scuba Diving are the two must water sports to try. But the best scuba diving happens at Haveloc Island.

title: Must Visit place.
review_text: Ross island was not originally included in our basic itinerary with 'Experience Andamans'. But on last day we had to spend 3-4 hours after checkout, so we requested Experience Andamans team to arrange for Ross island visit just night before. They arranged it despite being last minute request by us wonderfully. N We felt so good that we opted to visit this place. It's an island jst near to Port Blair jetty. Boat takes 10 mins to reach. Awesome place. Old headquarters of British colony. Now only ruins are left post stunami. But still much to see. Deers, peacocks, old buildings, Beach. Can spend 1.5-2 hours here easily.

title: sad part
review_text: i was unlucky to visit this place as the island had holiday on that particular date when i had visted andamans.. hope to visit again soon..

title: small island. rich history.
review_text:
this island has long history of occupation by british, thier dilapidated buildings. the place seems little eery and scary after the lights are swtiched off for light and sound show. 
light and sound show is amazing.

title: Must Visit if you love ruins and history
review_text:
Ross Island was the administrative center for the English in Andaman during the years of Kaalapani. Though the buildings in the islands are in ruins, it is a sight to watch with the buildings covered with roots giving a haunted sight. Every building has a history and a information board at every place gives tourists a guide. The walking tracks are well maintained and are clean, golf carts are provided for folks who cannot walk for long, for a fee. A good place to spend your day with history around, deers and rabbits approaching you without fear. 

The premises has a museum too with the "then" photograph of the island and buildings. 

The entry ticket to the island is fairly priced and is a must visit if you love history and ruins. 

The Boat ride to the island too is fairly priced, with all safety precautions taken mandatorily. More

title: Nice Same Day Trip
review_text: Take boat from port blair and visit this fastastic island with free roaming friendly deers and view the blue green vast Indian ocean.

title: New Light and Sound show at Ross is better than Cellular Jail
review_text:
We went there in evening using Govt ferry. Nothing much but whatever is there is good. Ruins of British Administration , Free running Deers, Rabbits, Peacocks (many). You can interact with them. Good photography options with Animals. Best part is Light and Sound Show of about 30 minutes in Hindi (Javed Akhtar's voice) and in English (Shabana Azmi's voice). Show is filled with Cartoon and light effects with good sound effect. Show talks about Ross and its relation with Cellular Jail and 2nd world war. Over all much better than Cellular Jail. Ross show has better light effects, better graphics and visualizations as compared to Cellular Jail show that is more of a sound show. But both are a must watch for History seekers. Show is best in Andaman but may not be best you have ever seen ( For me show in Akshardham Delhi is superb ). 
Island rating - 3/5 as nothing mush to see 
Light and Sound Show rating - 4/5 as its better than Cellular Jail show. More

title: Ruins and roots.. Beauty redefined
review_text: They said Ross Island has nothing more than some ruins. It was only when I landed there that the beauty of the place struck me. I took a ferry from Port Blair to Ross Island, it's a short journey. The place is filled with ruins with roots engulfing them. Nothing can beat the beauty of this place. The water is pristine and peacocks and deers can be seen everywhere. There is a church in ruins which has been cordoned off but is still very peaceful to visit. The return ferry starts in about 2 hrs, so you need to get to the boarding point in time.

title: A place to reminisce the history
review_text: This Island gives us the glimpse of how the British lived during their time in Port Blair. Many of the buildings were damaged and were shell of their past. All the government buildings during the British times were present here. This is also one of the place not to be missed.

title: Don't give its a miss , its a great place !!
review_text:
You would need abt 2-3 hrs to enjoy here . There are ferries available and based on ur budget u can book a ticket in anyone you like , ac/non ac etc. 
PAY CLOSE ATTENTION TO THIS :--- When you buy a ticket it would be return tickets for the ferry of your choice now the ferry will take you there , leave you there for an hour and the same ferry will comeback to pick you up after 60 mins , that isn't close to enough time required to peacefully enjoy Ross Island and explore the complete island, what you should do is buy a separate ticket for return which is scheduled for 2-3 hr later so that you can enjoy ur time here. 

The island is a paradise for photographers or ppl who like getting their pictures clicked, tons of amazing spots all completely diffrent from each other. 
Kids will have a blast here as there are many deers and birds like peacocks roaming around freely, even the beach on the other side and the japanese bunkers are not to be missed.

title: Nice island

title: Awesome....

Nice place to spend some quality time.very nice views. 
Very well maintained. 
More facilities can be provided for senior citizens.

title: Not much to see
review_text: An average place. Can watch how the English lived in late 1800s and early 1900.., all the buildings have been ruined.. Just a small ride from the port blair jetty.

title: Excellent & Spectacular Sound, Light & Multimedia Show
review_text:
I had been to both the Sound & Light Shows in Andaman. First day we went tot the Cellular Jell and next day we went to the Ross Island Show. The Ross Island show has an additional feature of Multimedia, which was spectacular. The story written & told by GULZAR in Hindi was just fantastic. Whenever, you go to Andaman don't give a miss to the Ross Island Show. 
Ross Island was the old capital of Andaman now a Indian Navy Base. The story told by Gulzar is about the history of Ross Island.

title: A piece of frozen history amidst sea - must visit
review_text:
Ross Island can be easily accessed by Ferry from Phoenix jetty of Port Blair & is a must-visit place....one can not only experience the natural beauty of the island & the surrounding water & beaches but also can be part of Japanese & British history. 
Depending on the travel schedule, the evening light & sound can also be witnessed in this island....a leisure stroll should take 2-2.5 hrs, excluding the light & sound.

title: A decent 3-4 hours excursion
review_text:
It all depends on how you are travelling and what your priorities are. I was travelling solo and wanted to explore the island on my own rather than follow the fixed route which guides show you. There is a hole different island waiting to be explored in Ross if you want. There is a fixed route to the Museum but if you turn left after crossing what appears to be a old lake in the middle of the island you will come encounter a 6 feet fall and then starts a jungle waiting to be explored. I found herds of deers and peacocks roaming in that part. Compared to the rest of the island deers they were pretty shy to come near you giving you feel of a real jungle. Then there is a pretty coastline waiting to be explored. There is no sand in that part but the beautiful colored rocks give an eerie feel. You can find crabs nesting in the bigger boulders and hundreds of snails. North Bay is visible from this part and the island looks quite pretty. There is a light house on the far end of Ross Island which is another point where you can trek up to. Additionally you do not need to make prior bookings for the island. There are ferries starting from 9:00 am for the island from phoenix Bay Jetty. You can purchase the tickets yourself and save 50 bucks... You can purchase the tickets yourself and save 50 bucks per person. There is another option of 2 island package (Ross + North Bay) or (Ross + Viper Island) but if you want to indulge in water sports activities there are better spots in Havelock, Neil and Jolly Buoy waiting to be explored. There are ferries to Ross Island every half hour. Try to take morning - afternoon ferry which will give you ample time to visit Cellular Jail Light and Sound Show in the evening. More

title: Must Visit when you are in Portblair
review_text: We visited Ross Island during our recent visit to Andaman. We loved the little island. It is a 10 min boat ride from portblair jetty. The boat which drops you will pick you up after 2 hours . I felt we could have little more time to relax and laze around. As you enter the Island you are welcomed by friendly deers and peacocks . They are freely roaming around. Then we got to hear the history of Ross Island from the lady guide Anuradha Rao . It was really nice walking around the ruins and exploring the place to get a feel of the history. The place offers a great opportunity for photography between those huge tress which has it is roots spread across the walls and all over . It was just amazing to spend some time there and must visit when you are visiting Andaman . More

title: Historic Island..!
review_text: It is a very historic island. It is near to port blair island. It has many deers, peacocks, old buildings with trees.

title: Very informative visit
review_text: We reached this island in the evening. Our boat was MV Saroj and the journey was pleasant - about 15 minutes and the return fare Rs 50. The boat immediately departs for Port Blair after the Sound and Light show. The show is a pleasure to watch and listen. Very clearly narrated by Shabana Azmi and the animation effects are wonderful. One sees the remains of Japanese bunkers here and gets to know more about the life of prisoners and tribals. The boat had started for the island very late- was scheduled to depart at 4 pm but actually started at 4.45 pm. So we could spend a few minutes for going around. Show started at 5.30 and the duration was about 40 minutes. Our Driver had suggested to go in the morning - evening both times but the heat during the day was extreme. More

title: Pleasant
review_text:
We took the 8:30 ferry. Its a 10 minute ride but takes longer because the little ferries have trouble pulling up to the jetty. As we walked around we thought of Kipling's story about the letting in of the jungle from the Mowgli stories. The big fig trees have taken over all the buildings of the British Raj. The British families posted at Port Blair lived a luxurious life here before the war. 
The island is now maintained by the Indian Navy. We had a pleasant hour long walk while contemplating the fleeting life of Empires.

title: Amazing experiences!
review_text: We enjoyed our visit to the islands very much. The hotel management was very helpful in arranging the trip. We didn't know that Ross Island had such a history. Recommend seeing the Light and Sound show in the evening.

title: History in Freeze mode
review_text:
Ross island is a mere fifteen minutes ride by ship from Port Blair marine station and it was the vessel M V Saroj that took us across . History has it that Port Blair was home to the cellular jail that the British built in 1906 to incarcerate hardened indian criminals and sevral freedom fighters including the famous Veer Savarkar. The british wanted to have a place exclusive to whites , that they could make their home . Much of the historical structures are in a state of ruin , but well preserved. Nothing is left of the Presbyterian church except the front wall , said to have been detroyed by the japanese bombs. The bakery building is still standing . many of the buildings are overgrown and enveloped by tree roots and offer an impressive sight of the march of time in feeze frame. Ross Island today is an excursion spot and offers breathtaking views of the sea and one can feel the island effect of being sorrounded by waters . A must visit on every tourist's agenda. Some parts of the island involve some gradient climbing . Electric golf carts are available for a quick look around for a fee of 75/- per person. History has it that Port Blair was home to the cellular jail that the British built in 1906 to incarcerate hardened indian criminals and sevral freedom fighters including the famous Veer Savarkar. The british wanted to have a place exclusive to whites , that they could make their home . Much of the historical structures are in a state of ruin , but well preserved. Nothing is left of the Presbyterian church except the front wall , said to have been detroyed by the japanese bombs. The bakery building is still standing . many of the buildings are overgrown and enveloped by tree roots and offer an impressive sight of the march of time in feeze frame. Ross Island today is an excursion spot and offers breathtaking views of the sea and one can feel the island effect of being sorrounded by waters . A must visit on every tourist's agenda. Some parts of the island involve some gradient climbing . Electric golf carts are available for a quick look around for a fee of 75/- per person. 

The island is now maintained by the Indian navy and is very well maintained as a historic monument . Some spotted deer and a few pea fowl seem to have made a hiome of Ross Island and this gives a nice touch to the otherwise barren place devoid of people save for the visitors/tourists. A Light and sound show is conducted daily at 5.30 pm or thereabouts , within minutes of sunset , lasting about 45 minutes. The show traces history back to the arrival of the British, freedom movement , Mangal Pandey , World war 2 and finally the Indian independence. Hindi narration is by Gulzar and the narrative and the laser 3D effects are simply world class. Every Indian should see this show. More

title: The light and sound show which takes your breath away.
review_text: Whatever you do, make it a point to take in the light and sound show, even if it means an extra day in the islands. Haunting words by Gulzar, excellent animation and lighting by professionals, and the music by Shankar Madhavan. We had antelope strolling between the rows of viewers, we had the sun set happening on the side and we had a breezy, happy ferry ride back to Port Blair.

title: Nice Island
review_text: Good Island to walk & click pics. It is old island used by Britishers to relax. Can walk down complete island in 1-2 hours.

title: Historical Island well maintained by Indian Navy
review_text: We visited this island on 12th February and liked the place. This was the first settlement of British Occupation. There is a nice cafeteria that serves reasonable quality food at a good price. Toilets are available and as you enter the island, there is a Kulfi vendor selling Kulfi (Indian style ice cream on a stick) which is very soothing. We were here for only one hour which was not enough to cover the whole Island.

title: Beautiful place with historical significance
review_text: Another place which has a history behind it..... With Japanese bunkers still present there....island has some wildlife as well.... And the construction made by the Britishers are also well maintained.....

title: Island under Navy control.
review_text: A beautiful island of historical importance at one time occupied by the Japanese. Bunkers built by them are strewn all over the island. Relics of the British rule are also visible, offering interesting insights into their living. This island is now under the control of the Indian Navy and protected property. Well maintained, red colour dominating the buildings. There is a cafeteria serving food and beverages. Lots of wildlife roam around freely in the island.

title: Must see location
review_text: One smust visit this island to admire then used advance technology of water filteration , sea water swimming pool, the church, friendly peacocks and hungry deers, soothing & calming waves, the most mesmerising views around.

title: compact earth
review_text: Oh. since it was the capital of the British in Andaman, it has everything. Rich history, Flora and Fauna, Variety of animals, Age old but still modern water purifying plants,...... so many of 'em. Prepare yourself for a long walk, This island wont disappoint you, whatever you're interested in.

title: beutifull island
review_text: The island is very pretty really like the place too much and you can easily spend 2 hours there really a bice place and nice restraunts are also there.

title: Compressed marvel......
review_text: The island is really mind boggling with the history it has with. The scenic and the shoreline beauty of this island is awesome.

title: Ross Island is a beautiful Island near Port Blair.
review_text: Its open for visitors. On this island you wont find any hotels so it is just drop and pick up by ferry. You will find deers, peackocks and beautifull Flora Fauna on this island.

title: Romantic Place with some History
review_text: Wonderful island with some essence of history. The beach area is just fantastic with trees lying down with rocks all over. But the tides are too hard so don't try for jumping inside. Also always wear the shoes while coming down as there are some stiff rocks around which can harm your leg.

title: For Historians
review_text: This place is now under the control of the Indian Navy. One can see the Church, Bakery, Commissioner's house, Junior officers mess, etc. All these buildings are in ruins. One can also see deer, peacocks, etc. These animals roam freely and can also be fed by hand as they are quite friendly. The place can be covered on foot. title: A good place!

review_text: this place is very nice , you can go to this place by boat . either sharing or your own. Nice light and sound show in evening and the tickets can be taken from TRC Portblair

title: Unique destination
review_text: Ross island was the capital for East India Company for many years. It is a part of your ferry to North Bay Island. Exceptionally clean and well maintained by the Indian Navy. There is a small canteen for basic vegetarian food. Must try is Idli dhokla. The Island has Deers, Peacocks, Rabbits etc open. Its a brief visit worth to be made.

title: Ross Island is a historical beauty.

title: Best island that i have visited on my andaman vacation
review_text:
For me, this is the best place i visited in andamans on my vacation. 
Its a small island with beautifully dilapidated buildings of british era,friendly wildlife(deers, rabbits, peacocks), serene and secluded beach, an unforgettable nature walk. 
Ruins of the buildings of british era give you rich feels of the bygones and the fact that the nature ultimately claims everything that belongs to her. 
The worst part although was that i just got 1 hour to spend there as the jetty was further connecting to north bay island. 
My advice is take jetty from port blair to ross island only so that you can spend 2-3 hours there, not the one that take you both to ross and north bay island. More

review_text: The light and sound show is a MUST(a very well projected).Those found of history must go there before 1600 h(no guides available after 1600 hours).

review_text: Is a left over of a glorious British past with what's left of past glory of Paris of East. It's a tragic rewind of colonialism. The food joints are sad, no shopping, limited sitting facility and a good round about island walk. Deers, rabbit, peacock are the only pleasant things amidst iconic views.

title: Light and sound.
review_text: Light and sound show is a must..Gulzar voice and screenplay. ..wow......such a small island and what history.....nice place for a walk...and see with times ..how a place can change.
