title: Amazing!!
review_text: You reach this place by riding a ferry for 20 minutes from Port Blair. It is a delightful little place. There are deers, rabbits, peacocks, etc on the island. Recommended time to visit is around 4pm when you can see the sunset as well as see the Light and Sound Show on this island - telling about the history of the island. Paris of the East!! We found the light and sound show at this place better than the one at the Cellular Jail.

title: PARIS OF THE EAST
review_text: At one time touted to be the Paris of East this was to be a British Settlement where they could supervise the administration of the cellular jail housing the freedom fighters it's now a lost paradise the Sound and light show is excellent you need to book the tickets from the jetty in Port Blair all inclusive of the fare a must see

title: Must visit!
review_text:
You can take a boat ride from Water Sports Complex to Ross Island. It will cost you INR 200 p.p. Once you step on Ross Island, you are in store for incredibly beautiful time of your life. 

Ross Island is a tiny piece of land graciously placed on the waters of Bay of Bengal. Water is deep blue while you are in boat heading towards Island and at Island you see beautiful topaz green colour of sea water. It's picture perfect! 

We were surprisingly greeted by gorgeous deers and peacocks. They were strolling on the Island freely and seemed more than happy to entertain visitors and even pose for them. 

You get to marvel at the beauty of mother nature and reimagine the past British colonisation. Ross Island was once headquarter capital of East India Company led British Empire on Andaman Islands. 

Huge island trees, various animals & birds in their natural habitat, ruins from the times of British colonisation. All very picturesque! But what is most spectacular and a must must see places is quitely tucked in a corner a mile or two away from the Old ruin Church. It's named 'Ferar Beach'. Aha! Divine and spectacular sea view. Layers of different coloured water. Emerald green, turquoise blue, deep blue. I and my wife are mesmerised for our lives. More

title: Best place to visit in Port Blair
review_text: The best place to visit in entire port blair. Its a photographers delight. Do not miss the light and sound show. The Ross Island has peacocks, deers and squirrels and wonderful view. I must say it was wonderful experience to visit.

title: Well maintained beautiful Island
review_text: We felt this island more of a park. A beautiful park rich in fauna and flora. Located some 15 minutes ferry ride from Port Blair city, this island is very well maintained. Flowering plants, bushes, lawns, good landscapes adorn the island. Ruins of few colonial buildings are seen. We saw spotted deer, rabbits and peacocks on the island. We spent quality time moving around watching the beauty of nature.

title: historical island
review_text: this is one of the historical island in Andaman.i took a ticket for 450 rs by boat including ross island and north bay island.they given time fr 2 hrs .old jail ,church etc we can see here.this is maintained by indian navy.location is good.

title: amazong place to visit
review_text: do add this island visit in your tour summary . specially famous for the clean beaches and water sports activites.

title: Average
review_text: You can easily skip this, at best you can do S & L show in the evening ferry. Dont waste whole day, rather spend in some other place.

title: Stay for the Light-Sound Show
review_text:
Ross has an eerie history, it was occupied and then abandoned by the British and finally occupied by the Japanese during World War II. In the middle of these events, there was an earthquake that split the island. AND then the Tsunami. 

This history is presented in a sound-light show like none other. It's an experience in itself. There are abandoned buildings, mostly destroyed by nature. There's a beach (Ferrar) that was destroyed in the Tsunami and you can spot the lighthouse of North Bay Beach. 

You can lose yourself on the island, so it's advisable to move around with a group. Highlights of the island: 

1. Light and Sound Show 
2. Deers and Peacocks that live there 
3. The graveyard (little sad and macabre, but beautiful) More

title: Beautiful beach
review_text: A beautiful place to stay around 2 to 3 hours,along with deer and a small restaurant .Swimming is prohibited so only for sight seeing and for some sitting in calm place e

title: Ross Island
review_text: Ross Island was one of the place for the british peoples when india did not had the independence. a must visit place for every tourist travelling to port blair.

title: Good place to visit.
review_text: Their is a lot of history attached to this place. Well maintained place with complete cleanliness. Their is a light & sound show which takes place every day except on mondays ( not sure ). Its good watching in the evening. Their are limited tickets available for tha show so ask ur driver to pre book the tickets.

title: Must visit in the evening
review_text:
The light and sound show is superb 

One special thing about this island is you can see many animals roaming around like dear. You can touch them.

title: A tiny island packing a big punch
review_text:
Ross island is a tiny piece of land that can be reached after a 40 minute boat ride from the main jetty. It has a total area of 0.6 square km but is loaded with history. 
You can see the entire island under a half hour. 
The light and sound show is awesome and leaves a lasting impression. 
Do not miss the awesome travel guide who calls out to animals. It's amazing to see deer, sparrows, pigeons and rabbits flock to her when she calls and follow her around the island. 
Must visit of in the Andamans.

title: A must see!
review_text: We took a trip to ross island during our stay in October 16. The tickets for the ferry were not expensive and we spent a total of 1 hour and 30mins on Ross island. Alot of time to explore, take photos and even have some coconut water before heading back. Great place to visit in Port Blair.

title: Ross Island. Old British HQ
review_text: It a sight seeing point while you visit Andaman s. Now only ruines and boards are there depicting pictures of the past. Freely moving herd of deers and peacocks are astonishing. Don't feed them its an offense there. Also called as Paris of East at the pre Freedom era.

title: Photogenic Place
review_text: This Island is a small one good for the photos with view of Blue water and north bay as background. Otherwise rest is normal. You have to get entry ticket into the Island after reaching there. Good for couples or group of friends.

title: Nice picnic spot with family and friends
review_text: Historically rejuvenating, well maintained, clean place. Kids will love the friendly deers and hares, they can even be touched. The light and sound show is a must watch. Pack some light food and you can have a nice picnic with family and friends.

title: Nice attraction
review_text: good for an hour-long visit. the colonial era structures are the main attractions, apart from the few deer and peacocks.

title: Could have been better.
review_text: I had booked for Ross island with viper and North bay for a whole day with my organiser. Unfortunately the boats were cancelled and we could go to Ross island in the evening for the light and sound show. If you are planning please make sure u get to visit the island in the morning as u can visit the old buildings and the beach on the other side. Historically the building have lots of significance. Since we went in the evening I could see only the Japanese bunkers and it was too dark to appreciate any tunnels if there were any. The boats can be arranged privately but quite expensive. The light and sound show was nicely done and much better than the one at the cellular jail. It was nice to see them use an existing building to project the show along with a screen. We enjoyed the nice slice of history. Sad we could not visit the buildings during the day. Hope u guys have better luck than us. More

title: History well preserved and told
review_text: Best Sound and light show. Gulzar had done a brilliant job of bringing the island to life. Highly recommended for a day time visit to discover the tree covered ruins....

title: Historic remains
review_text: Good place to visit for an hour. Nicely maintained. Good photo taking spots available. Historic place with remains of old church, bungalows, pool etc

title: Interesting
review_text: You can spend an hour or so without getting bored and it's a nice walk around the island. My son had fun watching the deer and peacocks running around. Cute place for kids. Didnt eat anything there so can't comment.

title: Ross island the beauty and heritage maintained by navy
review_text: Excellent place to watch and well maintained by navy,remains of old heritage building of british time can be seen the deer and rabbit like animals moving makes this place superb best time to visit in winters,trees covering whole building remains can be seen must watch with family

title: Nice place !! sea view at rear of island is awesome
review_text: This is the place where British posted to andaman, used to reside during pre-Independence era. You can have a look of thier Officers MESS , SNCOs MESS, library Cook house ,Church etc.. but everything has turned ruins after the invasion and devastation by Japanese. Nevertheless calm place to be at. You can sail through ship for 20 min from main island to reach here.

title: Best sound & light show in India
review_text: The Ross Island is maintained by Indian Navy. There is no need to say more about how the Island is maintained. Deers , rabbits are domesticated on that island. You go there by ferry from port Blair. The light and sound show played in the evenings about the history of the Island is the best in India and is much better than the one played at Cellular jail, Port Blair.

title: The sound and light show is a must do
review_text:
30-40mins from Port Blair by Ferry, The Ross Island is a must do. Don't keep any other engagements for that evening as boats do not stick to the timings. The show is excellent and covers The British settlement to end of World War II. So it is worth . 
When you visit the Island , do have a look at ruins. It needs ticket booked in advance, also in case of weather problems, it may get cancelled . 
There are many deer which come and roam around in between the seats which was lovely. 
When you buy tickets , please confirm from which jetty the boat will start and where they will drop you back. For us they picked up in one jetty and dropped back in another. Which led to lot of altercations between passengers and crew, as passengers were not informed. More

title: Eerie
review_text: A stroll around the ruins is gives an eerie feeling particularly when not many tourists are around. Ross used house the offices and residences of the Britishers. Not much of the original structures remain, but it is still worth a leisurely stroll. The light and sound show in the evening is quite nice.

title: Paris of East
review_text: First chosen as penal colony for rebels who opposed East India Company and British rule after 1857, this island, a horizon away from Port Blair, was found so idyllic that British decided to develop it as administrative station. It had a power house,post office,bazaar,bakery,fresh-water wells, besides residences for high posted officials. It survived a massive earthquake which split the island,though the buildings perished. Occupied by Japanese during WW 2,it still has a bunker on the jetty. Forgotten for decades after 1947,it was handed over to Indian Navy in 1979. Deers on the island are so friendly with Naval personnel that they actually snatch snack from your hands! prior permission from forest deptt is required to visit it as most of islands do. Light and Sound show depicting history of the island with commentary by Gulzar is fantastic. Permission to visit comes with the show if requested. But, i suggest one should visit the island during day,to explore it well and attend the show after dark. More

title: Ross Island : a clean and lovely place
review_text: It's a clean and lovely place maintained by Indian Navy. Carry your camera for awesome pictures but you have to pay for it. Also you need to pay for plastic bottles if you are carrying it but it will be refunded if you bring it back. There is cafeteria inside for snacks and cold drinks. Many animals roam freely feeding them is not allowed there. The ferry that drops you will also pick you. No other ferry would pick you so kindly note the time they tell you and be there on time.

title: Picturesque island
review_text: This is a lovely little place dotted with the ruins of a British settlement. Nice to stroll around amid friendly spotted deer and peacocks who follow you around begging for food. Get along your snacks and water as there isn't anything available on the island.

title: worth a visit
review_text: Ross Island was the settlement of the Britishers officers. After freedom this was handed over to Indian Navy for maintenance. It suffered massive damages during Tsunami. Here one can see and feel lot of deers roaming around. One must not miss the sound and light show in the evening on this island.

title: Must visit especially for Deers
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: Very near to Port Blair, only 15 min ride in boat. This island was residence of British Officers and now a residence of Deer, rabbits and Peacocks. This island offers a wonderful view of Sea with clean water. Not crowded and a good show for visitors.

title: Nothing to see
review_text: Dont waste your time going here. There is a long wait in the Port Blair harbour to get a boat. There is nothing to see in Ross except for some ruins. There is no food / cafe there and it is generally always very hot.

title: Historic island with beautiful wildlife
review_text: This is one of the "must see" islands in Andaman. It doesn't have any corals but it does have a lot of history and beautiful wildlife. Make sure you hear what Anuradha (the official guide) has to say - she can speak to the animals and make them do what she says.

title: Historic place
review_text: Excellent small island with deer and peacocks roaming around. Definitely worth a visit. This island is very close to port Blair.

title: Must visit
review_text:
It is a definite spot for anyone visiting Port Blair. 
It has a historical background and the remains of the buildings take you back in history. 
It is very clean facility but wish the guests were little more sensitive about maintaining it. 
Another great aspect was a lot of free roaming animals and birds including dears, peacocks, rabbits.

title: Fun but Overcrowded
review_text: Its a damn small island just off the coast of Port Blair, so if youre not going to Neil or Havelock, its a good idea. If you are going to some of the proper andamani islands, then this may be a bit underwhelming.

title: Scenic beauty
review_text: Nice scenic beauty, chance to see a lot of flora and fauna . Nice facilities need a little bit renovation.

title: Very Interesting
review_text: This was really interesting. Also seeing how the trees have taken over the building is amazing. Take the faster boat.

title: Small tour place
review_text: beautiful island near port blair just 2 km , have to go by ferry only. they will give you 1 hour time to go through the place. food items are available.

title: was a bright day trip for a few hours
review_text: its a beautiful visit with deers and other attraction like the japanese hide out. The landscape with palm trees beautiful green sea and bright morning wa smesmerising . there is a small cafeteria serving food and lots of old relics which has a lot of historical imporatnce the contours a re diffcult for senior citizens hence the trip could be adjusted as per their requirements and convenience

title: Excellent for a Half day activity especially evening
review_text: Nice nature and sight seeing, and evening show is amazing. Nice to see this island. Only draw back is, no food available here, please carry all your food including the water bottle.

title: Nothing spectacular
review_text: This island is 10min ride from mainland. There is nothing but the ruins of buildings made by british. Maintained by the indian navy now. One can see peacocks and deers wandering freely. Not a must visit but if time in hand then can be taken up.

title: Historical place near Port Blair
review_text: Ross island once housed the British and later Japanese now we can see the ruins is a must see place when you are in Port Blair. 10 mins by ferry. Entry ticket of Rs 30 and extra charge for camera. Maintained by Indian Navy. Best way to see the place is to walk around. Also for people who hate walking there are cabbies to take you around.

title: nothing but old crumbling British era buildings
review_text: This island is just across from Port Blair.. actually nothing here to see except for ruins of old British era buildings even the beach is unfortunately not accessible due to the Tsunami which had devastated this place. only plus point is the deer, peacocks and rabbits trhat you see moving about freely

title: Fascinating
review_text: Just wandering around Ross Island makes you experience several layers of history. The sound and light show is well worth it. The whole island is now managed by the Indian Navy, so it is clean and well organised.

title: The japanese bunker alongwith dears
review_text:
The beauty of this island lies in the old and ruined buildings of Raj era. you can have a look on them . they could tell you about the barracks of the soldiers of that time. 
there is a sea shore where you can sit and watch the open sea but nothing much to do on this island. The japanese bunker is on display there and in very good condition but dont think actually that it would have been the same in those years. you can have tea there but never forget to have coconut water and feed the dears of the island with leftover cream of the coconut. it is so good for your spirits and for the camera. you can also see the naval boat parked along with the jetty although entry in it is not permitted. this island is covered by the local ferry which conducts the day tour to the island around portblair More

title: Lost world
review_text: You can see the ruins of the old buildings. It is on the way to North Bay Islands. It used to be under British after which Japanese used it for keeping the Prisoners of war.

title: Small place with nice beach on backside
review_text: this is the place from where English ruled......locater in water from all round so very safe as they found this....now a day you find the dears, monkey and remains of church and other offices there.....what it may remind to you is the remains of house in Agneepath (those kind remains).

title: Not that good
review_text: This island is very near to port blair.. only 10 minutes boat ride. Only some ruins and deers. These deers are not afraid of humans and come close. If you have nothing to do ... visit ross island.

title: A great trip
review_text: Ross Island was excellent to visit... with the old english structures, the hidden beach behind the church and lots of peacocks and deers that were eating out of your hands and whom you could pet. Must visit!

title: Great Trip to see the light show
review_text: This place is charming. It is like a scene out of Jungle Book in the city where King Louie lives. The fig trees have taken over the old cottages. It is crazy. There are spotted deer with velvet antlers walking around and they will eat out of your hands. Bunnies roam free. The light show is great in the evening. It tells the history of Port Blair and Ross Island. Very informative! You have to take a very short ferry ride to get there.

title: Nice and clean island with scenic view
review_text: This island is near to Port Blair. Visit this island you can see remaining of British building / Church etc. there is one snacks corner, but don't expect much.

title: Nice beach..
review_text:
This is hardly 10 min away from Port Blair by Jetty. 
You can find Deer, Peacock, Rabbit roaming around you freely. 
Deer are very friendly and you can even touch them if they are calm at that moment. 
Jetty leaves you on this Island for 1-2 hours depending upon your jetty. 
You can also see bunkers build by Japanese govt. way back in 40'. 
Island has got one small restaurant for refreshments and snacks.

title: great
review_text: sound and light show was AMAZING have to watch. went there with my class it is in hindi so hard to understand for some but visuals are really really great. highly recommend

title: Ross Island
review_text: We visited in the morning, got less than 2 hours to see the island, we missed the new sound and light show which is in the evening. Basically it has remains of british constructions. The beach was beautiful, deers roam freely, lots of peacocks to watch.

title: History speaks here
review_text: The old ruins and old roots that run through have a mysterious charm.Lovely to watch the sea as you sit on the rocks.

title: An island with lost ruins, a backyard beach with company of deep bushes,coconut trees and its inhabitant deer & peacocks
review_text: A beautiful island. Has ruins from the British era. Also has lots of deer and peacocks which love some human company and getting clicked!! :) Do carry a water bottle to stay hydrated! ANd there is a kulfi wala, must try!!! it was awesome

title: Loved the beauty of the island
review_text: This island was developed by japanese during their rule at port blair.. Its been protected and maintained by govt. now.. its neat and clean.. different from other islands in the sense that there are not any water sports activity.. u can enjoy and roam around whole island watching church, japanese bunker, etc. its beautiful.. i loved it..

title: Light and sound show ross island.
review_text: We went there in evening to see light and sound show.this show was amazing and an excellent opportunity to know about the history of ross Island.even local people doesn't have knowledge about this. Tickets are available in the tourist department near district court. Value for money. And must see.I want to see again. Lyrics by Gulzar. Song was also good. 3 D animation is iconic. Definitely better than cellular jail light and sound show.

title: History and Beauty
review_text: This place is an island not much for from Port Blair Jetty. A 25-30 seater ship at minimal cost of 50-100 rupees per person takes you to the Ross Island. Has some tourist attraction like church, japanese bunker of world war 2, light house etc.. A small island captured by Japanese army during WW-II. Has a capturing beauty from some points. Must Visit during day time total time you can plan is 3-4 hrs including travelling and visit time. The Jetty from where you board the Ship to visit there are some water sports activity too must try.

title: A peaceful place with cute deers
review_text: It was a part of two island visit and really the place is so beautiful.The Japanese bunkers,Swimming pool,Bakery are worth seeing.Even the nature's beauty can be enjoyed,good for photography.

title: Best for ever
review_text: The island located 5 minutes distance from Port Blair.locaton was perfect with greenery,seaface.this is also a historical spot.bettery riksha were availabled for transport.a cafeteria also available here which provide snacks and beverages on a reasonable price.night stay here is not permitted.northway island situated on 5 minutes distance from here.

title: Amazing place
review_text: Rich heritage, naval base, scenic beauty, pristine beach, tsunami wreckage, wild animals, corals observation, cruise ride, water scooter ride.

title: vacation trip
review_text: one hour they are giving to stay on Ross island is not enough to visit.British ancient culture amazing to know about.

title: Very Beautiful
review_text: This is very elegant island. You can see real beauty of nature. It was official residence of Britishers. It has old buildings. Beach of Ross Island is very beautiful.

title: historic and animal loving
review_text: It is a small island. you can walk it fully. There is one small beach also available here. you can find plenty of animals also here. like peacock, hen, dears and rabbits. Better to wear shoes when you go here as you have to walk there.

title: beutiful island
review_text: One hour ferry drive from Port blair. Beautiful island. One can enjoy with family. Picturesque background of lush green coconut palms and sea

title: The island of "Lost"!!
review_text: Have you seen "Lost" the TV show? This is exactly the island... Mysterious and beautiful, this island started killing its inhabitants one by one. Now only the remainders of their civilisation is here, eaten up by the lush nature. Impressive, humbling, moving, deep. An absolute must see!

title: Enjoyed walk
review_text: Ross Island is an island with beautiful view. There is a small museum displaying collection of old Andaman. Lake, peacock and deers.

title: Many deers and peacocks raoming around freely
review_text: I really recommend a visit of this island, if only for the sake of seeing all the wild life that roams around freely here, unafraid of the human intruders into their territory. The deer allow you to stroke them and even pose for photos with you :) You can also spot many peacocks, squirrels, hens and other animals here.

title: A must visit
review_text: It is a must visit place if you are in Port Blair. This place is in ruins but beautifully preserved.

title: Colonial history re-lived
review_text:
Very accessible from port blair thru a ferry. 
Many monuments which remind of british colonial legacy. 
Either trek thru the island or use ecofriendly battery operated cars. 
Abundance of deers, peacocks. 
A giant Indian Flag to welcome as well as see you off.

title: Chance to Re-Live the Fascinating Old Time...
review_text:
Although this Island mainly has Ruins of old buildings, however takes us close to historical time, Club & Church building are the best... 

If you love adventure, can go down back side of Island, Ferar beach which is completely destroyed by Tsunami in December 2004...(be careful, don't go near water, very muddy open sea, very risky) 

Island also has around 30 Deers, roaming freely all around the places, you can even take pictures with them... 

Overall, good place to Chill-Out, can try snacks at only local restaurant there...

title: Fell in love with it!
review_text: On the second day of our trip, we were first taken to Ross Island and I must say I was instantly taken aback by the scenic beauty of the island. We had to pay an entrance of rs. 40 to get into the island. Once inside I instantly fell in love with it. You can find deers, chickens, ducks , birds, peacocks etc all roaming around freely. You can go and hold deers and they will not try to run away from you. Then we got to know a little bit f history also that because of Ross Island, tsunami in 2004 did not effect port Blair much! Also, we could see some old machines or what it is called I don't know why ch could turn salt water into fresh drinking water. There came a point where there was a seating arrangement or rather a bench behind which there was water and nothing else. It was an amazing experience. Also, I would like anyone who visits Ross Island to drink coconut and have kulfi there as it was very yummy..:) More

title: History with a view
review_text: Ross Island is a stunning site to visit. Located a short 5-10min boat-ride across from the Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex & Jetty, this island was home to British occupiers with a gymkhana, church & cemetery as well as a pond & Japanese bunker & bakery that are all almost retaken by nature. With a large herd of deer & several peacocks, the island is teeming with life & natural beauty that warrants a day's venture.

title: Vacation
review_text:
The remains of the island reminds you of the past ! 
Also the deers and peacocks roaming about gives you a special feeling . 
The ride in a battery operated car was worth the ride as it's quite difficult walking through the ups and downs of the terrain there ! 
But not much to explore there as the ferrar beach is closed to public after the tsunami in 2004 . 
The Japanese bunker too gives s peek into the past !

title: Must Visit island and must meet Ms. Anuradha Roy (Navy Guide)
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: Must visit the island and you will be very happy to meet Ms. Anuradha guide. She is very smart, handels and love the animals who stay on that island like deer, peacocks, rabbits, squirrels, birds etc and love them very much...she calls them with voice and all animals come running to her and you will have the pleasure to walk with them, touch them and feed them.

title: Very well maintained, nice historical landmark
review_text: Very clean and well maintained by Indian Navy. They charge Rs. 30/- per head nominal entry fee which is used for maintenance of the island. The island has very old British colony structures now remaining in shambles but clearly give a picture of the colonization in that era. The island currently houses many a deer and peacocks which are human friendly and come very close to you. You are not allowed to feed them. Local tourist guide especially Anuradha Rao as good as talks with these animals and feeds them in front of you so that you can get up close with them. Children really enjoy that. You get a very good view of the sea around and North Bay light house from Ross island which has a high rise viewing point. More

title: Visit it if you have time
review_text: Small island impeccably maintained by Indian Navy. Ross was the earlier capital of Andamans but now deserted. Indian Navy has maintained it quite well. can cover all the attractions in 1 hour. deer, peacocks roam about freely. provides a nice break.

title: Must visit
review_text:
A must visit place. Brief history of time. Photographers will love it. 
Britishers established such a beautiful Colony against all odds.

title: Headquaters for Britishers
review_text:
This Island have old building/barracks & remains of British Officers who stayed to Govern the Islands. Also refered as Venice of East during that period. 

One Should walk to the left of the Magistrate Bunglow to the very end to reach the Lonely Sailor pint . Amazing open view of the sea.

title: The Paris of the East during British India
review_text:
Not to be confused with Ross and Smith island. 
This was one of the most famous island of British India which now lies in much ruin and is used by the Indian defense. 
The island was an epitome of grandness during British rule. Aristocrats lived here and had the best provision. Lovely buildings with grand architectural design were constructed for the British, it even had a church built and a beach on the backside which is now destroyed because of the tsunami. 

On entering the island, one is welcomed by a series of boards that mention the history of the island, followed by a visit to the different aristocratic areas, 
While roaming around, one is greeted by a beautiful herd of spotted deer, rabbits, peacocks etc 
Ross island also has a light and sound show, details of which can be inquired with the guide. 

Another interesting fact is , This island saved Port Blair of much destruction during the 2004 tsunami as it stands in front of Port Blair, this caused much of the beach on the backside of Ross island to be damaged More

title: Historical place
review_text: The island is maintained by the navy, so I expected better management. There are toilets but most of them are sealed off and there is no water or light inside. On the better side, it is a beautiful open space, dotted by tall coconut trees, and deer and peacock roam around freely. In spite of many signs forbidding visitors to feed the animals, they continue to do so. Some of them leave the packets on the ground and the deer chew them too. More bins for garbage disposal must be kept and vigilance needs to be tightened and a heavy penalty must be levied for littering.

title: Old is Gold
review_text: This island was the capital in ancient times before Port Blair came into prominence. The island possesses all the remnants of old ear gone by. There is a bakery, distilling plant, swimming pool, light house, etc. The entire past era can be felt at this place. Its a wonderful place to visit. A boat ride of around 15 minutes from Port Blair takes you to this island. A 2 hour stay at this island would be good for seeing the interesting bits of this place

title: Beautiful british era island
review_text:
This island is located around 800 meters from Port Plair, accessible only through ferries, which can be booked and boarded from Rajiv Gandhi Water sports complex. Entry ticket to island is Rs 30/person, available at entrance of the island. Walk along the well laid paths to see the ruins of british era buildings, officers sleeping quarters, japanese bunkers, helipad, ferar beach, deers, peacocks, rabbits, huge trees and fiery red ants. 
There's a small restaurant at this island, which is good for samosas, chai, cup noodles and other such things. Also available on the island are coconut water vendors and delectable kulfi. However, i advise to always carry some food (bread butter/chips/puff etc available in port blair bakeries) with you wherever you go in Andamans. 

The toilet facility is well maintained. No Wifi anywhere on the island. 

There's also a sound and light show in he evening, the tickets for which can be bought at the tourist center at Port blair. The ferry leaves from the jetty at 5:30 PM. However, I decided at the last minute to visit the show, and the ferry person arranged for my tickets (rd 275/person, including boat ticket, entrance ticket and sound and light show fees). The show ends at 7 PM and is a visual delight with animations. Boat arrives back at sports complex around 7:30 PM More

title: japanese hiistory.. muust visit
review_text: its a must visit destination.. a short boat ride around 15 mins from water sports complex.. this is a historic site.. old ruins of Japanese and British rule.. deers n peacocks..

title: Great island for fauna
review_text: This is a great island for fauna. You will find deer, rabbits & peacocks. Apart from this, the island is maintained by Navy, hence you will get an insight into the role of this island during the independence struggle days. The sea is clear, so you can see a good number of small fishes swimming.

title: Beautiful place.
review_text: Good place to relax . Its a small island .Seaside is photogenic.Deer and Peacocks can be seen. Half day is sufficient . Aftersome time it fills boaring.

title: Remnants of a once bustling island
review_text: Ross Island was once a bustling island before it was washed out by an earthquake. Now all that remains are remnants of a once busy island. Bakery buildings, and officer houses still exist with creepers all over them. Peacocks and deer aplenty on the island.

title: Historical place
review_text: A peaceful Island to enjoy company of Peacock and Deers with children.History of Island is interesting.

title: Beautiful place
review_text: Half a day should be good enough to see this place. Though there is no beach here, it;s a nice place to roam around and relax.

title: Nothing interesting
review_text: avoidable as there is nothing much and no places to eat. Not much time to explore either. the old monuments have not been maintained

title: Beautiful island to walk
review_text: This is a pretty small peaceful island around 10 mins for Port Blair, where British officers used to stay. You can cover it by walk, its hardly 1 km. There are ruins of some old buildings. There is also a very nice sand beach on the back side. You can see lots of deers, peacocks in the open.

title: Beautiful walk in serene locale, even though in ruins
review_text:
I don't understand how can such a place of such historic signifance(capital of British in Andamans, held under Japanese also) be a 'private property'. 
My toddler enjoyed playing and chasing deer, hens, rabbits etc. The combo trip(north bay + ross) operators did not allow more than 1 hour here(understandably as there are no commercial incentives for them). With a family including senior citizens and a toddler, we did not have confidence to walk around the whole place in that time. 
But the place is very scenic(no beaches, nothing except tender coconut water to consume) and thoroughly enjoyable, and relaxing. 
Sufficient tree cover that you do not also feel the heat.

title: Ruined Paris of the East
review_text:
A visit to the Ross Island using inter island ferry service revealed a ruinous glimpse of 'the Paris of the East'. Ross was across the waters from Port Blair that housed the Cellular Jail, and was used for British residences. It had its church, clubs (separate for Senior and Subordinate Officers of the British Army), a graveyard that bore the memories of a lot of young lives lost on this tropical island owing to malaria and other water borne diseases and of course, the Japanese bunkers built during the 3 year occupation of the islands by the Japanese, during the Second World War. 

What came as a complete surprise was that the island was teeming with deer, peacocks, pea hens and rabbits- each seemed to have chalked out their undisputed territories. These roamed around the island, now protected by the Indian Navy, without batting a lid at the hordes of tourist eyes, staring them down and clicking selfies. 
Though Ross Island was now in ruins, its very location had saved Port Blair from being destroyed by the tsunami in the recent past. The roots of its very very old trees ,enmeshed with the overflowing branches, to make a ‘junglee’ lattice that housed the peacocks and other species on the island. Maybe they even stood forth as bulwarks against the might of a tsunami! More

title: Nice buildings !!
review_text: Nice cool locations for photos and there is a history associated with this place. please hire a guide which will be useful.

title: Ross island
review_text: It was like a museum , It was nice to spend an hour or so , after that it gets quite boring. However enjoyed the huge coconut water out there .

title: Rich but poor
review_text: Sailing over the sea and arriving at the island place you amidst the roaming Deer and Peacocks.Seaside is photogenic.The monumental dwellings are feast for Archaeologists' eyes but not for tourists'.

title: Lovely place for photography
review_text: Ross Island is a great place to visit if you are interested in natural photography. The huge trees with their exposed roots are really something very unique. Also, the old heritage buildings and the coastline is a treat to watch and take photographs. The coastline view is breathtaking.

title: Opposite of Cellular Jail
review_text:
Its very small island, impacted with Tsunami. But it's How Royal life style British had when Freedom Fighter life was hell. 
I am mix reaction to say good or bad 
So I suggest you visit and decide as their are many things with History Behind. 

Do meet Anuradha Rao Local Guide but superb women to meet.

title: Simply loved this island
review_text: This island located at a distance of 20 minutes ferry ride from Port Blair is one of the most beautiful Andaman Islands. This island is very well maintained and plastic free zone. You cannot carry any polythene bags or plastic bottles to this island. The island is covered with greenery and has good collection of flowering plants. Deer, peacocks, rabbits etc. can be seen. Ruins of some buildings of the British period is also seen here.

title: Nostalgic trip
review_text: Have visited Ross several times earlier but the last trip was 11 years back. It used to be an unkempt abandoned island 30 years back..This place is under the "Indian Navy" and you really get to see responsible tourism here. The "Light and sound show" is better than the one at cellular jail, written by Gulzaar and presented in the voice of Shabana Azmi.

title: Beutiful
review_text: One of the beautiful place to see.It's a very small island.British soldiers stayed here and monitored the whole island.Japanese bunkers are there.This will show you the second world war memories.

title: Superb!
review_text:
Its a good island. It is maintained by Indian Navy. There is old church and buildings by British and Japanese Army Bunker. You'll see deer, peacock, rabbits etc there in the island. Beautiful island for time pass. 

There is some entry fee for travellers. Defence persons and families will get 50% discount in entry fee by showing Armed Forces ID card.

title: Nice Attraction
review_text: We visited Ross Island on our vacation in Oct'16. The island is about 15-30 mins away from Port Blair by ferry. If you like animals, you will surely like this place. Deers, Rabbits and Peacocks are in plenty here and roam freely. In fact, we even touched the deers. Apart from the animals, this place has some ruins, monuments and Ferar (white sand) Beach which is beautiful and has few people. Do visit this place as it will take only 3-4 hours of your time but will leave you with some good memories to cherish.

title: Must Visit
review_text: This island saved Port Blair from fatal destruction during the 2004 Tsunami strike. Do pay tributes by spending quality time here.

title: A glimpse into British revelry in India
review_text: Called Paris of the East, the island is like a fossilised capsule of British revelry in India. Difficult to understand, without a guide or prior reading. I was lucky to have watched a documentary on the island, before I visited and therefore, enjoyed it more. Needs atleast 3-4 hours, to be viewed completely at a leisurely pace. Boat trips combine it with trip to North Bay, but best to do it as a separate day trip, as it becomes a very rushed visit, otherwise.

title: Most beautifyl place
review_text: It is a small island 3km away from PortBlair Ferry service costs Rs 90 and there are 5 ferry timings with a gap of one hour. good place for water activities like skuba diving,snorlking and other activities.

title: The Most Beautiful Place I've Ever Seen....Ever.
review_text: When our boat reached the Ross Island Boat Harbor, I didnt think there was anything of significance on this Island. After all, it looked pretty ordinary from the outside and all I've heard about Ross was that there was a Japanese Bunker there...not something that made me really enthusiastic to visit Ross. But we've all heard of the phrase, " Don't judge a book by it's cover" and so when we reached Ross, checked out the Japanese Bunker (it's ceiling was too low; maybe the Japanese people of that time were really short) and finally went further in, we were only to be awed. The island was full of deer. White spotted deer were spread all over the island. Couple of times we even saw albino rabbits darting around. And if that wasnt wildlife enough on this island, you can see flocks and flocks of Peacocks and peahens. And as the island wasn't much big, we finished sightseeing in about 30 minutes. I had the best experience in Ross and I enjoyed my time time there and I know you going to too! More

title: a perfect place to relax
review_text: scuba diving is an attraction over here and jet sking and speed boats too . all water sports are mainly here.scuba diving videos are also given to you

title: A tourist attraction in Andaman
review_text: It is a small island 3km away from PortBlair Ferry service costs Rs 90 and there are 5 ferry timings with a gap of one hour.It was a place for enjoying life for the British residents. It had a a very good bakery, a water treatment plant, a swimming pool ,cemetery and tennis court.During World War2, Japanese occupied it and made bunkers.There nothing much to see except the remains of the buildings.in decayed state.

title: An Okay Island
review_text: It is a OK island and not as popular or worth a visit as North Bay or Havelock but most probably it will be included in your ferry to North Bay

title: Good starting point in island section
review_text: This island gives you a really welcome feeling is island section.I really amaze to see this island first as this was my first vist to any island.But once I visited to Redski Neil and havelock I recommended this as an average

title: nice place to visit
review_text: the island was inhabited by Britishers and a nice place to visit to know indian history. Ms Anuradha is the guide here and is very kind. she even talks to the animals here( including deer, rabbits, birds etc.). she is the one looking after the island now. the island has a very nice light and sound show. dont miss out on this.

title: Lost city
review_text: This is a mini version of something like Angkor Wat in Combodia. You are only allowed there for a few hours, but it is all worth it!

title: A place that talks history
review_text:
This place is very close to Port Blair and can be reached by a cruise or a speed boat. The best thing here is to take the guide and listen to how she explains things. We really liked hiring a private guide by name Anuradha Roy and really enjoyed listening to her. 
The place shows the british ruins and a beautiful animal habitat.

title: Great Island to explore
review_text:
Ross Island was the former Capital of the Andamans and therefore there is a lot to explore. 
Normally the tour guides / boats first take you to North Bay where they give you a lot of time enticing you to indulge in paid activities there, from which they get commission. 
Then they bring you to Ross Island and the tourists are given only one hour. This is not enough to explore the Island. Not only was this Island the former Capital, but it was of great significance during the second world war, when it was under Japanese occupation. 
Hence one needs a lot of time to explore the entire Island. It is better to take a separate boat to Ross Island so that one has enough time to explore. The trips that take you both to North Bay and Ross Island, basically ignore Ross Island as they cannot get any extra income there. More

title: A place of ruins
review_text: It is a place which can be reached by boats from PortBlair.It is the ruins which is left over here. Nothing great.Can be visited if you have more time.

title: The island of the British remains
review_text: Ross Island was once the capital of Andaman and Nicobar Island having its own history of being one of the most favorite place of the British era. This Island was greatly affected by Tsunami and now only the remains are left. This island is only 15 mins far from port blair and 800 meters in length. You can see a wide variety of birds and deers. The best part was the traveling between the island. Great place for photography and scenic beauty :)

title: Only for ppl with interest in history
review_text:
It is an island near to north bay island and u will advertently end up visiting it on ur way to north bay. 
Ppl who don't like historical places hav little to do here. I liked the island as I luv the whole concept of imagining how things were in those days. 
I wud recommend to take the electric vehicle which costs rs 100 pp. It will take u to the highest point and return back. U can then trek again if u want. V had a small kid who was just interested in the deer present there and hence v did not go to trek again. 

P. S: It is pointless to visit just Ross island for more than 2 hrs. More

title: Nothing special
review_text: Nothing special exvept freely roaming deer and light and sound show ehich is much better than cellular jail.

title: Ross Island - nice attraction
review_text: We went to Ross Island which was erstwhile capital of Port Blair during the British regime. Now a days you can see some ruins of british - time buildings & churches & a good deer & Peacock collection.

title: Lonely island
review_text:
You can reach Ross island from the Marine complex jetty through boat by morning. Usually they carry around 20-25 passengers in the boat and would reach in 5-10 minutes. And about the island, entrance ticked is issued in the form of smart card (Keep it safe as you need to return it on exit) you will be welcomed by spotted deer, peacock and some rabbits. 
Basically this island was the erstwhile capital for the British settlers, where you can see their buildings but now in ruined state where only the walls are remaining and that too tree roots covering it. The silent atmosphere and the structures will give you a halloween effect. At the hill top there is again a ruined church structure, which is a must see. 
The other side you can find a small seashore but you need go down through steps from the hill. The island has a small pond and an Indian flag flying high nearby. 
Kids and photo enthusiast would love this place. More

title: Worth seeing

title: Family group
review_text:
Ross Island is one of the most popular place in port blair. People who visit port Blair should.not miss this place.

Also places of Queen and play ground like cricket . Park, Church many more was placed. And beautiful view of cellular jail from this island is also available.

title: Family visit to Andaman - Ross Island
review_text: Nothing much of entertainment, but enjoy the scenic beauty , lavishness of Britishers PRE-independence time - church, commissioner bungalow.

title: An alluring island
review_text: This is one of the small Andaman island located in close proximity to Port Blair. You can take a ferry to reach here from the jetty near the Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex. This island was an important hub during the colonial settlement but what remains today is ruins of buildings. Ruins of British period buildings - hospitals, market etc. can be seen. There is a museum here which has pictures showcasing the different activities taken up by the colonial rulers in the Andaman and specifically Ross Island. The whole island is covered with greenery. There are flowering plants, shrubs and we also got to see deer wandering about in between human population. More

title: Abandoned yet Beautiful
review_text: It gives a different look from a distance like that of an abandoned and doomed Island but once you visit it, you would see deers roaming in the middle and the old monuments like the church and offices are nice to capture in your camera. Especially the old distillery made by British.

title: An island to explore
review_text: It can be reached by a speed boat or by a local cruise. The timings can be checked at the ticket counter. Usually the speed boat drops the passengers on the island in morning and comes back to collect the passengers in evening. There are many things to do in the island. There are ruins of British colonies beautifully entrapped by the huge tree roots. This makes for a very good spot for photography. There is a small museum and a cafeteria. Walk along the front beach or go deep into the forests and explore the more hidden and isolated beaches. Its a good place to trek as well as to relax on the scenic beaches. More

title: A must visit place in Port Blair
review_text: This is a must visit attraction for a half day tour located at a 15-min distance by boat from Port Blair. The greenery and the wildlife (deers, peacocks) here is amazing, its like being in a different place altogether. You can have a short tour of the island and see the ruins of British era buildings and houses which is really amazing! Make sure u leave in the morning as no ferrys are available in the afternoon.

title: Little Paris!
review_text: Rightly called so in gone by days. Britishers lived a lavish life using freedom fighters and other prisoners as their salves. It includes swimming pool, power house, water filtering plant, bakery, club, church, tennis lawn, pond, cemetery, beach, Japanese bunkers in destructed condition. Well planned by Britishers, beautiful built by unskilled Indian prisoners, destroyed by Japanese in WW II & currently maintained by Indian Navy.

title: Definitely worth a visit from Port Blair
review_text:
This is a very small island and I think I managed to do a lap of the inner path in about 20 minutes. There are a few interesting things to see, there's a pool inland, some beautiful trees and foliage. There was at least one very tame deer who sat there quite peacefully while we touched him gently and posed for photos 

If you're in Port Blair and have time, it's well worth adding this to your island tour as this can be done as part of a day trip with North Bay island (where scuba diving can be done). Tourist information in the town centre in Port Blair sell tickets for all these activities, the scuba diving tickets are refundable if you get change your mind about the scuba diving More

review_text: Jet ski, wildlife, British history, water ridings, sea beach with a beautiful view in Port Blair near cellular jail. Must to visit if you are in Port Blair

title: More of a park
review_text: This is a beautiful island located close to Port Blair City. It takes about 20 minutes to reach here on a ferry from Port Blair. Ross Island is a very small island. There are ruins of some of the brick buildings seen here which date back to the British period. There is a museum which has collection of some photographs of the British people and events in the Ross Island. The island is lush green with beautiful gardens and home to animals like Deer, Rabbits and Peacocks.

title: Salute the National Flag and Enjoy the beach opposite side
review_text: Enjoyed the beach opposite side to Ross Island. You need to climb up and go down to reach the small, pristine beach. Just felt like being in a romantic place. Its a faraway beauty. Nice indeed.

title: Beautiful place to spend your day relaxing in nature
review_text: Like my title says, its a beautiful place to spend your day relaxing in nature. We saw flying peacocks, old ruins, deers running around and a crystal clear blue beach with varied colours.You can check my blog for some happy pictures of this place.

title: Ross Island - Part of India's Freedom Struggle
review_text: Ross Island is a nice island. This island can be reached by ferry from Port Blair which takes about 25 minutes. This island was occupied by Japanese forces in WW II. There are several Japanese bunkers. There are relics of different monuments build during Japanese occupation. You will have to visit this island by walking and to cover the entire island you need minimum 1 hrs 30 minutes. Must visit attraction.

title: Heritage site
review_text: Great place for photo opportunities. Good place to spend 2-3 hours. Very well maintained and good treking place. Carry water bottles and enjoy chai at the shack.

title: Land of Coconut Tree
review_text: An island with full of coconut tree. If you want to taste, you should pay Rs.30/- for one. You can also see wild deer, open air theater, an old church, Japanese bunkers and some historical signage's etc etc.

title: Never Miss this place if you visit andamans

title: Average
review_text:

You can walk around the island in an hour. There were ruins of building from Britishers time and some deers, peacocks, rabbits etc. 
There was no restaurant when we travelled. Just some stall with snacks and coconut water. So plan accordingly.

title: Lovely little historic place
review_text: Just a short trip away from Port Blair, has historic importance. Lot of old buildings, churches and clear beaches make this place a surreal hike. Amazing flora and fauna.

title: Peaceful place in port blare

The most beautiful place in Port-Blare. 
In Rose Island you can see how the British use to enjoy their stay in India.

title: Pearl in ocean around Port Blair
review_text:
5 minutes ferry drive away from port blair jetty having Rajiv Gandhi idol, Ross island is very well kept by Indian Navy & has deers, peococks roaming freely around you. It has ruins of commisiner bungalow, church, lake, swimming pool, backery & Japanese bunker with well displayed boards describing history of times. Japanese between 1942 to 1945 kept island under possesion, snatching it from British without huge violent war & left it post bombing on Hiroshima Nagasaki. 

Nice milk kulfi & coconut water is aavailable at reasonable price. You need 1.5 hour for visit. Excellent experience.

title: Destroyed Glory
review_text: A short 30 mins ferry takes you to this place right opposite to the cellular jail. It hosted lots of buildings which are destroyed but still some Japanese bunkers are left. The other side of the island has even cleaner waters.

title: nice place to visit

title: A good Place to Visit!
review_text: I booked ticket through Island Boat Operator for 600 INR for 2 Island i.e. Ross and North Bay Island, the ferry takes from Rajiv Gandhi Water sports complex. It was British habitat to British and Japanese in past.Evening Light show is conducted everyday,though i wasn't able to attend.

title: Fun time
review_text: The island is extremely popular and lots of tourists are also seen here. Water is as clear as mirror and is very well maintained.

title: Ross island-a must visit destination
review_text: Going by a small self chartered boat is worth the experience they charge 1000 INR for a return journey.800 metres distance from rajiv Gandhi water sports complex. And the island in itself is less than 1sq. Km in area.Great to see reindeer and peacocks in open habitat. rest is the thing to experience it's worth a visit,its different

title: A colonial Island
review_text:
Ross Island was a British administrative base at one point of time.The whole island has no beach but old British building ruins and a good garden where one can enjoy a long walk .Currently it is under control of the Indian Navy which has a office structure and some guestrooms there. 
The perfect outing includes getting packed lunch and enjoying it in the lush green lawns and thereafter taking a long stroll and interacting with the deer and occasionally feeding them as well. 
The island can be reached by ferrys which ply from Port Blair to Ross and the tickets have to be pre-booked.

title: Lunch and a stroll makes it perfect on Ross
review_text: Take some lunch and stroll around the lush green beaches lined up with long drawn tress and white sand. Its the closed you get away from Port Blair but thats where you start! Enjoy some good food and you can possibly head out to Corbyns Cove as well once done. Its an amazing treat to see the water lapping and the corals look pretty neat on your way to this little island

title: Ross tilted Island
review_text: After being devastated by an earthquake in 1941, the whole island titled on one side. It has been the administrative center of Andaman Islands under British and hence has number of ruminants of their colonial past. These include ruins of the church, a cemetery, old bakeries etc. It has beautiful beaches, number of dears and gardens. Currently the Indian Navy maintains the island and tourist need to sign-in while entering the Island.

title: Excellent place. Wowsome beach...
review_text: I had visited this place with my family for vacation.These are remains of a once flourishing British settlement. the beach is picturesque and clean. It is bordered by wonderful coconut trees and greenery. A must visit place in Port Blair

title: Worth visiting
review_text: This tiny island is slightly different from others as it don’t have beach life. But you will be pleased to see when a big family of deer’s coming to you to welcome once you enter the island. Peacock and rabbit will surprise you in some places. The main attraction is a ruin of Church, a beautiful pond, nice view, wild deer.

title: History unveiled
review_text:
Its an Indian Navy maintained island with strict monitoring. Entry tickets and camera charges need to be paid at entry. 
Regular ferries are available from PB-Ross-NB-PB at just Rs. 350 per head. Life jackets are provided but in very dirty conditions. 
Tickets are issued from Water sports complex at PB in the morning of travel date. Pre books not reqd as plenty of boats run in the circuit. 
Historic island with ruins of British and Japanese settlements standing as testimony to their rich presence in the island centuries ago. But the time alloted to visit the island is too less compared to the amount of things to be seen. Do not miss to try Kulfis by the hawkers. 
Be careful to mark the name of ur boat as u cannot board another boat to PB. The announcement system is very poor and its solely traveller's responsibility to get into the ferry. Jetty is concrete made and easy to use. More

title: Good place to visit
review_text: If you are on a trip to andaman and nicobars, then it is a must visit place. Marked with historical ruins, it was once the headquarters of the british govt which was later shifted to port blair. There is a small meuseum too to visit.

title: Time Capsule from Britsh Aristocracy
review_text: A visit to Ross Island (a must for anyone visiting Port Blair) is an amazing trip back in time to the hey-day of British Aristocracy during the British Raj. While it is amazing to see how nature has reclaimed this Ghost Town in just 70-odd years, it is equally amazing to get a glimpse of the opulence in which the British elite stayed on this Island (then nicknamed 'Paris of the East'). It would be worthwhile to consider a day trip to this island to fully experience all the historical buildings present here and marvel at the exceptionally modern and self-sufficient infrastructure. At the same time, not to be missed is the breathtaking Light-and-Sound Show of the Island. Tickets for all these including to and fro ferry are available at the Office of the IP&T Ministry at Port Blair, and are best booked in advance. More

title: Good Island with a historical importance to Andamand
review_text: Island is quite clean with reins of British Structures, this island was the administrative centre for Britishers for Andaman many of the structures are still in good condition which narrate the history in itself. The best is deers, peacocks which are inhibited here in open natural area and you can easily spot them here n there.

title: Perfect place and a must visit destination
review_text: This is a must visit island. this was the capital of Andaman islands during colonial empire. One can easily spot the remains of the colonial buildings here. Water treatment plant used by Britishers to convert the salt water to sweet water and other buildings are present there. DON'T FORGET TO TAKE GUIDE. Only available guide is a lady who will help you to interact with the animals and birds on the island, She is care taker of these animals and to my surprise these animals also listens to her and follow her instructions. She will also have you feed these animals with the special bread she have. So don't miss the main attraction here the deer, rabbits, peacocks and other birds. More

title: A peaceful and nice island!
review_text: A scenic island 2 km of Port Blair city. A peaceful place away from the hustle and bustle of city. The commute from the city to island is through a ferry which ply on a regular basis. It is a lovely place to spend few hours and learn about its history. The whole island can be covered in 1-1.5 hours. Don't forget to visit a quite and serene beach located just at the back of the island. A staircase goes down to this beach. Last few steps of this staircase are missing, so it requires a slight acrobatic stuff from your end (be careful).

title: Ross Island
review_text: It is great Island. but you have to do plenty of trekking to cover all the places. We did not cover everything. You can have a nice view of Rabbits & one Deer.

title: A lovely way to spend half a day
review_text: We had four hours to kill before our flight and we took a trip to Ross Island. We hired our own boat for Rs.1500 so that we could be sure to return whenever we wanted to. The island was quiet with beautiful shady walkways and plenty of dilapidated buildings. Apparently Ross Island was the seat of government when the British came to Andaman Islands. From the layout we could decipher that it must have a hive of activity in those days. We hopped onto a battery car which zipped around and stopped in front of various buildings. There are neat signs which explain what each structure was used for. What was most interesting was to see huge trees growing from the roofs and the massive roots completely encircling the structure. There is lovely lotus pond with two sit-outs on either end. There are plenty of deer which seem especially fond of tender coconut pulp!! However it is frightening to see visitors handle them carelessly as the antlers can do quite some damage. I really wish the authorities would warn people from handling these animals. We saw a peacock dancing with its plumage fully exposed and it was pretty sight in the green foliage of the dilapidated Secretariat building. We resolved to return to Ross Island during our next trip and do a leisurely tour of the island on foot - definitely a fun thing to do. More

title: Peaceful Island / Photographic View
review_text: We have travelled ferry to the island. An excellent island & fantastic sight scenery / view from the jetty. Very prime location for photography. his island was really calm and clean. can find more deer and peacock and definitely my kids loved much

title: Remnants of a glorious past
review_text: Ross island is at a 5 min ferry journey from Port Blair. It was the headquarters in British time. What lies now is thr ruins of it and it seems almost poetic how nature has taken over the man made structures. There are plenty of places to visit there the church, the ferrar beach, thr Water sterilisation plant, the diners club, the cemetery etc. If you love to draw or to capture photos this is heaven.

title: Lovely spot and lots of ruins
review_text: An excellent island away from the mainland. Loved the travel by ferry to the island. This island was really calm and it was great to see the main land from here. Dont miss the Japanese bunkers here.

title: Peaceful Island-Recommended to visit
review_text:
We reached Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex in Port Blair at 9:30 am from where we were supposed to go to ROSS island and NORTH BAY CORAL ISLAND. Ross Island is 15-20 min away and you need to walk on the island to explore it. British use to stay here before they came to Port Blair. It had some great old trees and some really big coconut trees. You can see a lot of deer roaming here. Island has a total of 400 deers. Don't miss to have coconut water here. You can see some of the old structures like water distillation plants, swimming pool etc., which were used by Britishers. 
In my opinion unless you are really out of time, you must visit this island as it gives a flavour of how people use to live here and has immense greenery and animals (deer, rabbit etc.). Ferry that will come here form Port Blair will give you approximately 90 minutes-2 hrs after which you need to head back to the ferry. 
Entry ticket to this island is INR 30. Ferry which takes you to Ross Island also takes you to North Bay island (assuming your tickets is for both islands) and it costs a total of INR 550. More

title: Rose Island in Andaman
review_text: Beautiful place to visit.We went through boat from port blair.It has many more deers with garden.People ca touch the deer and give some food just like cows.Childrens enjoyed well.

title: A good spot
review_text: It is a tourist spot in Andaman and nicobar islands. It has a historical story. When Japanese invaded Andaman islands, they would stay at Ross island. You have to take a boat to reach there. It is good as a trek. It has ruins of houses and everything. If you don't have much time in Andaman islands, I would recommend you to skip this place.

title: Nice place to relax
review_text:
We visited this place in February so it was a bit hot. But one feels cool at this island because of the trees there. It offers you the ruins of old buildings, giving one a peep into the past. We also spotted some deer there. It is easily approachable by a jetty from Port Blair. 

P.S. Take some water and food with you.

title: Worth Visit
review_text: It takes about 10 minutes To Ross island from Port Blair. The island represents the structures of British period which are ruined now. The island also has a beautiful hidden beach. A worth visit. Highly recommended

title: the smallest island
review_text: This is the smallest island and very close to port blair. jetty are available to this island. very quite island. you can walk the whole island in just 1 hour. many old workshops of british era are here

title: Must visit island. Spare two hours to the minimum
review_text:
People get off immediately to get into the buggy that will take you around the island. Once that is filled you are on your own. There was a empty buggy and on enquiry, he said he was a official but he took around another group that came later who must either be some officials family making using of the tax payer money or the official using the tax payer money to make some money for himself!!! 

The free roaming animals on the island are quite an attraction - especially for the little ones. Deers, peacocks, rabbits all roaming freely. Its a first for me. The walking takes some effort as some of the pathway is sloped. There is a small beach here on the opposite side of the entry point to the island. If only i had more time. My tour operator - Andaman excursions - arranged tickets for the unscheduled light and sound show on the island which was quite a visual and narrative treat. Be prepared for the mosquitoes once it gets dark. More

title: Beautiful Island at heart of Portblair
review_text: Nice island at heart of Portblair. Very close to Cellular jail. Worth a vist when you travel Andaman.

title: A heritage site
review_text: Ross Island has now ruins after Tsunami disaster, which saved the port Blair from major catastrophe. The island has many wild bears moving around the visitors fearless. A nice place to visit for 3-4 hours, but with guide, who navigates us through the memory lane of past.

title: One of the beautiful Andaman Island
review_text:
This is a must visit island during a visit to the Andamans. One could reach the island by taking a ferry from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex jetty in Port Blair. The ferry takes about 15 to 20 mins to reach the island from the jetty. The Ross Island is a small island which can be covered on foot. They is no other commute option available there. Once we walk into the island from the jetty area, we get an insight into the island's past. It was the head quarters of Indian Penal Settlement established by the Britishes for settlement of Indian criminal convicts in Andamans, distant away from the country across the sea. We can see remnants of old buildings which once housed bazaar, hospital, cemetry, church etc. built for penal settlers. There is a museum which has pictures of the British period and activities carried out in Andaman Islands in the past. The island has several Japanese bunkers and tunnels. The island is green and has thin forests - really good collection of flora here. Several different trees can be seen here. There are deer and stags roaming around freely. The deer here seems to be not scared of humans. They do not run away even when visitors are close to them. Peacocks can also be seen here. The edges of the island provide wonderful view of the sea and other islands - Viper Island and North Bay... This is a must visit island during a visit to the Andamans. This place is full of coconut tress, deers, rabbits and peacocks.

title: Calm and beautiful
review_text: This place can be visited only by Ferry which would take around 15 to 20 mins depending on the ferry you take. Its good for 2 to 3 hours visit. Other than the bakery all other building are in ruin. Dilapidated Church was little eerie and the small beach behind the church was pleasant with good view. Island is very well maintained and the last ferry out of this island is at 4.30. There is lot of deers in this island. More

title: Peacefull time with family

However the evening night and sound show is better than cellular jail light and sound show.

title: Magnificent and Historical
review_text: This is a MUST visit if your are travelling to Andaman, if not for anything else, then also certainly for the wonderful Light and Sound Show put up there. Apart from the British constructions that include secretariat and club, besides power house and church, there is also a Japanese bunker. You would spot a few deer and peacocks, the only inhabitants now.

title: " Creepy Haunting and Different "

review_text: Ross Island is one among the historical place all will love to visit. It was the former capital of the Andaman & Nicobar Island, Port Blair. The scenic view from here are so nice to see and enjoy. More

title: beautiful place with lot of trees and animals
review_text:

Kids too would have lot of fun here. Make sure you carry some snacks as you would be tired roaming about on this island. Sad to know the history of this place (no freedom fighter could escape from cellular jail. Even if escaped they had to cross Ross island and in turn would be killed or caught by the britishers. Wonder why human beings are so cruel!!) 
Visited in May end 2016 More

title: memorable history lost...
review_text:

title: Colonial glory gone wild
review_text: This is a weird and fascinating place. A small island from where the British ruled the Andamans. Now the colonial buildings, including a church, barracks and governor's mansion, are roofless and decaying. Trees grow in and around them, their roots entwining themselves around pills and posts. It's spooky. And there's an old British cemetery. Decaying and vandalised, sad and moving. Ross Island took the full force of the tsunami and you can walk down steps to the sea front to see the damage to the sea walls caused on that dreadful day. But Ross Island saved Port Blair and for that all the islanders are grateful. Well worth a visit. Take lots of bottled water. Some of the trips to Ross take in a detour (40 minutes) to Viper Island. This is the site of an old penal colony run by the British. The gallows still stand on top of the hill... More

title: Ross Island ,ruins of British era
review_text: It takes just ~15 minutes by ferry boat to reach Ross Island. Try to get guide Smt Anuradha Rao can be your best guide explaining British life of the island , different structure on the island , Tsunami effect on the island. If you are travelling with kids it will be memorable as Smt Anuradha will give call to animals on the island & animals like deers , rabits , squirrels , ducks , peacock will come running & kids can feed the with their hands. If visiting on Monday you may find somewhat more rush as other options like Baratang caves , some museums are closed on Monday & tourist have limited options of other places to visit. More

title: A must visit spot where abruptly time has stood still
review_text:
Across the 2 miles of sea by a large boat, from Andaman Sports Complex end at Port Blair, we enter the island, where structures stand, as the British had left, though now raptured in the Angkor Wat style. The delapidated bakery, the Church, water treatment plant, power house, printing press, the Commissioner's bungalow, etc stands as mute witness to tell us the past stories about the activities that had once happened back in history. There are the Japanese bunkers, which tell us about their occupation of the island, between 1942 to '45, when Netaji Subhas Bose had once hoisted the Indian flag there on the Government House. 

The island, surrounded by the blue sea, retains unique charm of unspoilt greenery and foliage, populated by a large herd of spotted deer and many peacocks, roaming free, so much so that you can take selfie with them, if you are carrying the camera (allowed with a fee). 

Two to three hours time would be good enough for the trip, and if lucky, one can witness the light and sound show, if the show is on. As the evening descends, an eerie silence and a haunted feeling grips you. Thus may hurry back home with a great feeling. More

title: Days bygone...
review_text: Close to the mainland, this island has known better days during the colonial rule. It was subject to disasters like an earthquake and the Tsunami. Some of the buildings remain and it is very interesting for those who love history...

title: Beautiful Island
review_text:
Ross Island is a beautiful Island near Port Blair. You can see the island from Marine Park, PB, 
It is a lovely place to spend few hours and learn about the historical importance. 
Ross still has ruins of some of the buildings that were built during British period. Though they have now been engulfed by the roots of huge trees but watching these buildings makes one nostalgic.The place can boast of the ruins of a British Church, Mansion, Market etc. 

There is also a small museum that has pictures taken and drawn in those times. 

The back side of the Ross Island gives a lovely view of the open sea. You can sit for hours reveling in the cool breeze and the amazing sea view. More

review_text: Ross is a beautiful island loaded with history facts & places as it was the headquarter of British empire in andaman islands during pre-independence era. Nice scenic views also available.

review_text: This island was once upon a time a British landing albeit complete with clubs and an open amphitheatre but stands in a dishevelled state today! Nevertheless the sound and light show is a good activity to see here !

review_text: Pre independence British rulers residence/offices, very small in area which first bombed by the Japanees during 2nd World War then by a tsunami. Small battery truck for 6 passengers available for old & physically handicapped persons. One can roam on foot also.

title: Of picturesque views, well preserved ruins and colored waters!
review_text:
Ross Island is just 10 mins by speed boat from the sports complex at Port Blair. You can engage a private operator (book at the sports complex) - for drop/pickup at your convenience. Once at Ross, there are 2 ways to do the tour - a battery operated car (like the ones at the golf course) that takes you around ramps on the island as you pass the heritage sites, OR you walk and explore at your own pace. Strongly recommend that you go for the second option. Not just because its good for you, but more importantly this is the only way you can access some ruins the battery car cant take you to. Places to see at Ross - check out the Japanese WW2 bunker at the entrance, walk across to appreciate the immense and old coconut & palm trees that cover the entire island. As you hear peacocks in the distance, go up ramps leading to the age old distillation plant, and even more steeper ramps leading to the officers & soldiers cantonments. Do not miss a climb up to the ruins of the Commissioner's bungalow, the church at the top, and the Indian Navy outpost at the tip of the island. Its amazing to see how the old trees have made these ruins their own. Few places offer these many opportunities to capture really good pictures of the island & the colorful waters around - from...
