Strongly recommend that you go for the second option. Not just because its good for you, but more importantly this is the only way you can access some ruins the battery car cant take you to. 
Places to see at Ross - check out the Japanese WW2 bunker at the entrance, walk across to appreciate the immense and old coconut & palm trees that cover the entire island. As you hear peacocks in the distance, go up ramps leading to the age old distillation plant, and even more steeper ramps leading to the officers & soldiers cantonments. Do not miss a climb up to the ruins of the Commissioner's bungalow, the church at the top, and the Indian Navy outpost at the tip of the island. Its amazing to see how the old trees have made these ruins their own. Few places offer these many opportunities to capture really good pictures of the island & the colorful waters around - from green to teal to blue & other shades in between. On your way down stop by the coconut vendors where you might spot a few deer eating the sweet coconut cream !! 
There's a lot of walking to do so in summers go early morning or later in the evenings; the elderly should take the battery car. For the rest, enjoy at your own pace. More

title: Good but not great
review_text: Its a good place to visit but nothing great. You need to walk a lot around the island. So if you are visiting in summer beware! There is not much within the island. title: Fascinating for a history aficionado !
review_text: This was the HQ of the Beastly British when they ruled Andaman and is a really interesting place to visit. The Japanese also ruled from here during WW2 and Bhose, the head of the Indian puppet government ( Bhose was intending to hand over India to the Japs after they had driven out the Brits; which they failed to do ) lived here at the time as well. Wonderful wildlife and food & drink are available. Too many steps for anyone with walking difficulties but you can stay at beach level and not climb the steep hill to the British HQ. Most enjoyable.

review_text: Its a good place to go and is clubbed with North bay. the Jetty/speed boat can take you to Ross Island first and then to North Bay or the other way round. It is recommended to go to Ross first and then North bay since water activities are at north bay.

title: Ross Island
review_text: Be sure to check on the website the days & timings. Ross island is closed on a weekday (i think its wednesday but please check again). its a great way to picnic from Port Blair. Kids will enjoy the closeup with deer whom u can also feed.Be sure to have fresh coconut to quench your thirst! Beautiful views of the sea from different angles

title: Beautiful!!!
review_text: Ross island was a great surprise outside Port Blair. It is indeed the best sightseeing when you are there! It's historical and full of animals living free around you... We loved it!!

title: Nice place to spend a day
review_text: This island is controlled by the Indian Navy. 15 minutes ferry ride from Port Blair Maintained neat and clean. Battery operated car takes you to the highest point. A good place to have a family picnic for a day.

title: A walk in the nature
review_text: Before I write about Ross Island I would like to say something about the Islanders. They symbolize a true united INDIA. You ask any islander where are they from and the reply is from HERE( read Andamans) - they may be Bihari, Bengali , Telugu or Tamil . So mainland Indians should take a lesson from them. We took the evening 1600 hrs boat to Ross Island . Roamed around the island interacted with the inmates (read Rabbits, Deers and Peacocks) . Each one has a name and they are very obedient to the guide . Infact the guide told us that just before Tsunami these animals forced them to move to higher grounds thus saving their lives. The Light and Sound show is also worth watching. More

title: Well preserved British settlement ruins
review_text: It was once a center of overweening life of British, is now ruins. The coconut tree filled island was once a place which was known as "Paris of the East". It was once a self - equipped town, ruined initially by an Earth quack and then by Japanese Invasion.It is maintained by Indian Navy and one can see numerous deer and peacocks roaming freely in the lawns. It takes a 10 minute ride from Rajiv Gandhi Sports complex to Ross Islands. You can explore the entire Islands in couple of hours and one must not miss the company of these animals

title: Average
review_text:
This island is 10 mins away (by boat) from Port Blair harbour. This island is not very well maintained. Lot of dirty stuff. 
Guide will tell you that you can see peacocks and deers roaming around freely but there was only one peacock and one dear :) 

One can go to this place as a tick mark.

title: Old British Heritage
review_text: Experience the tattered Ross Island artefacts. A great experience. The deers and peacocks are a novel animals brought by the British in the A&N Islands. These animals roam about freely here.

title: A nice trip.
review_text: Ross island is a must see place. Try to go early. Because its quite sunny out there. Please dont get lured by agents who offer speed boat and special boat. You will get baked in the sun, and its not worth it. Choose govt ferry. Charge Rs. 100 (Return). THey will halt for 2 hrs. We went by jaikar ferry. Ross island tour has good signages, well maintained. You can enjoy the spirit of the old glory. There is an entry ticket of 30rs per head. Camera 30rs. Have a leisurely walk. Deers will come without any fear towards you. THe old church, bakery everything has a charm to it. Enjoy the trip More

title: Beautiful Island of one time now a Tsunami hit island
review_text:
Ross island, a beautiful island which was struck by Tsunami long time back. This place is just 10 minutes away from Port Blair. You need to take a ferry to reach this island. I booked my trip though Dpauls located in Delhi. They did my complete package including all sightseeing tours & transfers. 
Local of Port Blair says that this is the island which reduced the impact of Tsunami coming to hit Port Blair. This island took the major hit of Tsunami and saved lot of lives of Locals staying in Port Blair. History of this place is related to Freedom of India from Britishers rule.

title: Reminder Of British Extravaganza
review_text: Once Administrative Head Quarters and Center of Extravagant Life of British Officials who ruled Andaman Islands is now a showcase of Ruins. 0.65 Square Kilometer of thick forest was cleared and converted to a place which was known as "Paris of the East" using Indian Freedom Fighters who was deported to Andaman Islands as Convicts. Once a buzzing township matched in facility to any modern city was ruined initially by an Earth quack and then by Japanese Invasion. Now it is maintained by Indian Navy

title: History
review_text:
This island is very close to Port blair..a speed boat takes only few minuts to this former capital city.You can take a walk along the well maintained walkway..There are many spotted deers and peacocks in the island. 
Carry some thing to eat as the cafeteria in the island has nothing other than some biscuits

title: Take you time, there's lots to see
review_text: We spent 2 hours here but could of done with staying longer. Very interesting and only a ten min ride from Port Blair. We got conned into taking a speedboat rather than taking the ferry! More expensive, very uncomfortable and it means you are committed to a certain time to return. Ignore the people at the gate, or friends of your taxi driver and head straight to the end of the jetty.

title: Former andaman captial
review_text: This place was the former administrative capital in the Andaman. It's in ruins now. Fun place to visit.

title: Has little of everything!
review_text: Ross island is very close to the city of Port Blair,you can see it from the roof tops of cellular jail.It is small island about .5 km*1 km in area.During colonial rule British built their colonies in this island ,ruins of whom can be found today.The island also has small forest cover which houses small variety of flora and fauna.You can reach this island by small ships and ferries for which you have to do advance booking or else be prepared to stand in long queues. The trip to Ross island is combined with trip to North Bay island.

title: Beautiful
review_text: The abandoned island is filled with memories of british life.. well maintained by indian navy.. greenery and animals like deer, rabbits etc can be seen. The audio visual show is a must watch

title: Only for Visit not For rest
review_text: Whole island as like a museum so as a traveller it's good for single time at whole trip plan but there have no option for take rest or spend your time with blue water.

title: Good place
review_text: There are only ruins of British buildings here. You can just roam around the island look at all the buildings and take pictures.No hardcore adventure here but its not bad to know the history of the place either.

title: Most beautiful island in Andamans
review_text: Disembark from the boat at Ross Island and it is a wonderful sight to see deers, peacocks and hares in the open. Try to book an electric car as soon as you reach the island otherwise it is tiresome to go around on your own. Can be managed though, as the island is quite small. Nothing to eat. Only coconut water and local kulfi ice cream is available. Ross island should be no 1 in the islands to visit in the Andamans.

title: Blast from the past
review_text: The island is visible from Port Blair and a must visit for everyone. After a 30 min boat ride, you find yourself looking at the map pf the premises, which is managed by the Indian Navy - INS Jarawa. The island is very well maintained, except the ruins, which are exactly how they should be. There are several treks, which are easy enough, and are a must do. There is an electrical cart for the elderly, and for the disabled. The ruins have informative boards about them, and the entire experience is wonderful. A must visit.

title: Terrible, Waste of Time
review_text:
Not at all reccomended to visit. 
There is nothing on this island. 
Only waste of time as there is nothing so see here. No canteen to have food or drinks. 
Best place if you want to ruin your day.

title: A Must See Place in Port Blair
review_text: This is by far the best attraction in Port Blair. It takes a 10 min ferry ride to this deserted island, which at one point of time was the capital of the area. Dilapidated buildings with trees growing around them give it an eerie feel. Has wild deer and Rabbits roaming around the island. The light and sound show in the evening is one of the best I have seen and is a must watch.

title: Quiet and Serene
review_text: visit this when there are less crowds(after 3 PM) and you are bound to be mesmerised by the beauty of the sea adjoining colonial era ruins.

title: Ruin of old Andaman Capitol
review_text: We were on a family holiday. Ross is very near to Port Blair. We reached by afternoon and explore the island.Most of the buildings are destroyed by earth quake. Deers and peacocks are roaming freely. You can have a look at Japanese bunker. Most interesting is light and sound program after sun set. It is far better than Cellular Jail.

title: Only beach in Port Blair
review_text: This is only beach in the city. This is at walking distance from Cellular jail and Amusement part is right next to it. The beach is clean and quiet.

title: Paris of East
review_text: It is actually the residential area of the British high official who were responsible to supervise the Cellular Jail. It still reminds about the living standard of the elite people in Andaman long back. The beach is very attractive as well as the design of the establishments

title: very good location
review_text: visit ross island .aware about use of this place for foreigners enjoyment and residential bungalow.maintained as such

title: Ruins....
review_text: With a glorious past, the place is in dilapidated state. On a hot, humid day one can avoid taxing oneself by not visiting this place. You won't miss much.

title: Interesting place
review_text:
One has to take a ferry ride to reach Ross Islands. The ferry ride is comfortable and lasts for abt 15 mins. 

The whole island would take you about 45 mins to walk around. 

Do wear your hat /scarf / sunglasses as it gets very sunny. If you have toddlers with you ; you may choose to carry some tidbits to eat and water to drink as there is nothing much on t island 

The island is filled with deers and peacocks. Though thr are innumerable sign boards suggesting against feeding animals..saw the official tourist guide, Ms Anuradha Rao feeding white bread to peacocks. 
Found tht shocking and no officials, guards or security seemed to care More

title: Scenic beauty
review_text:
Little far from port blair but a picturesque place with ancient history 
Book a good ride connecting the North buoy also if you like the Water sports adventure

title: Not as much cool .. Waste
review_text:
Don't opt to go there .. As it's waste of money using boats and other exhausting urself 
Mostly families visit there with children to show them.the old broken building s

title: Must visit
review_text: Can anyone imagine about water distillary at that time but that is there... History says & pictures proof that beautiful colony was there but Japanese attack destroyed everything

title: Good Historical Sights to visit
review_text:
You can reach this island from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports complex. You can hire tickets from 2 -3 boat operators with different options like 3 islands visits (North Bay, Viper Island or Ross Island) or 1 or 2 islands in combinations. But people mostly visits Ross Island or North Bay combine with Ross Island. 
This place is good to see Old British Monuments, Very Good Beach & mainly visits this place to see Deers which are freely roaming & you can feed them Leaves & will roam freely around you without fear.

title: Place to fall in love with
review_text: This is a beautiful place where nature has encompassed the ruins and made it look appealing. Deer's and Peacocks run freely and show you the way if you are lost (I followed them and directly went into their herd, a bit scared but they are friendly). There's a staircase that leads to the beach, when heading back take the old road next to the end of the stair and it will lead you to the most beautiful view you haven't seen. This place is for romantics, Victorian love affair and drama. This visit is the cherry on top

title: Erstwhile Paris of the East
review_text: Beautiful little island off the coast of Port Blair. The history is fascinating. Not as beautiful as it was in its peak but still a beautiful little island. Deers run free on the island so amazing place to click pics just be careful of the deer antlers!!!

title: Great Heritage Place
review_text:
Last day of our tour, we visited Ross Island. We have to reach this Island by 20 minutes ferry. It is one of the beautiful Island surrounded by blue sea. Not much crowded place. One can see India’s heritage and old monuments here. One can see rabbits and deer’s very closely. We enjoyed by taking selfie with deer’s. We can see places like 
• Water distilling plant 
• Presbyterian Library 
• Commissioners Bungalow 
• Troops Barrack 
• Lone Sailor 
• Ferar Beach 
• Smritika Museum 
• Japanese Bunker 
• Cemetery 
Same ferry will take you back after 1 hour. It is very difficult to walk along all these area during hot summer. Aged persons may find it difficult to climb. They have facility of mini battery operated cab, which will take you to all places. 
No sports activity in this Island. Swimming is prohibited in this island. Coffee shop available Inside the Island. No need to carry any snacks or water. 
LIGHT & SOUND show available at night. We could not see it as we visited in day time. 
Worth visiting this Island. We enjoyed this seeing a heritage and old monuments More

title: Wow!!
review_text: Travel Andaman... But if you miss this place, it will make no sense coming here. Go to Ross Island and enjoy corals.

title: Light and sound show
review_text: Excellent show and is better than similar show at cellular jail.Hightime the show is made more livelier at cellular jail

title: Masti mood
review_text: All family members enjoyed a lot. Make a trip by fary to see the natural beauty of island, and as a part of India it is a heritage,old monuments,and you can also view the destoriation by sunami here and the experience was speechless.

title: well maintained historical spot
review_text: We visited the island on the 4th day of our Andaman tour. Its a beautiful island surrounded by blue sea. There are lot of green, mainly coconut. Restricted entry with adequate control is appreciable for maintaining its clean image. We could not see the LIGHT & SOUND show as we visited it before noon. there were many deer which is an added attraction.

title: Beautiful tiny island
review_text: This was one of our favourites among the islands visited by us in our trip to Andaman. One can see peacocks,rabbits,deers and monkeys wandering freely among the humans in the island. It is very small island and one needs to take a ferry from Rajiv Gandhi sport complex. Not much to do here as swimming is prohibited in this island.But our experience with animals and exploring the island was a memorable part of our trip.

title: Average place to visit.
review_text: It is an average place to visit. Most of the time we have to spend it travelling itself. Either by boat or by car or by two wheeler. The beach was really nice. not so crowded. Even elders can go for it. Carry some snacks, water, cap and cooling glass.

title: EXCELLENT VISIT
review_text: Great visit, the first settlement at the Andaman Islands. The ruins bring to fore the life in the 19th century. A great light and sound show is also held. Some deer and peacock on the Island. A part of the Island was effected by the Tsunami in 2004.

title: A look at British life in the Andamans
review_text:
Old dilapidated town of the british. 10 minute ferry ride away from Rajiv Gandhi water sports park. 
Uninhabited and filled with Spotter Deer, Peacocks, Chicken and Rabbits!!! 

Don't miss the sound and light show here!

title: History of luxury
review_text:
It is a 5 minutes drive via Boat to this island, Very interesting place. One can see remnants of an opulent past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool and the chief commissioner's residence with its huge gardens and grand ballrooms. 
Hats off to Indian Navy for the hospitality.

title: Flashback to the British Era with some great Natural Beauty..!!
review_text:
Ross Island, a small islands in front of the Port Blair city used to be the Pre-Independence Capital of this Islands. I remember my grandfather saying how he use to stay in the Island when he was a small kid and the British era description of this island. 

Last month when i visited Ross Island after a gap of 10 yrs, was surprised to see the way the island have come up so beautiful to its originality by the effort of the Indian Navy and some volunteers. Miss. Anupama, know for her excellent knowledge of this Island is the best person to be accompanied if you really wana know the History of Ross Island. I was not able to see the Light & Sound Program but will soon share the experience of the that too with you all. 

ya, forgot to say the Island is house to a huge population of Spotted Deers...one can see them from real close without any barriers or walls grazing freely, but request you to not feed..!! More

title: Lovely Island
review_text:
We visited Ross Island in February, 2016. This island is done as a part of 3 island (Ross, Viper and North Bay) tour or 2 island tour (Ross and North Bay). A ferry takes you on either of these 2 tours. 
We did only Ross Island - so we took a speed boat (seating 6 people) ride to the island. By speed boat it was a mere 5 minute ride from the jetty at Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex. The ferry takes a little longer as it is a bigger vessel carrying more people. If you have issues with sea sickness, speed boat is not a good option. The island has bunkers, buildings etc but are not in good condition due to bombings during World War II and also due to Tsunami of Dec 2004 (Ross island bore the brunt and saved Port Blair). 
You can walk around the island and explore the place. There are deer, peacocks and pea hens which roam freely around the island. An hour and a half is good enough to spend on this island. If you are lucky you could meet Ms. Anuradha Rao - a super lady who has spent all her life looking after the animals on this island and at no charge!! We had the opportunity to meet and interact with her and were really awed by the amount of selfless work that she is doing. More

title: History revisited
review_text: Light and sound show in evening is great, one of the best in the country. did this as part of evening package though getting tickets from tourist office is a pain

title: Museum of old history
review_text: The old remains of the buildings , church and water purification system are awful. The way tree branches had engulfed the building was astonishing. Madam Anuradha is the excellent guide who has not only the command over history but her love for wild life is the gift of God to her.

title: Amazing
review_text: I would say the history of this place is known by very few. It's a small beautiful island located to the east of portblair. You are not allowed to stay there at night as it's uninhabited and a base of the Navy. Catch a boat in the evening by 4.. Roam around the island, watch the breathtaking sound and light show and get back to portblair by 7.30. It's not very expensive either. A trip to Ross from portblair would cost 600 RS

title: ROSS ISLAND:- The beautiful island!
review_text: Visited Ross Island through a boat from Port Blair. On reaching there we saw the different buildings built during British regime, which are now in a ruined state. One more attractive point is 'Japanese Bunker'. Enjoyed the trip!

title: Visit to Ross island
review_text: Nice place, Well maintained. Battery car is available to roam in the island. No much food available on island. Now it have light and sound show.

title: Only for historic lovers
review_text: This place talks lot about history of the past. You have old buildings of the British times. There is a sound and light show in the evening which is very interesting but only if you like to know about the history of the islands

title: A luxury Island before WW2
review_text: A nice place to sit in a cool breeze and imagine the, for then, luxury that the British Administration created for themselves. There is some historical information and explanation of the remaining buildings.

title: Ross Island visit
review_text:
This is contolled by Indian Navy 
Distance form Aberdeen Jetty is just 5 miniuts drive in Speed Boat, 
Very intersting place.

title: A must go place in Andaman
review_text: This is a must visit place on your visit to Andaman to get a feeling a British Legacy and to understand the lifestyle they followed during those era.

title: Our visit to Ross Islands
review_text: Ross islands is just across the main Andaman island and one reach it by a short journey by boat. It is a colonial legacy with dilapidated buildings of the colonial rule. A few deters are seen . Nothing much to see.

title: the japanese secretriat
review_text: its a lovely place for archaeological point of view as well the scenery the lush green and deer roaming freely. its lovely

title: A relaxing spot
review_text: The Ross island is another accessible island and is very much like a big open coconut grove. There are lot many deer and rabbits roaming around on this island. Visitors and specially children are more than happy to be here. There is a place on this island where tree roots have totally captured the old colonial buildings. This would be of interest for the photographer in you.

title: Worth the visit
review_text: Its interesting to go visit and worth it considering there is nothing much in Port Blair of interest. The boat ride is fun specially if the water is rough :) but some passengers don't find it so given their sea sickness.

title: A nice place to visit while in Port Blair
review_text:
An above average place to experience an era gone by. 

Nice views of the sea from the rear end of the island. 

Managed by the Indian navy and a boat ride is needed to reach here.

title: Nice place
review_text: Good one day trip place. The light and sound show is exquisite. Food availability poor especially after 4 pm.

title: History Amid the Ruins
review_text:
Ross Island once contained the township built for the Headquarters of the British Administration. A massive earthquake wreaked havoc on the Island in 1941 and all that remains today are the ruins with a fully restored Bakery that is near to the jetty. It will take a good couple of hours, even more, to walk around and get a feel of the layout but because of the change in the ferry departure place in Port Blair this is not possible. When I went last month, the ferry no longer departed from the Water Sports Park from where you can see Ross Island straight ahead. (The journey from there was about 10 minutes or so). It now departs from Junglighat jetty and the journey takes about an hour. Why it has been shifted is beyond me. All it has succeeded in doing is making the journey longer and shortening the time given to explore the Island. There are display boards just after you disembark which chart the history and life of the Island. There is also a sign saying, amongst other things, that feeding of animals is strictly prohibited. Sadly this is ignored by quite a few visitors who I witnessed, that seemed to think it ok to feed the deer and the peacocks. For those reading this review, please do not feed the animals; you may be doing more harm than good. They are not lacking any source of food... There are display boards just after you disembark which chart the history and life of the Island. There is also a sign saying, amongst other things, that feeding of animals is strictly prohibited. For those reading this review, please do not feed the animals; you may be doing more harm than good. They are not lacking any source of food nor are they starving. 

All in all a worthwhile trip for the 100 rupees charged for the ferry and the 20 rupees charged for entrance to the Island. More

title: Good historic island
review_text:
Ross island is for history lovers. 
Old british capital with ruins of their houses,offices and bakeries 
Place has lots of deers roaming around u and peacocks grazing here and there 
Overall fun place and must go place at port blair

title: Good animal spotting
review_text:
It's a short boat ride to this former British Administrative Capital. There was barely anytime to explore the whole island. It probably needs 1-2 hours of walking. 

The peacocks and deer feeding was a wonderful spectacle to watch.

title: Where history is alive
review_text: This tiny island was once the residency of British officers administrating Port Blair. Though majority of the remaining buildings are in ruins, few are preserved in good condition as well. There are many features of the once vibrant settlement that any history lover would praise. You can be lost in history by roaming around the paths, ruins. It's very beautiful also. No wonder why British used to choose this island for their own residence. Once you enter from ferrey, hundreds of deers and some peacocks would welcome you. Only complaint is returning ferries from Port Blair doesn't normally allow more than 2 hours, which is not at all sufficient to properly visit this excellent place. Also there isn't any staying arrangement in this island. Anyway, never miss this island to visit when you are in Port Blair. More

title: The British Island
review_text: It is an island situated near port blair which is accessible by ferry. It is an amazing place to visit. More than half of the island is drowned after the tsunami. Good scenic view.

title: Wonderful place
review_text: This was an amazing experience. The island is occupied with numbers of deer's, peacocks, squirrels and rabbits. One can take snaps with them. A must visit place that will rejuvenate you. Spend at-least 4-5hrs in the island for this ask your travel agent accordingly. Direct speed boats are available form Port Blair to Ross Island.

title: Place t o visit
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: Good. Nostalgic. Historical relevance. Gives insight as to the life of the British on this island where they enjoyed at the cost of the prisoners

title: Good Trip
review_text: we did a trip to ross island which was the capital during the british reign. you can have a pictorials view of remains of old buildings with trees on it. one can also spot peacocks and deer roaming around. Good place to visit.

title: A Delightful Island
review_text: Visited Ross during our stay in Port Blair. Anyone can visit this by having a day tour along with North Bay Island visit. Though the island is ruined and damaged from 2004 tsunami it should be visited for its architecture and pleasing views of ocean around. Deers and peacocks can be seen all over the island. Only an hour is allowed to visit by the boat people. It should be more in my view. A must visit.

title: Beautiful Habitat
review_text: I think the Indian navy have done a brilliant job at maintaining the place. The freely roaming deer, peacocks and rabbits add to the charm of the place.

title: Nicely made into a tourist spot
review_text: It takes 2 hrs to explore Ross island. On our way here, the boatman also took us to the Viper island where they used the hang the prisoners. Ross island reminds of old british glory and has their iconic buildings in ruins. There are free rabbits, dears on this island who give you good photo opportunities. The beach is amazing for photography. Ok for a short trip, not worth a day's trip for sure.

title: Visit and imagine British glory
review_text: For Ross Island, you have to book ferry 1 day before visit. Booking can be done at Information & Tourism office or at Junglighat jetty. You can also go by speed boat from water sports complex, however that's a bit expensive option. Cost per person is 100 Rs for ferry and at Ross 30 Rs at entrance. Here you can see British and Japanese structures like bunkers, church, bunglows, water treatment plants Also you can see animals like deer, rabbits and peacocks

title: Small and beautiful
review_text: This is a beautiful island were one can view the ruins of British era. Ferry takes around 15 to 20 mins to reach there from Port Blair water sport complex.

title: There is history n magic in this place
review_text: It is just a Day visit, since u cannot stay on this island. This island is known for its history and animals like deer n peacocks who have become very friendly to humans and allow us to caress them. The surroundings is also good and a well maintained clean island. Very limited shops you will find here, so it is better to carry your snacks and water bottle with you.

title: Interesting Island with good history and free foaming animals.
review_text: Me and my parents made a visit to Ross Island during our holiday in the Andaman Islands. Ross Island is about 1 hour maximum boat ride from Port Blair depending on the sea conditions and you can pay for ferry tickets at the booking office by the Jetty. It is a small island with ruined building overgrown by vines and trees. This used to be the main British town in the Andamans until it was wrecked by an earthquake and then not repaired when the Japanese invaded during world war 2 whose presence are noted by a few remaining bunkers left and preserved on the island. Our favourite part has to be the wild free-foaming animals on the island such as peacock, rabbits, squirrels and deer. We were lucky to be here in the afternoon as the keepers were feeding the deer and whole herds came to eat, providing us with fantastic photos opportunity. These deer are friendly but be careful as they are wild and can accidentally injure you. This experience together with vast coconut trees and the amazing view of the sea made our short stay on Ross island well worth the time. There are buggies available on the island to provide you with a tour on the island for those with mobility issues but my opinion is to explore at your own leisure. Food and drink are available by the jetty at a fee together with shaded... Me and my parents made a visit to Ross Island during our holiday in the Andaman Islands. Ross Island is about 1 hour maximum boat ride from Port Blair depending on the sea conditions and you can pay for ferry tickets at the booking office by the Jetty. It is a small island with ruined building overgrown by vines and trees. This used to be the main British town in the Andamans until it was wrecked by an earthquake and then not repaired when the Japanese invaded during world war 2 whose presence are noted by a few remaining bunkers left and preserved on the island. Our favourite part has to be the wild free-foaming animals on the island such as peacock, rabbits, squirrels and deer. We were lucky to be here in the afternoon as the keepers were feeding the deer and whole herds came to eat, providing us with fantastic photos opportunity. These deer are friendly but be careful as they are wild and can accidentally injure you. This experience together with vast coconut trees and the amazing view of the sea made our short stay on Ross island well worth the time. There are buggies available on the island to provide you with a tour on the island for those with mobility issues but my opinion is to explore at your own leisure. Food and drink are available by the jetty at a fee together with shaded seating area. Toilet facilities are present on the island but very basic and sometimes not well cleaned so advise caution. Be sure to plan your time wisely as they are only 2 ferries (one morning and one afternoon) that come and go between Port Blair and Ross Island. Strongly recommend that catch the morning ferry before 8:00am to make the most of the visit on Ross Island. It is very colourful and pleasant with the sound of the sea and the animals. If you like a bit of wildlife together with history and scenery then this is the island worth putting on your itinerary list should you stay a bit longer in the Andaman Islands like we had done. More

title: Awesome place with harmless animals
review_text:
though I had an idea by looking at the picture in Google what is there in Ross....the experience was far better than my thought. the feeling of deer around u, peacock dancing and flying....took away my breath. the best experience was feeding the deer. we all know deer are shy animals. they are always alert. When their antlers dashed with each other,they were scared and were ready to run. this is what we cannot express in words or in pictures...So go and visit this place. 
Peacocks here don't wait for rain to open their wings and display their beauty. i had never seen a peacock flying... i saw this for the first time. Wow!!! indeed they are beautiful More

title: The North bay & Ross islands are just 15/20 minutes away from Marina jetty in port Blair. A must visit.
review_text: This is on Ross island. One among the hundreds in Andamans & Nicobar. 15 min. ferry ride from Marina Bay jetty, in Port Blair. It housed the Britishers offices, commissioner's huge bungalow, a club with a dance floor resting on springs, a swimming pool, a bakery and a water treatment plant. All is ruins now with age & after a massive earthquake . The island is under Navy & no civilian is allowed to stay over night. It is full of very old trees having unimaginable large trunks. This island with retaining walls, took the brunt of Tsunami & saved Port Blair to a large extent.

title: Fun place to visit.
review_text:
It was a lot of fun visiting Ross Island. A number of Deers, Peacocks and rabbits were roaming there. Some buildings are completely wrapped in tree roots and look amazing. 
Its just 5 minutes journey from Port blair through a ferry. 
Definitely a go.

title: Historic island
review_text: Nice historical place which was the Capital of the islands during British reign. You can spot peacocks and deer roaming about freely. Good place to visit.

title: Old British Habitat and the friendly wildlife
review_text: It was the place where British during their rule in Andamans stayed. One can revisit the history, can visit skeletons of the houses, the distilled water factory, the natural swimming pool. But to me the best attraction was the current wildlife there. The friendly deers, peacocks, rabbits, birds and all. Loved being their with them.

title: BEST LIGHT AND SOUND SHOW
review_text:
one of the best light and sound show in the world. 
Anuradha Rao the great wild life conserver speaks with deer.sqirrel, peacock and bulbul,. 
stays and feed them ......very nice experience.

title: Historic
review_text:
You can see the affluent life style led by the British by enslaving the ethnic population. 
It is a good island destination. Trees consuming the old brick structures, as if out of vengeance, is a must see.

title: adventure and historic place
review_text:
take a mng ride from port blair ( approx 30 mins ) 
place being more of historic importance and beautiful wildlife and a scenic view of island ..

title: Island 'taken over' by Nature
review_text: Beautiful. Scenic. It can be reached by a boat ride of around 20 minutes from Port Blair. It houses the remnants of once beautiful structures like the Chief Commissioner's House, Church , Barracks, Cemetery and others- all in ruins now and taken over by the nature. Peaceful and inhabited only by wild animals like deer. Human settlement is not allowed-one of the reasons why it is beautiful and peaceful. As the sun comes down, the place seems magical with starry night sky and no lights to guard you back except moonlight, so it is advised to return to boat before dusk for back-journey to Port Blair. Deer, peacocks are friendly to humans provided we humans are same to them. As one climbs up the island, viewing old ruins on sides, they can reach the top to view the beach on the other side, though no visitor is allowed to go near it. The light and sound show at night is a brilliant work to depict history of the island. The best island so far of all that I visited in Andaman. More

title: History in every brick
review_text: Ross Island, located off Port Blair, is run and maintained by the Indian Navy. Boats are the only means to access this Island which is famous for being the erstwhile administrative headquarters of British pre-independence. The island houses the ancient buildings in ruins which were used by the British. It is worth the visit for this very purpose. The island also has a lot of deer, peacocks etc. You should also see the light and sound show on this island which tells you all about how the British came to these islands, all about Kaala Pani etc. It's like a video show and less of a normal light and sound show but it is still more than worth the watch. More

title: A decent trip from Port Blair
review_text: The scenery is mesmerizing. The islands are a mere 20 mins sail from the Port Blair port. There is a lot of historic aspects to the islands, and there is a sanctuary which has a decent collection of animals. We saw peacocks, rabbits, deers among other animals. Mostly, it is good for a quaint walk and silent musings.

title: Good to See!
review_text: The first sight of the island as you approach it is very beautiful! The island has ruins of buildings from the past. The island has a history of its own! The beach on the other side of the island is breathtakingly clean and beautiful... however it is out of bounds for visitors!

title: Great experience
review_text: Got an opportunity of meeting a great lady guide (Anuradha Rao). She takes care of animals and birds like her kids on Ross Island. On her call all deer, peacock came out of bushes. She gave food for them. Children fed them and touched them.

title: Good show
review_text: There are ferries to the island by government specially for light and sound show..nice n peaceful place.. The show was really good...there were some rabbits n deer also so kids can hv fun with them ...

title: Ruined place
review_text:
Had been Ross Island with intetion of meeting legendary Ms. Anuradha Rao;but disappinted as I could not meet her as she was not there on that day becoz of her health problems. Most of the buildings of erstwhile british raj are in now ruins. (aging and Sunami ). Could not watch light and sound show witch is held in the evenings; it is supposed to be a good show. ( ferry services arte available for this show) 
Ferry services from Port Blair's Jungle Ghat cover both Ross and North Bay. In fact Ross Island is included in that ferry package.

title: Best island 2 have a luk about british empire
review_text: Its the island of britisher at the ancient firm this island only the took watch on jail and also on the water . On this island at the time of Britisher there is all type of aminities swimming pool, library, canteen ,printing press, distillation plant ,etc also on this island u cant see the deer and peacock greatly

title: Wall of Port Blair
review_text: As the matter of fact this island has saved Port blair from Tsunami to a large extent, a large portion of the island was lost; nevertheless the island is still standing tall with ample of beauty and attraction. less than a mile away from port blair via ferry, it can be reached within 10 min. from port blair. The former capital of Andaman Ross Island still has many relics like Hospital, Church, water distilling plant. While children have good time enjoying with Deer, Peacock and Rabbit, this place gives lot of insight to what this place used to be in olden days. You don't get food here, however Nariyal pani and ice creams are available near entry. Entry tickets are very nominal Rs. 10/- per adult and if you are carrying a camera you need to get another ticket. The island is very neat and clean, very beautifully maintained. Worth visiting. More

title: small iseland with freely roaming dears and rabbits around you
review_text: nice scenic beauty of banyan trees, gardens , old monuments ,water purifiers and wild life around visitors

title: Amazing..
review_text:
OMG... I was amazed .. when Deer were walking around me. Awesome xeperiance it was.. peacocks and deer comes very near to you.. clicked various photos.... 

Persa wasoool...

title: major attraction
review_text: One of the places where everybody goes when visiting Port Blair. A boat ride takes the tourists to the rather small island. After instructions one is free to explore the terrain where the remains of once "Paris of the east" are dramatically embraced by huge branches of the trees. Descriptions on plates tell us about the time when life on this island was in full swing and how it all ended.

title: Must visit for all Indians - full of history
review_text: Interesting to note the immense history that this small island has - how the might of an Empire was stonewalled by natural calamities. The Old buildings and the scenic beauty just makes the visit worthwhile. An hour ride by a ferry from Port Blair. Not many are aware but there is one Golf Cart for hire - about 8 adults capacity. Try that - you can enjoy the whole Island in peace. Very small area so don't expect grandeur. Well maintained.

title: Nothing too great
review_text: This island is not so scenic as the picture suggests. I guess it was destroyed by tsunami and has not been rebuilt to its full.

title: The remains of the Paris of the East.
review_text: Probably tsunami destroyed the best part of Port Blair/Andaman, the Ferar beach of Ross island. Nested in beautiful coconut cove and a serene skyline with blue ocean and the remains of British administrative and social life makes Ross island very special. The ferry to the island is a romantic bruise in the backdrop of many other interesting islands, history and a knowledgeable guide. The bakery, the church and the clubs of the Indians and the British are well maintained although most of these are only ruins of the past. I was marveled to see the distillery plant which was used to produce potable water from ocean water and the hilly landscape of the island, going up and down. A very memorable and historic place to be in. Scarcity of bottled water and food was a bit of concern, which was met up with tender coconuts. More

title: Nothing Special.....
review_text: Better to ignore the island.... No Maintenance .... Nothing special... Better to leave north bay island also...

title: Historical place with ruins left after Tsunami
review_text:
Ita a historical place and has ruins which are left after Tsunami of 2004. It has some picturesque places and deers walking free. 
Although people are not allowed to feed the deers but can touch them if they come near us. 
We can reach Ross Island by ferry's operating from Port blair.

title: Ross island
review_text: It is an avg interesting island.not like kala patthar,or radhanagar.but evening 4 oclok show is good then cellular jail.

title: Half a day's trip well spent
review_text: Take a speed boat or a govt. ferry. Sped boat takes 15 minutes and charges more. Ferry takes 1 hour and charges less. Once you are on the island you look around and see a few deer around you, lots of peacocks and peahens and a couple of rabbits...you can choose to take the tour in the golf cart for 100 bucks or just go around the island where there is a beach, the ruins of a broken church and a bakery. All these were damaged by the tsunami...

title: Ross island
review_text: You would see what history and tsunami meant . The real picture is Ross island . I liked the grave most . Really eerie place though . You would like walking around and playing with deer too and eating the sweetest coconuts . Really good

title: Historic place
review_text: If you are History lover then you should definitely go to Ross Island. You can see old building of the British times, bunkers. Don't forget to see light and sound show at Ross in the evening.

title: Surprise in there
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text:
While reading reviews, it seems like a not so interesting location to visit. One gets put off by just reading of ruins. 
But actually it turns out to be a good surprising venue to visit with quite a few interesting locations and really well preserved monuments. 
Looks like a good professionally managed place and should not be missed.

title: If you like History then this is a place to go to
review_text: If you like History then this is a place to go to, All about the war and Japanese bunkers still present. Awesome half day trip not to far from Port Blair.

title: Ruined English resort
review_text:
It is a small island very near to main island. Fully ruined now but still the remains will explain how lavish English were here during their long term stay. 
A full setup colony in English style with swimming pool and all recreational facilities finally with the view of the jail 
Now the place looks like haunted. 
Few deers are there and they move with tourist for food. 
Worth a visit to know the history

title: Ross Island a peek into the past
review_text:
A short boat ride is required to reach Ross Island. 
Here they have a light and sound show is is the main attraction. You can see the ruins in this island. Trees growing out of dilapidated and ruined buildings. This island is home to deers, rabbits peacocks. You can avail the services of a golf cart car to go to the top most elevation of this island to get a picturesque view.

title: The Paris of the East
review_text: Truely the Bastian of British settlementin Andamans it still holds the Relics of the BY gone era. The Salt spray is refreshening and the island well maintained. The Bakery is good and functioning. The old relics of the distilleries and the power generators along with the swimming pool remind one of the Lavish life the British enjoyed there. Lots of tamed Spotted deer are an attraction and come to you fearlessly to have a bite at your coconut!

title: Nice scenic beauty
review_text: Really nice scenic beauty and archaeological site Nicely preserved and labelled. People should take some time to roam freely and feel the best and pure nature and vegetation, old buildings and dears, pacocks and scenic beauty.

title: Very Interesting !
review_text:
The visit to the island is interesting to catch a view of the life of the British officers posted there in the 1940s. 
Even though a large part has been washed away by the tsunami, it is still nice to see the Deer and Peacocks roam about freely on the island.

title: Visit if you like to see ruins
review_text: Nice island to see the ruins of the British era, major of them destroyed during Tsunami. You can visit this place in a speed boat from Aberdan Jetty. It take 5-6 minutes to get here.

title: Nice Location and well maintained island
review_text:
I have boarded in fibre cruise - MV Mark Marina from Junlighat to visit Ross Island. 
Entry Fee was Rs. 30. You will be additionally charged for still photography or videography around Rs. 100. The island is really nice for its scenic beauty where you can capture good clicks. After entering you will found some boards where the Discovery of this island been highlighted. As you go beyond you will see different parks, huts and all. 
But I was lucky to see a deer and also clicked several pics.

title: Free roaming of Peacock & deer
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: I was stonished to see deer & peacock roaming freely in the Island. This Island was Britishes Officer Colony & even at that time they were utilising Distilledwater from Sea water with the help of Steam Boilers. Running Club Activities & enjoying.The most part destroyed in last Sunami.

title: Average excited
review_text: Ross Island is nothing interested to see there except boat ride enjoyment and just can see Deers and very old and damaged British Buildings.

title: Not to be missed!
review_text: Historical place . Reminiscent ot the Raj . Nice view of the Portblair from Ross . Must spent 3 hrs there . If you dont want to walk sit near the cafetaria or in the museum and see the boats and ship going here and there . As the is under the administration of indian Navy be disciplened lest the will fine you. Full of old buildings and history . Enjoy

title: Ross Island
review_text: Ross island is a small island to the east of Port Blair. Attractive spot to visit. Jelly fish and golden fishes can be seen nearby in ocean water. This place can be reach by boat ride from Port Blair. It was a adventurous journey.

title: Great view
review_text: this is an half hour journey from aberden jetty(port blair) great view, total three hours of exploration.

title: Amazing & beautiful
review_text: Visited twice here, wanted to visit more & stay for a longer time as a trip is only for an hour, as per military rule. Light & sound show is much better than cellular jail one perhaps one of India's best. Animals are very friendly. Don't forget to visit the beach on the back side of the island.

title: DO NOT MISS LIGHT AND SOUND AT ROSS
review_text: Do not miss the light and sound show at Ross. It may be rated as one of the best such show in the country. The ruins of the British era present a splendid view.

title: Ruins of British Raj.
review_text: Ross island is a small island, one can see all attractions at this island in just one hour. Only thing one can see are the remains of buildings built by british officers and their families. One can easily imagine from those remains that the royal life style of britishers at a time when Indian freedom fighters were subjected to all kinds of inhuman punishments. Architecture of building remains suggest how beautiful were the buildings and luxury life style of british officers.

title: A good memorable trip!
review_text: We started to Ross Island from Junglighat Jetty gate no.2. It took 45 min to reach Ross Island. After 30 min of boat ride the boat was real shaky due to incoming waves. But it was thrilling ride and we enjoyed it. The history of Ross Island was interesting. The light and sound show was truly amazing. It was very well played with brilliant sound and light effect. Kudos to the Andaman tourism dept.!

title: Ross Island - Big history on Small Island
review_text: Ross Island is very close to Port Blair. 20 mins distance by ferry. Beautiful. britishers had a army presence there so had backery, printing press and commissioner house etc there. They were destroyed in bombing of Japan. Japan took over there for 3 years. There is Japenese banker there. There is battery operated cars at the reasonable price which takes you over to all the places. You can travel on your own. However, there are no shops to buy food but you can take your food and eat there. The govt has started light and sound show in evening.

title: Ross is awesome
review_text: This is a beauty. A must visit. Spend a few hours over here. You take a ferry from Water sports complex port blair to reach here. Very pretty place. There are peacock , deers also at this attraction. scenic beauty. They say japenese conquered it in WW-II. Now under Indian Navy.

title: Ross Island - Quick to-do at Andaman
review_text:
A very interesting place - quick to get to from Port Blair through a speed boat. You can do the Ross Island trip if you have say 3-4 hours to spare very comfortably. 
Lot of historical / british rule significance. Maintained well and very clean. 
Great views of Port Blair city, North Bay etc. There is a nice beach you can get to (swimming not allowed). Place for kids to play, some birds and animals to watch up close (they surprisingly don't run away when near humans). 30-40 rupee entry. 
A speed boat ride (4 individuals) costs about 1000 (to and fro) and is generally very fast compared to the larger boats (that are cheaper and start from a place far from city). The ride itself is 4-5 minutes by the speed boat. More

title: Time froze
review_text: A place which brings out the sheer luxury of colonial british era. the root covered old buildings present a unique sight. the light n sound show was the best that I had ever seen. A scenic locality with ample greenery and beautiful views

title: Tribute to Andamans Tourism
review_text: Went by ferry from Junglighat Jetty of Port Blair. To & Fro Rs. 100 per person for the 3 hour trip. Free guidance by Ferry staff. Pleasant sea journey amidst beautiful surrounding hills. At Ross Island, a free guide by Andaman Tourism department explaining so well. Her name is Anuradah Rao, who was brought up in Ross Island only. The deers, peacocks and rabbits are not scared of us. They come close to us. One can see the stuctures built by the British, Japanese and remember Netaji. Worth a visit.

title: Interesting Place if we have lack of options
review_text: The place has an entry fee of 30/person but with the secenary and the history its a place we can visit. The place has a beach and was very neatly maintained. Even had reindeer and great views.

title: Ross Island Visit
review_text: One time visit is must. you will see rabbits , peacock and dear . you can feed food to them . More things like church etc .

title: ruins and animals
review_text:
ross island was home to british troops and administrators during their rule here.since the island was destroyed to a great extent by the tsunami, this place offers views of ruins of british construction. 
highlights are: 
buildings held together and kept from falling by beautiful roots of fig trees, 
deer and peacocks that are tourist-friendly and not camera-shy. 
Nice stroll along a hillock, showcasing ruins of modest brit buildings.

title: History Revisited
review_text:
Ross island is a place with one of the most marvellous histories ever! The place is a story of human spirit, endurance, vision and is also a test case of how time can ravage everything.. 

ROSS is a story of a settlement which is built, destroyed, rebuilt and then abandoned - partly due to nature's fury and party due to man made war! 

The light and sound show is superbly made and is an experience to cherish. Its brilliantly produced with all possible use of graphics, animation and lighting techniques. The voice overs / narration of the story of Ross is in the magnetic and magical voices of Gulzar in Hindi and Shabana in English! its a MUST SEE for all who want a full view of the past. More

title: An amazing must visit island.
review_text: No sooner than you place foot on the Ross island a different world opens up- a historical venue set in a prisitine natural setting.

title: Strategic and historically important!
review_text: A small island occupied by the British for its opening to the sea and the ability to view any incoming ships. Later occupied by the Japs. Experience western as well as oriental(japs) imperialism and what it can do to a people. Thanks to this island Port Blair was protected during the 2004 tsunami. The beach eastern side is beautiful with the deer and peacocks on the island adding an aesthetical touch. A must see!

title: Original Head quarters of British settlement in Andamans
review_text:
Situated about 30 minutes away by boat from Aberdeen jetty of Port Blair. Boat charges Rs.50 per adult.The are frequent services if the boat. 
This was the original seat of the Britishers in Andamans from 1858.. Offices, accommodation for the Chief Commissioner,other British and Indians Swimming pool, Church, bakery,a printing press were built.All were destroyed during the earth quake in 1941. was abandoned and a new Head quarters was built in Port Blair. Today one can see the ruins of the buildings. 
The island has a huge number of peacocks, deer, rabbits and other animals today. There is no human habitation. Visitors can hire guides and golf buggies to go around the island. It takes about an hour to cover More

title: Great Place
review_text:
A great visit to visit is this Ross Island 
Don't the evening light n sound show- best that I've seen. 
Get down to the western side of the island, there is a small little beach there- remains unexplored by many. 
It was disheartening to see that a place which the Britishers of that time maintained n operated beautifully now lies in ruins... 
The indian fools know only how to make places like ross islands into money minting ventures n don't seem to b bothered about the upkeep of the place... 
It's a must go to place wen u r there in port blair...

title: Feed a Deer!
review_text:
A short ferry ride from port blair and you reach Ross Island. First thing you'll notice is that how well maintained that island is. You can roam around, click some cool photographs and feed the deer which will follow you in most adorable manner. 

Do not forget to check out all the informational boards which are mounted there which will take you on an information roller coaster ride :)

title: Interesting history, nice to walk around
review_text:
Ross island has a very interesting heritage from the British and Japanese times. It's a good way to spend a few hours in port Blair. The vistas of the sea from the higher points is very beautiful. Most of the buildings are in ruins, but the signboards provide lots of background. 

Take a ferry from water sports complex to reach there. 
I got left behind by the ferry on the island! But got back on the next round trip.

title: British ruins in a beautiful Island
review_text:
Absolutely brilliant. Place for the british officers and their lavish lifestyle. Ruins are well 
preserved by the government. Tend to become crowded. As mentioned by many, you need to hurry up to catch the boat back to Port Blair

title: History , Natural park and the sea Shore
review_text: Ross Island is the place which tells us about the history of Britishers along with the natural park consist of various pets . The greenery and the sounds of the waves is breathe taking.

title: Beautiful island with rare information
review_text: Beautiful island having wonderful greenery and natural park consist of rabbits , deer , peacock animals etc . The buildings there tells us about the story of British rule out there. Very clean and beautiful island with breathe taking view

title: History revisited
review_text: Thanks to the couple whom we met at Havelock, who told us about Ross Island. We went there only for the light and sound show but after going there I realised that we would have missed something had we not visited Ross Island. One can't really stay here overnight as there are no resorts or hotels. But it being a British jail once, has ruins of all the architecture and remnants of the city which was once called "Paris of the East". Its a refreshing experience and light and sound show really steals the whole experience and ends your trip to Ross Island with lot of memories.

title: memorable trip to ross island very good greenery with very well maintain natural park
review_text: very good greenery with very well maintain natural parkThis island has some of the most incredible set of ruins of building held up virtually by tree roots. Very well maintained by the Indian navy. The discipline enforced is welcome Their Bungalows, swimming pool, their party rooms. There is a entry fee for this Island of 40rupees per head. You get to experience the British empire through those ruins. Note: This Island was submerged during 2004 Tsunami. This island houses many peacocks, peahens and deer. . 10-20 minutes away from jetty stand.please keep umbrella handy in any season.

title: Nice play to visit
review_text: It houses the remains of british rule church and offices. Island is beautiful. You can also see some deers, peacocks and rabbits.

title: Somewhere you can care Deer and Rabit
review_text: If you want to care a deer and rabbit this is the best place. You can see deer, rabbits and peacock all around free at their own habitat. This is the place where the British used to come for recreation. There is a Japanese bunker from where during the Japanese reign of Andaman this was the place they stayed. There is only one food stall. You can take a guide and roam about in a battery operated car

title: Outstanding Visit to Ross Island
review_text: This island has some of the most incredible set of ruins of building held up virtually by tree roots. Very well maintained by the Indian navy. The discipline enforced is welcome.

title: Takes Back you in Time
review_text: Small Island just 10mins speed boat ride from Port Blair but make sure you reach the place early in the day as it gets crowded and have to fight for a boat ride back to Port Blair. Ross Island has all the ruins from British Empire. Their Bungalows, swimming pool, their party rooms. There is a entry fee for this Island of 40rupees per head. You get to experience the British empire through those ruins. Note: This Island was submerged during 2004 Tsunami. This island houses many peacocks, peahens and deer. We got a chance to touch the stag and hence realized that Stag's horns are covered with soft hair and they feel like velvet. Worth the visit. We had trouble getting back to Port Blair as the boat gives take money and do not provide receipt and pick up time which leads to chaos while coming back to Port Blair. On the whole, a pleasant visit. More

title: One time British office
review_text: Must visit place. Can see many British buildings in ruin today. Can see 100's of dears and peacock moving around. Magnificent sea view from top of the Ross Island.

title: Nice Small Island
review_text: This is very small island just 25 minutes away from port Blair by boat. You can walk all around island in 45 minutes to on hour max. Old capital but every thing is in damaged condition may be after Tsunami. When we got down there Deer, Peacock came in front of us. There are so many Deer, Peacock and rabbit we found. It was very nice to hear history from Anuradha Rao there.

title: Absolute beauty sitting next to Port Blair
review_text: Ross island is simply beautiful, nature's artwork, and flanked by great ferrar beach on other side. There are historical Tell tale signs on the island. It is lush green and just invites you to walk through the woods.

title: really a nice island
review_text: we enjoyed this island. good place to visit. you will able to see the marine life on the way to this island.

title: Historical Significance and Nature Love- Both at same place
review_text: It was just 2 km east of Port Blair. It can be reached by a short boat ride from Water Sports Complex. Ross Island is controlled and administrated by Indian Navy. Ross Island has it historical significance as it was seat of “British Empire” and now it has ruins of old buildings that English people used for their livelihood and leisure . There were ruins of bakery, tennis court, bazaar etc . Island was captured by Japanese during Second World War, there was a Japanese bunker still present on the island. Island also have a small beach which was destroyed during the Tsunami in 2004 , Ross island acted as saviour for Port Blair during Tsunami. One has to walk a bit to cover the whole island , so it is advisable to carry water and snacks along with you More

title: The trip too Small
review_text: Just one of the Small but peaceful well Maintained Island by Indian Navy. You go there by Ferry. Tickets are available at jetty. It has Deers to all the type of animals, beaches to Colonial houses well preserved. you can feed some of the animals photograph them and enjoy the walk around. Sign boards help you understand the place well and lets you know the islands history. At times you feel like staying back for an overnight trip. But its not permitted. You can load yourself back on any of the ferries from Ross to Port Blair.

title: unique experience you must visit this place if you visit andaman
review_text: ross island you must visit if you visit andaman , the old swimming pool and architecture of the year 1700 is unique

title: A reminder of the bygone era !!
review_text:
Ross Island preserves the ruins of the bygone era. The old structures, houses, church, cemetery, gardens, etc provide glimpses of the glorious past. The ruins were further damaged during the tsunami but it still remains a must visit place. 

There is a small beach adjoining the Ross island on the backside. It is very picturesque adorned by coconut trees. One can spots some wild life on the island like deer, rabbits & peacock. 

There are regular government ferries and private boats from Rajiv Gandhi sports complex.

title: closed on wednesday
review_text: could not get a boat as closed on Wednesday no private boats and the island is closed Wednesday, was really looking forward to seeing this so was mega disappointed :(

title: Incredible!!! A must visit for nature & deer lovers :)
review_text: If you are planning to visit Andaman, Ross Island is MUST VISIT. And by the way, if have no plans of visiting Andaman, I would suggest you to change your plan ASAP. Ross island , a 5 min speed boat ride from Port Blair is a nature lover's paradise- calm, serene and peaceful. You will have close encounters with rabbits, peacocks and deer. It also houses the relics of erstwhile british empire. Unlike any other zoo or santuary, they roam about freely and there are literally hundreds of them.

title: Do not miss the Light & Sound Show here.
review_text: The place is a neat and clear island controlled by the army. Nothing much to do on the island but the Light and Sound show is a world class entertainment experience. It covers the history of Ross Island using some cool techniques like video mapping with light and sound. The narration in the Hindi version has been done by Gulzar while the narration for English has been done by Shaban Azmi. I saw the Hindi version and loved it. It is an experience that I would recommend to everybody who wants to know a bit about the history the way a classy Hollywood or Bollywood production would do.

title: Visit to ross island
review_text: Ross is land is just 15 min boat journey from port Blair . The is land is the place where the Britishers used to stay the bakery ,the swimming pool and the farzand Ali store are in decent condition.

title: Historical Place for Andaman & Wonderful Location
review_text: The old capital of Andaman & Nicobar Island , its very beautiful and Historical memories of British Empire,fully nature & wild animal with a awesome location, its only 15 minute journey by boat from port blair city.

title: A Nice Place
review_text: This is a good place specially i loved the deer, rabbits and the small beach.Apart from that the remains of the old machines of water purifier are something we must see to understand the engineering marvels of those days.

title: Exploitation by the British Raj
review_text: They ruled us for 200 years but that need class and discipline which is clearly depicted here in Ross Islands. What could they not demand, it was no less than slavery. You have to admit they did have style too.

title: An excellent place with state of the art light and sound show
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: Ross Island is an Island located about 2 km east of Port Blair. It was the Administrative Headquarters for the islands, before an earthquake rocked it in 1941. The headquarters were then shifted to Port Blair. One can see the past in the ruins of the bakery, power house, church, swimming pool and the chief commissioner's residence. The island is connected via ferry from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex. While travelling, please carry water and food from port blair as nothing is available at Ross Island. At the evening, a light and sound show is organised with projection, lights and dolby sound. The best time to visit the island is at around 1630 Hr. After roaming around the island, see the light and sound show at 1730 Hr. More

title: ross rocks
review_text: very nice place...since entrance to end...very calm beautiful with full of animals and natural beauty...all side views are awesome and romantic...must go

title: Wonderfull island stroll
review_text:
Ross island is extremely close to Port Blair and it takes hardly 10 mins to reach. The place is quiet and there is not much to do on the island itself. You can take the ferry or ride in the speedboat. We took the speedboat and that experience was great. Just make sure you are not overpaying. They might ask you 500 each person but will eventually settle for 200. 
Make sure you take a stroll till the lighthouse on the other side of the jetty. It is totally worth it. You will see deer, peacocks along the way. The island itself was house to the army and you can see all types of army buildings. Most of the buildings were destroyed by the earthquake, but the sea and nature is more than enough to make it worth your time. A must do if you are in port blair. More

title: Old Capital of Andman
review_text: This island is approximately 2 km from Port Blair.It was informed that this island was capital of Andman islands during British period.Now only remains of old buildings are there.Golf carts are available for touring ihe island.Deers can be seen during the visit of island.

title: A great place to see also called the Paris of the East
review_text: The island was ,once , developed as the administrative and residential island of the English. They had developed almost everything for their comfort . Then an earthquake destroyed everything. The ruins of the Water Distilling plant , a printing press , a canteen and all things of use show the grandeur of the island. The beautiful animals &birds are great. The grand old lady guide , who nourishes them is really very great and she lives among these birds and animals.

title: Re visit the glory enjoyed by the british while they were in idia
review_text: Ross island was the head-quarters of the british while they were in andaman..You can see the amazing systems in place which were there even in those times and realize the kind of life the britishers lived here !!!! the place is managed by the indian navy presently and they are doing a fantastic job....

title: The Angkor Wat of India
review_text: The Central Jail and Ross Island are diagonally opposite each other and both present a very vivid picture of the life of its inmates in the era gone by. While the Central Jail was primarily used to house political prisoners and used to dole out horrendous torchers to then, Ross island presents dilapidated ruins of the grandeur of the British officers who were stationed at Port Blair to control this strategic island for the British and was their administrative capital at Port Blair. One can still find the bakery, the distillation plant, the ball room, the church and many other structures from the British era at this island.

title: A Visit to the Ross...
review_text: Amongst several other breathtaking experiences in the Andamans, Ross Island is another one marvelous journey. It has a charming beauty of its own, speaking of the history wrapped around in the ruins. One can get to see the remains of the glorious past in the ruins of the Church, swimming pool, the chief commissioner's residence, the bakery etc. The Ferar beach adds charm to the ruins. Ross Island can be reached by a short boat ride from Water Sports Complex. It is about 2 km east of Port Blair.The island is controlled by the Indian navy now. One can cover the whole Island by walk in 2 hours. However, there are Buggy's on a chargeable basis which takes you to the whole island trip. A trip to Ross and North Bay together in the speed boat would cost one Rs 700 plus the entry fees which is Rs 35. The visit is worth and would definitely recommend it. More

title: beutiful island jus like a wonder land
review_text: very beautiful little island , with deers , rabbits and hens running around, very nice light show , must visit

title: Light and sound show
review_text:
Landing onto Ross Island from the ferry I didn't have huge expectations. I have interest in the history of the place so was happy enough reading through the information boards and taking a walk around the island, seeing the ruins of old buildings and imagining what life would have been like here in the 1850s when at some point it was even dubbed the Paris of the East. There is so much history and almost a melancholy to the place imagining what went on here ~200 years ago. The walks around the small island in that sense are quite serene. It is not a ghost town but an entire ghost island albeit a small one. The big surprise to me was the light and sound show in the evening. I had a pre conceived notion of a fairly boring and standard show but boy was I wrong ! I have seen many a show and exhibition about history is many places around the world but hands down this was the BEST light and sound performance I have ever seen. The whole show is scripted brilliantly and in the open backdrop that it is is projected it is just awe inspiring. The narration by Gulzar and the poems he includes for this show can make your hair stand on their ends. And the overall quality of the sound and projection is right up there. Throughout the show I was left hoping... Landing onto Ross Island from the ferry I didn't have huge expectations.
