I have seen many a show and exhibition about history is many places around the world but hands down this was the BEST light and sound performance I have ever seen. 

The whole show is scripted brilliantly and in the open backdrop that it is is projected it is just awe inspiring. The narration by Gulzar and the poems he includes for this show can make your hair stand on their ends. And the overall quality of the sound and projection is right up there. 

Throughout the show I was left hoping that it goes on and on and doesn't end. This will remain one of the highlights of the trip to the Andamans. I would go so far as saying this show was better than the one at the cellular jail in almost every aspect. 

Just don't miss this! One has to reserve an evening in port Blair for the trip across the channel to Ross More

title: Worthy of 2 hrs. visit
review_text: Ruins of the Japanese rule were worthy to watch. Had time with some domestic animals. Presbyterian church, pond, printing press are some of the highlights.

title: Must visit
review_text: Pls don't miss this island.I would recommend travel by government ferry. The light and sound show is a must in the evening.

title: worth visiting
review_text: 10 minutes ferry from port blair , could spend three hours there as had to catch ferry for havelok in the afternoon , beatifull beach , trees and old offices covered with trees.

title: A small beautiful island
review_text: This is very small beautiful island. This place where we can see old British buildings, this only 4 km area.

title: A resort for the British soldiers
review_text: This place gives us details of the life style and luxuries the British officers and soldiers had when they were here. It is amazing to see the huge water filter and geyser systems which were installed for their convenience. Besides that, the place is now know for its fauna! Not to forget the 'animal whisperer' Anuradha! We were lucky to have her as our tour guide, and got a glimpse of her calling to animals. You will be surprised to see animals small and big, birds all respond to her and come in flocks. I enjoyed my time petting the deer and squirrels.

title: Ross island, once the British headquarters for Andamn Islands
review_text: is 10 to 15 minutes by a steamer from Port Blair. It is now with the Indian Air Force. Entry fee is Rs 35/- plastic etc are banned. Dilapidated church, water purifying plant, bakery, ballroom and club house, swimming pool are warped in time and entangled by roots of trees so also few Japanese bunkers. 2 hours is sufficient as the island is less than a square km. Britishers and their families used to here only and not the Port Blair of today.

title: Beautiful island with Historical Bulidings
review_text: This island has ruins of some old buildings of british era like a church, a bakery, a swimming pool etc. Also there are lot of deers and peacocks roaming around along with few rabbits etc which kids may like.

title: Marvellous atmosphere in Ross island.
review_text: Visiting Ross Island is a life time experience. Once, the administrative headquarters of the British government was located in Ross Island. Now only ruins are there to remind one about the mighty power that ruled India for nearly 190 years. From Ross Island, one can see only blue water everywhere. The atmosphere is cool and its cool breeze is really charming.

title: A trip to remember
review_text:
Visited Ross Island with Family in November 2015. We reached there via a ferry - It takes about ten minutes to reach the Island from the mainland. 
The Island has been well maintained and so are the Historical buildings. There is a provision of taking the tour of the Island by motorized cabs, on chargeable basis - We however decided to move on foot. 
The authorities have also located some wild life on the island viz. Peacocks, Deers, Rabbits etc who move around openly on the island; and they provide a unique experience.

title: Not worthwhile
review_text: Unless you want to see how the British exploited our wealth and locations do not go here. Nothing of value.

title: Ross island
review_text: Deers are free to watch. No food packets allowed on the island ,no plastic bottles allowed . old structures of buidings in the British empire , old hot water bathing facilty for the British are to be seen. Deers roaming freely.It takes hardly 15 - 20 min speed boat to reach Ross from Port Blair.

title: Historically beautiful
review_text: The island takes you back to pre-independence era. There are structures constructed by British occupation (though partially destroyed). Light and sound show is must.

title: Historical Place... Must Visit.
review_text: Really a great Island to visit. It has lots of history within itself. Tsunami almost distory the island but still its a very beautifule place to visit. this island is under Indian Navy.

title: The most beautiful place I have ever seen!
review_text: The Island is a marvel, no doubt why the British settled there, the ruins of the church, the deers that rome around, the birds, and the most beautiful the water, you could see three different shades of blue water form the Island!!

title: Historical legacy of British empire
review_text: Amongst numerous island which embrace this beautiful land ,this island stands out as testimony to the kind of lifestyle the British created for themselves ,the place they to live during those era .It is an irony that while they indulged in lavish life,they made the life of hundreds of brave freedom fighters a hell by building the cellular cell to up press the movement in a most barbaric manner. Now ,this place is a beautiful resort for tourist coming from various parts of the Country as well from other countries.This is an abode for attractive animals,like ,deers,rabbit,under the lush green trees

title: Unforgettable trip to Ross Island
review_text: Day trip you cannot stay there,Ruins of British Empire in the island worth spending ,do not miss sound and light show in the island, carry raincoat and umbrella with you it is open air show,ferry ride is very good .rainy island take some nibble food with you.

title: Unforgettable trip to rose island
review_text: A wonderful ferry ride to rose island. The ruins were worth a visit, do not miss the sound and light show in the island.

title: Ruins of British empire in the island
review_text: Ruins of British empire in the island.. All the stories were clearly written in the Entrance itself. Sure visit.

title: Small island but must to be visited
review_text:
In case going to Andaman, do not forget to visit this island. 
To reach this point, one has to take a speed boat or jetty from Port Blair sports complex which takes max 5-10 mins. it's beautiful small island consisting ruins of buildings which were earlier used by British. It includes church, hospital, graveyard, power plant etc. Entire area is clean and gives feel of well planned British lifestyle. 

Over to that lot of deer & peacock are on this island which makes this place more beautiful. View of turquoise blue ocean from back end of island is really breathtaking. 

Its good to reach this place around 10-11 in morning as after that it becomes hot and little crowded. More

title: Great island... Small and historic
review_text:
Visited during our trip to Andamans. A chartered speed boat took us there from Port Blair water sports complex. It was a place that British used for short term stays and still has a lot of structures still standing , though in a dilapidated state. Some deer are kept there in the open and our mindless Indian public, despite warning anf notices feeds them all sort of things!! 
It is a good place to spend an hour or so. Also have the Kulfi there. Absolutely smashing!!

title: Small Island which was the Residence of Britishers before 1947
review_text:
Small Island with a beautiful ferar beach.. All the buildings which housed the elite and the ordinary Britishers are in ruins. Island is maintained by Indian Navy. There is a ferry every 30 mins which leaves you for 90 minutes in the island to see things in the Island. 

Island is small with a small hillock and can be covered by foot. there is a small electric cart available but when we visited there was only one driver though there were multiple carts available. 

It takes approximately about 20 mins to cover the island in these carts. Many of the buildings have been consumed by vegetation and the fig trees have spread their roots and make interesting patterns as they have spead all over the walls and pillars of certain buildings. Was reminded of Angkor wat but they are not of the scale as in cambodia as forests have consumed them for less that half a century. 

You can see Deer, Peacock, Peahens ducks and other animals most of them are comfortable to human presence. More

title: Historical place, needs better maintenance.
review_text:
Good place to visit. All the British ruins in a small Island. Good place for kids, as Deer, Peacocks, Rabbits are freely roaming around. 
NO FOOD available. So please carry from Port Blair. 
Entry fee INR 30, Camera Fee extra, think its INR 50.

title: Paradise of Birds, Deer and a Lady Guide
review_text: A great place to visit. The Lady guide is a great attraction. She feeds deer and birds from her hands. A very important historical island with beautiful flora and fona. Must visit if travelling to Port Blair. Now they also offer Light and Sound show at night.

title: Walking though Hisotry
review_text: Ross Island is the smallest Island in A&N group of islands and nearest to PB. Worth visiting as it gives a glimpse of history how the British lived their life in luxury whereas our freedom fighters were struggling to keep the fight for independence alive. Now the remains have been taken over by nature and only the memory remains. Some glimpse of Japanese structures also remain...

title: Serene
review_text: Extremely Beautiful, Scenic ,picturesque ,calm. Cannot depend for food over here, but the view here is mesmerizing.

title: Paris of the East :-)
review_text: The Ross island is a island very close to Port Blair which was considered by the Britishers as the Paris of the east. It is a strategically located island which is controlled by the Navy & has an old church & few other monuments from the British era. Do get a short guide tour when you visit

title: The best island to visit - close to Port Blair
review_text: Ross is just 3-4 kms from Port Blair, seen with the eye as we come to the jetty. It is a beautiful island which has its own history. This island is the one they say saved Port Blair from the Tsunami wrath. If you land here, look out for a guide by the name Anuradha. She is amazing and does a quick 40 minute trip of the island with great detail & passion

title: Haunted island - Don't miss the last boat at 5pm
review_text: The island still has those British time church, bakery, tennis court, Farchand ali tea shop, his clay oven, 300 yr old banyan and peepal trees, bunker, cemetery and so many ancient constructions from the pre British period. No hotels to stay. AC boats are available from Port Blair for day trips. Last boat leaves at 5pm. Don't miss the last boat else you will be perhaps the only living entity in the island other than the age old trees and a handful of deer. It would definitely be a lifetime visit for thrill seeking tourists.

title: Nice place.
review_text: Lots of old colonial dilapidated buildings. And some deer, rabbit and peacocks too. And nothing else. Just a rockey beach. We got about 2 hrs to explore the island due to ferry timings. U have to take the same ferry back to port Blair which brought u to Ross. Ticket price was just ?100. In all a good exp.

title: It was an awesome place to have nice pics with old buildings...
review_text: Yes the buildings look old but they are really photogenic!!! A must visit place.... It is very close to port blair so could be covered in first half of city tour.

title: A look back in 17th century to today
review_text: Ross island is a beautiful island to visit. If u planing better go early in the morning trip or late in eveing . To enjoy more avoid on hot and rainly days. island have many beautiful spices of birds and animals. Densely forest with hares, peacock , dears living in close harmony . old bunkers and building shows it importance in british regime.

title: Old Capital of Andaman in British period
review_text: Ross island is approx 20-25 minutes ferry ride from Port Blair. It has many ruins of British time. Ross island maintained by Indian navy. You can find many old building standing with the help of tree roots (Hati Panjar).

title: ross island
review_text: nice place...if u r intrested in history...worth visiting...its a small island with every facality built by Britishers..

title: good to look
review_text: it is the island which is accessible from marine park with the charge of 100 rs per personal and good to see history here you can see the deer which will eat coconut from your have with out fear.

title: Awesome !!!!
review_text:
Beautiful island n must see for all tourists!! The ruins n maintenance is 
very good.. It's a scenic place n great for pics!!

title: Paris of East
review_text: A 600 Sq mtr. island ! It was used by the British for all their comfort in a place where they otherwise were torturing Indians who were given jail sentence.This place is very well maintained. Here the British would relax after they had finished with their work in the cellular jail. It's amazing that at that time they had most of the comforts that many Indians would still dream of even today. It boasts of a bakery which would give them their daily bakery needs which they were used to in England. There is an amphitheater which still looks amazing. Swimming pool near the shore of the island is very good even today. There are ruins of water treatment plant, ,library & Church. Good thing is that no plastics are allowed in this island there is a Japanese bunker which is well preserved. There are plenty of deers around., giving ample opportunities for photography. Surrounding sea has starfishes of different colours. Boat ride to & fro from Ross island is superb ! More

title: British ruins
review_text:
Ross island which was the British head quarters, The Ross island which is around 1 mile in length and 3/4 mile in width. From water complex area , a boat ride takes you to this island. The same boat takes you back after 1.5 hours. 
We have to walk and see the ruined bungalows, barracks, temple, church cemetary and so on. 
The Ferrar beach on eastern side is the one you have to go by climbing down from the church 
There is a fee for entry and separate fee for video as well as still camera. The tickets are of smart card type and a fine of Rs 200 is charged. The island being of strategic importance , strict security against wanders in the vee hours of the day is ensured. 

In 19th century itself how the British built amenities for their own living is what we could feel More

title: Nicely maintained island
review_text:
This is supposed to be the military head quarters in the past and has been preserved with great shape. There is a nice walkway in the island and you can see old buildings like officers club, filtration plant and a old church. There is access to a beach on the other end of the island as well. 
The area is under Navy control and you need to show identification to enter it with a nominal ticket charge. You need to board a ferry from the jetty next to water sports complex and it is a 10 minutes ride.

title: Truly awesome experiance
review_text:
An Island with welcoming you with the heritage of Britishers/Japanese/India.After landed this Island you will be overwhelmed by the natural habitat of deer/rabbits/peacocks.You 
will take the moments with you wherever you go.

title: Time travel!!!
review_text: Don't miss out of this place. This was called Paris of the east for a good reason. Visit the ruined british empire and their structures and relive the history. A fantastic place to visit

title: Old capital of British colonisation of Andaman
review_text:
Must visit to witness old British monuments, church, bakery, boilers etc. The guide Anuradha Rao is a sporting lady who takes you around the island. 

Deers, Hens, Birds etc.all listen to her and follow her instructions...a memorable site.

title: Must see- Good for Snorkelling and swimming in the Beach
review_text: The waters here are to die for. They have made all arrangements here, right from shelters for you to avoid the sun, life guards for your safety, showers with cold fresh waters, changing rooms, everything. Only warning, the sun can be really strong and you need to be prepared for it.

title: Not much there...
review_text:
I would suggest to visit this island definitely but don't miss the other 2 islands (Most tour operators only take you to Ross only for low ferry cost) 

It takes roughly 10-15 minutes by boat from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports complex. 
The scenic beauty from the boat itself is so picturesque, that I took almost 100 pictures from the boat (only few within the island) 

Entry ticket and digital camera they charge for. 

Deer park is okay (nothing much I see there) 

No restaurant (so, plan your trip accordingly) 

Overall, I don't see any reason spending more than 20 minutes there.

title: “A great place to visit”
review_text: Ross island is approx 20-25 minutes ferry ride from Port blair.It has many ruins of British time.It's a historical place and have broken structures of church, bakery etc.A good number of birds, peacocks, deer to give you company.The view of the beach from the highest point of the island make it worth a visit.There is a light & sound show in the evening, most people dont know about it. This show thousand times better than cellular jail show.Just love it..

title: Beautiful
review_text: Very nice place nearby port Blair 30 mins in ferry island maintained by Indian navy full of greenery and you can see lots of seers roaming very close by to the people try to take the trekking route if ur fit and have lots of time else take the regular paved way. Need half a day for a good visit

title: A photographers paradise
review_text: This is a must visit if you travel to the Andamans. It's a place where you can get great shots to post on your DP. The place is filled with the ruins of the British era. Basically the old buildings are being run over by the ever growing mighty banyan trees. We went there a day after it had rained and got some great stills. Not to miss... guess who welcomed us onshore... a very friendly spotted deer...the place is actually inhabited by them and they are super friendly. To reach this island you can catch a local ferry from Port Blair. You gotta carry water and snacks along because there is nothing much you can get in the island. And again don't forget your camera. More

title: Must visit
review_text: Kids loved the visit to Ross Island though the found the climb up the hill in the sun a bit tiring. When visiting the island, dipping feet into the sea at Ferar Beach is not to be missed. An electric buggy is available for hire for old folks or those in a hurry. The deer, peacocks and rabbits on the island are almost tame. We didnt find any decent restaurants / food stalls so best to carry your own snacks and water.

title: Nature's beauty at its best
review_text: Beauty lying everywhere..loved to see deers and rabbits roaming freely. Britons put swimming pool, bakery and whatever luxury you can think of :-)

title: Very good historical place
review_text: Must go vising place in Port Blair. Family will enjoy. Can get boats from Marine jetty. Visitors have a option for visiting two more islands in one go. The place is maintained by Indian Navy. Have old building of British and bunkers o the Japanese.

title: Memorable visit
review_text: Ross Island is the highlight of the Andaman visit. History is strewn all around this small deserted island. The dilapidated old buildings have been left to decay naturally and that is the best part of the place. Seeing decayed structures with huge trees overwhelming them gives a haunting feeling. Must spend at least 3 hours to explore the place fully.

title: Ruins of erstwhile British HQ
review_text: Known as the Paris of the East in the early part of the 20th century, Ross island is now a relic of the past. The ruins offer a glimpse of the opulent life of the inhabitants of the British HQ. A 15-min ferry ride from Port Blair brought us to Ross Island, and we were pleasantly surprised to be greeted by deers & peacocks freely wandering about the vegetation. After seeing what was left of the power station, ballroom, bungalows and Church, we wandered off towards the other side of the island and a beautiful, clean small beach said hello !

title: Must Visit
review_text: Visiting Ross Island should be a priority for anyone visiting Port Blair. The combination of excellent sceneries, ruins, a mini trek and the freely moving wildlife can be a heady experience for everyone. The is also an excellent light and sound show regarding the island's history in the evenings, which is highly informative and very entertaining.

title: Well maintained island ...
review_text: Had a chance to visit Ross island this June , with my wife , Daughter & few more colleagues with their families . Heared a lot about Ross Island during thr tsunami & on Epic Channel . And was amazed when witnessed in reality , things have changed , except the beach side which was affected by Tsunami is damaged , rest of the damage is managed by locals , Anuradha Rao ( Guide cum care taker of the island ) with Indian Army & Navy . Its a bful exeperience having a walk around the island , British Bakery , Amphitheatre , Church , swimming Pool & Water filtering plant are the attraction , with Deer , Squirrels , Peacock & local animals who have great bonding with Anuradh Rao . My daughter enjoyed feeding the breads to Deers with her own lil hands . Recommended to see the disaster done by Tsunami & the beauty of the island . It takes 8-10 min ride on boat from Port blair to Ross island . More

title: EMARALD GREEN WATERS
review_text: The 2hours Tour of Ross Island was a Photographers Dream and we were shown all the Luxury enjoyed in the Island in the olden times. Coconut water available here quenched our thirst and we took many photos from all angles

title: " Nice island"
review_text: Good to see. 15 min boat drive to reach the island. Island is maintained by indian navy.Deer ,peacock roam around freely . Ross Island is the old British residential colony of Port Blair.

title: Really beautiful
review_text: It is a nice little island. Good to see the pre-independence days structure, though in a very dilapidated condition. Could see some beautiful deers and rabbits roaming around freely with big trees dotting the island.

title: Feel the weight of history
review_text: This place makes you understand how mighty imperials fall prey to nature. If you love nature and history, this is the place to be

title: Not to be Missed at any Cost
review_text:
Ross Island is the old British residential colony of Port Blair. It is a short boat ride from the Aberdeen Jetty. The island has been preserved and maintained in an exemplary manner by the Indian Navy. One can go on a guided tour (or by oneself) of the island. The walking route is very well maintained and full of information boards that explain various landmarks on the island. 

The best part of the visit is the newly commissioned Light and Sound show. The show lasts for about 45 min and is a mix of laser special effects, lights and high quality audio. It is one of the best Light and Sound shows I have ever seen. 

Only 100 tickets are sold for the show every day. Tickets have to be bought from the Tourist Information/ Resource Centre in Port Blair. More

title: Old broken buildings
review_text: It was good clean type place with old torn out infrastructure to roam around. good with kids who enjoyed watching few deers around

title: Best of 3 island tour
review_text: Ross island was our 1st island in our 3 island tour. The place is now lil deserted due to tsunami effect however it doesnt lack lusture in visitors. U can spot dottted deers easily here

title: Nice visit.
review_text: Ross island has a lot of history attached to it with a lot of greenary to click pictures and mesmerise into it. Very beautiful place. Good that we visited it.

title: plz do see the ferrar beach at Ross Island !!
review_text: Please dont forget to see the Ferrar beach .. its beautiful !!... generally people miss out on it as it is on the back side of ross... u need to walk up the island..

title: Nice Island
review_text:
Visited Ross Island where you can go by taking a five minute boat, i suggest taking a deluxe private boat instead of govt. boats which are smelly. 

Ross island is beautiful and nice but need maintenance.

title: Amazing light & Sound show
review_text: Must see the Light & Sound show after you reach there. The island has a rich history and is beautifully projected.

title: Great for nature/history lovers..
review_text: This is a great place if you are a nature walker...it offers great view of the surrounding islands and the history. There is no fun if you are looking for crowd/shopping etc...this is great place for nature/historical walk/climb

title: place to be here if r u in andmaan
review_text: a very fine and well planned island around andamaan ,,lots of things to be explore over here,,,history of its have a thought to you

title: Quiet & Lovely Place
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: Indian Navy is maintaining it very nicely. It depicts the lifestyle of bygone era. A quiet and lovely place

title: Pretty island!
review_text: Nice island about 10 minutes by boat from Aberdeen Jetty. Has a beautiful view of Port Blair and a historic significance. Recommend spending a few hours here on your trip to port blair

title: A one hour tour
review_text:
Taking a ferrry from Rajiv Gandhi Aquatic complex which starts by 8:30am and runs every one hour, we reach Ross island in a matter of 15 mins. There are tickets combo to ross and north bay too, if you have the time. The ferry ticket cost 100rs, while you could also take a speed boat for 250rs. 

The ROss island was the previous administrative block of the ENglish when they ruled there. They shift base to Port Blair after some tremors shook them. The history is displayed on various boards on the island itself. Currently under our Navy, its opened to public. 
The ruins of the old printing press, swimming pool, water distillation system etc can be found there. Here on ROss Island is also the famous Presbyterian church that is a hot shooting location for some of the chart-topping movie songs. 
Entrance fee 30, plus camera 30 more More

title: Simply a perfection
review_text: This island is situated near to Port Blair. Basically visit of this island comes in package with North Bay Island which one can confirm through local agents. This island was once used to be the vacation place for the British people and the evidences of all the facility can be found today also. Island is a protected area by Indian Navy. And its an earnest request donot carry anything that can pollute this beautiful place as well as the health of the Deers. Over here you will get to see lot of deers roaming around freely along with peacock. The rear view of the island adjoining mountain is also amazing. Its a must visit once ya in Andaman. More

title: Very Beautiful Island
review_text: Ross Island is an island which is visible from Port Blair. However, you need to take a ferry to reach there. Also, you have to get an entrance ticket which costs Rs. 30 and for camera, Rs. 30 again. When you purchase the tickets, you will be provided with an access card which you should return while coming out of the island. Else, you should be ready to pay 250 - 300 INR. The total island can be completed by a walk around in 45 - 60 minutes. You have deer, hare etc roaming. You should definitely carry your water bottle or any drink or snack that you require. You have very limited options there. It's an island where no one stays and just used for tourism purpose. Check if you can visit the light house. This light house is famous and is the same one in our 20 rupees note. Good sight seeing place. More

title: Sun, Sand and beach
review_text: Ross Island promises exotic views, radhanagar and kala pathar beach and much more. The landscape and beauty is something worth experiencing in a lifetime. Beaches are clean, well kept and sport activities are a must.

title: Beautiful island
review_text: A very pretty island. Every part and every view was beautiful. The deer and peacocks add to the beauty. Maintained by the Navy, have to pay an entry fee of Rs 25

title: Calm, Beautiful
review_text: Should visit if you are going to North bay. I had done water sports activites at other places, so went to ross island. I liked the place

title: 2 hrs well spent!
review_text:
Ross Island has to be visited from Port Blair by ferry. It takes hardly 10 min to reach there. There are govt ferries at specific times (last ferry is at 2pm from Port Blair) and private operators too. Ferry costs Rs.100 per person and the entry ticket to the island is Rs.30 per person. We went by the 12:30 ferry. You need to come back by the same ferry after 2 hrs. 

The place is full of ruins, which look amazing. It takes an hour and a half to walk. Elderly might find it difficult to visit some places which need a climb. There is a small children's park, which is not much to talk about. Our 4yr old kiddo's got little bored, for him only attraction were the animals. There are rabbits and squirrels and deer in plenty,who are not scared of visitors. 

The place surely deserves a visit for its historical importance. More

title: Glimpses of British elegance in 19th century
review_text: One can reach this place through a short boat ride from Rajiv Gandhi water sports complex jetty by paying Rs 100/- and the entry fee to enter the island is Rs 30/-. Worth walking through the pathways showcasing the ruines of earstwhile British era. There is an electric vehicle for the older people. Coconuts with water are sold for Rs 30/-. It is like a picnic spot.

title: Clean Island
review_text: Ross Island is used by Britisher and Japneese during and before 2nd world war,Nice location for 1-2 Hour, Nice Deer you can feed by your hand,Nice Rabit,Peacock etc.

title: Good to Visit!

title: Live life king size
review_text:
This picturesque island gives a glimpse of how the British rulers of India lived a life of plenty and comfort while the Freedom Fighters languished in the Cellular Jail half-fed and tortured (and finally hanged ‘’till dead”). Keeping this painful history behind, one may try to mentally reconstruct the magnificent place it was. The buildings are in ruins today with roots of huge trees spreading through the red-brick structures (in process cracking these up or holding these together?). The residential quarters, club houses, offices, warehouses, pools etc complete with a chapel are well out with roads winding through these – greeneries abound and beautiful blue sea all around. Try imagining what it was like! 

Pardon my naughty thoughts. I have a suspicion that the settlers also had resorted to the process of tendering, selection of lowest quote, under the table gratifications etc when these buildings were constructed. How else the settlement withered (with due consideration to salt-laden humid condition) within say one hundred years given the kind of engineering prowess the British claimed those days. 

Usually in a package, tourists visit this island for an hour or two, but this site definitely deserves more attention. 

Finally, I would like to record a word of appreciation and gratitude for the excellent upkeep of the site by naval defense establishment. More

At that time they had a tennis court, bakery, market, boiler, church.clubs, hotels, entertainment center ,,The ruins of these buildings are still alive which would make anyone feel that money spent was worth. Adding to the thrill experience with plenty of dear and a picture with these animals would surely make the trip to Andaman’s a memorable one.

One can see many deers rabbits in the island which was nearly destroyed during Tsunami .The only highlight of this Island is the light n music show which takes place every evening.Otherwise the beauty still remains.

title: an interesting place to visit
review_text:
This island is a 10 minute charter boat ride from port blair. during the off season, the charter boat is priced at 250/- per head. it is also covered as a part of the ferry ride to north bay, both islands ferry ticket cost 550/- in total. 
this island was the capital of Andaman during the british rule. It is managed by the navy now and there is a lot of heritage there. You can see japanese bunkers, an old broken presbyterian church, ruins. a lot of deer, peacock, rabbits roam about freely in the open. a lady comes to feed them everyday and you can observe them up close. do not feed them your own food stuff. overall, worth a visit. title: good

title: Stunning

title: A Journey to the past "With Nature as a Spectator"
review_text:
The boat ride (should be pre booked atleast a day before) to Ross Islands is a short one but can be made adventurous if it rains. The whole area is maintained by Defense forces in India - making it very clean and tidy. 

Lots of old buildings and remains and u can carry food along with you and rest along with the humming voice of Ocean. Feel the sensation of deep breath away from all the noise of city life. 

Everything in the islands have perished but Ocean is a witness to this and the looks of the ocean from this place is "grand" - No wonder the British used this as their holiday spot 150 years back More

title: History with coconut water.
review_text:
15 minute ferry ride from Port Blair, ruins on Ross island is a good time pass on a 3 day trip. Old british buildings, complete with bakery, power station, church and barracks compete with the 400 odd deers for attention. Especially ironic is the fact that the supposedly brave British army surrendered to the Japanese without a single shot being fired !! 
Tip : take the toy car ride for the elderly and children.

title: Nice Place
review_text:
A small beautiful island with deer's and peacocks to feed. Lots of coconut trees. 
The island itself has a history one can learn by being there. Most of it got washed away during the Tsunami.

title: Alternate Option.
review_text:
There have been quite a lot of reviews on Ross island and hence nothing much more to add from my end. However, apart from scenic beauty of Ross island, I wish to add an alternative option as well at Aberdeen Jetty for tourist, as we visited the jetty on all the 3 days we stayed here. 

Just before the Aberdeen Jetty bridge there is a small back water bay with a over-bridge. The ocean water level increases or reduces in the small back water bay depending whether is a low tide or high tide. When its low tide with cool climate and if you lucky you can view fishes, coral reef etc. Apart from fishes, coral reefs we were lucky to spot even star fishes. 

There is a good walk way & park at Aberdeen jetty and hence you spend time gazing at scenic beauty of this place, particularly in the evenings. More

title: Even Ruins can be beautiful!!!
review_text: Ross Island is one of those places that takes you back into time. The boat ride from Port Blair is enough to get you in the spirit of travels but as soon as you land there its like you have travelled to another time. The Japanese Bunker that welcomes you along with the azure blue waters is just amazing. As you traverse on the island you encounter Deer, Peacock, Squirells and so may flaura and fauna. The ruins add a certain mystic nature to the place and the remnants of the British Raj will bring memories which are etched in History. All in all one of the best places I have visited in the Andamans. Will wait to go there another time soon!!! More

title: Beauty in destruction

title: ross island

review_text:

A small museum is also there, it shows how efficiently the Britishers had equipped the island with facilities like Water purifier plant, hospital, club house, electricity generators, swimming pool, school, church, bakery & cemetery even before so many years. 

You need to take a fairy to reach that island. There is entry fee as well. There is a beach down the hill, is a must visit place. It will take half day.

title: Ross Island - An enchanted island
review_text:

A gateway island created in the British Era - had everything from a Chuch, Officers Clubs to swimming pool and filteration plant . you see ruins and can almost imagine the glittering ball ,clink of glasses ,if you let your imagination run .Serene and peaceful with Deers and peacocks residing in large numbers ,it also has a fantastic beach and lighthouse .HAs golf cart paid rides around the island for those who have trouble walking . A cocunut water seller close to the Church ruins is a welcome releif to charge your energies .an enchanted island -you may love it or think no big deal -its all in the way you see it . Have recently started a sound and light show here More

title: A forlorn throwback to a majestic era
review_text: Ross Island, with its stately ruins of a church, bakery, club etc stands as a reminder of the past glories that it wielded. It is difficult to imagine that such a tiny piece of land could have housed such a bustling population and that it lacked for nothing in terms of entertainment, all basic needs taken care of. Now uninhabited except by a few deer and lots of rabbits, there was a time when people were born, lived and died there. When i stood at the altar of the now dilapidated Presbyterian Church, my mind went back to the numerous services that must have been conducted there. When one walks into the musty remains of the bakery, one wonders of what delightful items it must have churned out, long long ago. Barring the ruins, which make one ponder and wonder how life must have been back then, is also a small little stretch of beach, quietly tucked away at the eastern tip of the island. This is an idyllic spot with some good surf. It might take one away from the overall melancholy of the island and its ruins. More

title: Old ruins of the British Era...
review_text: Located just bang opposite to the Rajiv Gandhi Sports Complex. Takes around 10-15 mins by Ferry. You can see the old dilapidated British buildings over there and roam around. Nothing else much.

title: Good one
review_text: Got the tickets from water sports complex. It is a nice island. British ruins. Do take umbrella sunshades etc because there is lots to go around.Quite nice. The trees with its roots with water retaining capacity and all were very magnificent. Visited on April 2014

title: Very Good Scenic Picture
review_text: The Island offers very good scenic picture and worth visiting it once. It also has remains of old church, German bakery though much of the attractions have been destroyed by latest tsunami as well.

title: Lovely Island
review_text:
The island is about 3Km from Port Blair and is quite peaceful. The island is huge and it takes time to go around. You have deers walking next to you. 
The story of the Island is nice and historic.

title: History of the British and Japenese
review_text: Ross Islands is a small boat ride away from port blair. Regular boats as well as specialised motor boats ply on this route. The islands had the housing of the British from where they kept a watch on the cellular jail on the port blair island. The Ross Island has on the remains of the historical buildings. Entire round of the island can be completed in a few hours. There are deers who have become accustomed to people. All there are bunkers which were built by the Japanese. The island changed from the hands of the British to the Japanese and again back to British. There are images of how the historical buildings looked in their prime. The island had its own power station!! Nice place to visit to know about the history. More

title: The Anglo-Japanees cultured island
review_text: This Island is used as for the officer's residential area. Beautifully maintained place can be made as tourist guest house by Andaman Government to provide the experience of heritage living

title: A cute ghostly town, perfect combination of history and nature!
review_text: It takes around 10-15 minutes by a local ferry from Water Sports Complex to reach Ross Island. Once the Administrative Headquarters for the islands now one can only see remnants of an sumptuous past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool, hospital, open air theater, bakery, water distillation plant and other facilities for chief commissioner's residence, now engulfed by the roots of huge trees. There is also a cemetery and a small museum managed by the Indian Navy. The place gives picturesque views from all around. A ghostly town taking you back in its history turns live with your eyes, its nostalgic yet so peaceful being there with just nature talking to you, an added perk is the number of Peacocks, Parrots, Deer and Ducks you can spot at the Island. The back side of the Ross Island gives a lovely view of the open sea. The island is organized in a good manner, pathways, barricades and proper signs to navigate. The Japanese occupation of the Andaman Islands occurred in 1942 during World War II. Japanese bunkers and Cannon still stand as a memorial in this island. There is an entry fee to this Island, its controlled by Indian Navy. More

title: Portblair
review_text: One must visit this Island.It is near to Portblair.British and japanese empire stayed there and ruled the Port blair.It is also historical place.

title: Just off Port Blair
review_text: We had taken the 3 island tour and Ross Island was the first island that we visited. It has the ruins of the British establishment that used to run the Andaman and Nicobar Islands in British times. It is now under the Indian Navy.

title: Ross Island visit
review_text: The Britishers were so scared of the jailed Indian freedom fighters lodged in Cellular Jail that they stayed on a different island. The ruins of all the facilities that they had can still be seen on Ross Island. The island is now under the control of the Indian Navy, and is well maintained.

title: old paris
review_text: it is island with flora and fauna there are peacocks deers rabbit you can touch them there are bunkers made by japanese during worldwar 2 there is a little lake and ruins of church once it was capital during british period

title: Paris Of East
review_text: It is a small but breathtakingly beautiful island. In Eighteen century it was administartive Capital of Andaman and Chief Commissioner and other English Officers used to live there and at that time all modern facilities as available in Paris, was there. So this island is called " Paris Of East". But After 2nd World war this island was captured by Japanese and lost it glory. Now is is a Ghost town. Nowadays there are only Old ,ruined dilapidated buildings and signs of 100 years old British settlements.

title: Animal Kingdom of Anuradha Rao
review_text: Ms. Anuradha Rao was our guide, who arranged the car for us and showed us arround the little animal kingdom which she built with just 3 deer, 2 peacock and 1 rabbit in the beginning. This island was the capital of the britisher's who used to rule andamans during the colonial rule. a nice place to spend time

title: ruins of world war II
review_text: nothing much to see, you have to catch ferry from port blair water complex , it takes 10 mins to reach ross island. This island has some history related to world war II. you can feel that magic here .

title: VISIT TO ROSS ISLAND
review_text: This island was the home of the British community before India's independence. It was well guarded with its own power plant for supplying electricity and potable water. You can see the Lancashire Boilers lying there. It is a well laid out island, being occupied by Indian Navy Today. It has become a tourist spot and you can see deers running here & there. Lot of places to sit & rest. A nice museum depicting Andaman during British days.

title: Animal Lovers
review_text: Excellent flaura and fauna, variety of animals at hands reach and very safe. A very exciting and nostalgic place.

title: Historical place now, worth visiting
review_text: The biggest surprise post entry there was Deers, rabbits etc at the site. It was like a mini Safari with them for the historical place. Generally clubbed with North Bay island viist.

title: Very interesting and scenic
review_text: I wasn't sure what to expect, but the island is basically a large, well set-up museum of old British rule. The ruins on the island are fascinating to look at/walk through and everything is well-labeled. The island itself is very beautiful and if you hike across the island (it's not far!), you're rewarded with a view of the ocean.

title: Simply Breath Taking
review_text: Make sure you visit the beach on the back side of Ross Island. The water over there is amazingly clean & clear. Although this is not much hyped or advertised, the beach is simply brilliant. The Island still has glimpses of the luxury that the Britishers had while there were here...

title: A must visit place with history "A Lost City"
review_text:
A lost city which is having ruins of church, british rule, swimming pools, ground, deer park, peococks. 

For more details : http://www.thetravelreminiscences.in/2015/02/amazing-andamans-day-5-north-bay-island.html

title: where history and breathtaking scenery merged together
review_text: The old dilapidated buildings, testimonies of more than 100 years old British settlements, takes one back to the colonial past while the vast stretches of coconut groves extending into the pristine blue waters of Andaman Sea leaves one with an exotic feeling. While taking a stroll one comes across deers, peacocks and rabbits which adds to the charm of the visitor. One can see the remnants of a printing press, power station, water distillation engines, a club, swimming pool, a church and the cemetery, not to mention the Ferar Beach.

title: Must Visit Island in Andaman for its brilliant beach views & archaeological structure
review_text:
Superb place in port blair, itself a Island in port blair. 
Many ferries are there to visit the same island as it is only 2-3 KM sea distance from port blair. 
Indian Navy is handling & maintaining the Island,View is superb ,many old archaeological second world war & tsunami destroyed buildings blocks & church are there.some back part of Island was destroyed and completely dissolve in sea in 2001 & 2004 Tsunami, The place looks awesome & picture perfect. 
Old British capital for leisure & summer holidays in india before indian independence. 
Must Visit Place in Andaman Island, happy travelling.

title: Must Vist place
review_text: ruins of british rule, damaged buildings,church are highlight. Lot of Deers,Rabbits and Peacoks are available...

title: way back in time
review_text: If you are in Port Blair, you have to visit the Ross island. It takes 20-30 minutes via boat to reach the island. Get introduced to Anuradha Rao, who takes care of the animals inhabiting the island. Take a tour of the island and hear remarkable stories from her.

title: Something extraordinary
review_text: This is one of the best island of Andaman. You will easily find deer, rabbits, peacocks on the island. You can even click photographs with them.This is exciting. Untouched and clean environment makes you feel amazing. Don't miss Ross island if you are in Andaman!

title: Very close to nature
review_text: It was the capital of Andaman at time of British. Animal like deer, peacock are available here. They dont fear human, they will come close to you. you can touch them.

title: Ross, ross
review_text: just beautiful island . easily accesible by boat, there is not much to see, but visit itself is mind blowing. you go via aberdeen jetty, which is full of natural breeze.lovely place, even to sit for hours.

title: Close to nature & animals
review_text: Its one of the beautiful island in Andaman. Its beauty can be seen only when you visit the island. Animals like Deers & Rabbit are close watch. Heritage & ruined buildings like Commissioner's House, Church, Bakery, etc. can be seen. with a small virgin beach on the opposite side of island is must visit.

title: A must on itinerary
review_text: Very interesting place to visit. In fact a must if you are in Andamans island. Just a couple of Kms away from Port Blair. They have saved it from onslaught of visitors. Very well looked after. Old ruins and views are breathtaking. Only one thing that there is no good restaurant type eating place. Deers, ducks, peacocks, rabbits move freely. They have a small museum as well. Just pictures of old and present structures, but interesting.

title: Ross Island - Ruins / Remains of high class past.
review_text:
Named after the marine surveyor Sir Daniel Ross, Ross Island is one of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, about 2 km east of Port Blair. Ross Island was the headquarters of the Indian Penal Settlement for nearly 80 years. The freedom fighters built houses, offices, barracks and other structures. The bungalow, meant for the chief of the Penal Settlement, was constructed at the northern summit of the Island called Government House. Today remains of high class past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool, water treatment plant, printing press and the chief commissioner's residence found hugged by huge roots and trunks of century old trees. The Government House became the residence of the Japanese admiral also for three years (from March 1942 to October 1945). During this period that Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose, who took the help of Japanese in his fight against the British, stayed at the Island for a day in December 1943. Netaji also hoisted the national Tri-color at the top of the Government House. The Japanese too left their imprint on the island which stood in the form of bunkers. The bunkers were used as watch points to safeguard the Island from any foreign invasion. The island is full of greenery stags and rabbits can be seen wandering here and there. In the eastern side Ferar beach lays which has clear water and beautiful green surrounding. Huge trees can be seen. For children a park... To reach Ross Island, private ferries are available from Aberdeen Jetty except on Wednesday. Combined ticket for North Bay and Ross Island is Rs 600/- each for return journey. More

title: Historical Gem and DO NOT miss the light and sound show
review_text:
This island has a rich piece of history and was the capital of the Britishers during their rule in this region. The ruins of the Commissioner's Bungalow, Presbyterian church, distillation plants and other buildings are magnificent. 

After spending an hour there in the evening, do not miss the light and sound show. It's a brand new show with Hindi narration by Gulzar and English one by Shabana Azmi. Technically superb and well narrated.

title: Must visit if you are at port blair
review_text:
you can get boat from port blair water sports complex jetty , the round trip tickets around 300INR per person for private boat , goverment boats are cheaper 

you are at ross in 1,2--5 minutes by speed boats. 

things to see roaming deer , rabits , view port blair , old power house, lancashire boilers are there , sea beach , coconut tree , 

you can take pic with deer and peacocks .

title: Bit disappointing
review_text: Though this island is well kept, it has nothing much to see except few deer and peacocks. Its part of package to North Bay island

title: Beauty
review_text: A very beautiful island which is easily approachable through government ships. It is also said that during the Tsunami this island saved Port Blair as it stood between Port Blair and deadly Tsunami.

title: An island that saved port blair!
review_text: It took most of the brunt of tsunami & saved most of port blair. This is also a historical place of pre independence era that brits developed. There are a few japanese bunkers here. A nice place to see for couple of hours.

title: Just an another island!
review_text: its very scenic and nice to visit ross island. generally u get an hr or two spend here. good place to chill and roam around. nothing much to do except the boat ride and and few places to see in ross island. dont expect anything spectacular but again if got nothing else to do then its worth the visit

title: Gr8 lady Anuradha Rao if you don't meet her you missed it
review_text: This place is nothing if you don't meet the gr8 lady named Anuradha Rao she is ultimate I have never met such gr8 human being, you know why I am praising her because she communicates with the animals in Ross island she treat them as one take care of her kids. The best part they listen to her very nicely in fact they obey her. She is really a nice lady with lot of knowledge of the island she is living in port blair since her birth she knows many things about the island we loved her the knowledge she shared with us is really useful, we were honoured to sit with her for few minutes my son loved her the most as she was not harming any animals there @ island she communicates with the birds she feed them with the bread without yeast especially made for them. Hats off to you Anuradha Mam...Please whenever you go just meet her. More

title: Beauty of Port Blair.
review_text:
If you are planning a tour to Port Blair you can't miss out on Ross island. 
Located approx 20km west of Port Blair surrounded by blue water can be accessed by boat which just cost around 50rs one way. 
Place is known for Japanese bunker's and it's history which once use to be the favorite place of Britisher's. 
As you have limited time Coz your ferry back to Portblair permits you 90 min on the island you will be able to access the eastern part of it where you can see some old Japanese bunker's and old buildings such as a printing press, a water distillery and badminton court etc. 
However don't miss out on the sound and light show which is newly introduced starts after sunset around 7 PM it tells you about the history of the island and believe me it's worth it. 150 Rs for to and fro ferry and the show just make sure to buy the tickets before they get full. More

title: Don't miss the light & sound show..
review_text: There's nothing much to see in Ross Island, only remains of broken buildings wrapped up with trees & shrubs.. But the main attraction of the island is the light & sound show. I was taken by surprise to see the technology used for the same. Its Asia's first HD video mapping technology.. You have to see it to believe it.

title: Good place
review_text: V took ferry from port Blair to Ross Island n back. Island is very calm n beautiful. U Wud find Some historic broken/damaged monuments. U can also see deers, peacocks, rabbits, cocks etc. roaming freely. U won't get anything to eat/drink except kulfi n nariyal Pani. Also thr is a beach, bit difficult n far to reach but worth exploring.

title: Roots all around.
review_text: A short journey from jetty. The island was developed by the British for their comfortable stay. The most notable part of this island are the roots that covers the walls forming beautiful patterns and make u wonder that trees are actually growing on the roofs.

title: Awesome island
review_text: This island carries history. This is the island which saves portblair from tsunami.This is basically a baren island.lots of deer,peacock and rabits can be seen.But boats are giving very less time to experience this beatiful island.

title: Absolute beauty
review_text: I will call this small island as the savior of Port Blair. The fact is that, this island took a big tsunami wave onto itself thus saving major devastation in the city of Port Blair. From Port Blair side, this island appears very beautiful & photographic with the different colours of sky adding to its beauty. Not just this, the island itself is very historic and was called the Paris of East by the British rulers of India then. Just do not miss it.

title: Barren Island
review_text: Nice place to see, lots of rabbits, deers and peacocks to view. It is a short trip from port blair to Ross Island via a boat.

title: Do not miss the beach... Its tough to access it but worth the pain
review_text: The best part of Ross island was certainly the beach. The access to the beach is tough, steep and atrocious, if I may say so, but it you can physically manage it, its a must see. Another attraction is the deer and peacocks. The ruins of the bakery, press, secretariat, church and other monuments are really in ruins.

title: Small Island with big history
review_text:
Ross Island, a small Island of seventy acres was the original capital of Andamans. Initially, the seventy acre Island was divided into halves by a wall measuring from the east to the west. The accommodation of the British officers and soldier’s barracks remained in the north of the wall on the hilltop, while the convicts and the barracks of Indian soldiers were in the south. Needless to say, British side was opulent - ruins of the church, swimming pool,water purification plant, ice-making plant and the chief commissioner's residence with its huge gardens and grand ballrooms stand testimony to those days. Life at Ross Island, was leisurely for the English officers and their wives while convicts [freedom fighters] struggled to keep the island spic and span. The end of the golden era of Ross island began in June 1941 when it was rocked by a severe earthquake. Deep cracks were spotted in many buildings, inhabitants assumed that island was sinking and abandoned Ross Islands. Once feted as the Paris of East, Ross Island became a ghost town. In the year 1942, Japanese landed on the island and took charge of the Island. There was hardly any resistance by British as much of the Island was evacuated. During their tenure, Japanese forces demolished the public buildings at Ross Island, extracted materials for various strategic constructions works all over the Islands. Today 
Since 1979, Indian Navy maintains Ross island. The place is devoid of any permanent human settlement. However, it is home to extra friendly 350 deers and 70 peacocks. More

title: Be there definitely
review_text:
Right from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex, it’s a short boat trip to reach Ross Island. There you will have “Island Tourist Boat Operators’ Association” to issue ticket (Rs.100/- per head, to and fro) after completing the formalities like filling up a form, provided by the authority. There are other operators, who offer speed boat and claims Rs.250/- per head (to and fro). 

We, however, preferred ITBOA and were allotted the boat at 11-30. On reaching the island we were greeted by the ruins of wealthy past. Once the Headquarter of the islands is now taken care of by the Indian Navy. In every trip the visitors are allowed to stay there for two hours and fifteen minutes. 

There is a Cafe in the island, where you can have tea, coffee, snacks etc. And yes, we had the chance to spare some minutes with a nice little cute deer. 

Be there definitely. More

title: Excellent place
review_text: This is a must place to visit all tourist.Lot of human friendly deers and peacocks.You can feed deers here.You will be sorrounded by deers when you arrive at this Island.Very Good light and sound show.Good Quality sound system.A must place for every one

title: Must watch & value for money
review_text:
This is the best place. the view is excellent & animals u found. 
you can spend 4-5 hours. But dont forget to take water.coconut water u find there.

title: Nice ambience
review_text: The island is small and clean. However there is nothing much to do there. Only attraction are the deer whom you can feeding with your hands. However make sure to take private boat there as the public boats are not clean and carry about 60-80 people together which becomes really very crowded and fussy.

title: Relics of the British Raj
review_text: While the cellular jail will break your heart, the relics of the style and comfort in wihch the British rulers lived will leave you fuming at the injustice. It is a beautiful island no doubt. Go there as early as you can as the sweltering heat will make it impossible to explore otherwise

title: A nice ride down history
review_text: It was the place where the British officers set up their quarters. So you will find an Officers' club, a church, quarters and even a 200 years old graveyard... The island is closed in the evening.

title: good one
review_text:
Britishers and Japanese captured this island worth seeing . 
Bunker and other old buildings are self explanatory

title: Must-Must Visit
review_text: This is something you can simply not ignore. The history associated to this place is immense and you'll be amazed with the technology used in those times for their comfort.

title: Sound and light show
review_text: There's a new sound and light show on Ross island using new technology. It describes the history of the island in particular. Very different from the show in cellular jail. The 3D imagery, the narration and in fact the entire show is just amazing. A must visit place. Plan it separately in the evening.

title: One of my favourite Andaman Islands
review_text: BEAUTIFUL. The way nature has grown around historical relics is amazing. The "light and sound show" reminded me of Disney Dreams (for Indian history buffs, that is :P). The sunset, the gentle animals, the pristine beach...it's all fantastic!

title: Positive surprise
review_text:
Ross Island turned out to be an unexpected highlight in our time around Port Blair. Having only half a day to kill we didn’t have high expectations, but what we found there was pretty stunning. Being interested in botany, it was amazing to find tropical palms and trees from all over the former British Empire. Royal Palms from the Caribbean, Mauritias from South America and a mature Morton Bay Fig from Queensland, Australia. Better than any botanical garden I have visited in Southern India. It is hard to believe that the buildings being slowly reclaimed by the rainforest have only been abandoned in the 1940s. The overgrowth was kind of reminiscent of the remoter Mayan ruins in Quintana Roo and Guatemala. There are lots of deer, peacocks and rabbits roaming the island, an absolute delight if you travel with children. 
The only drawback was the time limit. We would have appreciated to spend one more hour on this interesting little island. More

title: Must Visit
review_text: Earlier known as "PARIS OF THE EAST" is really exceptional.Makes no sense,if anyone returns from there without watching Light & Sound Show.

title: Visit to Ross Island
review_text: Please keep the island clean and leave only your foot steps. Say BIG NO to plastics and please do not tease/touch the animals. The authorities should implement strict rules which they display only - do not seem to implement

title: Ruins, but good to see
review_text:
This island used to be the headquarters of the British army. Currently, it is governed and managed by Indian army. 

There's nothing much to do on this island except for admiring the historical monuments like British administrative office , church, residents of British officers etc. Most of the buildings are in ruins. There are a few deer and rabbits on this island. One of the guides told us that this was the places where the Tsunami hit first

title: Average place to click some photographs
review_text: It is a small island, where you can see lot of deer, birds etc. Do not spend much time here as it has nothing much to see except you can have some photographs clicked there.

title: Ruins are beautiful
review_text:
A 10 minute ferry ride from the Rajiv Gandhi sports complex takes you to the wonderful Ross Island. This was the British capital while they were here and since then it has been left to rot, and how well has it rotten. It is currently maintained by the Indian Navy and is a must visit place in Port Blair. Be prepared to walk and hike if you want to catch a glimpse of everything as you only get around 2 hours here before the ferry leaves. 
All the amazingly architectured building have been left to natures fury. It really feels like you are in a video game and are trying to find a treasure stacked somewhere in one of those ruined buildings. 
To add to that there is some tame wildlife as well, There are plenty deer and peacocks that roam around freely in the island. The batter down church is a sight to behold. Lots of informative boards are placed all over the place so you don't really feel like you need a guide for this place. 
The island spans 3/4mile by 1/2 mile, but make sure you are fit and have lots of water as the heat can really get to you. More

title: An island of history deer, peacocks
review_text: A small island inhabited either by numbered coconut trees or deer and other domestic creatures. You take one round on the paved path and you will reach the other end of the island. A historic church, a cemetery and few other sights with peacocks flying over you is what you get here. The shining sun on water amidst bunch of coconut trees is what I couldn't help capturing. One can also easily see groups of colorful fishes(tiger and clown fishes) while stepping out of the ferry.

title: HISTORY IN NATURE
review_text: From Aberdeen jetty boats are leaving for Ross Island for Rs100 charges to and fro. The island is maintained by Indian Navy and they charge nominally from the visitors. Defence persons get discount on showing I Card. the Place is nicely maintained. The roots of trees grpased the debris of the old buildings. Peacock, deers are just freely roams, enjoyed their close view and taken photos.The boat leaves the tourist there for two hours. Though this time is enough to see the place still we had to make a hurry. Nice place and not to miss.

title: Historical place!!
review_text: It consists of old buildings that Britishers built. There is no restaurant so get your food packed before you leave for the island.

title: A worthwhile trip
review_text: Despite the fact on the ten minute trip across to the island one has to don a life jacket, the effort is very worthwhile. A route round this once extensive colonial town is well marked out, and the markers are very informative. With a bit of imagination one can almost see the original inhabitants!

title: A stroll worth remebering
review_text:
The most unfortunate part of visit was we had a bare minimum of 1 hour to roam in the Island. The place has a lot of deer , peacocks, squirrels and occasional rabbit. There are a lot of old building, water treatment plant, church etc. The tree root covered remains of the structures are excellent place for a few photo snaps. 

Me and my husband to find a really beautiful beach when travelling further away. This beach was covered in smooth pebbles surrounded by palm trees. It's was pure pleasure to just enjoy the scenic beauty of it for a few moments. 
Though there are no proper restaurant or cafe near by. The Walk was still enjoyable. More

title: Place with British History
review_text: 10 minutes from portblair by jetty and you get to the place where britishers had their base to control the cellular jail... Place full of historic importance, you would see deers, peacocks. Overall a nice place.

title: Good for a stroll in the british history
review_text: 10 min from the jetty close to cellular jail, hire a guide, it is really better with a guide, island is big keep atleast 2 hrs to roam around the island at ease, got to the lone soldier memorial to pay a salute to the brave sailors at one end of the island, very few people reach it. the island has ruins of british settlement which have nicely been overtaken by the huge artistic trees growing on them.

title: Just walk around....
review_text: There are dears roaming about, you can hear peacocks and kids had fun spotting them. They chased a few rabbits too. As for history, its all round....

title: An eye opener to times gone
review_text:
Considering that I had so much to see and do in a seven day holiday in the Andamans, I wasnt initially sure about visiting Ross Island. I did not desire to just "log" an attraction! However, I was pleasantly amazed at what I saw in Ross Island. Ross Island is an amazing piece of history. With its dilapidated structures - often still held in place with mangrove vegetation - it gives one a rare glimpse of British colonial history and their lifestyles. The Commissioner's Bungalow, the church, the cemetery, the subordinates' club, the distilled water plant, officers quarters, a couple of other bungalows still manage to take us back to that period. The island is with the Indian Navy and they are doing quite a wonderful job maintaining it. Maybe better than even the Archaeological Society of India or some of the tourism departments. But then that is not their forte. Construction of a cemented path in some places is not in keeping with the general theme. I saw ground behind the Commissioner's Bungalow being dug up - probably for constructing some new Naval Bungalow. Wonder who it is for. But if this construction is permitted - it might just damage the heritage Commissioners Bungalow. The Ferrar Beach is another attraction on this island. It also has a quint Japanese bunker. I am told that a Light and Sound show has been started at Ross - however, my itinerary did... title: excellent island in Andaman
review_text: Really beautiful and excellent island for nature lovers Ross island was one of the important headquarters of British rular in that time present this island is under administration of Indian army many historical monuments like British administrative office , church, residents of British officer, boilers, many beautiful animal like deer rabbit etc.

title: Must visit
review_text: Hi guys.. this island is very close to port Blair.. you can take ferry boat for this island from jetty.. Must Carry food or snacks with you.. only coconut water is available... 90 min required to watch this island..

title: Colonial Masters Citadel
review_text: This tiny island is the last leg of my package tour.I boarded a boat from Aberdeen Jetty and was taken to this island which is a short distance away.This place has many historical features like the era of British colonial masters,the occupation by the Japanese and after WW2, the British handed it over to the Indian Navy.The island also took its toll from the wrath of a major earthquake, where many buildings were damaged,the island nearly cracked into 2 halves and later by the devastating effect of a huge tsunami.The sea walls built by the British surrounding the island was damaged at many places.The island is small ,hilly and heavily forested and an energetic person can walk around the circumference of it quite easily. The damaged buildings are engulfed by the roots of old tall trees.There are many deers which is tame,many types of birds and other wildlife found in the island.This is a very interesting place,worth a visit. title: Best beach
review_text: Just the boat trip from the main island port blair to ross island is amazing. Watching the dolphins on the way is awesome. Its a really good place for a family holiday trip.

title: nice place for one time visit ....
review_text: its good experience to visit a small island with a history ... nice historical places ..., Lots of Deers & Peacock ... very friendly with the humans... if possible go with Anuradha guide ... She is the only guide there .... knowing this island since her childhood ...

title: Well maintained and Scenic
review_text: I liked the place very much. It is a place of historic importance. Got chance to see Deer and peacock very closely. We wnet to the backside of the island. A beautiful location.

title: Japan Banker here
review_text: I Like grave yard of 1700 AD and a grave of 23 yrs old British Navy boy. and the action of tsunami on this hill

title: The good old britishers
review_text: Fortunately, this place has been retained as it was during the british regime. A nice little island, surrounded by sea from all sides had luxurious facilities for their leisure time. An wonderful place to spend some time.

title: Royal island...
review_text:
The entire island is one of its best kind. The animals and birds are so human friendly that kids enjoy their company to the core. Probably this is the USP of this island. 

Infact we have never come across the deers in such a close contact...the best part was we saw dancing peacocks which is a lifetime experience..sitting on the pond side was absolutely charming on the island which was the source of fresh water.. 

The only beach at the rear side of the island, though visitors not allowed to get down..was absolutely mesmerising. The water so clean and blue...I can't express my elation through words spending time there. 

The island still show cases the royalty which Britishers enjoyed keeping it capital of Andamans, they produced one of the dream islands of their age... 

Overall it had been one of the best attractions of the local sites in Port Blair. More

title: Visit review
review_text: Well maintained by the Indian navy. The past glory can only be imagined, magnificent place. Wish there were good eating joints.

title: Really enjoyed it!
review_text: 100Rs for the government ferry, 30 for entrance when you're there, and another small fee depending on if you have a still/video camera. It doesn't look much from the jetty but it's a get at island to explore. Lots of signs for learning along the way, and the trees that have taken over the buildings are incredible. Some trees you can tell a building use to be there for the fact the roots have created door holes and windows although bricks are no longer there. You're free to explore yourself or get a guide. Unfortunately my boat left 15 minutes late so I didn't have all the time to explore when I was there but I saw most of it. There are wild deer, peacocks and bunnies everywhere too! Well worth a visit and only a few hours of your day, I do suggest taking bottles of after with you though. Some parts are very hilly and in the sun it can be quite draining. More

title: Paris of the East
review_text: "Paris of the East" as it was called during the British rule, this island gives you the feel as to how posh the top British officers used to stay in India. We were about to skip this attraction due to lack of time, but luckily we made time and visited this island. No one should miss visiting this island. By the way, this island took a big tsunami wave onto itself & saved a massive devastation from taking place in Port Blair. An heroic island indeed.

title: Don't miss the sound & light show
review_text: Ross Island is ideally a two part trip, the morning to evening portion includes going around the island looking at the ruins from the era of the British and Japanese rule. the late evening portion includes a spectacular sound, light & video show (yes you read it correctly!!) which has been created specially for Ross island by Revathi (the actress)

title: Good to spend few hours here...
review_text: The time the boat guys give to roam here is not sufficient to go around this island unless you're jogging from the word go...should spend atleast 3-4 hrs to go around the entire island.

title: Another brilliant place
review_text: This is another wonderful place ! We took the evening ship which takes you to the island and includes the light and sound show! It is actually more than a light and sound show and a must visit! If you miss it you will really miss something so make sure you go for it!

title: Quite, Breezy and Relaxing
review_text: The best island to sit back and relax. Deers, peacocks, rabbits were few animals seen roaming around. The island is small and has lot of old buildings to see like church, hospital, japanese bunkers etc. Entry fee is Rs. 30 and if you want to take camera then shell out another 30 bucks. The beach has very beautiful view and you will have some of the best pictures clicked at this location.

title: EARSTWHILE CAPITAL OF ANDAMAN
review_text: It was a memorable experience to see all remains of the capital of British Era. It was very good learning to listen to the guide telling history of the remains at this dilapidated township. Its closeness to the nature and the animals like deer,peacock,variety of birds with all urban facilitiesmust be a enjoyable staying those days.

title: A truly unique experience - don't miss it!
review_text: This is a small island like many others in Andaman - but has some very unique features. Maintained by the navy, it is clean and has well-defined processes. You will use the same boat from and to Port Blair. They will give you 2-3 hours on the island to explore and relax. There are deer, rabbits and peacock that roam around freely on the island and seeing these creatures (esp. the deer) at such proximity is amazing. They are docile and will give you a wonderful photo op. PLEASE respect & follow the rules set by authorities - don't touch, feed or scare these creatures. Besides this, the island has old abandoned houses from the British era that have been covered by growing trees and creepers. It looks haunting and beautiful at the same time. This island took the brunt during the Tsunami and the navy has done a wonderful job of restoring it. There is a govt.-run canteen with nominally priced meals. If you are tired and can't walk around the island anymore - just sit and enjoy the relaxing view of the blue sea around you. Warning - the water leading from Port Blair to Ross Island is a little choppy - so be careful if you get sea sick easily. More

title: can visit if u have time

title: Quite and Relaxing place

title: beautiful island
review_text: u can see a variety of birds,dear,plants etc.u can also see old villas ,old church etc.nice place. One can see remnants of an opulent past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool and the chief commissioner's residence with its huge gardens and grand ballrooms. There is also a cemetery and a small museum managed by the Indian Navy.

title: british power show
review_text:
this is the island on which the British made their home for administering the cellular jail in port blair,situated directly opposite this small island. 
the British officers and staffs stayed here and everyday moved by boat to port blair.this island is a miniature British set up, complete with a bakery, the building being still intact. 

most of the quarters are in ruins.the church only has the facade now. 
the pond with lilies is a show piece.the Japanese occupied it for about three years, including the port blair cellular jail.they made a few bunkers, one survives to day on this island. 
it is a very small island but looks very cute. a visit is recommended. More

title: capital of Ruler.
review_text:

Its a beautiful island and there is walk way made up and there are picture side by side which is self explanatory.
