one hours time is required to surf around this place. 15 to 20 mins will be time duration from sport complex jetty to reach ross island by boat.

title: Has the best beach in the port blair area
review_text:
Ross island is an historically significant island owing to the fact that it was the first place inhabited by the British with 200 freedom fighters as prisoners. 

This is currently under Indian Navy. 

One could spend a whole day at this place and still could not capture all its beauty. 

The Ferro beach at the back of Island is one of the most beautiful beach I have ever been too. 
Alas we could spend only 1hr30min here due to the jetty and our tour planner regulation.

title: Ross Island with added attraction, A must visit site
review_text:
Ross Island, the erstwhile capital of the islands recently added a feature in the form of a Sound and Light Show to its list of offerings. The one hour show takes visitors into the history of India's freedom struggle vis-a-vis the islands, specifically the Ross Islands. 
Trip to Ross has been planned in such a way that visitors are ferried to the island (Ex : Aberdeen Jetty at 4pm) well in advance so that visitors get ample time to see the islands before the sun sets, thereafter the show is conducted near the ferry point. Tickets @ Rs 250/- per head inclusive of ferry charges, entry permit and show are available from single window at Directorate of Information Publicity and Tourism, Port Blair. A must visit site while in the Islands. More

title: Awesome

title: Beautiful
review_text:

The Island was a home to the Britishers & it is such a contrast to the Cellular Jail just opposite to it. 
Although all would not recommend you top go there but i would as it has historical importance.

title: Picturesque but grotesque
review_text: Ross osland ,known as the paris of the east when the british empire ruled . .had all that a king could ask for ,but at the expense of the convicts and freedom fighters .meet anuradha the official guide who ia a very interesting and unique guide ,takes you thro histiry here

title: A must do

title: History, Geog and Adventure and the 20 Rs. note (Indian Currency)
review_text:
History: 1.A day trip to Ross is worth everything, There is an old British christian church, which is now in distorted condition but once you enter the building , something makes you stay over there for a while and breathe in the chastity of ambiance,it is surrounded by thick forest of coconut and palm trees. 
2. There are old military bunkers dug by Japanese troops during the second world war . 

Geography : The size of island is shrinking at winking speed, first due to its geog position, it is now in slanting position , though you do not feel it ,due to the presence of building ,which were on higher altitude .Secondly, due to tsunami and frequent earthquake in last few years. 
Fresh coconut water is a delight , the coconuts are large enough to feed you tight.(Tip; share the coconut water between two.) 
Deer , peacocks and other birds will interest the ornithographer inside you. 

Adventure :The boat ride, the walk around island (TIP: Take a guided tour,to avail best information.it is worth) 

TRIVIA : On the Indian currecy note of Rs, 20, there is a beach image with coconut trees, on the back side. YES !! It is the Ross Island :-) More

title: Visit it for the historical importance of this island
review_text:
It is a small, neat and clean nicely maintained island. It is ~15-20 mins ferry ride from the Port Blair. You need to walk and explore the island on your own. There are signs available through out the island for the benefit of the tourists. It will take about 2-3 hours to explore the entire place. 

It was the headquarters of the Britishers in Andaman during the colonial era. You can check out the old building which are in ruins now. There is also a small photo gallery where you can get a glimpse of the opulent lifestyle of the Britishers, which they got at the cost of the prisoners in the cellular jail. Another thing to look out for here are the deers and peacocks which roam about freely in the island. More

title: Can see the Ruins of English empire run from a small island to control Andamans Islands
review_text: Full of ruins of our history. The Island was originally 200 sq km but now the same is shrunk to only 60 sq km because of earthquake and Tsunami and recent Hudhud. You must hire the only guide (a lady) available here. The boat trip from Port Blair starts from Rajib Gandhi Marine Park bay every hour starting at 8.30AM. The same boat will bring you back after 2 hours 15 minutes (8.30AM starting boat will rerun with the same set of tourists at 10.45AM). There are many things to see in the island - mostly ruins. The building which housed Farzland Khan bakery and provision store is still standing with the rooms for Teresa and Diana Ross. The Church is completely destroyed. Recently cyclone Hudhud destroyed the pathway inside the island which earlier allowed to take a round walk around the island. Near the church, you will find a small pathway steps which will take you to the sea beach. Since the last few steps are destroyed, you need to be careful to walk down through coconut groves. The beach is beautiful and you can have some good time here. Then you can visit the cemetery which housed the English deads including a young child of 22 days (Lawrence). title: Island with Historical importance worth visiting
review_text:
Just 10 minutes away by speed boat, the island is beautiful and well maintained. It was once upon a time the residential island of the English officers. The remains of the houses, ruins, church and other buildings tell about the life at that time. The islands is a must visit for any photo enthusiast. It has many deers and peacocks roaming freely everywhere which as a city dweller was a feast for us. 

We went there by boat and there was a return time of 2 hrs after arriving there. We wished we would have spent more time. One really needs to walk all over including slopes and steps to explore the full island. So go in comfortable shoes and the elderly may not enjoy it so much. 

The view of the beach and the sea are great from the terrar beach side. Do go on that side when you visit. More

title: Fresh coconut water and pristine beach
review_text: Ross Island was the residence of the cellular jail administrators, who lived a life of luxury. The reason for the British choosing this island becomes evident as soon as one approaches it. Clean and white beaches, green hillocks with leaves of coconut tree swaying in the wind, marvellous views of the aquamarine Andaman sea and the pristine blue sky, completely takes away the fatigue. Today, along with the ruins of the lavish bungalows, churches and infrastructure like the water treatment plant, one can enjoy the flora and fauna within the island. I am not sure if there’s only one guide, but if she, is a blabbering female who speaks with the animals and birds, then it’s useless. It is also not advisable to feed artificial food to the friendly deers and birds, which in not good for their health. It’s better to study some facts about the place to relate with the ruins. Infrastructure wise this island is far better off than the other island of Andaman- it has snacks shop, water bottles are available, clean toilets etc. During a sunny day the heat can be scorching, so sun screen lotions and a hat with dark glasses is a necessity. Fresh coconut water is available but its recommend to carry lots of water as the only way to move about in this island is by walking, sometimes negotiating steep slopes. title: Architectural Ruins of British Era
review_text:
This is one island where you don't go to see beaches.

Now, it is only the ruins that remain! Never seen a more ghostly place (i mean just the buildings), otherwise it is very clean and well maintained. 
You need 4 hours for return trip. Take the 2 PM ferry if you wish to see deer feeding.

title: Beautiful Island
review_text: This was the best Island during our tour. Surrounded by beautiful sea this is a small island with deers roaming around freely. Loved the place.

title: beautiful island
review_text:

it has great historic value. A good light and side show.

title: Saviour Island - Ross
review_text:
Said to be Andaman's capital during British empire, this island had lost most of its beauty to tsunami, but it took the impact of tsunami from affecting Port Blair. This small 0.75mile*0.5mile (length*breadth) island, has a foot way that guides us to 12 spots indicated in the map, right when we enter the island. It has entry ticket Rs.30 per person, Rs.30 for still camera and Rs. 70 for video camera. This place also has a helipad. 
Don’t miss to get down the ferar beach, the view is awesome and the white beach sand is inviting.

title: the best light and sound show
review_text:
the island doesn't offer any great sight for tourists. There are some dilapidated ruins of British raj scattered over the island. But the best part of it is the 3D light and sound show on the history of island. This is far, far better than any light and sound show, The show had started barely three months ago. 

If you plan to go to the island you can think about a 3pm-6 pm slot.

title: Ross island
review_text:
Ross island is a beautiful island with tall cocunaut trees. Deers, rabbits, peacocks and peahens roam around amongst the tourists. Most of this island is prohibited to tourists as it is a naval base of the Indian navy. 
You can see the ruins left behind by the World war 2, and the tsunami of 2004. Ross island was the erstwhile capital of the Andamans, due to its strategic location. Amongst the ruins, the church stands out. It provided shelter to the population of this island during the tsunami.

title: Ghost Capital!
review_text:
Ross Island used to be the earlir Capital of A&N Group of Islands, till the Japanese invasion forced the British to retreat to Port Blair. The Japanese occupied it for a few years till they were defeated in the WW II.However the Brits did not return. As a result, the island has become a Ghost Town, the Nature reclaiming what was originally its. Ficus trees have grown over many buidlings, strangulating them with aerial roots. The only building left preserved is the Bakery. The Church and the Commissioner's mansion occupies the top of the small hill. 
A Must visit from Port Blair, less than a Kilometer away.

title: Deserves one time visit
review_text:
Hello, 

I visited this place in Nov. Ross island was used by British rulers for enjoying their lavish life at the expense of Indians. It was island where all officers, lieutenants used to stay. 

Place is nicely maintained. It is clean and tidy. They charge about Rs.50 something for the entry. You can still see old constructions like water boilers, hospitals, temples, lakes, bakery etc. Animals like Deer, Rabbit, Peacocks are free and safe to roam in the premises. It takes about 1 to 1.5 hrs to roam around the island. 

Ferry from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex jetty drops you at Ross island. Many people recommend using private boat but cost of the ride is double than government. Government has given contracts to private firms to operate the boats. I found them OK. Distance between Ross and port blair is not much so it is manageable. You also get return ticket of ferry scheduled to return after 2 hours. 
If you have 3-4 hours of time I recommend to visit the place. Do look for information boards, they are useful. 

Hope it helped. 

Thanks. More

title: Ross Island- testimony to Colonial Past!!!
review_text:
The deserted island stands to narrate the history of India’s colonial past. It once served as the headquarters of Indian Penal Settlement for 80 years. Replete with amenities of colonial living, the Island was known as ‘Paris of East’. 1857 mutiny compelled the British to punish the freedom fighters by bringing them to Andaman Islands. These prisoners were used as slaves to build houses, offices, barracks and other structures at the Island. The Government House was a large-gabled home with Italian tiled flooring. Remnants of the same are still visible. The Presbyterian Church was built of stone, Burma teak and stained Italian glass. The wood has survived the vagaries of weather for over 150 years. A structure south of the church was built to accommodate the parsonage. The bakery was a tastefully constructed building based on the 19th century British architecture with modern facilities of the times including a self contained cook house. The deserted island stands to narrate the history of India’s colonial past. It once served as the headquarters of Indian Penal Settlement for 80 years. Replete with amenities of colonial living, the Island was known as ‘Paris of East’. 

1857 mutiny compelled the British to punish the freedom fighters by bringing them to Andaman Islands. These prisoners were used as slaves to build houses, offices, barracks and other structures at the Island. 

The Government House was a large-gabled home with Italian tiled flooring. Remnants of the same are still visible. The Presbyterian Church was built of stone, Burma teak and stained Italian glass. The wood has survived the vagaries of weather for over 150 years. A structure south of the church was built to accommodate the parsonage. The bakery was a tastefully constructed building based on the 19th century British architecture with modern facilities of the times including a self contained cook house. 

The ruins of other buildings such as the Ballroom, Chief Commissioner’s House, old 'Andaman’ home, hospital, printing press, swimming pool, troop barracks and cemetery stand the testimony of British architecture. Almost all ruins, except the bakery give a spooky appearance due to overgrowth of tree roots over them. The island also had a picturesque beach called Ferar beach and a jetty. 

The Japanese too left their imprint on the island in the form of bunkers. The bunkers were used as watch points to safeguard the Island from any foreign invasion. 

The 1941 earthquake, forced many people to leave the Island. Later the island was completely abandoned in 1945. In 1979, the island was handed over to Navy. The Navy was responsible for upkeep and maintenance of the Island. In 1993, a museum was established to display a collection of old records and photographs. A guesthouse has been put up for the Navy officers on the Island. 

The Island has a lot of deer/stags in the forest. All the deer have been named by a middle aged tourist guide. The deer respond to her whenever they are called by name. Tea, snacks and coconut water are available on payment. Walking around the Island is the only option. 

Light and Sound show is interesting and enlightening about the history of the Island. The timings for the show are from 5:30 PM to 6:30 PM. It is advised to reach by 4 PM to explore the island before the light and sound show. Tickets for the show are available at Tourist Office in Port Blair. 

Ross Island is accessible only by a boat from Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex. More

title: Definitely worth a visit

The main attraction there is the ruins of a World War II British army base. Since its a largish island there is a bit of walking required to get around. Interestingly you will find a herd of spotted deer (some of them are quite tame and will allow you to approach them) and a lot of peafowl. 
The island is very well maintained (by the Indian Navy) and is certainly worth a visit. 
A round trip, including the ferry ride both ways will take you about 2 hours. More

title: A Barren Treasure Island
review_text:
It’s a 10 min boat ride from Aberdeen jetty to the Island. This Island was the erstwhile capital of Port Blair during the British regime, and is presently home to the ruins of old architectural structures of the Goras. It is very well maintained by navy and local people as natural habitat These ruins of trees, roots, buildings and more constitute amazing picturesque views.Some of the great photos can be taken here. In order to see complete island one needs to walk a lot so better be prepared, carry water to hydrate. There is small beach - Ferar Beach-which was completely destroyed by 2004 tsunami yet it is so beautiful and serene to be there. 

A trip to this beautiful is a MUST when you are at Andamans! More

title: Ross Island-Destroyed by nature
review_text:
Ross Island is a small island just a few hundred meters off the city of Port Blair and after an earth-quake the island was abandonned and nature now is "taking back the island again" step by step: The roots and branches of the trees started to Crash the solid walls of the abandonned buildings and in some places These buildings look really spooky. 
All fo the Island is an open-air-Museum and you can walk inside all of the buildings, gardens etc.without restrictions.

title: Amazing, much much better than expected, dont miss the beach!
review_text:
Ross island is reach in history, its amazingly scenic and has a secluded untouched beach. Something for everyone? Absolutely. Its beautifully well maintained by the Indian Navy, you can take a stroll around and visit the remains of the buildings (including a swimming pool/clubs/dance floors :) ) and take a peak into the rich history of the french colony here. Otherwise there are lot of scenic spots, one thing not to be missed is the beach. Its absolutely pristine, secluded, easily accessible although little small. 
Also you will see wild animals (Deers, peacocks, many types of birds) just roaming around with you while you spend time at this island.

title: Can have beautiful snaps here!! :)
review_text: Ross island is a small island, wit remains of a church and commissioner's residence of the British. You can find Deers and peacocks when you walk around. If you look for some photographs with beach view, walk straight away to other end of the island. This place is best for snaps :)

title: Nice island, near to PortBlair
review_text:
To reach Ross island, one has to take a boat or speed boat ride from Rajiv Gandhi Sport Complex Jetty. We took the Private speed boat ride (INR 250pp). The ride was awesome. 

The island itself was very different, since it had lot built during 1900s... must visit. 

lovely deers, peacocks roaming around... 

It takes about 1.5 to 2 hours to see the entire island.

title: Glorious island with historical value.
review_text: We visited this island as part of northbay island trip. Finish scooba diving and see this beautiful picturesque island with old historical buildings of English emperor and Japanese bunker. This island has entty fee. Has some food courts. Will be visited before 2.30pm. Has boat and speedboats to come here. You can see deers freely moving on island.

title: Ruins of Gothic British Island Spooky and Beautiful
review_text:
I should admit its one of the must visit place at andaman, the island is a broken beauty with historic buildings in pieces. You could see deers and peacocks roaming around with some beautiful sparrows. 

Ferrar beach in this island is AWESOME, the only romatic spot in other wise gothic and spooky island. My advice is please dont get lost :)

title: Lovely place
review_text:
Great place to spend the morning. Guide is available locally at a very reasonable price.There are a lot of deer in the island. They come to you in the mornings in search of food. Carry some biscuits, bread etc so that you can feed them. Takes hardly 10 mins to reach from port blair jetty by boats available throught the day. 
The island is maintained by the navy.

title: Amazing Experience
review_text: One can Smell n Feel the History here, a Beautifully Constructed Island by Britishers though ruined badly by Tsunami But a Must Visit in Port Blair. The View of building Ruins, natural habitat and a Beautiful View of Beach takes your Breath away.

title: Island of great historical importance.
review_text: Ross Island was fondly called Paris of the East.The ruins of the remains of british constructed buildings like the english bakery,presbyterian church,the commisioners bungalow and the dance hall speaks of the pomp and splendour of the British Officers..It also had a water distillary unit and a power house.Its now maintained with great care by Indian Navy.Deers and peacocks can be seen roaming freely all over the island. During the tsunami Ross island took most of the damage while saving port blair.

title: Untouched Paris of the east.
review_text: I liked The way the island was planned to live in luxury way back in history. I liked to imagine how people lived.

title: wonderful little island
review_text:
Trip to Ross island for few hours is really worth it. Go there around afternoon and evening time; to enjoy the outdoors. The island has many deer which roam freely and you can get very close to them. 
Beautiful peacocks are also present and if you are lucky, you will see one in its full glory with its wings spread!! 
The ruins of British era are also an interesting watch for history lovers....and along the trek route, one comes across a huge tree which locals say is more than 500 years old!! 
A must watch if you have kids along...

title: Nice place for a short trip
review_text: A well laid out small island with a lot of greenery. Very few remains of old british rule except for a bakery.

title: Optional visit
review_text: This island is very near to the jetty(Andaman water complex). Nothing much here instead of abandoned collapsed houses from 50 years or so.

title: History revisited...
location: National Capital Territory of Delhi, India
review_text: An island so small...you can cross it on foot easily, old ruins of portugal buildings covered in roots looks stunning, nice n green with some deers for company...a beautiful place for a short trip...but only way in or out is the ferry...so don't miss it...

title: historical island
review_text: when you enter rose island you could see japanese bunker at first.rose island contains old damaged buildings of the british period.They built swimming pool,water plant,church,solders residences ,helipad etc.All were in ruin. The island was in the hand of japan from 1942 to 1945.Also it prevents heavy damage from tsunami to port blair in2004.It is a very beautiful island.It has a old light house.

title: British or Japanese..!! They deserve an appause
review_text:
My wife and me visited the place and we were surprised by the architecture, design and the planning of the island. The residence, meeting rooms, the church, the crematory, the prayer rooms, etc were so beautifully planned. 

Dont miss out to see the ferar beach which is behind the ross island.

title: Not much impressive but beautiful
review_text: Take a combine trip to rosss , viper and north bay but try to visit ross and viper in short spn so that you can spend more time at north bay. Nothing much to see at ross some old history but dont miss the abandoned church and canon houses.

title: Beautiful tiny island
review_text: A very beautiful place. Sea shore is very nice but needs some more care and maintenance. Trip to the island is not so costly.

title: Nice Place
review_text: History to be visited, Surprise were the Barking Deers and Family of Golden fawns. Peacocks yes.. Ferrar Beach was nice..

title: Good Place
review_text:
You can go to this place from port blair in a Jetty, Seeing this place completely would take about 4-5 Hours including the Jetty travel. You dont get any food/snacks here, there is only one shop which sells water bottles and some cool drinks, so better carry your snacks. 

This is place has been used by British as administrative headquarters for the entire Island. The remains of the buildings here shows the Royal life lived by british. The lone sailor statute is a great location dont miss this.......... 

You can find lot of peacock, deer in this island..... You can even feed the deer. 

For a better planning of your trip to andaman, better go to this place by the first boat (9am) so that you can be back in portblair for lunch around 2-2.30 and you can visit cellular jail by 4 pm, continue in the Jail with the Light and Sound show and End your day in Marina park More

title: Corals leave you stunned
review_text: Just visit these islands for its lovely beaches and corals, they are simply adorabe. Now you just have to have a dslr and u r ready to enjoy the beauty of these islands

title: Nice place to spend your first half of the day.
review_text:
Make sure this is the place that you're gonna visit first when you land in Port Blair. Coz, it works out good to cover most places. 
Finish this and go to the Cellular Jail in the evening. Two important things covered in the City and if time permits, go visit the two museums - Aqua and Archaeology. 

First day spent good. :)

title: Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose ki Jai
review_text:
Ross Island is at about 2 km to Port Blair. Prior to 1941 it was said to be the Administrative Headquarters for the islands. There was an earthquake in 1941 hence Port Blair became the capital of these Islands. There remain the ruins of church, swimming pool etc. The Indian Navy is managing a museum displaying a collection of old records. Ross Island is controlled by the Indian navy. Every visitor on entering into it has to sign in a register. People desire to know more and more about it because it is a hot tourists spot as it contains treasury of ruins of its territory. The Britishers have left behind them the legacy of the names of their officers who were in control of the areas in such officer’s name. It is commonly seen throughout the country. So also we see the kind of British treatment to these islands. One marine surveyor Sir Daniel Ross was kept in charge of this island. So it carries his name as Ross Island, similar is the case of Port Blair, the so called capital of Andaman and Nicobars. Ross Island is at about 2 km to Port Blair. Prior to 1941 it was said to be the Administrative Headquarters for the islands. There was an earthquake in 1941 hence Port Blair became the capital of these Islands. There remain the ruins of church, swimming pool etc. The Indian Navy is managing a museum displaying a collection of old records. Ross Island is controlled by the Indian navy. Every visitor on entering into it has to sign in a register. People desire to know more and more about it because it is a hot tourists spot as it contains treasury of ruins of its territory. 

The Britishers have left behind them the legacy of the names of their officers who were in control of the areas in such officer’s name. It is commonly seen throughout the country. So also we see the kind of British treatment to these islands. One marine surveyor Sir Daniel Ross was kept in charge of this island. So it carries his name as Ross Island, similar is the case of Port Blair, the so called capital of Andaman and Nicobars. Ross ordered to put up crude barracks of bamboo and grass to house the freedom fighters and made other criminals to stay on board the ships that had brought them. Subsequently he made the freedom fighters to built houses, offices, barracks and other structures at this Island. Once the construction work was over the freedom fighters were sent to Viper Island, where the first jail was built for them. He got built a bungalow called Government House. 

There was earth quake in 1941. The Japanese admiral occupied this Government House during 1942 to 1945. Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose sought the help of Japanese in his fight against the British. He stayed at the Island for a day in December 1943. Every Indian must be proud of this great patriot and Hero of freedom struggle. It was he who hoisted the Indian Tri colour at the top of the Government House in Ross Island. But after the Second World War the Island was re-occupied by the British even though they never went back to the Island. 

It is in the Indian history that Ross Island was handed over to the Indian Navy in April 1979, which has set up a small post, INS Jarawa, named after one of the indigenous tribes of the Andaman group of islands. 
A museum was opened in December 1993. 

You can avail the boat services from Port Blair to Ross Island on paying entry fee but for children up to nine years no such entry fee. You can’t take photo from the front part of the island as it is a secured place. Don’t ignore to take tickets for all kind of cameras at the entry point itself to avoid embarrassment of being caught. 
The guide will certainly take you to the Picture gallery where you can see photos of Ross Island 

You will love the bakery items in Ross Island. 
The natural scenic beauty and landscape are marvellous. I experienced soothing effect here. Better wear sunscreen and sunglasses, a cap and carry an umbrella while walking as a safety measure. 

You will wonder to see Japanese bunkers and a lot of tunnels, deers and peacocks in the forest over here. 
I am sure you will like to visit it again. Good luck. More

title: nice picnic spot
review_text: Very nice and calm island on east of South Andaman. Its a nice picnic spot, don't forget to keep some snacks and drinks.

title: Nice small island
review_text: Deers roaming freely alongside you...you may feed them, a few trekking trails + museum, nothing much to do except roam around aimlessly. Check the weather before you go...if its hot you may not like it

title: Little Red Riding Hood.....
review_text:
Well, don't get confused by the heading. The story "Little red Riding Hood" was not based on this island at all but what reminds me of that story is the reddish nature of this island. From a distance it's all red and even the housekeeping staffs working here also wears red. Ross island is 30 minutes boat ride from port blair Rajib Gandhi water sports complex. There are two ways to reach there. Firstly, there are boat operators who conduct a 3 island tour daily(except monday or wednesday, I forgot actually which day it is). The 3 island tour includes Ross, Viper and North Bay island. They either start with Ross or ends at Ross. In either case they halt for 1 hour at Ross. Alternately, there are frequent boats from the same place which will take you to Ross only and you can return at any time of your convenience. The last return boat is at 5pm and there are almost one return boat per hour. North bay is only for snorkeling, water scooter and glass bottom boat so if you have already enjoyed those in Neil/Havelock/Jolly Buoy/Red Skin you can easily skip visiting that island. Viper island is a completely historic spot. Ross island is a combination of natural beauty and strong history. There are many old buildings which were constructed by British but later destroyed by Japanese Bombing. There is a small museum on the island which... Well, don't get confused by the heading. From a distance it's all red and even the housekeeping staffs working here also wears red. 

Ross island is 30 minutes boat ride from port blair Rajib Gandhi water sports complex. There are two ways to reach there. Firstly, there are boat operators who conduct a 3 island tour daily(except monday or wednesday, I forgot actually which day it is). The 3 island tour includes Ross, Viper and North Bay island. They either start with Ross or ends at Ross. In either case they halt for 1 hour at Ross. Alternately, there are frequent boats from the same place which will take you to Ross only and you can return at any time of your convenience. The last return boat is at 5pm and there are almost one return boat per hour. 

North bay is only for snorkeling, water scooter and glass bottom boat so if you have already enjoyed those in Neil/Havelock/Jolly Buoy/Red Skin you can easily skip visiting that island. Viper island is a completely historic spot. Ross island is a combination of natural beauty and strong history. There are many old buildings which were constructed by British but later destroyed by Japanese Bombing. There is a small museum on the island which describes ancient history and displays souvenir. There are 2 3 food stalls as well so you don't have to carry food at all. 

Upon arriving the Ross island jetty, you have to pay an entry fee and extra charge is there for camera(a very small amount though). You can stay as much time as you want. There are roads in multiple direction and if no tourist guide is there with you, you can roam on your own. Deer in Ross are very much friendly and they will come very close to you but do remember feeding them is a strict offense. We have spotted many deer near the jetty and they are friendly in nature. Another beauty of the island is peacock and there are plenty. You won't find them near the jetty. In order to have a glimpse of them, you have to move a little deeper into the forest. We were warned that snake is also there but we didn't care. 

There are three beaches in Ross island. By three beaches I mean, three openings are there to face the sea and each has seats with shade so you can enjoy at any one among those three. Overall it's a very fantastic island but don't got there with very little time in hand. You won't find it appealing if you stay for a very short time. More

title: nothing much to do
review_text: nothing much to do on the island. one can spend couple of hours enjoying the greenery and take the boat back to port blair

title: Ruins of the Capital...
review_text:
A short ferry ride from Port Blair brings you to this abandoned island which was once the Headquarters of Andamans. The place was rocked by a massive earthquake in 1941 and was hence abandoned. The place is now kept alive by the very helpful Indian Navy. 

From a traveler's point of view, the place is a explorers paradise. On he jetty you are greeted by a handful of free indian spotted deers making you think when was the last time you saw the species roaming so freely. Few things not to miss- Japanese Bunkers, ruined Church, English Barack, Helipad & the Huge Tankers. The place is easy to walk and spread over 400sq mtrs. The beauty of the island are the huge trees which have exposed roots crawling over these ruined buildings and binding them together. It looks as if mother nature couldn't loose more and held everything together! 

Traveler Tips: 
Carry something to snack on. Drinking water, tea/coffee, bottled beverages are available at the navy souvenir shop inside. The place is exposed to the sky so carry your umbrella, sunglasses & sunscreen as the weather here is unpredictable. Take the three island ticket from Aberdeen Jetty to reach here. Its available instantly and on the spot. 

Cheers!! More

title: Very nice place to see.
review_text: You must read the history of Ross Island before you visit this place. You can't help but admire that howsoever bad the British were, they were just fantastic in making things which were truly royal and a class apart. How they developed a forested island into their capital with the best possible amenities that too in the 1930s, is something you have to see to believe.

title: Ross Island ... A trip to British capital !!!
review_text: Worth visiting island , a big salute to our defence people for maintaing it ... As soon as you enter there are deers rabbits and others will welcome you .. You can find old British office , swimming pool , church but I would recommend to step down visit other part of this island which has a beautiful beach !!!

title: Old Capital of andaman
review_text: Ross island was old headquarter of andaman which was destroyed in an eartquake.Its just 15 min ferry ride from portblair and good for 2/3 hour.There you will find ruins of old british structure like churches,offices,baracks etc.It is very well kept and maintained by indian navy.

title: An unlikely Island
review_text: Worth visiting and worth having interaction with the local guide/ caretaker. Hats off to Indian navy and the caretaker for all the efforts to maintain and flourish the island

title: Voyage into the Past
review_text: Liked everything except the sweltering heat. Please visit this during winter and please do not rush through it. Take leisurely stroll all over the tiny island. If you take a speed boat which gives you just an hour there , you will miss the charm. See the exhibits , photographs and the map which are displayed at the entrance point.

title: Glimpses of the Opulence in which the Gora Sahibs Lived
review_text: Though it is in ruins, it is a must. A three hour window from Abardeen Jetty is the least you need to spare. And those deers!!!! Oh my God, you cant find such a friendly animal, not even the pet dog

title: Ross Island, the British Capital of Andaman
review_text: This was the British Capital of Andaman situated very near to Port Blair. Also known as Lakshmibai Island. During World War II Japanese conquered the Island and constructed bunkers. Old Light house, Power house, Church, Chief Commissioner’s House, Tennis Court and Cemetery remind us of the past. Lot of deer and few peacocks can be seen here. Can refresh yourself with fresh coconut water. Not very attractive place for visit and hence can be skipped if you have tight programme.

title: Good experience
review_text: The island is well maintained and is good if you don't mind the walking. The beach was nice and the deers and peacocks added to the charm.

title: Great half day trip
review_text: We decided to head over to Ross Island as we couldn't travel to havelock straight away. So glad we did, Ross Island is really interesting the old British style building which have been taken over by the trees and nature of the island is quite surreal! Some surprise animals living on the island as well

title: Most beautiful beaches ever seen
review_text: Breathtaking experience with great sea adventures. Worth a visit in case visiting india. love the corals.

title: If you do not have sufficient time, ignore this place
review_text: The place contains dilapidated buildings of yesteryears of British Raj. But there is nothing much to see, as the entire place looks like a deserted place without any human activities. Govt could have worked out better themes and made this place an attractive one.

title: Beautiful island with wild life
review_text:
As soon as I landed on the island, a Japanese bunker welcomed me. On going further, I was in for a surprise. I saw deers and peacocks strolling past. It was such a beautiful sight to watch the deers and barasinghas mingle with the tourists. The kind of trees that I saw there were one of a kind. There is only one beach there. You do not go to Ross for the beach, but for the old buildings of the british times and breath taking views of the ocean all around. 

You need to buy a ticket for nominal amount to enter the island. The island is under the control of Indian Navy. More

title: don't expect too much
review_text: its a quick crossover from port blair. mostly dilapidated ruins of old british buildings. but the walk up beautifully paved walkway to the top of the hill and then down to the lighthouse & statue out in the blue sea, is wonderful. kids love the deer & peacocks that roam the small area.

title: Going back to British Raj and their opulence
review_text:
Ross Island is a 15 minute ferry ride from Port Blair jetty center. This was the place Britishers and their families stayed. There was so much opulence that this place became known as the "Paris of the East" in those days. Now most of it is destroyed but still a nice place to visit. One can also see Japanese bunkers, which they had built after capturing this island from British in WW II. Wish there was some guide to take us around and explain the historical significance of the old buildings that are now in dilapidated state. 

We visited this place after the Cellular Jail. So in some sense, it was a sharp contrast to see how the Indians were ill-treated in the Cellular Jail while the Britishers enjoyed their time in this beautiful island.... More

title: Back in time to britsh raj!
review_text: Ross island is an island part of the 3 island trip from port blair; it was the HQ during british occupation and once can see all the facilities they had created for their comfort.I found the water cleaning facility for malaria interesting.it justifies one visit i suppose; there are other terrific island in the Andamans though.

title: Very good - British ruins
review_text: Ross island has old British ruins, like the Admin block, printing press, a dance floor, a church and a cemetry. All overgrown with trees and barely recognizable for what they were since most buildings are in dilapidated ruins. Also has live, tame deer and peacocks. Ferry leaves at for 8:30 am in the morning, and drops you for an hour on the island. Last ferry stops by the afternoon.

title: Visit to the Past
review_text: I have always had that special knack to visit places with historical backgrounds, Ross Island has been my first to that list, when I went there (for the first time) at the age of 8, since then I had been there 3 times (Till Now). And every time I went there I have discovered it in a fresh way. Yes of course if you don't fascinate places with historical backgrounds, you can always visit it as just another spot with remnants of the past. Apart from the ruins, what can attract you is a number of Deer casually walking here and there around you, and if you can trick them with a biscuit or chips in your hand, they will come to you and eat it (perfect chance to click them as well). There are a few peacocks as well playing hide and seek with you, if you could find them don't miss to click. It just takes a 30 minute boat ride from Marina Park, there are boats service at regular intervals, but I would say as you visit Ross, you must give time to explore it. It is a very small Island, and you hardly take much time to cover it. Enjoy the calmness of that place with the history ticking in your head, I am sure You'll like being there. More

title: read
review_text: it is a good place to visit .....plays an important role in tourist attraction in portblair . it gives an important account of the british settlements of that time . you cant have bath in the beach ...but its a good place to stop at . there are mysterious ruins which are good to see . its a kind of forest in which deers roam around freely to be touched and played with . seperate washrooms for men and women available .

title: See it while it lasts
review_text: This island was home to the british when they ruled A&N for almost 100 years. It now lies as ruins remniscent of the time gone bye. The island has been reduced to about 65 acres from the more than 200 acres it used to be (thanks to the tsunami of 2005). You don't know when there will be just rocks here. So, visit it and enjoy the peacoks, deers and rabbits (and chicken's) that you will spot all around.

title: Amazing view
review_text: the way to ross island is from port blair. you can board the boat and vie this amazing island. The island is the house of deers which you could see roaming around you. the greenery and beauty of island is truly mesmerizing.

title: A quick visit
review_text: good for a quick visit in a govt. ferry. We went in the afternoon when it was very sunny, hot and sultry. provides good view of Port blair and the sea but was not too excited to walk around in the heat. Nevertheless worth a visit when you are in port blair

title: Known for Japanese Bunkers
review_text:
One of the wonder to see Dears waving around you all the times, it is only one place to see them in this part of the India. 

See some Japanese Bunkers and some offices used by them, which are destructed during the tsunami here. We have to go to this place from Andaman Water sports Complex. From here we have to get ticket for ride boat and seeing this places.

title: Worth a visit
review_text:
Its a place u would not want to miss. This trip comes as a combined package with Viper Island (would not recommend this one). But Ross island is very good. It has a charm of its own. Part of the island's destruction will still give u the memories of the tsunami that struck the Indian Ocean. 
U should not miss a guided tour by the lady named Anuradha, who resides on the island. She actually communicates with the peacock, deer and birds and this is a treat to watch

title: Residence area
review_text: I like all the things .It is a nice place for historic hunters.It is admirable there that any general will be coming with cake and tea.

title: Lovly small Iseland
review_text: It is a small iseland close to Port Blair.Govt. nd private Ferry available from Rajiv Gandhi water sports Complex close to Marina Park.Ticket costing Rs.100/head return.This place is maintained by Indian Navy nd Britishers made their home there.It was destroyed during second world war.

title: The ruins of british era were excellent.
review_text: despite the cruelty of britishers on indian heroes of freedom struggle, the advancement of equipment and other facilities seen for their own use were remarkable.

title: place worth visiting
review_text: ross island is the pace of stay for the British officers who were staying in port blair .In its heydays it was called Paris of the east such was the beauty of the place . Much of its building were destroyed during world war II because of japanese bombing . Travel to the island is by a launch from aberdeen jetty, tickets should be booked in advance. Since the island is under control of Indian Navy travellers are needed to carry proof of identity and required to show when asked . A visit to the memorial of lone sailor is must , but it take quite a bit of trekking to reach there . More

title: Not very pleasing but very dipressing
review_text: Ross Island was the capital of Britishers to administer Andaman Islands. This place has the reminiscences of the cruelty with which they treated our freedom fighters using them as labourers to construct their luxury requirements like swimming pool,club houses, mineral water plants etc.,All being in ruins it is not that enjoyable visit. If you have no time left at the end of the trip to visit this place you need not regret.

title: Excellent
review_text: Old British Administrative buildings and its ruins are still there. the only disadvantage is transport facilities are very less to this island

title: worth every penny
review_text:
got an insight into the difference of living between the british and the indian people before independence 
need more time than the 1 hr 30 mins given by the boat people who ferry us to ross island from portblair 
we missed the beach there due to time constraints , but from the top it looked beautiful

title: good place
review_text: good place to stay for a hour or two. calm and quite environment, well maintained. Deers living in the island are almost like pet animals. Good to see them so near to people.

title: If you have a few hours free go for the views and some peace
review_text: The whole experience was good and different for us .. Its a small island with deer, rabbits and peacock. The view of the sea and ships from the port and the ride to the island are worth a visit. There is no beach to swim but the island has some old ruins and is of historical importance

title: Beautiful
review_text: Very beautiful & a very clean & quiet island.You cannot afford to loose the chance of following the tour of the island by a very special local lady tour guide.Hats of to the lady tour guide (courtesy our navy).She takes care of number of animals & birds & they follow & obey her commands.She is like an Alice in Wonderland

title: Historic Island
review_text:
This island was the administrative center of the British before the Japanese occupied it during the 2nd World War. The ruins of the British buildings are largely undisturbed, save for the vegetation that has taken over in many places. That makes an interesting view. 

Please do carry water, for the small counters only serve fast food. 

Boatmen who take you to the island generally want you to go island hopping, but it is best to sped some time here surrounded by lush vegetation and serenity

title: Pristine Charm & Natural Beauty!
review_text:
This is the first destination in the day long three island tour from Portblair. The boat takes about 15 min to Ross Island, which happened to be the capital during the British era and was destroyed by the natives as soon as they left. 

Presently, it is occupied by Indian Navy, which has invested enough efforts in preserving its flora and fauna. One could easily spot several species of deers roaming freely on the island as well as spot many bird species. 

There are several spots which provide a breathtaking view of the sea apart from remnants of old british settlement viz. An abandoned church, messes etc. 

Well endowed with natural beauty indeed! More

title: Beautifully Designed
review_text: Ross Island was the first island in the tour. It was a 10 min ride from the main port. There is a miniscule fee of Rs 10 to enter this island. The island has a lot of history attached to it. It used to the capital of the Andaman and Nicobar islands during the British era. No wonder the island is so beautifully designed. No one lives on the island anymore. We also got to know that Port Blair was saved from the 2004 Tsunami cause the strong waves hot Ross Island instead The island is like a mini town equipped with all facilities that were used by the British. (Meeting houses, gardens, a Swimming pool, a bakery, a church, etc.)If you’re lucky you get see some deer here too. The island is ok on a whole and I doubt you’d miss anything if you plan on excluding it out. More

title: must
review_text: pl plan to spend minimum 3-4 hours here. carry water along. there is a small eats counter here but it serves basic stuff like chowmien etc. This island is a must sea and pl do find energy and time to go up to lone sailor point next to lighthouse. View from here is fantastic. Keep your cameras ready. Bad experience is that the boat men have made a cartel. They do not like to take relaxed passengers like us who do not want to do island hopping tour within a day who pay higher tickets than us. We only wanted to go and spend time at ross on day one. Came back for lunck at andamans. Went to cellular jail late afternoon. It was not crowded More

title: A very beautiful island
review_text: Ross Island is a very interesting blend of nature, history and architecture. Having been nicknamed the Paris of the East during its glorious days, Ross Island has beautiful buildings, peaceful trails, a small rocky beach and other small hidden gems all across the island. A must visit destination in Andaman. Please do plan half a day on this island for your visit.

title: History, just a boat ride away
review_text:
This Island used to be the administrative center during the British times, and the ruins at the place takes you back to those times. 

Private ferry takes you to the Island from the Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports Complex Jetty and the last one leaves at 2 PM. The Island is now managed by the Indian Navy and there is an entry fee when you reach the Island. 

The ruins at the Island are not interfered with much, and nature had its course with them, This makes very interesting sights at the Island with the trees and building mingling into one entity. 

The views on the Island are great and it is recommended to spend some time here. There is a very beautiful beach on the back side of the Island, and should not be missed. Around 100 or so steps takes you down to the beach, but the natural beauty makes up for it. 

Don't forget to carry water and something to eat, if you plan to spend time here. More

title: good heritage place.
review_text: this is 1 spot when you travel Ross island then viper island last northbay island. this is a very good place, but 1 & half is too less time to complete this island. back side of this island is a very good beach side. but we couldn't visit due to time crunch.

title: beauty
review_text: click photos and feed deers is all you can do here..but you don't get tired doing both even the whole day long! pls take a guide the moment you step down on the island..it helps

title: best island near port blair
review_text: its beautiful ...pls take assistance from guide anuradha rao as she is the best and with her only u can see a large number of deer and peacocks..she also gives u a detailed history of the island which is worth listening

title: Ruins of lavish British Headquarter's
review_text:
Visited this island on 28th Nov morning during my cyclone affected trip 
We took a ferry from Andaman waters complex at 8.30 am, this ferry was for single island,reached in 15 minutes. bridge well maintained,you saw a board ROSS island. Right infront is a japanese bunkar. took ticket with camera ticket. 
Wonderful ruins of administrative capital of British having everything for their lavish life style like club,bakery,water purifying plant , power house,swimming pool, lake,church 
Most of old buildings are in ruins with lot of creepers on them. 
But well maintained pathways,gardens, lot of peacocks & deers 
There is only one guide Madam Anuradha 
Must see place. 
Ticket Rs 20/=, Camera ticket Rs 10/= 
Ross island is closed to tourists on Wednesday 
Most important thing is that ferry ticket to this island cost Rs 100/= to & fro but you have to remember name of boat & return in same boat More

title: Nice location
review_text: Its nice to start trip from Ross island. Good to touch dears and peacocks on the island. Also see Ross lake.

title: visit if a history buff
review_text: Ross island can be visited by people who are keen to see the relics of early british life in andaman. the place has ruins of church, club etc. highlight is the large population of deers who are bold enough to come close and pose. Ross island was instrumental in bearing most of the brunt of tsunami and thus saving port blair from big damages.

title: Spooky Story of a Ravaged Power Regime
review_text: This island was a luxurious camp of the British administration in the late 18th century. Ruins of their grand living quarters, clubs, church, swimming pool, offices show how the mighty can fall!

title: Beautiful place...though in ruins now
review_text:
This is a beautiful place - though in ruins now. 
One has to take a boat from Aberdeen Jetty close to Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports complex. 
The boat costs Rs. 100 (One Way or that is what was told to us) and further Rs. 20/- to enter the island. 
I would hope the whole process of purchasing tickets and boarding boats can be a bit better organised. 
We took a 9:30 am boat and had to comeback via 11:30 am, but by the time we reached jetty on Ross Island at 11:30 the boat had already left. 
I wouldn't recommend the 3 island tour to start at 9:30 as it only gives 45 minutes in the Ross Island before the boat starts for next island. 
One needs to have around 2 hours to have a good relaxed stroll around the island. 
Please don't miss going to the far end of island where you can go upto light house going down the stairs and then the bridge above the ocean - was the highlight of Ross Island for me. More

title: A small but important Island
review_text: A good start to the Andaman trip is the Ross Island. Though there is history associated through the British and the Japanese Invasions, it was a nice place to enjoy a day moving through the small pathways looking at the remains of the buildings which I understand was nothing less than a modern day Paris. It also has an excellent beach and to relax a number of spots are available with fresh coconut water and kulfi to give you company.

title: Don't Miss this
review_text: A surreal experience, as one walks through the ruins of the old British settlement. The structures are now almost entirely covered with creepers and roots of peepal trees, but one can still get a feel of how the place would have looked like in the heydays of the British Raj. The place is being maintained well with well-laid paths that connect to the main attractions. Large signboards provide details about the place to travelers (a rarity in most Indian historical tourist spots) It would have been nicer if some of the main buildings like the chief commissioner's bungalow (where Netaji, apparently stayed during visit to the island in 1943) were cleared of the vines a bit and some attempt made to restore them to something close to their former glory. The island also has a beautiful beach. Do not miss the statue of the lone sailor and the lighthouse on one corner of the island - particularly if you are a keen photograph. There are restrooms available. There is one canteen that serves veg and non-veg fare (tastes good if you are hungry :) ) Since you have to cover the island on foot, try to visit in the morning. More

title: Ross...the eeriest place in Andaman
review_text: it is heaven for both history and nature lovers.....it was the British head quarters of the Port Blair....now u can see the ruins of the once magnificent buildings half engulfed by the stilt roots of the banyan trees and serving as the home for the numerous deer and peacocks that roam around the island.....when we went there was no transport facility inside the island so u have to walk through the island....however ferry services are there from Port Blair to the island....it is obviously better for u to take the help of a guide....also the view of the sea from th island is also awesome.....

title: Must see
review_text: Overall good ambience with deer and peacock in plenty. It has lot of historical buidings. You can easily spend 2 hours. It is preferable to go there in the evening. We can easily see how Britishers enjoyed good life while our freedom fighters were suffereing in cellular jail.

title: History and more
review_text: This place is usually known for its history but we loved the beach here too. Dont miss the lone sailors statue at the far end of the island.

title: Great Island near port blair
review_text: Fantastic Island having remains of old British Colony i,e, Swimming Pool, Bakery, Church and small deer park. The beach at the is also beautiful. Nice place to spend half day near port blair

title: Not to be missed
review_text: Wonderful experience specially if you can get Anuradha Rao the guide to tell you all about the history of that place. Friendly deers which eat out of your hands

title: Average and nothing more
review_text:
Summary - Those interested in history may find the place interesting, but otherwise there is nothing mush to see or to do. In fact, the entire "3 Islands Tour" (along with Viper Island and North Bay Island) can be avoided in case of time shortage. Ross Island is a small island (0.8 sq. km.) situated at a distance of 2 km. from Port Blair. It is mostly covered by tourists as a part of "3 Islands Tour" Although well maintained, there is nothing to do or see over here. It was once the Administrative Headquarters of the Britishers before an earthquake hit it in 1942. But all one gets to see currently are not even the ruins, only the ruins of the ruins. It is slightly disappointing. On the brighter side, the island is very well maintained and has basic amenities (shades, toilets, cafeteria). History of the islands is nicely depicted using pictures at the entrance. You can see the ruins of a church and the of the chief commissioner's residence. You get a chilly feeling standing inside those ruins, imagining what it must have been like for the Britishers to live here all those years back. How to reach - One has to board a ferry from Aberdeen Jetty (near Rajeev Gandhi Water Sports Complex), Port Blair. It takes about 20 min. to reach Ross Island. After returning back, one can enjoy water sports (Jet Ski, Banana Ride, etc.)... title: Nice historical island and a great place for shutterbugs !!
review_text:

You will find remains of a church and clubs build during the British rule. A nice beach is there as well, which is not visited by too many tourists. review_text: This is one island where you can come and stay and just relax n walk n experience! The island is very photographic! Specially the wall that didnt fell even in Tsunami since it is hugged thoroughly by the roots of mangroves! Amazing view! You get to see dears on the island, just roaming and lazying!

title: Beautiful place - worth a visit for historical purposes.
review_text: It is located in the southernmost part of the Andaman islands. It has the beach covered with rocks carved beautifully due to their constant interaction with roaring tides. Sound of the tides is lively. It has the historical importance due to Japanese intervention during World War II.

title: Worth a visit - go with a guide
review_text:
Short ferry ride across to the island which was the Capitol during the British regime 

We went with a guide, which we were happy about, as he could tell us so much more than what it is mentioned at the signposts. You could nearly imagine life in the now overgrown ruins. 

It is also nice to visit here naturewise, a soft trek to the small beach, lots of greenery, deers and the real treat: A few peacoks posing beautifully quite near.

title: An Island housing historical ruins..
review_text:
Ross Island is about 20 minutes ride by boat from Port Blair. It is under the administrative control of the Indian Navy. It has following places of interest used by the British but now in ruins : Bakery, swimming pool, water distilling plant, subordinates club, Church building, Commissioner’s bunglow, troop barracks, cemetery, guest rooms, cafeteria, Smritika Museum (maintained by the Navy), Japanese bunker and tourist shed. 

This island is completely inhabitated except for some navy personnel. The only habitation is the tourists who come from Port Blair on boats, see the place around and return. By sunset, the island will be empty.

title: Worth a visit!!
review_text: this place is worth a visit and has its own piece of history. Do visit this place. It gives you an insight how this place has evolved and how important this island was during those years. it will require about three hours for the entire visit. and yes, there are deer roaming free out here....it is a great sight

title: Lots of history
review_text:
Went to Ross Island on 30th Nov'13. You can take a ferry from Rajiv Gandhi Sports complex. Ferries are available every 30 minutes for so. Last ferry from Ross Island leaves @ 05.00PM. Ticket is Rs 100/- per adult. There are no tickets for kids less than 10 years 
This place is 10-15 minutes away from mainland. 
There is a Rs 20/- per person entry ticket that is charged once you land at Ross Island. 
It is amazing to see how Birtishers made a home at this place . There is a shed near the jetty where adults of the family can sit..as there is a lot of walking on needs to do. It is at this shed you will find tourist guides who will give you a brief of the island. 
We were accompanied by a lady who gave us an overview of the island...although there are boards everywhere giving you a brief history of everything. 
Bakery, Swimming pool & Boliers are a must watch...where scenic More

title: Historical place
review_text: it is a small island near to port blair, one can spend 1 or 1.5 hour on it. not much to see but worth to visit.

title: A Little Bit of Britain
review_text:
Wherever the Brits went they made it home - ballroom, church, bakery, shops. The deer come straight from Richmond Park, although I'm not sure how happy they are in the heat. 

The ruins are like the Cambodian temple, with trees and roots holding up the crumbling bricks. Very atmospheric. 

Take a ferry across, it is very quick, and then wander for a couple of hours and come back to Port Blair. We did Ross Island the the Cellular Jail in one morning before taking the plane home.

title: Ramble at will...
review_text:
We took the ferry to Ross island, which took about 10 mins or so to reach. It's a fascinating experience and most certainly worth an hour or so of your time. There is a small additional charge for entering the island as well as the cost of the ferry ride, so still a really cheap adventure! If you are a foreign national, you will need to fill in your details in the book, so you'll need your passport number handy! 

My husband and I loved rambling around at our leisure and seeing all the 'time gone by' buildings, now just ruins, covered in growing vines, around the old bricks. The church is an amazing structure and the coast line is beautiful and worth the trek to 'the other side'. Do go and explore this wonderful place, you won't regret it. 

The animals roam freely and we saw beautiful deer and peacocks, with delightful green feathers, quite unexpectedly too, when on the other side. You never know when a stag will pop out in front of you, as you clamber over the huge root structures of the trees. 

Enjoy this perfect spot if you have an hour and a half to spare :-) More

title: Ross Island
review_text: The island now stands with ruins of old British empire. But, what I liked about the island was free moving deer and peacocks. It is a short ride from water complex to visit the island.

title: British Headquarter-Ross
review_text: Located at 10 minutes boat ride from aberdeen jetty. One can see the ruins of British Headquarter. Ruins of Old red bricks building.One can admire the better planning of Britishers for establishing this place as their Headquarter. Ruins of Old bungalows, church, ballroom, officers quarter and cemetry can be seen. One small museum maintained by Navy can be seen. It gives u the real idea of this Island.

title: Moss-covered marvel!
review_text:
The well-heeled tourists,both domestic and foreign,travelling to Andaman and Nicobar Islands generally give this place a miss.It's a short ride by motorboat from Aberdeen Jetty in Port Blair,and as we bob in the lurching waters,the island with its walls of tall palm trees shines like an emerald in the turquoise blue sea,and as we draw closer,the red of the bricks of the ancient buildings on the island complete the colour palette. 

It's a tiny island that one can walk across and all around in roughly an hour.This erstwhile headquarters of the British is in ruins but the fascinating history of that period is still very palpable if one looks around carefully;guides provide a lot of info too,and a small museum at the jetty contains some artefacts from that era. 

The meticulous organisation of the colonisers is very much in evidence here-a desalination plant,printing press,bakery,officers mess,Administrator's bungalow,church,etc. are all laid out carefully,and though overgrown with moss,creepers and even humungous trees,still tell a story of their own. 

The greenery is astounding,and a few deer roam freely;one can amble down the top of the hillock on which the church sits to the pebbly beach for a quick dip.It's a day trip and overnight stay is not allowed.Along with the North Bay Island and others nearby,though greatly devastated by the 2004 tsunami,it still offers an unforgettable experience! More

And yess the delicacy of Andaman coconut water.. you will get plenty of them.

title: BETTER YOU VISIT IT
review_text: its actually a good place to visit . you have deers here , moving freely . you can feed them , touch them . this is not a place to have bath in the sea . this place is only to be seen . the island is actually an abandoned british colony . there are few ruins as well . there are canteens to buy snacks and washrooms are also there .

title: Paris of the East
review_text: Presently under the Indian Navy and earlier known as the Paris of the East, this little island which used to be the capital of Andaman and Nicobar Islands under the British is now in a state of ruin - both by Father Time and the Tsunami. Being a small island, it takes about an hour to tour it to check out how the British built all facilities for themselves while the Indian freedom fighters were languishing in various jails in Andamans. While touring, one comes across plenty of deer, peacocks, squirrels and birds. A must visit destination, especially since it does not take much time to tour.

title: Mysterious ruins
review_text:
Ross is quiet a famous name known when people talk about Andaman. It is a haunting place which lingers in our thoughts even after many many days. The Island is named after Sir Daniel Ross, a marine surveyor. 
Ross must have been one of the most happening places during the British period in the late 17th century. It is now left with ruins which tell silent tales of dark history. It is sad to see that the dark history is sinking into the sea slowly. It was only because of Ross Island the Port Blair did not face as much damage as expected during the 2004 Tsunami. Ross Island stood shield and saved Port Blair from devastation! More

title: Beautiful ruins
review_text: This truly must have a been a very good place to live and epitome of luxurious and comfortable living. The ruins are spectacular and quiet mesmerizing. The beach on the other side of the island is also a must visit.

title: Enjoy with deer and old monuments
review_text: It was british colony at the time of british rule. It was very well designed and architected. Walk under the alley of coconut trees. You can see the see from many face on the top of this island. Ferar beach is good to have a look.

title: A Lovely Panorama
review_text: Ross Island is among one of the best panoramic sights. Very close to the city of Port Blair, the Ross Island is not only famous for natural prosperity, but it has historical importance too. It was once headquarter of the colonial British govt before Port Blair developed. Named after Sir Daniel Ross who discovered this island, it served with important historical event. It was occupied by Japanese in 1942. The island was devastated in an earthquake in 1941. Even today one can find the ruins of Church and Commissioner's house. The Island deserves a visit of every tourist.Ferry services are available at short intervals.

title: Awesome stuff
review_text:
15 minutes from port Blair on a ferry and you reach Ross Island, a great place to see history and enjoy also. 

What's there to enjoy? 
- Historical buildings: the Island is in ruins. You can actually see historical buildings of English era which are totally depleted and add to the beauty of this island. 
- Animals: one such place where you can see Deers, peacocks, squirrels, hens, Rabbits and many more animals outside any cage. 
-Beach: The Beach on side of this island is excellent with clear water. 
-Museum: While you can see today's buildings, the museum shows you how the buildings used to look in 1800s. 

Overall, it's a must do trip to Ross Island from Port Blair. More

title: Walk down the past
review_text:
Enjoyed the island for its scenic beauty, rich history and ferry ride :) 

Take a Guide while you are here otherwise not much fun. You have to get into ferry to enter the island. An earthquake moved the British Administrative Headquarters from here to Port Blair in 1941. Enjoy what is left of the Bazaar, Officers Quarters, Bakery, 100 yr old distilling plant and swimming pool!

title: A beautiful Island of historical importance
review_text:
A beautiful island just off Port Blair with a lot of historical ruins of british time. Peacocks and deers roam around freely and mix with the tourists. Greenery in abundance and part of history well preserved. As told to us in 2004 Tsunami waves first dashed against this island and a lot of destruction was there; but the silverlining - this saved Port Blair from bigger destuction and losses as it was protected by Ross Island. 
History - This island was first occupied by British in 1858 who brought freedom fighters from India, who cleared the jungles, made houses and offices for the British and then they were moved to Viper island where the first jails were built. Subsequently markets, clubs for officers, tennis courts, swimming pools etc were constructed to serve a population of around 500 people who were stationed here. The remains of these can still be seen here. In 1942 it went into Japanese occupation who were here upto the end of second world war (1945). More

title: A little from the past
review_text:
Ross Islands is a tiny island off the coast of port blair. The place has been largely destroyed by the Indian tsunami of 2004 and what is left of it, has been preserved. The place houses old monuments of the british era. Place also has some animal population - deer, peacocks etc. The difference is that all of them are very used to humans and are very friendly. Make sure not to litter the area. The place is monitored and you may get rebuked by the locals if caught red handed! 

Read more at : http://neenapaul.blogspot.in/2013/04/andaman-islands-mthariett-and-ross.html

title: Lost Glory .. ancient capital of British rule...
review_text: This is an excellent place where we can see teh glory of British and huge historical remains.... The total structures are supported by nature ...
