( ferari beach )

title: Very Interesting Ruins - Just Like The Colonial Era
review_text:
This place is 20 minutes ride from Jetty at Rajiv Gandhi Water Sports complex in Port Blair. This was the administrative headquarters of the british. The place was destroyed by an earth quake in 1941 and the HQ was shifted to Port Blair. Presently the island is under control Indian Navy. 

The place is well maintained with RUINS, I wonder how ruins are well maintained?!!! Anyways, it's worth visiting. 
Some important areas are the Presbyterian Church, Commissioner Bungalow, The Ballroom, Hospital, Press, Generator room etc.. 

The island also is guarded by a Japanese Bunker, built, obviously, by the Japanese during their invasion from 1942-45. 

The place is full of Deers roaming around who are very friendly to human beings. But it's request that please do not feed them with things that they cannot digest, and you don't know what are those things. Hence better not to feed them. 
If you're dying to feed one, buy a Tender coconut, drink the water and peel the inside and give it to them. They tolerate it well. 

Must visit. A Nominal Fee of Rs 20/-. More

title: Ruins!
review_text: Once compared to London and Paris cities, this Island city is now all about ruins and the plants overgrowing on the walls. Superb place for photography. Farrel Beach is one must visit area as well the Church.

title: Ultimate place, seriously...
review_text:
Just a 20 minute ride from the Rajeev Gandhi Water Sports Complex in the Jetty(A small passenger boat). You reach there after visiting the North Bay Island, after doing Scuba diving or Snorkeling activities at North Bay, and you feel, Man, why i wasted my energy looking for the corals when i was about to visit Ross island... The place is simply, wow... Although the jetty driver only gives you an hour to roam around the whole island, the time is sufficient to experience the British Life there. What is Ross Island... Ross Island is one of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, about 2 km east of Port Blair. It was the Administrative Headquarters for the islands, before an earthquake rocked it in 1941. The headquarters were then shifted to Port Blair. One can see remnants of an opulent past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool and the chief commissioner's residence with its huge gardens and grand ballrooms. There is also a cemetery and a small museum managed by the Indian Navy. The museum has on display a collection of old records. The place tires you, but tiring doesn't put an end to your curiosity there...The most amazing thing i saw there was, that the place is habitat to deers, which roam around very freely, and you can hug the dears, play with them, have photos with them and all... It felt so amazing coz i hav never... Just a 20 minute ride from the Rajeev Gandhi Water Sports Complex in the Jetty(A small passenger boat). You reach there after visiting the North Bay Island, after doing Scuba diving or Snorkeling activities at North Bay, and you feel, Man, why i wasted my energy looking for the corals when i was about to visit Ross island... 

The place is simply, wow... Although the jetty driver only gives you an hour to roam around the whole island, the time is sufficient to experience the British Life there. 

What is Ross Island... 

Ross Island is one of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, about 2 km east of Port Blair. It was the Administrative Headquarters for the islands, before an earthquake rocked it in 1941. The headquarters were then shifted to Port Blair. One can see remnants of an opulent past in the ruins of the church, swimming pool and the chief commissioner's residence with its huge gardens and grand ballrooms. There is also a cemetery and a small museum managed by the Indian Navy. The museum has on display a collection of old records. 

The place tires you, but tiring doesn't put an end to your curiosity there...The most amazing thing i saw there was, that the place is habitat to deers, which roam around very freely, and you can hug the dears, play with them, have photos with them and all... It felt so amazing coz i hav never ever thought of deers roaming so easliy with humans... Just visit the place to experience... Again, very low ticketing price, 20Rs for rntrance and 20 for camera... More

title: Take you to the British Era
review_text: A must go place in Andaman visit. Well maintained, possibly because it is under Indian Navy's control. Lots of deers, a few peacocks & a lots of ruins which will take you to the past. British era hounds! Good for patriotic persons. Worth a visit.

title: Erstwhile Capital of Andaman
review_text: Brilliantly maintained neat & clean, wild dear & peacock passing by your side makes your day. Those old buildings have so much to say to you, if you are a bit of Nostalgic & like history Ross Gives you a feel of the British Era..

title: Ruins
review_text: Beautiful reminder of history.. due to the rain the path were slippery so Humpty Dumpty did fall...but none of the kings horses rode by with its men even from the crematorium...

title: Well Maintained...
review_text: One of the well maintained island in Andaman.The island is left over with the ruins of old buildings, Power house, water distillation plant, Bakery, Press and so on. The island was very clean and there is a lot of history related to this Island.

title: Interesting place
review_text:
A very nice n interesting island. 
Very well maintained by Navy guys. 
Kids will love it as they had many peacocks, deers. 
A very clean and tidy. 
You can easily spend 2 hours there, enjoying.

title: beautiful place
review_text:
nice place just another island of andaman very close to portblair, 
even you can see the island from port blair jetty very clearly.

title: A unique place
review_text:
This place is not an ordinary man's idea of beauty. It is Small Island not far from Port Blair. The entire island is in ruins. There are thick roots of trees growing all around the dilapidated structure. It is beautiful in an unconventional and unorthodox way. I can’t find words to express the beauty, have some pics hope they can express what I am unable to. It did remind me of Angkor Wat I had seen in documentaries. 
If you spend time here you can almost see the families of the Brit here in all their glory. The Church, the swimming pool here can transport you to glorious past almost like a time machine. Also the Japanese bunkers here tell altogether a different story. 
Do try to go in early as walking in the sun can be tiring. Also do end the trip with tender coconut freshly cut off the trees on the island. 

Ps:We did hire out a private boat to do Ross island and North Bay, was a little expensive , but totally worth it. 
. More

title: it was okay
review_text: it was alright actuallly we were going for snorkeling and to go there we ha to cross three islands and ross islands was one of them so we didnt saw much there other than a deer and stayed there for 15 minutes only

title: Waste of Time
review_text: This small Island is not the perfect place for holidaymakers. Its a wastage of time and money. Even Though it was the British Capitol of Andaman Island, and still has the wreckage of their establishment

title: Very good for Honeymoon
review_text: This is the another place which we liked... Better than north bay.. Have a good SLR and go here. Nice fishes!!!

title: Japanese Bunker
review_text: It was a very nice historical place and was very happy to see somany Peacocks and deers and rare types of birds over there, nice place for photographers. Well kept and please continue to preserve the life of all species over there.

title: VERY BEAUTIFUL
review_text: One must go there, it is a very beautiful island, developed by British. Still look very beautiful. you have to take a walk for 2 to 4 KM approximate.

title: Good place for a short visit.
review_text: It is a good place for nature lovers. Tree roots and branches over old buildings create a fascinating view. Beach behind Ross Island is very good but is not none to many travelers.

title: An evocactive reminder of India's colonial past.
review_text: This interesting collection of buildings from the days of the colonial administration has been partly preserved and some have been left to be reclaimed by nature being swallowed whole by trees, rather like a modern version of Ankor Wat. Most of the buildings were military in nature, officers quarters, various recreation areas for different ranks etc. The remains of the governor's house are still there and it is incredible how a large house can be virtually destroyed in just a few short years. 2-3 hours can be spent wandering around the ruins and also seeing the legacy of the Japanese occupation. Definitely a highlight of the trip to Port Blair. There are also places to sit and have a leisurely cold drink or a snack. Ferries are fairly frequent and it has not been overpriced for foreigners. The cost was 60 cents each. More

title: Good Visit if you like historical ruins
review_text:
This Island is a part of 3 Island tour/ 2 Island tour package available at Ragiv Gandhi Sports Complex(RGSC). The package consists of 3 Island tour (Viper, Ross and North Bay) in a motor boat accommodating about 50ppl. It costs 390Rs for 3 Island tour and 220Rs for two Island tour (Ross and Viper Islands). If you are found of history then this Island and Viper Islands are worth a visit. Its better to carry your own food when on visit to these Islands, as options are very limited. Other option is to ask for package with food, which would cost 500Rs for 3 Island tour. Both the 3 Island tour packages with or without food includes a glass boat ride at North Bay Island, but the water is not clear hence the visibility under water is very low. North Bay Island is not that great its mainly visited for the water activities like scuba diving etc. The Island tours start at 0930hrs from RGSC and ends by 1730hrs or 1500hrs(2 Island). In Ross Island you need to buy a ticket worth 20rs/head to explore the Island and Rs.10/camera for still images. You need to deposit Rs.10/20 for the each plastic bottle that you carry inside. There are lots of deer and peacocks in this Island. The best thing to do is go to the small museum first , there is a map of whole Island in this museum, click... There is also a beach behind the church in this Island which is quite beautiful and you can see the lighthouse on North Bay Island from here, this is the picture in the backside of Rs. 20 INR notes.

We were staying at hotel Shreesh at middle point and took a rickshaw from there to reach RGSC and it took just 10mins. More

title: Ross Island trip
review_text: Trip was extremely nice. Lot of structures are in dilapidated condition but you can feel the life of the Britishers in those times. The presence of freely roaming deers & peacocks makes it very interesting for the children. Wish there were 1 or 2 good cafes/restaurants for the tourists. Condition of the boats carrying passengers from Port Blair is also not good

title: A good sojourn
review_text:
Nice to spend half a day here - feeding the deer and just lazing around amongst the ruins of the erstwhile British Establishments. 

Again - a simple route-map with arrows by the Authorities, highlighting the various points of interest would have made this place better.

title: British Capital
review_text: The site is in ruins. The best part of the island is guide Anuradha Rao who has fantastic knowledge and passionately talks about the island. It is a worth a visit iffor nothing else then to see the animals (deers, peacocks, rabbits) roaming freely and interacting with people. Worth a visit.

title: The Land That Time Forgot
review_text: Ross Island was the admin hq for the 19th century British colonials. Here you can see the ruins of everything from the Water Distilling Plant to the Subordinates Club. The highlight though is the gutted shell of the old Church where nature has stamped it's ownership in the form of an enormous tree which has conquered the Brit's pile of rubble. More poignantly a visit to the cemetery reveals stories of men who lost their lives at sea. The Japanese Army's brief invasion also left it's mark in the shape of some machine gun nests that you can ferret around. I also enjoyed spying a Peacock strutting it's stuff to a local Peahen and the deer are ridiculously tame (please treat them with care). On Ross Island is you have great freedom to explore, there's minimal signage and no attempts to mediate your experience by tarting the place up unnecessarily or providing guides. You could spend anything from an hour to a day exploring the natural beauty of the island and wandering through the old ruins. There's a small kiosk and signs for a restaurant that was not open when we went so you might want to bring food. More

title: Wonderful experience with deers and peacocks
review_text: Well, look for the lady guide, Anuradha Rao. Its worth paying her. Without her you may not like the place.

title: A great experience
review_text: I went here at the start of Andaman travel so I was really amazed by the vegetation and wildlife and how very different it all was from where we had been travelling in India. There are lovely little deer, beautiful bird life and peacocks etc. Bring your binoculars. We spent around 3 hours wandering the island and loved it. The deserted buildings and history are really interesting. We had booked a speed boat there and back which was fun but the public ferries looked pretty regular and interesting also.

title: British Govt Buildings
review_text:
As soon as you enter the island one will be welcomed by Japanese Bunker & Deer in their Natural Habitat. 

Try to look as many buildings as you can with Trees reclaiming them. 

My wife said after seeing them "It's a nature's way of reclaiming its own space from the mankind."

title: Scenic
review_text:
place is well maintained, very scenic. Lil climb up the steps will take you to a small beach called perar beach, very remote and cute. 
Like a picnic spot. Good for people with children as there are plenty of deers and peacocks

title: Wonderful zoo
review_text: It was a part of history, but now one must visit to see the deer and birds in the island. Go in the afternoon and stay back till the last boat. Animals come out when most visitors have left. 4:30 PM is the feeding time.

title: good
review_text: it is a historical site to visit to feel how the britishers had enjoyed in our country with our natural and human resources

title: Have a leisure visit
review_text: Its the nearest island to the Port Blair. There is a govt.ferry starting around 9 am to North Bay and Ross Island as a regular trip and returns to Port Blair by evening. Both Islands doesn't have much exotic things to see but you can have casual visit for water sports (North Bay) and to see the life of the English men in the pre-independent India. Though there is only the ruins remain, the island is calm and serene with deer,peacock,etc. and has an unusual aura. Have a visit without any expectations.

title: A step back in time
review_text: Ross Island used to be the administrative capital of the region before Port Blair. It is now controlled by the Navy, but a part of it is open to visitors. You can walk around a pathway and see the ruined buildings of the erstwhile British settlement - a water treatment plant, swimming pool, officers mess, church, the mansion of the Governor or whatever he was called....all ruined and grown over with trees. There is also a Japanese bunker from the time the island was occupied by them in WW2. It's interesting if you are into history. Makes for a pleasant half-day trip out of Port Blair which is just a 8-10 minute boat ride away. Go in the morning as the sun can get hot. Carry shades and a water bottle! More

title: Beautiful historical place
review_text: The place is a beauty in itself with lots of pages of history to flip through. You can see a deer galloping, a peacock dancing and hens running as you take a stroll through the island. A must visit for all who embark on Andaman trip.

title: First Island we visited from Port Blair
review_text: This is the first Island we visited from Port Blair. A beautiful island. Best for photography. If you love landscape and abstract photography then this place is gem for you. We spent 3-4 hours here. We love this small island with lots of trees, old buildings, Peacocks and human friendly Deers.

title: Good one
review_text:
We were at the last day of our trip, and were very tired and wanted to skip Ross Island. But our tour operators and other friends sugested for it, and we went for it. Thankfully we were NOT disappointed. A nice and beautiful place with a good historical importance - we really loved the place. A plastic-free zone, its maintained nicely. With lots and lots of deers, peacocks around, you never ever get bored. Had a good half an hour rest under the shades too. The canteen there is decent, and the Veg Pulao we tried there was good. Little bit on the expensive side, but cant expect much in that island. 

4:30 PM is the last ferry that leaves the island, and it literally takes every one on the island back to the mainland Port Blair. So, plan accordingly. More

title: Ross
review_text: A mile across Port Blair, very nice and calm place. Lots of deers in open, kids can even touch them. Old church, just a calm place.

title: Not so great
review_text:
Very small island and hardly 10 min away from Portblair. You can a good walk and see ruins of buildings that were constructed during the British era. 
There is also a beach on the Island-Ferar beach. Very clean and beautiful beach to get some quiet time. 
There are a lot of deers on the island. Not sure if they are being regularly fed by the authorities. The animals wait for the visitors to be fed and eat anything that people give. Feels very bad to see animals hungry and waiting like that. Its better if the animals are properly fed or atleast transferred to a different place where they get enough food. More

title: Ride to Ross
review_text:
Ross Island is the first of a three island stopover that includes Viper and North Bay. 

Ross was the administrative post of the British in the late19th century and its ruins and little museum, Smritika make for great viewing. 

The coconut vendors at Ross are busy doing brisk business and the coconut water is refreshing after a brisk walk around the island.

title: Closed on wednesday :(
review_text: I had heard a lot of appreciation for this island . But our bad luck as we could not visit this island during our tour to Port Blair since the island is closed on every Wednesday and there is no possible way to reach this island on this day. So plan your visit to Ross Island accordingly.

title: Balas visit to Ross island
review_text: Ross Island can be reached by boat and it takes about 45minutes from Portblair. Understand Ross island was the capital of Andaman prior to Portblair. There are structures and buildings built by the British which are painted in Pink colour and well maintained. One can go around and see offices, church in dilapidated state, pond, power house, pump house etc. People interested in history and historical places will find Ross Island interesting. One can shoot lots of photographs. This island is full of coconut trees and fresh tender coconuts are available for the consumption of tourists.

title: Amazing Place to be
review_text: One amazing and must visit place in this side of world. The Ross Kitchen is amazing. Hide-outs for the newly married once are there ;). Amazing place for a photographer.

title: Interesting little island
review_text: The island has tame deer and beautiful Victorian-English ruins in the jungle. It is reached by the trip boats from Aberdeen pier.

title: british ruins with beautiful sea
review_text: ruins of a british town.. no structure intact. though one gets to play with dears and the splashing waves are very enjoyable. the water is beautiful with waves dashing the rocks. moreover the ferry ride from port blair is a memorable experience!!

title: Relax and watch
review_text: The island is under Coast Guard. If you wish to watch the sea and count waves, this place is best. You get to see the ruins of Tsunami here with roots of trees gone inside buildings and climbed the roofs. Bit of peacocks and deers and hens. Good for walking around.

title: Must visit to see the ruins
review_text:
Ross island has some very beautiful old buildings. These buildings were built and used by the Britishers. If you take stroll around, you would come across a number of deers and peacocks. The deers have been introduced to humans and aren't scared of us. Some even allow us to caress them. The last boat from the island to Port Blair is at 4:30 p.m. At around 3:00-3:30, the workers at the island feed the deers. This is a beautiful sight. You can see all the deers approaching the food as the workers let out a cry for them. At this time, few of the peacocks join them for the food. 
Its best if you are able to walk the entire island. Should take about an hour to do so. 
The island is a nice, calm place, especially suitable for people who love to walk and explore. More

title: Different island
review_text:
Ross Island is a different sort of experience and not the regular beach kind of setup. Ross island was once inhabitated by the Britishers since its located right across Port Blair. Veer Savarkar said that he could see Ross Island from his jail on 3rd floor of Wing 7. 
Ross Island mainly has ruins of British buildings. But these ruins are creepy with enormous tress grown over them. Do visit the musuem on Ross Island. 
There are ruins of old church, temple, bazaar, officers quareters, etc. We were given only 45 mins to see the entire island and it surely wasnt enough. 
We had taken the 3 island cruise by Andaman Tourism. It is currently maintained by the Navy. One more interesting point of this island is that you will see deers, peacocks all over moving around freely. Be ready to completely walk on foot to see this island. More

title: Beautiful island
review_text: Ross island is very beautifully made and well maintained.. This attraction is on the way back from north bay to port blair.. Can be reached by boat.. You will find many dears roaming around freely and standing next to you when you are enjoying the beauty of the place..

title: Ross Island , a very rosy island :)
review_text:
This is an Island in the Andaman & Nicobar group of Islands and is a must visit on a trip to Port Blair. The small island with its treasure of ruins has become a hot spot for tourists spot. It takes around 4 to 5 hours to go around this island which has dilapidated structures of the bakery, water purification plant, a Protestant Church, printing press and many others which the British build. This Island was basically occupied as an Administrative headquarters for the islands before it was shifted to Port Blair. The innumerable coconut trees, deers and the ruins alongwith water fronts on all sides is highly romantic place and one will fall in love with this place. 

The island was also under the Japanese for 3 years and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose also stayed for some time here. 

A MUST MUST MUST SEE. More

title: Very Picturesque
review_text: Its a must see place if you are there. Very well maintained lovely sea and ferrer beach is the best I saw in A&N islands. Enjoy seeing deer and peacocks. The old church is just awesome.

title: Brilliant and humbling... Definitely worth it!

title: nice visit
review_text: Showcases the offices of British government then. One can see the buildings , bunkers etc. we visited the same as part of 3 island tour. The tour was worth the price i.e Rs 500 per person.

title: Beautiful Island, open and mesmerizing.
review_text:
Corals 
Tall palm and deciduous trees. 
More like a big open park. 
Old dilapidated Military establishments

title: The only must-see place if you are at Port Blair
review_text:
The ferry ride from the Water Sports complex jetty at Port Blair takes about 15 minutes to get you across the bay to Ross Island. Plan to visit for at least 3 hours - there are several ferries and you can check the timings on the attached photo. Ross Island was where the British officers lived and had their accommodation, place of worship and also activities for their entertainment like tennis courts etc. These are all in ruins now and massive trees have overgrown and put in roots around these buildings. Pretty spectacular sights to see. There's a beach on the side of the island opposite the jetty and its worth visiting even though the current pathway ends abruptly due to what looks like damage caused by the tsunami. You can clamber down carefully to the beach from some spots. There is a huge herd of deer in one part of the island with some peacocks as well. There is a huge herd of deer in one part of the island with some peacocks as well. They are not completely wild and you can go relatively near them. There was one lady, a guide, who seemed to know them pretty well and they even responded to the names she called them !

You are encouraged to not litter the place, there are waste bins kept conveniently and also warning signs of the fine should you be caught. Naturally this does not deter our littering brethren and we found quite a lot of plastic and other waste at various corners of the island. A shame. The Indian Navy is supposed to be responsible for the upkeep and I think they should be more strict about enforcing this. More

title: ross island
review_text: if you got kids then they would feel happy about seeing deer, peacock in their live surroundings. some bit of history is also there to be seen. nothing more than that. a short visit as a package of two island deal is good enough

title: Historically Very Interesting--Go For At Least Two Hours
review_text:
I visited as part of the three island boat trip to Viper Island, North Bay and Ross. We were only given 40 minutes here which was not nearly enough time and I would have gladly skipped the other two sites for more time at Ross Island. 

There is a small museum some nice walks but the star of the show are the colonial buildings crackd by the earthquake of 1941 and now reclaimed by the jungle. It's like a British Raj version of Angkor Wat. Photographers and history buffs will really enjoy Ross lsland.

title: Nice Place
review_text: Ross is a nice place to visit. Well maintained with a slice of history. Ideally don't take the 3 island tour but visit Ross separately and explore it. The view of the sea is breathtaking. Take a leisurely walk,enjoy the sight of deers, peacocks and other birds. It's great. I reached Ross at 1pm and left by the last ferry at 4.30pm. Worth the trip.

title: another good thing you can do in A & N
review_text: History revisited....the ruins of the administrative and residential island of the British in Pre independence period

title: Lost in time
review_text:
The place gives us an insight into the life of the English men.It has been maintained very well. The Island is a huge one. There is a lovely,crumbling church inside the complex. With age many of the buildings has been destroyed.The guide provided us with some very good information.It is a must visit place for History buffs. 
.

title: Can be skipped
review_text:
We had a day reserved for Ross Island and North Bay as per our itinerary. Our day started on a very bad note with North Bay and then we visited Ross Island. Ross island is very close to Port Blair. We did not find this place to be fantastic though it is pretty well maintained. The highlight of this island according to me were the peacocks and deers. Credit goes to Anuradha madam who has selflessly devoted her entire life to this island. She is always available as a guide and you can get to know the entire history of this island from her. 
In a nutshell, I would not put Ross island as a must visit location. Just spend an hour here if you have nothing else to do. More

title: Ghost Island
review_text: Thanks to the Indian Navy, the island is kept in Pristine condition. If you have a sense of history, if derelict churches and overgrown vines over old buildings excite you, you are in for a treat. First - Take a guide (There is only 1). Otherwise, you will be lost staring at placards in front of all buildings - saying what the building was, but the associated folklore will not be found written anywhere. Ross island is a wonderful trip for an morning / afternoon - try not to do the famous 3 island trip in 3 hours or some madness like that if you are a history buff and want to enjoy the place, you will want to stay longer at Ross. Its amazing how time has recaptured the place and it fills you up with a sense of wonder as to how life would have been here, back then. More

title: Beautiful walk through the past
review_text: A small beach just 2 km off the port blair which was the ruling center of the British. The island today is controlled by Indian navy and is not open for permanent habitat. This island bears the remaining ruins of the once magnificent british installatiions. The walk through the ruins of barrack, church, water distilling plant, power house gives the thrill of a walk through the past. Once the bustling British civilization of Ross Island has left into ruins because of earthquake during 1940s. This island was also occupied by Japanese during Second World War and they left their foot mark as bunkers. The small museum in the island hosts pictures of the buildings and life in Ross during the British rule and worth a look. More

title: Administrative capital till1945. Well maintained by Navy
review_text: One has to give it to the imperial rulers they had a discerning eye for beauty and prime locations in India. Ross Island is no different.Though mostly in ruins there is a museum on the island that provides stunning views of the structure in an era gone by. One can almost go back in time to imagine the buzz on the island. Ferrar beach is beautiful and so are the imposing banyan trees, deer and peacocks on the island.

title: good to visit
review_text: Ross island has some unique British time structures of war. It is well worth a visit. Takes about one hour to completely go around on the Ross island.

title: Worth a visit
review_text: Very near portblair and takes around 10 mins by govt ferry to reach ross island . This island has relics of old building but is pretty well preserved by government . One can see number of freindly deers grazing around . Nothing much to do or see over here but still worth visiting once

title: Example of British Royality
review_text: One Lady explains everything what happened there if all is ture one can imagin how royal british was...how they have planned such a biggest thing there 1000 km far from chennai/India

title: Barren land
review_text: Nothing much of spectacular view. Just the remains of an old British township that existed long back. One has to walk along the course of the island to find places of interest.

title: OK for a Quick trip.
review_text: If the weather is nice one can hang out and explore the old British Army residence, otherwise a one hour trip is enough.

title: Ross Island-Remnants of British period township-transformed into Nature's Museum.
review_text:
My trip to Ross Island was memorable, magical and informative .Very easy to reach here as it is only 10Mnts ride by a ferry or 5 Mints by a Speed-Boat from Aberdeen Jetty of Port Blair.It’s a clean and secure Island. Once a vibrant , British period township, complete in all the respects, having its own ,Power-house, Water Plant, club ,church, Bakery and other buildings, in echo-friendly ambiance. Present day Ross Island is like a museum of crumbling dilapidated buildings, damaged during World War II bombing. It is now engulfed from all sides by the roots of trees, grown over the years, which gives it a very unique reticular pattern formed by the roots. To me it looked like, as if nature has made its art—Root-Art making these dilapidated structures as it’s canvas. It was delight to watch these on every buildings. It will definitely be an attraction to nature lovers and travelers with a artistic sense. Next very unique thing about this Island is its lady guide, Anuradha Rao .She is not only guide but –“ Lady with the Message of Care and Love for Animals and Respect for Parents.” At first glance she looks unimpressive, but the way she start explaining, each and every details of the history and changing geography of this Island was simply fantastic and informative. She is like a Pied-Piper for the inhabiting animals of this Island. Deer’s, Peacocks, ducks start coming from different... My trip to Ross Island was memorable, magical and informative .Very easy to reach here as it is only 10Mnts ride by a ferry or 5 Mints by a Speed-Boat from Aberdeen Jetty of Port Blair.It’s a clean and secure Island. 
Once a vibrant , British period township, complete in all the respects, having its own ,Power-house, Water Plant, club ,church, Bakery and other buildings, in echo-friendly ambiance. Present day Ross Island is like a museum of crumbling dilapidated buildings, damaged during World War II bombing. It is now engulfed from all sides by the roots of trees, grown over the years, which gives it a very unique reticular pattern formed by the roots. To me it looked like, as if nature has made its art—Root-Art making these dilapidated structures as it’s canvas. It was delight to watch these on every buildings. It will definitely be an attraction to nature lovers and travelers with a artistic sense. 
Next very unique thing about this Island is its lady guide, Anuradha Rao .She is not only guide but –“ Lady with the Message of Care and Love for Animals and Respect for Parents.” At first glance she looks unimpressive, but the way she start explaining, each and every details of the history and changing geography of this Island was simply fantastic and informative. She is like a Pied-Piper for the inhabiting animals of this Island. Deer’s, Peacocks, ducks start coming from different directions when she starts calling them- Aao-Aao. Then she feeds them .Deer’s nod their head and follow her directions like obedient child .It was a treat to watch. Travelers also enjoyed feeding them. 
Other things to see at this place is one small museum having pictures of British period and a 500 Yrs. old tree, as told by the guide. You can watch a light house from the entry of this ,Island, which is printed on Rs.20 Indian currency . 
Tips:- You should come in your walking shoes if possible, This is an deserted island with few residences for Army personnel ,so don’t expect any restaurant dine or wine places here .Bring your own eatables with you, although there is one small Cafeteria ,serving tea ,coffee and few eatable ,but that too in limited quantity. 
To end with, I can say that visit to this Island of remnants of British period ny will have lingering effect in my mind .It is one of the must see place for the visitors to Adman. 
By Dr.S.C. Tripathi Gorakhpur , Email-Scrtri48@gmail.com,Mob 09415258501 More

title: Well Kept Surroundings!
review_text: The effort to take you back in time is commendable with the sign posting and markings. Guide Anuradha Rao is a great source of information, look out for he. All the animals and birds come to meet on her call, dedication redefined! Kudos to Indian Navy.

title: A piece of history
review_text: This was a fantastic but of history, with the bombed out British township, and the Japanese bunkers. The Japanese had occupied it during the Burma Campaign of World War II. Signage was helpful on the whole. Almost the only building left in tact (unless it was rebuilt later) was the bakery. Otherwise the Japanese destroyed everything built by the British who administered Port Blair from Ross Island, which is bout 10 minutes away by ferry. The ferry doesn't operate when the sea is rough. Ross Island is clean and well maintained, the deer were an unexpected delight. The whole place felt as if one had walked into a film set or novel. It needs stamina and good shoes to walk about, and don;t expect luxurious eating there. The museum was dark and not so well kept. But the older museum had a hen nesting in a window, obviously someone's pet because she was sitting on a clean sheet of newspaper. More

title: good historical place
review_text: a lot of historical buildings to see. relax between greenery and spend some peaceful time. My ferry stopped for only 1 hr. I can spend 2-4 hours easily.

title: Ross Island..Untold history
review_text: Another must visit place when you are in Port Blair.10 minutes boat ride from Abardeen Jetty..My suggestion would be not to visit this island as a part of three Island tour. Post north bay Island, one would be too tired to enjoy the Island..We visited the Island by taking 2:00 p.m boat from port blair..make sure you explaore the island with guide, Anuradha Roy..she is a nice lady to keeps on telling interesting stories of the island and also we got to feed animals with her. Feeding bread to deers was an amazing experience. Apart from Deer, there are peacock, hen, ducks and other birds. Last boat to port blair leaves the Island at 5:00 p.m..had fresh coconut water on our way back.Island is nicely maintained by Army. More

title: Cool place
review_text: We went there on our 3 island tour. Did not do much as there is hardly anything to do. Cool beach with less amenities.

title: Lunch with deers
review_text:
The only way to fully enjoy this small osland is in company of Anuradha Roy. 
She is a guide there and you'll be amazed to see her talking to all the animals and calling them to meet you.

title: ross island..
review_text:
it is a ok..ok place..not more to see...and when u r coming from north bay after doing snorkling and all the water sports..than..u r tired enough to see anything.. 
but yes this place is close to nature..deers..peacock..duck..all will be roaming near by you..

title: An interesting place for people who have interest in history
review_text:
It is really very interesting to see how britishers managed to develop a township at such as remote place. This island was developed and township was established approx 100 years back when the resources & technology was very limited. 
One snack shop is available on this island but quality of food and snacks items is very bad. Avoid eating at this place. 

This place might not be of any interest for people who do not have any interest in history.

title: do this last.
review_text: I thought it was a lot more hype than substance to this place of tourist infiormation. It is poorly maintained. It is poorly manned. Only saving grace was that a small restaurant was serving very good food

title: ruins of a quaint life
review_text:
The ruins of a British settlement and headquarters that was abandoned when the Britishers left India in August 1947. 

It's stunning simply for the breathtaking manner in which Nature has gone about reclaiming what humans took from it on this beautiful little island. 

Don't forget the only blink-and-miss signs of World War II Japanese presence in India.

title: Amazing
review_text: my oersonal favorite.. take a jeety to ross island.. it is maintained by indian navy.. nice place for photography.. bird watching is nice.

title: Very Good place
review_text: Wonderful place, well reserved and clean. Also trek the whole area, and you will find a beautiful beach lower down, worth the effort.

title: Ruins of British Administration
review_text: Close to Port Blair. A ferry shall take you there. Gives you picturesque view of the sea. Well administered, still under Navy control. Clean with minimal plastic and paper pollution

title: Loved the Island
review_text: I visited this island in January 2012 and absolutely loved it. The peace and the tranquility was wonderful. Explored all the interesting ruins from the British time and found them to be fascinating. I just loved the way the deers were so tame I didn't feed them but still they came to my table when we were eating and let me pet them we were at the little restaurant which served delicious simple food. We spent about 21/2 hours on Ross Island travelling independently which I found to be great and just took a boat back to Port Blair when we were ready.

title: Deer Park
review_text: It's the old capital of the British overlooking the Cellular Jail on the Port Blair island. There are lots of deer around which people feed though feeding them is banned. Otherwise there is nothing worthwhile to see. There are peacocks but the boat guys do not allow you enough time to see everything on the island.

title: Live colonial life though devastated by Tsunami 2004
review_text: Imagine life in 18 th Century at a small island just a little more in size to a Big mall. Historical Water treatment plant, swimming pool, Modern bakery and grave yard of English men those died there.

title: worth a short trip to this historical island
review_text: We took a 10 min ferry from Port Blair to Ross Island, walked around for about 1.5 hours, and then returned with the next ferry. This island was the British HQ during the time the Andaman Islands were a penal colony for prisoners from South and Southeast Asia. interesting to see the old buildings and imagine how life was then. Also beautiful views+nature and walking on the island.

title: Old world charm but lacking tourist investment
review_text:
Ross Island was the military and admin HQ of the British Colony as well as the Japanese, when for a three short years they occupied the Andamans. 

But the place can be improved for tourist amenities, propoer guide facility can be included and signages and information plates put at various monuments would help the tourists a lot. 

We saw some old militaru buildings covered with growing trees, reminding us of the Tai Phrom temple of Cambodia.

title: BEAUTYFUL ISLAND IS ROSS
review_text: ITis a really beauty ful island in andaman.It was a head quater of British administrator in andaman.It was under japan for 3 years.at the entance there is a japanees bunker.blue sea and coconut trees are increasing its natural beauty.it is a important place in indian history.you may lesson cry of freedom fighters those were killed at that time.you have to go by boat/sheep from portblair.it wii take 30 min.so dont miss to enjoy the beauty of this island.

title: notthing much to see
review_text:
It is the place where british soldires and officers used to live. 
during world war 2 this place was demolished. it is good to spend 1/2 to 1 hr experience. nothing much to see.. if you have less time u can avoid it..

title: Ross Island- Nothing great
review_text: Nothing great to see- except the old British settlement that is now in ruins or the Japanes Bunker. Was taken here as part of the Three Island Tour.

title: An island with deers, peacocks and coconut trees
review_text: This island was the headqurter of Britishers in the Andaman Island. Thoush most of the builidings are ruined due to Tsunami in 2004, this is still a good place to spend an afternoon in the port blaire. The place is 10 min ferry ride away from Rajiv gandhi sports complex and far better option than watching the museums and every thing in PB itself. Inspite of going for a fullday city tour, I would recomment first visit the Cellular Jail in the morning and then go and visit this place.

title: great place to kill an hour or two
review_text: really cool island - there are trees that have grown into these old ruins. it's something i've never seen before and there are great pictures to be taken here. you can also hike up to the top and there are nice views. there are bathroom on the island but i recommend that you plan ahead so you don't have to use them.

title: good Island , Interesting ruins ....
review_text:
The mistake people do ( and also done by me ..!!!!! ) is that they go for three island tour ( Ross/Viper/North bay ) package run by the Andaman tourist association for 1 day . The tour will cost 500 rs per head and they will give lunch also . 
Problem is the tour starts at 9.30 am and the first island visited is Ross Island ( 10 mins by the ferry ). They give only 45mins to see the island and it is not at all sufficient to cover the whole island . so i will recommend to plan at least 1/2 day tour only to Ross Island . Please avoid the three Island tour . 
The Island was once Capital , and was well planned but today you can only see very interesting ruins . It will be good to hire a guide to understand the importance of the place . 
Also one fact we came to know that Ross Island blocked the high waves during the tsunami to reach sports complex and thus avoided some damage . More

title: A beautiful island with coconut groves.
review_text: We visited this as prt of three island tour from Port blair and spent about one hour after lunch. The old capital of Andaman with a couple of old buildings and reared deer is a nice place for picnicking.

title: amazing beauty
review_text: This place will take you through the ages of history, the untouched beauty,history and glory all will leave you amazed.take umbrella, wear sun lotion and keep fresh water.get set for the best of best world,njoy!!

title: Interesting Ruins!!
review_text: This is a small island of the port blair harbor. It has interesting history. One can spend 2-3 hours in the afternoon walking around this island. We had hired Anuradha Rao as a guide. She was a bit weird but there was an interesting thing about her. All the animals and even birds on the island follow her wherever she goes. The birds were lining up on the branches of the trees next to her.

title: Nice place to visit in port blair
review_text:
Liked the Deers, peacocks and good portblair city view. 

It is best place to visit after cellular jail in portblair.

title: Good but travelling to the place is poor
review_text: The place is good if you are interested in a bit of history and photography but travelling to the place could be better. The ferries just dump people in like cattle.

title: beautiful island
review_text: The Japanese settlement was on this beautiful island. the old building now entanlgled in the roots of huge trees are a picturesque sight. Deers, peacocks and the view of the beach down below from the highest point of the island make it worth a visit.

title: Nothing left
review_text: The so called 3 island trip - Ross, North Bay and Viper ; is an easily avoidable one. Nothing is left at Ross island. Only the ruins of British colony.

title: Ross Island !
review_text: Ross Island - No much attractions - But a place to see many things if you are interested in details of British rule in India. They had all luxury even in Andamans even 100 years back!!! Witness buildings, cemetery, hospital sculptures there. Another attraction is many animals ( non violent !! ) are freely living in this island, even when we take photos with them, they dont care. But we were instructed not to touch them or feed them, which we followed. The boat runs from Port Blair to Ross island is not upto the mark and thats a big negative, as they could have arrange a good service by comparing the MAKRUZZ which runs between Port Blair and Havelock Island More

title: A Must visit place for Animal Lovers and Historians
review_text: First thing first, please never opt for the '3 Island Tour', Viper and North Bay does not have anything to offer. We saw most of the tourists were lured by that 3 island tour. Now, coming back to Ross Island Trip, one can buy the Ferry tickets from the Andaman Water Sports Complex, which is at a walking distance from Cellular Jail. We took the 2 PM Ferry(I guess that's the last ferry to Ross) after our lunch. Though the distance is very less, it takes around 15 minutes to reach there as the Ferry is very slow. There is an entrance point where you have to buy tickets and camera passes. Once you enter Ross Islands, you get greeted by 100s of deer, and birds, peacocks. We also took a Guide(Mrs. Rao) who is born and brought up there and loved the place and the animals. She explained us in details about how the British Officers lived there, the distilled water tank they used for bathing and drinking, and about the Tsunami attack and a lot of other stuff. She was carrying loaves of bread and was continuously feeding the deer and the small birds. The whole time all of them were following us and it was an wonderful experience to feed them ourselves. We returned by the last ferry at 4.30 PM. Overall it was a wonderful and enlightening experience at Ross. 3 Hours Worth spent. You can plan to go for the Light and Sound show at the Cellular Jail after having some snacks from nearby shop(10 minutes walk) More

title: Haunted memories
review_text: If you have that vision inside you to imagine a complete picture of those broken remains of roots swallowed buildings in the island, you can enjoy this place fully. A great place for photography. A good number of birds, peacocks, deer to give you company. A short trip for 2 hours will kill your 2 hours time before waiting for flight in port blair

title: Good place
review_text:
It is a good palce to visit but the problem is that the ferry package takes you to North Bay, Viper Island and Ross Island in one package. 
But there is nothing to be done at North Bay and Viper Island. 
Find a package that takes you to Ross Island and North Bay. 

If that is not available then it makes no sense to go to Viper Island where you have nothing to see. I fail to understand what is the tourist attraction on that place. 
Also the water sports activities available at North bay can easily be enjoyed while you stay in Havelock. 
One should leave the water sports part to Havelock. 
Ross island trip is ok timepass . More

title: Historical Place
review_text:
This is a historical place in an Island. There are boards marking the places and the guide in the boat gave us a vague idea about Ross Island before we reached. 
Some buildings were damaged in tsunami. Still there are many. Some buildings still exist due to the roots of the big trees which protected the buildings from getting washed away in Tsunami. Good place to click photos too. 
You can find few deers around. This is a plastic free zone and the navy is maintaining it well.

title: walk and take a break
review_text: Nice small island near port blair... one can spend an hour or couple of hours just roaming around.. looking at sea and greenery.. no activity to do just leisure around

title: Where is the maintanance?
review_text: Sorry to sound like a critic who is never satisfied, but after visiting places like Singapore and Mauritius, we have seen how the most simple place can be made beautiful. But our case is opposite. We know how to make the most beautiful places awful!! The scenic beauty of the island is unbelievable, there are lots of ruins with lots more history. There could be simple sound effects (Silosa fort in Singapore for example) to tell the history, the entire place will be live!! Honestly believe me, people should look at us to learn how to forget our history and do nothing about the places of historical monuments

title: ruins !
review_text:
the island can be done in a day trip from the main port blair island as there are passenger ferries shuttling across... 
just remember that the passenger boats drop you off and head to drop off other pple at near by islands and then return back at the mentioned time and you DONT WANT TO MISS that while going back in the evening ,so check before hand with the staff at the island about the last trip timing.... 
on the island its got a lot of british ruins, this island was sort off an entry point/check point into the port blair islands and there were mineral water plant in those days, bakeries, guest houses,etc which are now ruins and can barely be seen.... as no restoration work has been carried out .. its just difficult to know of what existed... 
the place has some wild life ,like peacock, deer freely moving around you ...... there are also japanese bunkers from world war , which can be viewed... 
these are the main attractions and the whole island tour wud on foot wud take you not more than 3 hours to the max........ More

title: Beautiful Island
review_text: It is a beautiful Island to visit. Nice weather adds a sweet flavour to it. You can get beautiful pictures there.

title: Nice
review_text:
Ross island and a few others are covered from Port Blair in a one-day trip. The island had a relevance during British raaj when the island was used for parties and functions. 

As of today, there is nothing much on the island but one thing I liked was lots of deers and ducks roaming around in the open. These deers are so used to human beings that you can go up to them and pat them and get yourself clicked with them. 

The island was ravaged during the tsunami.

title: History sleeps here, literally!
review_text:
This island has a lot of history in India's freedom struggle. But all that remainants of Hinstory are almost gone. None of the buildings are being maintained. Only the sign borads about the buildings are seen everywhere. 

We can just enjoy the scenic beauty of Port Blair and other islands nearby

title: Ertwhile capital
review_text: Extremely neat and clean. Could have spent a whole day there

title: Ross Revisited
review_text: I as a youngstar was there with my family in Port Blair in late 70s. That time we visited Ross Island a number of times. It was a almost virgin island with jungles and reminiscent of Brit Empire. In 2007, I revisited this tiny island with my spouse and kid. In last 30 years or so, as the rest of the world, Ross has also changed.

title: Superb Place!!
review_text: Awesome place!! You will have deers and peacocks roaming around you freely.. you can feed them play with them and if they allow you can have an awesome pic with the animals.. The place is taken care by Indian Navy and holds a strong historical ground.

title: Good for a jungle walk and virgin beach
review_text: The small museum has some good pictures depicting the life of the days gone by.All the buildings are in ruins so go for the walk through the terrain meeting very friendly deers on the way. There is hardly any food options so do remember to pack food and take an umbrella and water

title: REMINISCENCE OF BRITISH REGIME
review_text: Ross island is few kms from Aberdeen jetty(in water sports complex).it takes 10min to reach there by ferry from this jetty.ferry ticket Rs75p/p to ross island or you can also book a whole day tour from here which will take you not only to ross but also to viper island and north bay.ticket Rs400p/p(including lunch and entry fee of ross island).Ross island entry ticket Rs 20p/p and Rs10 for camera.this place is full of greenery.cool breeze from the sea,deers running around,chirping of the birds all creates a soothing effect.This island had been the administrative headquarters of britishers.they had a luxurious settlement here.but earthquake of 1941 devastated the whole island.now only the ruins of some old buildings of british regime like bakery,church,chief commissioner's house,press.cemetery etc can be seen.there is a small museum inside this island.you wont get any eateries here only nariyal pani is available. title: Captivating...
review_text:

When you alight on the island, look out for her. The first thing she will tell you is that today if we are in this place all the credit goes to the Indian Army and that the government has done nothing for the place. Jaago neta Jaago!! The erstwhile administrative capital of the British before they shifted their base to Port Blair, Ross Island is the ruins of a full-fledged town established by the British. The place is full of coconut trees, banyan trees, deers, and peacocks. Watch out for the coconuts falling on your head. You will see a lot of structures held together by the roots of huge banyan trees, which otherwise would have been rubble by now. Nature has its own way of taking care. The erstwhile administrative capital of the British before they shifted their base to Port Blair, Ross Island is the ruins of a full-fledged town established by the British. The place is full of coconut trees, banyan trees, deers, and peacocks. Watch out for the coconuts falling on your head. You will see a lot of structures held together by the roots of huge banyan trees, which otherwise would have been rubble by now. Nature has its own way of taking care. The walk around the island, partly destroyed by the Japanese in WW-II and partly by Tsunami MMIV (2004) may take anywhere between 1 – 2 hrs, depending on your walking speed, stamina and interest. And to replenish your sapped energies, you have sweet coconut water and not-so-sweet kulfis. At the back end of the island there are the ruins of a church overlooking the sea from a hill top. You can stroll down to the sea. Not much of a beach but you can catch your breath before embarking on your walk back. By the end of the round you will like what you have seen. But then memory will fade. To make this memory memorable, people like Ms. Anuradha Rao help you discover the place, the need of the structures that are present there and the technologies that were employed over a hundred years ago to distill salt water or to generate electricity. Some of the facts she reveals are worth admiring – availability of sweet water right next to the sea if you dig 10 meters into the ground, which still is the main source of potable water in Port Blair, the secret tunnel under the sea from Port Blair to Ross Island (which is now closed), etc. 

On your visit to Andaman islands, Ross Island is a must visit place. Eat well before you go there as you would need every ounce of your energy to traverse the hilly terrain. More

title: Colonial headquarters
review_text: Ross Island was the British Headquarters in Andamans. This is just about a km away from Port Blair, where the freedom-fighters were kept. This island is worth visiting for the ruins of colonial times which are almost engulfed by Banyan trees with the roots holding the ruins in a tight grip. However, there isn't much to do here for longer than an hour and if you go there on a hot sunny day, you will like to run away asap!!!

title: Remains of the British Raj....
review_text: Going around the Ross Island and seeing the remains of an era bygone really gives you goosebumps. The britishers lived like a king here with all the facilities in one place. The island is very beautiful, lined with coconut trees and the deers running around is worth seeing. The view of the Cellular Jail from the island is awesome. Worth a visit!

title: The Seat of British Rule in Andamans
review_text: Wow!!! What a place!The British knew how to actually live. A must visit destination if you go to Andamans.

title: ISLAND IS WELL ORGANIZED!!!!!!
review_text: Ross Island, which is accessible from Phoenix Bay Jetty through a boat.You have to buy tickets to entry the island and you have to buy tickets for cameras both video and still. Ross Islands, once the administrative head quarters of British Colonial Rulers, still bears the ruins of a Church and cemetery.there is a presbyterian church though it is fully ruined.You can see deers,peacocks freely moving around the islands.While entering the island you can see japanese bunker.The island is very photogenic but beware of the coconuts as it falls from trees.The island is open to the public for all days except Wednesday.It takes just a couple of hours to explore the entire island. There is just one small shop on the island from where tourists can buy snacks and soft drinks,but better to take your own foods.there is a ruined swimmimg pool,power house and a bakery in the islands which were used by the britishers. More

title: Quiet place with great photo opportunities
review_text:
Old British buildings taken over by nature, the result is very photogenic. Nice place to walk around for a while - if you walk away from the jetty, you virtualy have the place to yourself. 
Limited facilities though, e.g. all toilets were closed during my visit.

title: Ross Island
review_text: Great destination for a quick trip. Close to Port Bair with easy connectivity. Many ancient Brtiish colonial builidngs to see. Scenery very good. Lots of deer and peacocks add a pristine feel. But beware it can be very hot, and there are hardly any shades. Take umbrellas and plenty of bottled drinks. The ferry can be very primitive.

title: A great place to visit
review_text: The island is fantastic! The remains are well preserved. You get to see the remains of the residences of some of the British officers, the clubs, the church and so on and so forth. To top it there are so many spotted deers and peacocks and lush green trees! This is a must see. Unfortunately, the stupid tour operators are more interested in your money than your enjoyment. They will take you to North Bay first (which should be avoided at all costs) and will give you less than an hour to spend at Ross Island. Please do not fall in this trap. Just get an ordinary ferry ticket and go to Ross Island early in the morning and come back only after you have enjoyed this place thoroughly. More

title: awesome wild life
review_text: awesome wild life...cant believe...wondering how much more better it wud have been in the olden days

title: Interesting Island and worth to spend half day. Heaven for photographers
review_text:
Ross Island, the erstwhile capital during the British regime, is a tinyisland standing as guard to Port Blair harbor. You can spend 3 to 4 hours on island. 

There are ruins building on islands and very interesting shapes made by tree + roots + ruin building. It’s Heaven for photographer and best to click black and white photos. 
If possi read about Ross Island before visiting or hire guide to know historical information. Island is very clean and maintained by navy and local people. To see complete island you need to walk a lot so better to carry water and some snacks. There are lots of deer and peacock. 
There is small beach which is completely destroyed by 2004 tsunami and you can see that. 

Entry fee to island is INR 20/- More

title: First British city in Andaman islands
review_text:
Ross island is approx 20 minutes ferry ride from Port blair. 
It was the first island developed by Britishers. You will see broken structures of printing press (Lots of roots spread all over the broken walls), water purifying unit, bakery, church, subordinate club, cemetery and Farzan ali store. There is a small beach on the island. 
On the right side as we enter the island, there is one Japanese bunker. build by them during there control during second world war. 
The island is maintained by Indian army and concrete path is made for walking around on the island. Its a must visit due to its historic importance. 
You can see deers roaming around freely on the island. More

title: Decent outing
review_text: This is part of a popular trip covering Ross, Viper and North Bay island. Out of these 3, Ross island is the only place worth visiting. It has many ruins of British time. You should buy ticket only for Ross, and not for all 3 island.

title: Place to Step Down
review_text:
It's a historical place and have broken structures of church, bakery etc. This was the british capital and bcoz of a demoloishing earthquake, they vacated Ross Island left to port Blair. You can watch Deers walking around in open. And one can also find Peacocks there. It was aNice experience. 
I would suggest to visit Ross Island after visiting Cellular Jail.

title: It is so so
review_text: It is not a very good place to visit. Ruins are not well preserved.

title: Really interesting
review_text: Went with our small kids and it was lots of fun exploring the ruined buildings. Lots of wildlife on the island to keep kids amused too - and fabulous kulfi on the boat home :)

title: Unique half day excursion
review_text: It's a 20 minute boat ride from the water sports jetty at Port Blair. The first boat leaves around 8.30 am and there seems to be a service every hour. A small hilly island with ruins of one floor buildings all over. English architecture. What's left of the standing building walls are enveloped over the decades by roots of large trees giving it a very ancient look. Certainly worth the visit.

title: Amazing!
review_text: Its actually eerie, especially the tree jutting out of the center of the church and the roots englulfing the walls. Climb up the roots but with care from the red ants! The other side of Ross island has a beach of white sands, which most tourists do not know about. Bliss! spend some time there!

title: Felt sad to see the destroyed colonial buildings
review_text: Ross Island is a likeable island - looked like it was a self-sufficient British garrison town. Beautiful and complete with everything one needed in life. These were destroyed, as I was told by my tour guide, by the British themselves when the Japanese occupied the Andaman Islands during the World War II. A big tree has penetrated the church building. There are hundreds of trees in this small island that are more than 100-200 years old.

title: Worth Visiting.
review_text: This island is full of history. This island was former British capital for Andamans and hence there are colonial style buildings and ruins. Island is also full of deers which is fun to watch. Much of the island area was lost during tsunami. There is a lot of walking on the island, so should carry water.

title: the earst while capital
review_text: go with a guide and also read some history about the place

title: beautiful
review_text: ross island is the nearest island from port blair. A beautiful place covered with coconut trees.A historical island.The cruises will not give much time to explore this island so you have to explore it by planning a separate trip.

title: headquarter in ruins
review_text: Half an hour ride on water takes you to ross island from Port blair, speed boats are faster. Ross island was for some time headquarter of british empire controlling the Islands. and have runs of that era, including a church, swimming pool, officer mess and quarter, a good getaway for picnics...

title: Amazing place and beautiful animals
review_text: Our guide was amazing! She told us everything we needed to know about the island and also introduced us to the current inhabitants - deers and peacocks! If you can, hire a private boat otherwise you will be stuck with general public who have no manners and will push you to get into the boat!

title: Ross island
review_text: Beautiful scenic place to hang around especially you have kids there are quite a few animals in there , my 8 yr old had a great time aquainting them

title: Ross Island Lost Glory
review_text: We had a good time at this island. Once upon a time being an administrative office place of the Britisher this island now has a haunted look. There are almost destroyed office buildings, church and other utility centers. However, still it is well orgnaised and clean place to visit. One can spend a day at this island and a beach at the backside. Few wild animals like dear, etc are good attraction for kids. Overall good place to be in and one should visit this place if visiting Andaman.

title: Excellent Place
review_text: This place gives a complete picture of the Britishers ruling headquarter with ruins of there buildings. The friendly approach of Deers, Ducks, Peacoks was worth living an experience. Clean beaches, gardens, breath taking views, tall ancient trees. Overall a majestic place to visit.

title: Nice Relics
review_text: Its a good place for a visit but the buildings are broken and very old. Get a guide who will explain whats what though. One of the best places in andamans. Must visit.............Definitely go here. The boat ride here is also lovely.

title: The old capital of Andamans
review_text:
On the last day of our trip to the Andamans, we missed the ferry to Jolly Buoy and were wondering how to spend the day. 

This had us take a boat to Ross Island from the Sports complex in Port Blair for a post-lunch trail in the Ross Island. 

Ferar Beach inside the Island is very nice besides the deers, peacocks and ducks one can spot inside the island dancing to the tunes of nature. 

End of the day, we had a feeling that the day was well spent indeed.

title: Capital of Andamans before Independence
review_text: A place where memories of freedom float around. Gives a feeling how planned and structured were the rule of foriegners. At that time they had a tenis court, bakery,market,boiler,church. The ruins of these buildings are still alive which would make anyone feel that money spent was worth. Adding to the thrill experience with plenty of dear and a picture with these animals would surely make the trip to Andamans a memorable one.

title: British Colonial Administration Relics on Tiny, Beautiful Island
review_text:
Ross Island is located about 2 kilometers offshore from Port Blair and is reachable by ferry from Aberdeen Jetty (not from Phoenix Port as described on some websites). The island used to be the British colonial administration headquarters for the whole Andaman and Nicobar Islands. However, all the buildings have now fallen into disrepair making for a scenic, tropical island testament to the once great and mighty. It is interesting to witness how trees and vegetation invade and takeover what were once the residences and barracks of mighty colonial powers. Ruins of a large church, cemetery, the Chief Commissioner’s House, a bakery and barracks can be seen. At the southern end of the island there are remains of Japanese bunkers and tunnels from their occupation in 1942-45. The northern end of the island is used by the Indian Navy and is now off-limits. The whole island of coconut palms is a delightful place which can be walked around in one hour. However, two or three hours are needed to see all the ruins and an exhibit of historical photographs near the jetty in a former storehouse. There is a small, basic outdoor restaurant on the island, and a small store where drinks and snacks can be bought. Ross Island is located about 2 kilometers offshore from Port Blair and is reachable by ferry from Aberdeen Jetty (not from Phoenix Port as described on some websites). 
The island used to be the British colonial administration headquarters for the whole Andaman and Nicobar Islands. However, all the buildings have now fallen into disrepair making for a scenic, tropical island testament to the once great and mighty. It is interesting to witness how trees and vegetation invade and takeover what were once the residences and barracks of mighty colonial powers. 
Ruins of a large church, cemetery, the Chief Commissioner’s House, a bakery and barracks can be seen. At the southern end of the island there are remains of Japanese bunkers and tunnels from their occupation in 1942-45. The northern end of the island is used by the Indian Navy and is now off-limits. 
The whole island of coconut palms is a delightful place which can be walked around in one hour. However, two or three hours are needed to see all the ruins and an exhibit of historical photographs near the jetty in a former storehouse. 
There is a small, basic outdoor restaurant on the island, and a small store where drinks and snacks can be bought. 
It is best to visit in the cooler morning, taking a ferry from Aberdeen Jetty at 9 a.m. the ferry costs about 100 rupees return and there is a small entrance fee to the island of about 20 rupees. Many of the tourist boats from Aberdeen Jetty go to Ross Island, North Bay and Viper Island on a one-day trip costing about 300 or 400 rupees. More
